HEADLINE: BUSH IS CAUTIOUS ON DOMESTIC GOALS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
President Bush lent oratorical flourish and the weight of his office to his domestic agenda tonight but added little new substance to policies outlined earlier this week in budget proposals that Democrats have already criticized as inadequate.
The only major new aspect of Mr. Bush's comments on domestic policy in his first State of the Union address lay in a set of education goals that he sought to portray as ambitious, including making every adult literate by the year 2000.
But Administration officials suggested that the real goals in the Department of Education's strategy for the coming years were actually more modest than Mr. Bush suggested, and Democratic leaders immediately complained about the scope of Mr. Bush's education proposals.
 
The Central Conflict
This conflict has been central to Mr. Bush's Administration: While he has outlined some broad visions, he has constantly been constrained by the tightness of the Federal budget and his determination not to raise taxes. 
The speech tonight was shot through with the sense that while change is convulsing Europe, Mr. Bush's view of the State of the Union is more placid, less a call to join ''the revolution of '89'' than to build on a solid foundation.
The President said he envisioned ''a better America, where there's a job for everyone who wants one. Where women working outside the home can be confident their children are in safe and loving care, and where the Goverment works to expand child care alternatives for parents; where we reconcile the needs of a clean environment and a strong economy.''
 
Two Standing Ovations
Mr. Bush, smiling as he was announced into the House chamber, got two standing ovations before he spoke.
He brought most of the audience to its feet when he spoke of the Panama invasion. He drew his longest applause when he said his new budget would reduce the deficit without raising taxes. The Republicans stood. The Democrats sat, applauding quietly, and Mr. Bush laughed as Republicans waved at the Democrats to stand.
At times, the speech was quintessential George Bush, filled with the litany of his campaign oratory - drug-free schools, help for the disabled and homeless and commercial enterprise zones, without the offer of substantial money to back the programs.
But Mr. Bush also borrowed from the stage directions of Ronald Reagan, using Mr. Reagan's technique of reading a letter from an ordinary citizen. This time, it was from the mother of a soldier killed in Panama. Taking out his reading glasses, even though the letter was on the TelePrompter like the rest of his speech, Mr. Bush read from a note the woman's son had sent before he went into action. ''Do not mourn for me,'' the soldier, Pvt. James Markwell, wrote. ''Revel in the life that I have died to give you.''
 
General by Design
Outlining his domestic priorities, Mr. Bush said he was asking Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, to review Federal medical benefits and ''bring the staggering costs of health care under control.''
But that and most of Mr. Bush's comments on domestic policy were deliberately vague in keeping with his stated plan to allow his budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which he sent to Congress on Monday, to carry the brunt of his agenda.
''I come not to speak about the 'state of the Government,' '' Mr. Bush told a joint session of Congress, ''not to detail every new initiative that we plan for the coming year, nor describe every line item in the budget.''
Mr. Bush's comments reflected the general philosophy of his budget. He proposed major investments in what he called ''human capital'' - including substantial increases in subsidies for basic scientific research and space exploration - and equally substantial reductions in the growth of benefits like Medicare and Federal pensions.
 
Cuts Are Envisioned
His budget would trim Federal investment in such areas as highways, railroads and bridges, cuts that Administration officials say reflect the proper role of the Federal Government.
The only portion of Mr. Bush's speech that was not contained in his 1991 budget were his remarks on education.
''Last fall, at the education summit, the governors and I agreed to look for ways to help make sure kids are ready to learn, the very first day they walk into that classroom,'' Mr. Bush said, referring to the meeting he held with the nation's governors following a conference on education in Williamsburg, Va., last year. ''By the year 2000,'' he said, ''every child must start school ready to learn.''
Mr. Bush said his request for a $500 million increase in the budget for the Head Start program ''made good on that commitment.''
Mr. Bush said that by the end of the century, the high school graduation rate must be ''no less than 90 percent.'' The Bush Administration calculates that figure by the number of children who finish high school within four years of entrance. That rate, last calculated in 1986, was 72 percent, Education Department officials said tonight.
Officials said Mr. Bush was proposing ''dropout prevention assistance grants.'' But the White House has budgeted only $45 million for the effort and, as with many of its domestic programs, is counting on the grants to get states to increase their own spending.
 
Meaning of a Diploma
Two of Mr. Bush's other proposals sounded more all-encompassing than they did when described by Administration officials.
''We're going to make our schools' diplomas mean something,'' he said. ''In critical subjects - at the fourth, eighth and 12th grades - we must assess our students' performance.''
Officials said Mr. Bush was referring to efforts to expand a program that samples several thousand students in those grades across the country and measures their achievement.
Mr. Bush also declared that ''every American adult must be a skilled, literate worker and citizen'' by the year 2000. Officials said that meant ''functional literacy,'' which is loosely defined as being able to read well enough to perform day-to-day functions. The Education Department has said that 13 percent of Americans 20 and older are functionally illiterate.
 
Foley Agrees in Part
In his reply to Mr. Bush, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said: ''We will set a national goal of making our schools once again the best in the world by the year 2000. On this issue the President's words seem to agree with us, but his actions say something else.''
The Department of Education's spending in 1991 would increase to $23.7 billion from $22.3 billion, an increase of about 1 percent. But most of that budget is made up of student loan guarantees, which are mandated by law.
Mr. Bush, who has been lashing out at Congress on taxes, crime and other issues, said tonight: ''The American people did not send us here to bicker. There's work to do - and they sent us here to get it done. Once again I offer my hand to all of you.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Spells Out Shifts in Foreign Aid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Bush Administration told Congress today how it will distribute nearly $8 billion in United States foreign aid this year. In an indication of its shifting global priorities, the Administration plans a dramatic increase in aid to Poland and a sharp decrease in assistance to most of Central America, including El Salvador.
The overall amounts for the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, have already been appropriated by Congress, with more than 85 percent of the money earmarked for specific countries and the Administration given discretion in deciding how to spend the rest. No further action by Congress is needed. 
The draft list of allocations, prepared by the State Department and sent to a few members of Congress today, shows that economic aid for El Salvador, $185 million last year, is being reduced to $130.6 million this year. Military aid will be $84.6 million, about the same as the $85 million last year.
The United States has repeatedly affirmed its commitment to the Salvadoran Government, and the Administration has vigorously resisted efforts by Congressional Democrats to reduce aid to El Salvador because of human rights abuses.
 
Budget Considerations
State Department officials said the cutback in assistance to El Salvador did not reflect any dissatisfaction with President Alfredo Cristiani. Rather, they said, this cutback and others reflect fiscal pressures in the United States. In addition, they said, Congress earmarked so much of the aid budget for a few countries that relatively little was left for Central America, Africa and East Asia.
The official list shows that military aid for Honduras, $40 million last year, would be cut to $20.2 million this year, while economic aid is reduced to $60 million, from $85 million last year.
Military aid for Guatemala, which totaled $9 million last year, would be cut to $2.9 million this year. Economic aid would be cut to $56.5 million, from $80 million last year.
The Administration is also cutting economic aid for Costa Rica, to $63.5 million this year, from $90 million last year.
Jamaica's economic aid would be slashed to $5 million this year, from $25 million last year.
In Eastern Europe, Poland is scheduled to receive $227.5 million in cash assistance for its economy, up from $3 million last year. The State Department list shows that Hungary is to get $2.5 million of such aid this year; it did not receive any last year. Both countries are eligible for other types of assistance under legislation signed by President Bush in November.
 
Israel and Egypt Get Less
In allocations for other parts of the world, Israel and Egypt suffer small reductions as a result of an across-the-board cut mandated by Congress to provide extra funds for combating drug traffic. Israel is to receive $1.79 billion in military aid and $1.19 billion in economic aid. Egypt will get $1.29 billion in military aid and $811.5 million in economic aid.
The Philippines will get an increase in aid this year, but less than it expected under an agreement permitting the United States to operate military bases there. The allocations for this year - $140.1 million in military aid and $124 million in economic aid - are less than 80 percent of what Manila was expecting.
Military aid will be cut 15 percent for Portugal (to $84.6 million from $100 million) and 86 percent for Thailand (to $3 million from $22 million).
In sub-Saharan Africa, only two countries are scheduled to receive economic aid: $1.7 million for Djibouti and $2 million for the Seychelles, where the United States Air Force operates a tracking station. In addition, at the insistence of Congress, $10 million is earmarked for scholarships to bring black South Africans to this country.
Among the countries scheduled to receive increased economic aid are Pakistan, which is getting $229 million, an increase of $14 million, and Jordan, which is getting $34.9 million, an increase of nearly $20 million. The program that provides food and health care for Afghans would also increase, to $34.9 million this year, from $22 million last year.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Moscow McDonald's Opens: Milkshakes and Human Kindness (Reuters)

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Connoisseurs of fast food and human behavior were doubly satiated today as anxious crowds of Soviet customers engaged in traditional pushing and shoving to place ''Beeg Mek'' orders at the nation's first McDonald's restaurant, only to be calmed by uniformed compatriots dictating that they have a nice day.
''We added our own spice to the menu, our usual commotion,'' said Valentin Gmyzin, a pipe factory worker, after making it through the counter crush at 27 cash registers and spending four days' salary for a Big Mac, cheeseburger, apple pie and two milkshakes.
As exotic as the food seemed, opening-day customers said they were most impressed at the simple sight of polite shop workers - Soviet workers - somehow having been trained in this nation of commercial boorishness to actually smile and say, ''May I help you?'' and ''Thank you for coming.''
''There is a lesson to be drawn from this for the country,'' said Tatyana Podlesnaya, a teacher. ''What is killing us is that the average worker does not know how to work and so does not want to. Our enthusiasm has disappeared. But here my meal turned out to be just a supplement to the sincere smiles of the workers.'' 
She vowed to lead her elementary-grade students into the gleaming restaurant. ''This is a lesson in humane treatment which our children have to learn.''
 
To Go - to the Ukraine
Mr. Gmyzin was less didactic about progress as he scarfed down half his order himself, murmuring in particular at the cheeseburger and looking happily unrushed at a window table. He was watched by throngs of hope-starved Soviet consumers who waited in lines far longer than those outside Lenin's mausoleum.
He showed a gold-toothed grin of pleasure and departed, taking the rest of his fast feast home to the Donets Basin in the far-off Ukraine, the bearer of an exotic innovation in a nation currently spiralling through an economic crisis. Soviet consumers must spend long hours searching for scarce, inferior goods, and then hoard them, so little faith do they have in daily mercantilism.
The debut on busy Pushkin Square seemed to mark something of a reversal of stereotypical values: the West was being hailed for perfecting socialized eating.
The event was enough to attract commentary from such institutional sages as Stanislav Kondrashev, international analyst for Izvestia, the Government daily, who explained that this was ''the expression of America's rationalism and pragmatism toward food.''
''The contrast with our own unrealized pretensions is both sad and challenging,'' he wrote on the front page, recalling old Kremlin vows to commercially bury the West's cola industry with Russian kvass and its pasta craze with stuffed Siberian pelmeni. ''All that has turned to sand,'' he rued.
 
Blini Advocacy
Sure as ketchup comes in packets, the restaurant has prompted still another grave Soviet debate over what might be termed delectable materialism. A chauvinistic commentator in a Moscow neighborhood newspaper called the ''monotony'' of McDonald's quality characteristic of Western imperialism, but then he had to admit yearning for the return of a pre-Revolutionary Moscow cafe, Yegorov's Blinnaya.
This fabled place for ''incredible Russian blinis,'' or pancakes, ''filled with the most imaginative fillings,'' was the archetype of quality fast food, said this partisan. Just so did some Soviet accounts insist that the cuisine of marauding Tatars, as in steak tartar, prefigure the hamburger's storming of Mother Russia.
''It's a rather complicated sandwich,'' said Valeriya Kaverina during her first encounter with a Big Mac. It cost 3 rubles and 75 kopecks, a good bite of her daily wage of 12 rubles, but a decent price compared with the costs at Soviet restaurants that customers agreed offer nothing like the same quality. Tourists will find that price a bargain, the equivalent of 63 cents in United States currency at the official rate in effect for most cash exchanges.
 
Revenge of the Ruble
''It is a three-story sandwich,'' Lyubov Paladeva said carefully, marvelling at the lettuce tucked within. She was pleased at the roll, a high compliment in this nation of canny bread lovers.
Customers who waited up to two hours to get into the 700-seat restaurant, the largest McDonald's in the world, greatly appreciated the sweet revenge implicit in the sign by the front door: ''For Soviet rubles only.''
Usually Muscovites can merely salivate outside several richly stocked groceries and restaurants newly opened for Westerners, exclusive marts that want none of the internationally valueless rubles and so bear the sign: ''For hard currencies only.''
Many departing customers proudly took their logo-ridden refuse with them to show they were pioneers. They had seen the future and it works, as least as far as their digestive tract.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Muscovites flocking to the country's first McDonald's, which many said offered something as rare in Soviet society as Big Macs: polite workers. (AP)

HEADLINE: Seoul Officials See Accord on U.S. Troop Cut

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Senior Government officials said today that they ''fully expect'' to reach an agreement with the United States this year for the largest withdrawal of American military personnel from South Korea since the end of the Vietnam War.
The officials said that they expected that the reductions would involve 4,000 to 5,000 of the 43,000 Americans serving in the armed forces in South Korea. The move would bring United States forces to the level of the early 1980's, before the Reagan Administration began a broad buildup that swelled the American military presence in Asia and around the globe.
Despite their surprising willingness to reach an agreement, South Korean military officials have in recent days stepped up their warnings that the sweeping changes in Eastern Europe have yet to reduce tensions in Asia, or to have any detectable influence on North Korea. 
The officials' comments, in interviews with foreign reporters here, came two days after the Pentagon announced proposals to close three of its five Air Force bases in South Korea, eliminating 2,000 support positions and consolidating fighter aircraft at two remaining bases.
A senior South Korean official deeply involved in military affairs said today that the Government of President Roh Tae Woo had no objection to cutbacks ''as long as the basic element of deterrent defense remains in Korea.''
That appears to mark a subtle but important change in South Korea's stated position. Previously, the Government had regularly sought assurances that there would be no reductions of any kind.
The change in tone appeared to reflect a decision by South Korea that, given the choice of bearing a bigger share of the cost of stationing American troops here or watching their numbers dwindle, the more attractive option is to allow at least some decline.
The question of how deeply to cut the United States presence here is expected to be a top subject of an Asian tour by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, scheduled to begin in about two weeks. Mr. Cheney will visit Japan, South Korea and the Philippines, the three main sites of United States military installations in Asia.
The last major pullout of American troops in South Korea came in 1971, when President Nixon moved about 20,000 military personnel from the peninsula. In 1978, President Carter announced a plan to withdraw all but 14,000 troops and support personnel, but it drew intense criticism from both in South Korea and on Capitol Hill. He ultimately canceled the plan after pulling back only 3,600 people.
For several days the Korean press has been likening President Bush's efforts to reduce American strength here to Mr. Carter's. Some have suggested that the move amounts to an abandonment of South Korea.
''Any plan to reduce the size of U.S. ground forces in Korea in haste is unrealistic,'' the English-language Korea Herald asserted this morning, saying North Korea's ground forces outnumber South Korea's by about 10 to 7. Dong A Ilbo, a leading newspaper here, insisted today that ''the military threat from the North has not decreased,'' but said that ''the question of American troop withdrawal has left our hands.''
Government officials disputed that view, saying that the United States was acting only after full consultations with South Korea. During the Carter Administration, they argued, North Korea was more threatening and the South had yet to surge ahead economically or build up its own military forces. Most officials here say that they now view the North's economy as unsustainable, and that North Korea will soon have to reduce its own army.
But Hyun Hong Choo, the Minister of Legislation, said today that the United States ''must link its scaledown with developments in North-South relations.''
Mr. Hyun suggested that in return for troop cuts the North should withdraw some troops now stationed just above the demilitarized zone, arrange for exchanges so that families could cross the border to visit relatives, and open a suspected nuclear weapons installation for inspection.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); KOREA, REPUBLIC OF (99%); ASIA (93%); NORTHERN ASIA (93%); PHILIPPINES (79%); KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (79%); EUROPE (79%); JAPAN (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (56%);

HEADLINE: St. Paul Journal;
He Says Populist but Foes Say Pasha

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Jan. 26

 BODY:
While other states grapple with crime or drugs or unemployment, the Minnesota gubernatorial race this year may hinge on one question: Is Gov. Rudy Perpich an arrogant autocrat who lives in a Middle Western Taj Mahal or an offbeat populist who carries his own luggage?
As half a dozen opponents line up to run against him in November, the three-term Governor, a Democrat, is at the center of a front-page squall over what critics call his ''lavish life style'' and quirky behavior.
The trouble began last month when The St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch published a list of the contents of the Governor's mansion, a 33-room English Tudor house used by Minnesota governors since 1966. It included 156 chairs, 81 tables, 26 sofas, 16 rugs and 23 lamps. 
In what opponents called an overreaction, the Governor responded that the mansion had only 113 chairs, 59 tables, 15 sofas, 12 rugs, and, yes, 23 lamps. The rest of the furnishings named by the paper were in storage.
The Governor's wife, Lola, was so outraged that she cut short a trip to New York to tell the Minnesota press that she wanted to sell the mansion and give the proceeds to the homeless.
The trouble did not stop there. Angered after a reporter referred to his Lincoln Town Car as a limousine, the Governor scrapped the car and driver for a Chevrolet Caprice, which he drives himself.
Then came an article in the St. Paul paper saying that the state police had been escorting the Governor's 29-year-old daughter, Mary Sue, to concerts and on shopping trips. Governor Perpich immediately declared that if his family could not have security, neither would he. He got rid of his own bodyguard.
The Governor's supporters note that a mansion, a bodyguard and a limousine are standard perquisites for most governors, and are dwarfed by the boats and indoor swimming pools that others get.
To defuse some of the talk, the Governor and his wife took reporters on a tour of the mansion the other day to show how difficult it is to live there. They pointed to a leaking roof and told of an oven door that was held up by a string before $1.3 million in renovation work began.
''This entire first floor looked like Bangladesh,'' Governor Perpich said. ''You have to have it so it looks right.''
The mansion uproar comes after years of what people here describe as offbeat behavior by the Governor that at first endeared him to Minnesotans but now seems to mystify them.
A few years back, for instance, small farm towns in Minnesota were abuzz after the Governor began dying his graying hair brown. Indeed, one theory for the Governor's behavior, said The Star Tribune in Minneapolis in a recent editorial, was, ''The horrid shoe-polish brown tint that's been applied to his hair also has affected his brain.''
Charles Backstrom, a professor of political science at the University of Minnesota, described the hair coloring and other eccentricities this way: ''It's un-Minnesotan.''
''People are unpretentious around here,'' he added. ''He acts kind of flaky. People like somebody a little bit more stable.''
The Governor's approval rating among unassuming Minnesotans reached a low this month with fewer than one in three saying he should seek re-election, according to a poll in The Pioneer Press Dispatch.
''It's going to be a recurring theme in the campaign - his behavior and his arrogance,'' said Duane Benson, a Republican who is minority leader of the Minnesota Senate. ''The person who grabs a lunch pail in the morning is having a hard time identifying with someone who spends a million dollars on his house and still can't fix the roof.''
Governor Perpich dismissed the charges as campaign rhetoric. ''I've been center stage for four months, bleeding and bruised,'' he said. ''It's a wonder I'm still standing.'' Amid the ruckus, William J. Janklow, former Governor of South Dakota who is a Republican, wrote to the St. Paul paper to extol Governor Perpich. Mr. Janklow said that on their travels abroad, Governor Perpich ''rode in the front seat of cars, readily took taxicabs when a chauffeured limo was available, carried his own luggage and never acted or presumed any regal role.''
Some say the attention to Mr. Perpich's life style says as much about the governed as the Governor. ''Perpich has been around longer than any other Governor and some people are just tired of him,'' Professor Backstrom said. But few are willing to say the Governor is out of the game.
''He has been in trouble before and bounced back to win big,'' the professor said. ''He is not to be counted out by this.''

HEADLINE: Environmental Groups Told They Are Racists in Hiring

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Several members of civil rights and minority groups have written to eight major national environmental organizations charging them with racism in their hiring practices.
The letter, which did not accuse the environmental groups of actually refusing to hire or promote anyone on racial grounds, said the national environmental movement was isolated from the poor and minority communities that it said were the chief victims of pollution.
Spokesmen for the environmental groups, including the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Wilderness Society and the Sierra Club, agreed that they had a poor record of hiring and promoting minority employees, but they denied that racism was involved and insisted they were trying to correct the situation.
They said they had not had an aggressive recruiting program in the past to attract minority employees. But part of the problem, several of the spokesmen contended, was a scarcity of black or Hispanic people among the pool of trained environmental specialists, and the fact that few of them wanted to work at the relatively low salaries offered by nonprofit environmental groups. 
 
No Response in Writing
Among those criticizing the environmental groups were Dr. Benjamin Chavis Jr., director of the United Church of Christ's Commission for Racial Justice, and the Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth, co-chairman of the Southern Organizing Committee for Social and Economic Justice. They demanded that the environmental groups take steps within the next 60 days to assure that 30 to 40 percent of their staffs are members of minority groups.
None of the environmental groups has yet responded in writing to the letter, which was sent Jan. 16.
''I don't think anybody is as aware of the whiteness of the green movement as those of us who are trying to do something about it,'' said Jay D. Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation, the nation's biggest conservation organization.
In addition to the wildlife federation, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Wilderness Society and the Sierra Club, the letter was sent to the Environmental Defense Fund, Friends of the Earth, the National Parks and Conservation Association, the National Audubon Society and the Isaak Walton League.
None of the top leaders of any of those groups is black or Hispanic or Asian, and few of their middle managers come from minority groups. Of 315 staff members of the National Audubon Society, for example, only three are black, said Bob Norman, the society's director of human resources.
 
'We Are Not Proud'
Friends of the Earth's staff of 40 includes five minority workers, counting secretaries. The Natural Resources Defense Council has five minority professionals among its staff of 140. The Sierra Club's 250-member staff includes one Hispanic person but no blacks or Asians among its professionals, said J. Michael McCloskey, chairman of the group. The other groups have similar records.
''We are not proud of our record -we are terrible,'' Mr. Norman said. But he said: ''I can't believe it is racism. We are not getting the candidates from the minority community.''
Frederic D. Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, said, ''The truth is that environmental groups have done a miserable job of reaching out to minorities.''
One problem, he said, is that minority members who are ''cause oriented'' tend to be attracted to issues like discrimination and poverty, rather than environmental issues. Only recently, he said, have environmental problems been recognized as falling disproportionately on the poor and minority neighborhoods.
 
At the Grass Roots
On the grass-roots level, many local environmental organizations, whose members and constituents are often those directly exposed to environmental threats, are led by blacks, Hispanic people or women, in contrast to the national groups.
The national environmental groups have formed an Environmental Consortium for Minority Outreach, which its , executive director, Gerry W. Stover, described as part of a ''concerted effort'' to remedy the hiring imbalance.
Among the other civil rights leaders signing the letter were the following:
 
Richard Moore of the Southwest Organizing Project.
Amos Favorite Sr. of the Ascension Parish Residents against Toxic Pollution in Louisiana.
Sharon Lewis of the Monte Santo Tenants Organization in Baton Rouge, La.
Bettye Ewing of the Mississippi Tenants Organization.
Rose Mary Smith of the Marrero Tenants Organization in Jefferson Parish, La.
The Rev. Avery C. Alexander of Louisiana.
Anne Braden of the Southern Organizing Committee For Economic and Social Justice.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Benjamin Chavis Jr., director of the United Church of Christ's Commission for Racial Justice, criticized environmental groups on their hiring practices. (NYT)

HEADLINE: Immigration Policy Sends Blacks Back to South

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The explanations offered by the Census Bureau for confirmation of the movement of blacks back to the South, where the percentage of black Americans rose in the 1980's (news article, Jan. 10), overlooks the major reason for this exodus: namely, the urban black work force has been adversely affected by resurgence of mass immigration into the cities of the North and the West.
As late as 1910, more than 92 percent of the black population lived in the South. It was not until mass immigration from Europe was curtailed by the outbreak of World War I that blacks began to leave the South in unprecedented numbers. After that war, immigration was sharply curtailed by legislation. Immigration receded dramatically over the subsequent four decades. The percentage of the population that was foreign born fell from 13.2 percent in 1920 to a low of 4.7 percent in 1970. By then, the percentage of blacks living in the South had fallen to 53 percent. In the mid-60's, a new immigration law was adopted. It more than doubled the annual number of legal immigrants admitted. Significant increases have also occurred in refugee admissions (through administrative parole procedures and by new legislation enacted in 1980). Extensive abuses of the laws by illegal immigration, as well as the new gimmick of allowing United States employers to hire tens of thousands of nonimmigrant foreign workers each year have added to the scale of the immigrant flow. 
As a result, the 1980 Census showed that the foreign-born population had reversed previous declines and rose to 6.2 percent of the population (the real figure was higher because of the acknowledged undercount of illegal immigrants - especially in areas like New York City and Los Angeles). With the immigration and refugee policy developments of the 1980's, the foreign-born population should easily reach or exceed 9 percent of the population in the 1990 Census.
The impact of immigration is wholly an urban phenomenon. The 1980 Census showed that while 74 percent of the United States population was urban, 92 percent of the foreign born were. In cities like New York, the impact has been far greater (for example, 23.6 percent of New York City's population was foreign born in 1980, and the figure should easily exceed 25 percent in 1990). As the Census report shows, outside of the South the black population is overwhelmingly concentrated in urban areas -especially in the inner cities. Consequently, the urban black population has borne the brunt of the competition with immigrants for jobs, training opportunities, community services and housing.
In 1981, the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy (the Hesburgh Commission) found that United States immigration policy was ''out of control.'' It urged reforms that would confront ''the reality of limitations.'' Unfortunately, Congress has paid only lip service to this request and has found piecemeal ways to increase the annual flow of immigrants, refugees and nonimmigrant workers. Pending legislation will add only more ways to increase the size of the annual immigrant flow.
As matters stand, immigration is more out of control than it was when the reform movement began in the early 1980's. The major deficiency is that immigration policy is primarily designed to accommodate political goals. It is not accountable for its economic consequences. For much of the nation's urban black population outside the South, immigraton policy is but a revived instrument of institutional racism. It provides a way to bypass the national imperative to address the employment, job preparation and housing needs of much of the urban black population.
Before the 1920's, the effect of immigration policy was to keep blacks out of the urban North and West; in the 1980's, it has sent blacks back to the South.
 
VERNON M. BRIGGS JR.
Ithaca, N.Y., Jan. 12, 1990
 The writer is a professor at the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Cornell University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: First Aid for a U.S. Agency

BYLINE: By Lowell Weicker Jr.; Lowell Weicker Jr., a former Senator from Connecticut, heads Research! America, a health-education group.

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va.

 BODY:
Every American ought to be outraged about what is happening to one of our great public assets - the National Institutes of Health.
The N.I.H. is to medical research what NASA is to space exploration: uncontestedly the best in the world. Unfortunately, we're letting this great national resource run down badly. To picture the seriousness of the situation, imagine that the N.I.H. is not a public agency but a private corporation. 
This hypothetical 100-year-old ''company'' has an unparalleled reputation for discovery. From the beginning, it has been at the forefront of technology development. It holds innumerable patents and has a closet full of Nobel Prizes. Its basic research has spawned the commercial success of many other companies.
The market for its output is of vital importance to the health of every person now alive or yet to be born. In its long history it has developed a proud tradition and a fierce sense of pride. As a financial investment, it has been the bluest of chips, producing a tremendous return on investment for its shareholders.
In recent years, however, it has fallen on hard times. Senior managers are leaving in droves, lured by the promise of greener pastures. Worse yet, it is failing to attract the bright young people who are the lifeblood of any organization.
Management is doing its best to cope, but there isn't enough money for salary increases, and cash flow is insufficient to continue operations at acceptable levels. Despite across-the-board cutbacks, layoffs may be needed to close budget gaps.
Deeply in debt, the parent company has been unable to raise money for new plant and equipment or to modernize its outdated facilities. Foreign competitors have begun eyeing the company's traditional markets and investing heavily in new equipment, technology and research.
On top of all that, the company's chief executive officer resigned more than six months ago, and no replacement has yet been found. Search firms have found several highly qualified candidates who, for philosophical reasons, were unacceptable to the company's chairman.
This hypothetical account pretty well describes the actual plight of our National Institutes of Health.
We should come to the rescue, as we did for the Chrysler Corporation. If we don't, we will be turning our backs on the best science that money can buy and on millions of people with incurable diseases whose only hopes are discoveries from the medical laboratories of America.
Preserving the N.I.H. is a matter both of national prestige and personal importance to every American. It is also a matter of considerable economic significance. Biomedicine is one of the few areas where we still outshine foreign competitors and enjoy a highly favorable balance of trade.
There's no better time, and no more urgent cause for Americans to rally around than medical research. There's no more deserving Government enterprise than the N.I.H.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Bush Won. Who Lost?

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The President won. Oh, yes, the President won - no question at all.
The man knows how to play hardball, no question about that either. When it came right down to it, down to showing who was boss and who would decide what was right or wrong, moral or immoral, no matter what Congress or the American public thought, the President knew how to throw that old ball right for the head. 
What a show he put on. Professionals will talk about it for years.
He threatened, warned, cajoled, made deals, called in every chip, summoned the help of every ally and vassal, until he whipped those Republican senators into line - all but eight of them. Thus did he prevent an override of his veto on a bill guaranteeing Chinese students the right to stay in this country.
Everybody knew the bill was a mark of Congressional outrage against the Bush policy of dumping the democracy movement in China to go along with the Communist Government that gave us Tiananmen Square.
So the President fought real hard and won. Now all that remains is to answer a couple of questions, which become more important every day. What did he win? That is a bit complicated. Certainly not the support of the American public on China. Certainly not the affection of the senators he turned around. Nobody forgets being forced publicly to go back on his word.
A few days after the Bush victory, the Senate, 98 to 0, passed a bill supporting the economic and military sanctions he seems so inclined to wipe out. But the bill permits Mr. Bush to drop the sanctions if he really wants to. The Senate stuck its tongue out, but its gums looked toothless.
But Congress did show the country once again that its members, even the turnabouts, do not have a stomach for the President's China policy.
Members of Congress would much rather have their constituents identify them with that young Chinese who put his body in the way of the tanks than with the wicked men who ordered the tanks in.
But, yes, it can be said that Mr. Bush won a couple of things. He showed Republican senators he could connect his power to their heads, and in Washington that commands respect if not affection.
Also he certainly made the butchers of Beijing happier. Now they should come across with one or two political favors; they owe him.
The pro-Beijing crowd in the U.S. coos with pleasure when the Chinese Communists disdainfully toss Washington a morsel - like ''lifting'' martial law imposed at the time of Tiananmen.
But other Americans, the rest of us, may be getting smarter. We have seen that when the Chinese Communists lift martial law, what is left under the lid is not legal freedoms but the same old ugly stew of kangaroo courts, police power, arbitrary arrest and forced labor. Under the martial law lid is martial law.
And surely most Americans will contemptuously dismiss the main Bush argument that we cannot boycott a billion Chinese. Nobody ever said we should.
We have an Ambassador in Beijing and did not need the high-level delegation the President stealthily sent over, the fawning toasts, the promises abandoned. All those were meant not as a message to the Chinese people but to the Chinese tyrants who rule over them. The message to these men, who ordered the shooting at Tiananmen Square, was: Murder may out, but it pays, boys, it pays. That leads to the second question. Who lost? Who will pay the price for the Bush victory?
Perhaps a few of the turnaround Republican senators may lose their seats. At primary or election time you don't have to remember all 34 of them, just your own man. For New Yorkers, the name is Alfonse D'Amato.
Eastern Europe has shown the only way to reform Communism is to end it. That is difficult for Americans who have spent years apologizing for one Chinese Communist Government after another to accept. They have too many political, economic, career or emotional interests at stake. In his State of the Union Message the President talked about the struggle for freedom in Europe but had not one word for the struggle in China.
But in China that lesson, reinforced in blood at Tiananmen, has been learned by the democracy movement - and by the Communist regime itself.
The struggle will continue. Because of Mr. Bush's Beijing veto victory it may be longer, and more Chinese will go to the horror camps, more will die.
So, Al, that answers the second question.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
From Rohatyn, Unlikely Praise For New Mayor

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
David N. Dinkins was Felix G. Rohatyn's second, maybe third, choice last year to be mayor of New York City. Now Mr. Rohatyn pays Mayor Dinkins what appears to be the ultimate compliment.
Yes, says Mr. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, there would have been stylistic contrasts had Edward I. Koch or Richard Ravitch, putatively Mr. Rohatyn's first choice, been elected instead. Also, each offered different strengths and weaknesses. 
''On balance,'' Mr. Rohatyn said, however, ''I can't see that anybody at this stage of the game would have done better than David.''
His tentative assessment, which many skeptics seem to share, reflects several factors that have defined Mr. Dinkins's first month as mayor:
Low expectations. One measure of just how low was that within two days of promising to be the toughest mayor on crime, Mr. Dinkins was roundly applauded for delaying the planned hiring of 1,848 police officers, thereby demonstrating the fiscal prudence that some feared he lacked.
''I don't think expectations were low,'' said Meyer S. Frucher, a former state official. ''I think there were concerns about how he would function in an executive capacity.'' Mark Green, the incoming Consumer Affairs Commissioner, offered another analysis, which repeatedly proved correct during the campaign: ''David has one asset: he's invariably been underestimated.''
High demands. This David was magnified as he immediately rose to the challenge of a budget-gap Goliath. Apparent preoccupation with the budget also bought more time to organize the government.
''David Dinkins has made in a timely fashion what are obviously painful decisions without drama, without histrionics and without flinching,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. ''He has given the lie to people who thought he would be paralyzed by an inability to act and torn by his compassion coming into brutal connection with economic realities.''
High time. ''Enough already!'' was a major factor in Mr. Dinkins's defeat of Mr. Koch. This mellower mayor, said Richard C. Wade, an urban historian and former Ravitch campaign adviser, has assembled a cabinet that is ''the most representative demographically that I've ever seen in any city.''
More blacks and women, in particular, predominate; white Catholics constitute a minority. Lucius J. Riccio, the Transportation Commissioner, is Italian-American but Protestant; Sanitation Commissioner Brendan Sexton, who hopes to remain in the administration, might be the last vestige of the Irish hegemony in New York City government.
That the crucial human resources commissionership remains vacant is as much a reflection of the lack of willing candidates as of Mr. Dinkins's deliberateness. Yet, even with so many new faces, his administration is considerably more conventional than that of Joseph A. Fernandez, the new Schools Chancellor. This reflects, in part, different mandates: Mr. Fernandez's, to brutalize the inefficient bureaucracy; Mr. Dinkins's, to soothe the city.
Mr. Dinkins's naming yesterday of Justice Milton Mollen as a fifth deputy mayor suggests that the fledgling Dinkins administration is still evolving. With policy largely driven by the budget, Norman Steisel is emerging as First Deputy Mayor in title and fact.
Has Mr. Dinkins made mistakes? A few. He failed to persuade the City Planning Commission to let the Board of Estimate vote on Brooklyn's biggest unsubsidized housing development in decades. He allowed opposition to his choice for health commissioner to fester, but again demonstrated he was not the captive of any single constituency.
Other tests loom larger. Today, he will signal his priorities in a preliminary budget. He resisted suggestions to scrap separate athletic programs for disabled students and raise class sizes in early grades, but delayed planned expansion of day care. Disparate cuts among agencies contrast with the review of possible across-the-board reductions that he suggested during the campaign. His next scheduled test will be labor negotiations in late spring.
On the surface, at least, Mr. Dinkins has surpassed the expectations of skeptics, but his term is only 2 percent complete.
''It's like the fellow who is falling out of the 12-story window,'' said Mr. Wade. ''Nothing's happened yet.''
So far, actually, Mr. Dinkins has landed on his feet. Soon, though, comparing him favorably with the candidates he defeated may continue to comfort lingering skeptics, but may no longer mollify supporters thirsting for change.
''In six months or a year,'' said Representative Major R. Owens of Brooklyn, ''that certainly won't be a compliment.''

HEADLINE: Threat of 455 Layoffs in Westchester

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Westchester County Executive said today that layoff notices would go out to 455 county employees starting on Thursday. But county officials said that it was uncertain how many would eventually be forced from their jobs to balance the county's budget, or which programs and services would be cut.
In a news conference, the County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, said the notices would include a ''cautionary statement'' asking employees ''not to make career changes'' because he will propose budget amendments to the County Board of Legislators that could avert some or most of the layoffs.
The threat of the county's first layoffs since 1979 arose late last year, when the Board of Legislators rejected a 1990 budget proposed by Mr. O'Rourke that would have sent property taxes soaring an average of 27 percent. The budget that the board approved, the largest in the county's history at $1.008 billion, will still require an average property tax increase of 17 percent, but it is $37.5 million less than the original. 
The budget troubles, a result of the economic slowdown in the region and cutbacks in state and Federal aid, have spawned a political struggle between the legislators, who insist that the money can be saved by eliminating unfilled positions, and the County Executive, who has in recent weeks maintained that such amounts could not simply be ''taken out of pencils.''
 
Compromise Possible
A listing of all areas to be affected, which Mr. O'Rourke prepared earlier this month, included the closing of several parks, the elimination of all county dental clinics, the loss of $500,000 in overtime for corrections officers and a one-third reduction in the Department of Social Services's daycare unit.
The Westchester County District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said that his office, told to trim $1 million from its budget, will now drastically cut back on prosecuting misdemeanors.
Though hundreds of pink slips are ready to go out, it appears that Mr. O'Rourke and the Board of Legislators might reach a compromise, at least on the issue of layoffs. The budget amendments Mr. O'Rourke will propose either late this week or next, include spreading $12.7 million in personnel cuts throughout the entire budget, eliminating the need for as many layoffs, and taking out short-term loans.
His statements today were little comfort, however, to the hundreds of employees who were to receive the layoff notices. Even if many positions can be saved, county residents will almost certainly see the elimination of some programs and services.
 
'Our Patients Are Worried'
At the Westchester County Medical Center's Psychiatric Institute in Valhalla today, the mood was especially somber because the center was scheduled to be shut down under a recent money-saving proposal by the County Executive's office.
''I'm sick about it,'' said Michelle Turturro, from Yonkers who works there as a secretary. ''It's not just the paycheck. It's the emotional security that comes from working in a place you feel good about.''
Dr. Juliet Lesser, a staff psychologist, said the center was support for thousands of children and adults. ''There is no place else in the county that serves our patient population, which is largely poor,'' she said. ''Our patients are extremely worried. These people are really in grave danger.''
Farther north in Croton Point Park, a 550-acre finger of land jutting into the Hudson River, park employees were similarly anxious. Croton Point has been targeted to close. George Smalls, the 70-year-old assistant parks superintendent who has worked there since 1960, said, ''I wouldn't want to see the park close down completely, because after 30 years it's like home - aside from the job.''
 
'Bump-and-Retrieval'
Some members of the Board of Legislators point to Mr. O'Rourke's proposal to close 20 percent of the county's parkland as an example of his overreacting to their slimming down his original budget.
''Although they originally wanted a 19 percent increase in spending, the Parks Department is still getting a 12 percent increase over last year,'' said Sandra R. Galef, the Democratic minority leader on the 17-member board. ''I just don't see how they can't live on that.''
The people who receive layoff notices in the coming days will in all likelihood not be the ones ultimately to lose their jobs because of a process known as ''bump-and-retrieval'' in which seniority and rank are taken into account. Even though notices will go to the least senior person in an affected office or department, that person may have seniority over an employee in a similar position in another department. In that case, veteran workers would assume the jobs in another department held by employees of lesser seniority, who would then be laid off.
Priscilla Wheeler, 44, a district manager in the White Plains health department, is sure a notice will eventually float down to her. The Health Department's district office in Peekskill is scheduled to close, along with the district manager's job there, and of the half-dozen such managers in the county, she is the newest.
Other county governments in New York are also experiencing budget contraints.
The Suffolk County Executive, Patrick G. Halpin, recently projected a $20 million to $25 million shortfall for this year's $1.3 billion budget. The county has begun an austerity program, including a hiring freeze for all positions that do not concern public safety or produce money. Out-of-county travel is off-limits, as is most overtime there.
''Layoffs are not being considered at present, but certainly that's something we have to look at,'' said the Suffolk County Executive's spokesman, Bradford W. O'Hearn.

HEADLINE: Suffragist's Birthplace Is Bought

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOUNT LAUREL, N.J., Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Alice Paul Centennial Foundation has completed the purchase of Miss Paul's birthplace here, said a spokeswoman for the foundation, Janet Tegley.
The Moorestown-based group exercised its option to purchase the suffragist's 19th-century farmhouse and protect it from development in Mount Laurel, a booming community in Burlington County, Ms. Tegley said.
The foundation, formed in 1984 to commemorate the 100th anniversary of Miss Paul's birth, had raced to raise about $500,000 to acquire the Greek Revival house, formally known as Paulsdale. 
Dozens of politicians, feminists and celebrities loaned their names to the cause, including Marlo Thomas, Bella Abzug and Shirley Chisholm, but the group raised only about $50,000.
In November, a consortium of seven New Jersey banks, backed by the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, loaned the foundation $365,000. The foundation has three years to repay the loan, Ms. Tegley said.
''The fund-raising must continue,'' she said. ''There is still a lot yet to be done.''
The 12-room house, which was built in 1840, will be refurbished, and its broad wraparound porch will be restored.
The three-story white house, with its well-kept exterior and blue shutters, is listed on both the National and New Jersey Registers of Historic Places. It will be used as a conference center where the work of the suffragist can continue, and leadership seminars for women can be held.
Miss Paul was born in an upstairs bedroom in 1885 and lived in the house until she left for Swarthmore College in 1901. The house once overlooked the Paul family's 173-acre farm. It now sits on six and a half acres with a few crumbling outbuildings.
Miss Paul, who died in 1977 at age 92, founded the National Women's Party in 1916 and is widely credited with keeping the suffragist movement alive during World War I, when other advocates switched to the war effort.
She took the fight for enfranchisement out of parlors and into the streets when she organized a demonstration of 5,000 women to march during Woodrow Wilson's inauguration in 1913.
She also wrote the proposed Equal Rights Amendment, which was first introduced in Congress in 1923, and lobbied successfully for a clause barring sex discrimination in the 1964 Civil Rights Act.

SECTION: Section C; Page 20, Column 3; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1628 words

HEADLINE: 'Roger and Me': Documentary? Satire? Or Both?

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
The first among the many questions that could be raised these days about Michael Moore's ''Roger and Me'' is this: Why has this low-budget muckraking documentary, with no box-office stars, no glamour and none of the content that normally draws the moviegoing public, achieved such popularity and profitability?
The answer embodies an irony. Mr. Moore's success is almost certainly due to his style of deadpan facetiousness, a style of black humor that has been likened by some admirers to Voltaire's ''Candide'' or Jonathan Swift's ''Modest Proposal.'' ''Roger and Me,'' as the critics have pointed out, is plainly entertaining, and moreover, it is a kind of David and Goliath revenge story, in which a modest, plain-speaking nobody triumphs morally over an evil corporate giant.
But lately some dissenting voices have arisen amid the general chorus of praise for ''Roger and Me,'' and that is where the irony lies. These critics - notably Harlan Jacobson, writing in Film Comment magazine, and Pauline Kael, in The New Yorker - have complained that Mr. Moore's film, although funny, is factually inaccurate. The film maker, they say, is guilty of manipulating the sequences of events and compressing them for the sake of emotional and political impact. ''Roger and Me,''in their view, is thus biased and misleading. 
 
Satire Is Exaggeration
What Mr. Moore's detractors are saying, in a sense, is that the very qualities that made the film successful - the elements of irreverence, satire, ridicule - are the very ones that make it misleading, since satire inevitably depends on a certain partiality and exaggeration, the creation of a villain, an artistic deformation of the real world.
And that in turn leads to a deeper issue regarding the genre of documentary film that Mr. Moore, an experienced advocacy journalist but a man with no film experience, seems to have defined anew. The complaints of unfairness are based on the assumption that a documentary is a piece of filmed journalism, and that it should obey the same rules of balance and objectivity that newspapers and television news are supposed to obey.
This does not mean that a good documentary can have no strongly held point of view, no quality of idiosyncracy. Some of the most celebrated examples of the genre, like Marcel Ophul's ''Sorrow and the Pity,'' Claude Lanzmann's ''Shoah,'' and Frederick Wiseman's 'Near Death,'' clearly embody the film makers' personal views of their subjects, just as Mr. Moore's film does.
 
A Question of Standards
Mr. Wiseman - whose 1967 documentary ''Titicut Follies,'' about conditions at a Massachusetts state prison for the criminally insane, still remains under a modified ban imposed by that state - says the question is really one of standards.
''I readily acknowledge that my films are biased, subjective, prejudiced, condensed, compressed,'' the experienced and well-regarded documentary film maker said in a telephone interview. Indeed, he said, all documentaries are necessarily distortions of reality, since, obviously, they are filmed through a lens and edited. Events that might have taken place over weeks, months or years are reduced to a presentation of, at most, a few hours.
''But I think that my films are fair,'' Mr. Wiseman continued, ''and by fair I mean that they are an accurate account of the experience I had when making the film rather than an imposition of a preconceived point of view.''
But does this apply to ''Roger and Me?'' Is it really a documentary like any other, or is it more like a Swiftian satire - with the audience knowing it is satire - and therefore dependent on intentional exaggeration in order to call attention to what might be seen as the higher truth? Moreover, if ''Roger and Me'' had hewed to standard, impartial journalistic practices, could it have been as entertaining, as personal, as sharply targeted and therefore as successful as it has become?
 
Finding a Target
Mr. Moore's film focuses on his hometown, Flint, Mich., once known as Pontiac City, where, according to ''Roger and Me,'' the closing of 11 factories and the layoff of 30,000 workers by a callous General Motors management created unspeakable hardship and decline.
Mr. Moore, who is the film's narrator, interviewer and chief screen presence, not only traces the deterioration of Flint, but also finds a target for his satire. This is Roger Smith, the General Motors chairman, who, protected by a blindly obedient bureaucracy of guards and public relations agents, rejects all of Mr. Moore's efforts to interview him or to bring him to Flint to see for himself the suffering that his policies - portrayed as greedy and unnecessary by Mr. Moore - have allegedly brought about.
The criticisms of Mr. Moore, which were first outlined by Mr. Jacobson and then were picked up by Ms. Kael in a sharply critical review, are based on several points. First, as Mr. Jacobson wrote, the film compressed events that actually took place over a long period of time and altered the sequence of some of them. The 11 plant closings affected 4 states, not just Flint. The 30,000 jobs lost in Flint were lost over 12 years, not the far shorter span suggested - though never explicitly stated - by Mr. Moore in ''Roger and Me.''
 
Assumptions Are Inevitable
Aside from the factual complaints - most of which are deemed innacurate by Mr. Moore - Ms. Kael argues that ''Roger and Me'' is a piece of ''gonzo demagoguery'' in which most of the people who appear, with the exception of Mr. Moore, are portrayed as just a bit idiotic, as though they have been ambushed by the camera. At the same time, there is no effort to explore in any depth at all what might be seen as General Motors's and Mr. Smith's side of the story, no accounting, for example, of why the plant closings took place and what General Motors tried to do to cushion the blow suffered by its workers.
Mr. Moore is thus assailed for making, by clever cutting and editorial work, some people appear more ridiculous than they might otherwise have appeared, while at the same time giving a false impression of Flint's economic calamity. ''Roger and Me,'' these criticisms imply, make it appear that the city underwent a brutally sudden collapse, all due to the uncaring, inhumane policies of General Motors's Mr. Smith, who is protected by a phalanx of guards and public relations agents who exempt him from having to justify his policies or decisions.
Mr. Moore has said in interviews that he did compress events, but that his film nonetheless is true to what actually happened in Flint, his hometown, where, he believes, General Motors did abandon its social responsibility to help workers it was laying off.
 
'All Art Manipulates'
''I am partial,'' Mr. Moore said in a telephone interview yesterday. ''The film has a point of view, but I did not distort the facts or, as Harlan Jacobson says, play fast and loose with the truth in order to make my political point. There's a certain comedic license that is being taken with the film.''
Pressed in his interview with Mr. Jacobson about his presentation of events, Mr. Moore said: ''All art -listen, every piece of journalism -manipulates sequence and things.''
''It's a movie, you know,'' he said. ''You can't do everything. I was true to what happened. Everything that happened in the movie happened. It happened in the same order that it happened through the 80's.''
It is possible to end up in a middle position on the question of ''Roger and Me'': a belief that the film was clearly intended to poke fun, to be satire rather than conventional documentary and thus should not be condemned for its partial and even biased presentation of the data. But mingling with that idea is an unease that, in the end, some of the impact of the film is dissipated precisely because the audience cannot rely on the history of Flint as Mr. Moore presents it. The basic question -what was the responsibility of Mr. Smith and General Motors for Flint's decline? - is obscured by the very mode of comic exaggeration that Mr. Moore employs.
''I think the criticism is carping,'' said William Wolf, a former film critic who teaches at New York University, ''because I do think the film is special. Moore might have been a little more savvy in guessing that he would have some criticisms and in guarding against them, but he was doing a personal essay and should have a lot of freedom to raise all sorts of hell.''
 
Parody Is Attention-Getting
Mr. Moore, this argument could continue, was no more operating within the standard framework of journalism than was Jonathan Swift when he wrote his ''Modest Proposal,'' in which he suggested that a cure for the Irish famine would come if people started eating their babies. Swift's parody was aimed at calling closer attention to the famine than yet another even-handed, judicious piece of reporting could have, and so, it could be argued, was Mr. Moore's.
What makes ''Roger and Me'' different in this regard is its clear message from the beginning that it is going, as Mr. Wolf put it, to be ''a highly effervescent expression of a film maker who is sounding off on a topic that films don't usually treat.'' Mr. Moore in this sense signals from the very beginning - indeed, from the title itself - that he is fashioning a highly personal document, not a dispassionate academic treatment of a complex subject.
If, for example, Mr. Moore had entitled his film something like ''General Motors and Flint: The Making of a Calamity,'' he would have been signaling a conventional journalistic treatment. To his supporters, the title ''Roger and Me,'' clearly shows in advance that irreverence, eccentricity and a highly personalized view are all among his primary intentions.

HEADLINE: Policy Shift On Bailouts Is Explored

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The chairman of the agency created to manage the bailout of the savings industry said today that the number of ailing institutions had soared to such an extent that the Government should consider keeping some of them open rather than taking them over.
''The whole point is to find the lowest-cost way to handle this problem,'' L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, said in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee. ''The problem is that once an institution is taken over, the costs of selling it off rapidly goes up.''
Later in the day, Federal regulators seized control of Merabank, Arizona's largest savings institution. Merabank is the fourth largest of the more than 300 institutions seized so far by regulators. [Page D5.] Abrupt Change in Policy In an interview after the session, Mr. Seidman said he had asked the oversight board of the trust corporation to consider trying to revive some ailing institutions. He said the board had told him to conduct a feasibility study, which is under way. 
Such a strategy, if adopted, would represent an abrupt change in how the Government deals with ailing savings institutions. Mr. Seidman is the first regulator to raise publicly the possibility of trying to nurse ailing institutions back to health.
Congress and the Bush Administration decided last year that the best way to control the cost of the savings crisis was to take over all the problem institutions as quickly as possible and sell them or close them to prevent further losses.
Some members of Congress had repeatedly criticized savings regulators for delaying the closing of ailing savings institutions, arguing that doing so increased the cost of the crisis.
Those critics say that keeping ailing institutions open is expensive because they must pay higher interest rates than competitors to attract deposits. In turn, those higher rates force healthy institutions to offer higher interest rates to hold their depositors.
 
Reputation for Straight Talk
Considering that vehemence in Congress, Mr. Seidman is perhaps the only regulator who could credibly propose such a change in strategy. A longtime Washington hand who served as President Gerald R. Ford's chief domestic policy adviser, Mr. Seidman has a reputation in Congress and in the banking and savings industries for straight talk and skillful management.
Members of the banking committee did not make much of Mr. Seidman's statement, which came at the end of a three-and-a-half-hour hearing on the progress of the savings industry cleanup.
In suggesting that the takeover policy be re-examined, Mr. Seidman seemed to imply that the risk of further losses from institutions kept open was more acceptable than the ultimate cost of taking them over in the next year.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady estimated a year ago that $50 billion would be needed to take over and sell 300 insolvent institutions.
But regulators now warn that the number of such institutions is almost certain to exceed 600, and might go as high as 800 institutions, with assets approaching $500 billion.
Last week, Mr. Seidman testified before Congress that the cost of the savings bailout was likely to far exceed the $50 billion allocated by Congress last year.
Regulators have estimated that once the Government takes over an ailing savings institution, investors reduce the amount they are willing to pay for the institution by as much as 20 percent.
When the Government intervenes, there is generally a certain disruption of continuing business activities, as regulators impose restraints and perhaps foreclose on some income-producing properties.
 
'This Is Total Heresy'
Banking experts who know Mr. Seidman described his statement as a subtle but highly significant admission that he fears the potentially astronomical cost of the bailout plan.
''For a Republican Administration, this is total heresy,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association. ''But, thank God, Seidman is leaving ideology behind and going with a new approach, which may be less expensive to the taxpayer.''
Eric I. Hemel, a securities analyst at the First Boston Corporation and former director of economic policy at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, commented: ''It is a very plaintive cry by Seidman. He is saying that the R.T.C. does not have enough resources and operating flexibility they need to get the job done and that they are being badly taxed by the job they have to do. He is being forced into this position.''
 
Not a Return to the Mid-1980's
Mr. Seidman noted that he was not advocating a return to the regulatory approach of the mid-1980's, when savings and loan officials kept hopelessly insolvent institutions open in the hope that the economy would turn around.
Rather, he said his agency would focus on distressed institutions that were still profitable and had some hope of survival. He added that any institutions that might be left open would be subject to heavy scrutiny by the regulators.
He would not estimate how many institutions that might be, but suggested that they might be treated like the New York savings banks were in the early 1980's.
Because of soaring interest rates, the savings banks found they were paying 15 percent and more on deposits, while earning only about 7 percent or so on mortgage loans, a situation that is called an interest-rate mismatch.
''In effect the entire industry was broke,'' Mr. Seidman said.
Regulators thought that interest rates would eventually fall and that the banks could return to profitability as long as they could be prevented, through growth restraints and other management controls, from making high-risk investments out of desperation.
 
'We Kept Those Banks Open'
For the most part, the savings banks did recover, and Mr. Seidman said the ultimate cost of the New York crisis to the nation's bank insurance fund would be about $2 billion.
''We kept those banks open, helped them out and eventually got them back on their feet,'' Mr. Seidman said.
Mr. Guenther of the Independent Bankers Association said the approach Mr. Seidman was studying was similar to that taken in the 1930's by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which injected aid into hundreds of ailing banks, kept them open and eventually nursed them back to health when the country came out of the Depression.
''We suggested an R.F.C.-type approach last year and were rejected by the Treasury,'' Mr. Guenther said. ''We were told it was a Democratic idea.''
The cost of the bailout continues to concern both lawmakers and regulators, and members of the panel tried to get Treasury officials to acknowledge that the $50 billion allocated to the R.T.C. over a three-year period would not be enough to handle the task of cleaning up the industry.
''I don't want to sit here and have everybody say, 'Robson came up here and told us it was $50 billion, period,' because it could be more,'' said John Robson, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury. ''Circumstances of the economy, circumstances of interest rates and a variety of things can affect that.''

HEADLINE: Stocks End 5-Day Slide; Dow Up 47.30

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
After five losing sessions, stock prices rose yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 47.30 points, or 1.9 percent higher, to 2,590.54.
The jump on the Dow was the biggest since it climbed 56.95 points on Jan. 2, to a record 2,810.15. Between that rise and yesterday, prices had moved lower, and the Dow ended the month down 162.66, a drop of 5.9 percent. It was the Dow's worst month since it fell 8 percent in November 1987. 
Secondary averages moved up less briskly, with the American Stock Exchange market value index gaining 4.57 points, or 1.3 percent, to 350.07. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index moved up 5.09 points, or 1.2 percent, to 415.81. For the month, the Amex index fell 7.4 percent, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 8.6 percent. 1,116 Issues Up Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by more than 2 to 1, with 1,116 issues higher in price and only 449 lower.
Analysts said the market's rally was technical in many aspects, after its slow selloff during January.
Investors, traders said, were also encouraged by speculation that President Bush's State of the Union address would call on the United States and the Soviet Union to reduce their military forces in Europe. The President, in fact, did make such a recommendation last night.
That speculation also helped prompt a rally in bond prices that pushed yields down and, traders said, encouraged buying in the stock market.
''Despite the final outcome, the market had the same problems today that it faced yesterday - an unyielding Federal Reserve Board, reduced corporate earnings, disappearing mergers and acquisitions, and widespread pessimism,'' said Gene Jay Seagle, chief technical analyst at Gruntal & Company. ''But what a difference a day makes.
''Sentiment is depressed as we get to important bottoms,'' he added. ''With the market down for five straight days, a normal retracing of the decline would mean about a 150-point rally back to 2,650 before the selling overhead resumes.''
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.10 points, to 329.08, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 3.07 points, to 181.50.
A total of 189.7 million shares changed hands, up from the 186 million traded on Tuesday.
''It appears that rising interest rates and already announced fourth-quarter earnings reports, which dragged stock prices lower throughout most of January, have at least temporarily come to a halt,'' said Robert E. Walsh, a portfolio manager at Jenswold, King & Associates in Houston. ''After a four-week decline, the market was oversold from a technical standpoint.''
Mr. Walsh said the four-day advance in the interest-sensitive Dow Jones utility average indicated that interest rates are not likely to move appreciably higher over the near term. ''Other positives include a high institutional cash position and net buying by insiders for the past 10 out of 12 weeks,'' he added.
 
Occidental Most Active
Among individual issues, Occidental Petroleum was the most active stock, ending unchanged at 26 5/8, on a volume of 6.3 million shares. Oil industry officials said Occidental's chairman, Armand Hammer, had held talks with Moroccan officials on an oil exploration agreement.
Dow Chemical dropped 1 3/4, to 63 7/8. The company reported lower than expected fourth-quarter earnings of $1.59 a share, down from $2.29 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Some analysts had expected profits to be about $1.95 a share.
Philip Morris rose 7/8, to 37 7/8. The company reported that net earnings for 1989 rose 26.1 percent on an operating revenues rise of 41 percent.
Xerox climbed 2 3/8, to 55 1/2. The company reported higher than expected earnings of $2.01 a share. Most Wall Street estimates had been in the range of $1.25 to $1.75 a share.
Active glamour stocks included A.T.& T., up 1 1/4, to 39; Chase Manhattan up 3/8, to 30 3/4; I.B.M., up 1 3/8, to 98 5/8, and General Electric up 1/2, to 62 1/4.
