HEADLINE: School Reform: Business Moves In

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER

 BODY:
When it comes to reforming the nation's schools, these days the leading radicals are likely to be wearing pin-striped suits and come from oak-paneled board rooms rather than the ivy-covered walls of academia.
Many of these corporate leaders have for years had tutoring and ''adopt-a-school'' programs that put computers in classrooms and lent employees to help students with lessons. But now companies are moving into a second phase, some experts say, one that emphasizes core structure - how the schools are run -over core curriculum in their aid to education.
In doing so, companies are trying to transfer to schools some of the organizational, management and free-market approaches that executives have used to meet the challenge of foreign competition.
Now, concerned about losing business to foreign companies with better-educated workers and dismayed by the slow pace of educational progress in this country, Xerox, Chevron, I.B.M., A.T.&T., Exxon and other corporations have recently spurred some of the most fundamental revamping of schools in decades:
* In this city, Eastman Kodak and other businesses have strongly backed reforms that are turning the local school system into a national prototype for modern education. The changes have sharply raised the salaries of teachers and set up programs to help them do their jobs better. At the same time, they are held more accountable for students' performance and can be dismissed more quickly for incompetence. 
* In Chicago, a coalition of businesses successfully led the lobby to pass perhaps the most sweeping school decentralization plan in this country. Now each of that city's nearly 600 schools is a semi-independent operation run by its own governing board.
* In Milwaukee, a group of corporations is providing management experts to help individual schools take into their own hands more decision-making on curriculum and other policies. New York City has a smaller version of the plan, using retired executives.
* And in at least two cities, companies have even started their own elementary and secondary schools, offering them as models of progressive education on a limited budget.
''Corporate involvement in education, historically, has been a grip and grin kind of thing,'' said John Lennes, director of governmental relations for the Minnesota Business Roundtable. ''You would go out, shake a lot of hands and give out certificates and a $500 check at the local high school. It was all one big photo op. What's changing is that the private sector is talking about sharing ideas and experiences.''
The companies are pushing such ideas as allowing principals and teachers to make more policy decisions; increasing perfomance incentives for teachers; making teachers and administrators more accountable for student achievement, and raising the competition among public schools for students. Some companies are supplying technical expertise and contributing research and development money.
Companies are also banding together to put pressure on state legislatures and school boards to adopt more business-like approaches to education. But so far there has been more talk than action.
 
A Fear of Mistrust
Many executives are moving tentatively, and for the most part are avoiding curriculum issues, aware that they lack knowledge of many basic educational issues. Some are also concerned that their efforts may breed mistrust among educators and local politicians.
''I think that one of the things that is holding business back is that they are not quite sure what to do,'' said Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman and chief executive of RJR Nabisco Inc. ''There have been traditional responses such as adopt-a-school and internship programs. They are terrific, but they perpetuate the status quo. When you talk about being an agent of fundamental change, of helping the reformers shake up the educational establishment, that becomes more difficult for business.''
Still, despite these concerns, there is enough activity to indicate a nascent trend.
In November, RJR Nabisco announced it was giving grants totaling $30 million over a five-year period to school systems that develop innovative, yet practical, ways to improve education. RJR said it wants to finance programs that bring more control and accountability to the individual school, provide more options for students, make greater use of technology and employ non-traditional concepts, like longer school days and alternative and speedier ways to license teachers.
''We want to fund the china-breakers,'' Mr. Gerstner said, ''people who want to try very different things that bureaucracies traditionally don't want to fund.''
 
Inner-City School Started
In Chicago, whose schools were once described by former Secretary of Education William J. Bennett as the ''worst in the nation,'' a group of businesses including Quaker Oats, McDonald's, Baxter International and Sears, Roebuck has started its own private school for poor, inner-city children as a demonstration laboratory for educational innovation.
The Minnesota Business Partnership, an organization of 87 corporations, was a prime force in getting that state's Legislature to approve a plan to spur competition among schools. The main part of the plan gives children the choice of attending any public school in the state.
Supporters of the plan say marginal schools will have to improve to attract students - and state aid - or go out of business. Critics say the bad schools will remain, filled with poor and probably minority students unable to move as freely as more affluent ones.
The California Roundtable, whose lobbying efforts in 1973 helped pass legislation to toughen high school graduation requirements, is now promoting a bill that provides $57 million for local school districts to design and carry out demonstration projects that involve early childhood education, provide more autonomy for individual schools and develop student and school performance standards.
 
A Fight on Tenure
In New York, New York City Partnership Inc., a business and civic organization, plans to lobby the State Legislature to abolish school-based tenure, which prohibits the transfer of a principal unless he or she is guilty of gross incompetence.
In September, the National Alliance for Business issued a ''Blueprint for Business on Restructuring Education,'' a primer to help business develop strategies to pass fundamental changes in their local or state school systems.
Among the changes supported by business leaders in Rochester were improved salaries that allow some teachers to earn nearly $70,000 annually; a peer review process to help teachers who are performing poorly and to make it easier to dismiss incompetent ones.
One of the biggest changes made in any school system is a requirement that Rochester teachers take responsibility for small groups of students, including making home visits to see if problems outside of school are affecting classroom performance.
Rochester has also set up management committees of teachers, parents, administrators and some students to run each school.
 
Better Skills Required
The impetus behind the corporate embrace of education reform is concern about the quality of the American labor pool. As robots and computers increasingly take over rote manual work, even entry-level workers will require better reading, math and problem-solving skills than are now the norm, labor experts say.
The most recent comprehensive Federal reports show only slight improvement in reading skills since 1971, and virtually no change in writing proficiency since 1974.
Further worrying corporations is that within 10 years white males, who tend to score the highest on standardized academic tests, will constitute less than 10 percent of the net growth in the work force. While minorities, especially blacks, have made significant progress in cutting their dropout rate, and improving their performance on standardized tests, they still lag far behind white pupils.
 
Giving Schools Independence
Key to the changes promoted by many business leaders is decentralized decision-making; an idea often summed up by the phrase ''school-based management.'' Under this theory, teachers, principals and parents at individual schools are given much more independence in areas like budgeting, designing curriculum and contracting for services. Proponents say they have a clearer idea of the needs of the school and students than do administrators at a central school board. By treating pupils more like consumers, local schools can move much quicker to improve in the areas most needed by their students.
''School-based management is a concept that appeals to business executives who have gone through two decades of organizational thought that stresses decentralized decision-making,'' Mr. Gerstner said.
Skeptics note that a form of decentralization has been in place in New York City for 20 years, during which time the schools have deteriorated. Recently, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, decreed that because of scandals and allegations of widespread corruption, the city's 32 local school boards had to let him review all candidates for district superintendent.
But Mr. Fernandez is a strong proponent of school-based management, making the concept the centerpiece of his first budget.
 
Accountability Stressed
Executives and reformers who advocate school-based management say the concept will work, as long as the success or failure of the local governing councils can be measured and they are held accountable for their school's performance.
Marc Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, an educational study group in Rochester, said that one way to inject a measure of accountability was to make schools compete by allowing students to choose their schools.
''We need to decentralize for a lot of sound management reasons,'' Mr. Tucker said. ''But we also need a free-market system because of the incentives it provides.''
For local management to work, many reformers add, individual governing councils will need training in budgeting, planning and other skills needed to run a small company. Businesses can provide expertise to schools in many of these areas.
The biggest worry, executives involved in school reform say, is public and corporate impatience. In recent years, American businesses have been criticized for concentrating on short-term profits and neglecting long-term investments. Reformers say it will take years before educational restructuring produces real gains.
''The big unanswered question is whether these guys have the staying power to hang in there,'' said Denis T. Doyle, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute and a co-author of a book on educational reform written with David T. Kearns, chairman of the Xerox Corporation.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Climb 0.8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Government's most widely followed economic forecasting gauge rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, the biggest gain since April, the Commerce Department reported today.
The rise in the index of leading indicators was somewhat larger than anticipated and was regarded as pointing to continued growth, even though some of the advance represented a statistical rebound from a 48-day strike at the Boeing Company that ended in late November.
''It's a good, solid, respectable increase,'' said Jay N. Woodworth, a senior economist at the Bankers Trust Company, adding that the report was ''a welcome change of pace from the flatness'' registered by the index since early summer.
But a report today on home sales offered something of a counterpoint to the leading indicators. The Commerce Department said sales of single-family homes fell 9.6 percent in December, ending the worst year for home sales since 1984. [Page D6.] Greenspan Testimony The leading indicators report followed assertions on Tuesday by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, that the chances of recession had waned. In his testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Mr. Greenspan cited the index, whose historic patterns had been scrutinized by Fed analysts, as signaling only a one-in-five chance of a recession during the first half of 1990. 
In another report today, the National Bureau of Economic Research said its experimental recession index now registers a 6 percent chance that the economy will be in recession at midyear, down from a 9 percent chance a month ago.
The research bureau, based in Cambridge, Mass., is a private organization headed by Martin S. Feldstein, former top economic adviser to President Ronald Reagan. Economists consider the bureau the nation's quasi-official designator of a recession, which is usually defined as two straight quarters of contracting economic activity although shorter or longer periods could be deemed recessions.
 
Research Firm's Outlook
Another private-sector forecasting index, one compiled by Safian Investment Research in New York, rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month after showing little change in November. Eleven of the 22 components making up the firm's Composite Forecasting Index rose during the month.
A less optimistic reading, however, came from Jesup & Lamont's Macro-Economic Index, which rose slightly to minus 70 from minus 72 but still maintains the recession prediction it first signaled in August.
In addition, the leading index compiled by the Columbia Business School of activity in the service sector of the economy fell again in December, reducing its annualized growth rate to 1.7 percent from 2.5 percent in November.
The rise in the Commerce Department's index followed a November increase of one-tenth of 1 percent and matched the gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent in April 1989 and August 1988. Not since June 1988, when there was a 1.6 percent jump, has last month's rise been exceeded.
For the year, however, the index rose a scant four-tenths of 1 percent, down sharply from the 3.9 percent increase in 1988. This was the weakest performance since 1984, when there was a 1.5 percent decline, and suggested that although economic growth is expected to continue this year, it will probably be sluggish.
Economic growth in the fourth quarter of 1989 slowed to an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, or to 1 percent, after adjusting for the strike at Boeing.
 
Increases in Factory Orders
Six of the 11 elements in the leading index contributed to the December advance, paced by a rise in manufacturers' unfilled orders and contracts and new orders for plant and equipment. Both of these were higher largely because of the end of the strike at Boeing, which is enjoying a boom in commercial airliner orders.
The other four advancing elements were higher stock prices; more rapid growth in the M-2 money supply, which measures currency plus checking accounts and some time deposits; a rise in building permits, and a strengthening of consumer expectations.
Restraining the index were a decline in prices that are particularly sensitive to swings in the business cycle, like copper prices; a rise in initial claims for state unemployment insurance; lower new orders by manufacturers for consumer goods and materials, and a speedup in the delivery of goods by suppliers.
The 11th component, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged at 40.7 hours.
 
Previous Predictions
Since most of the items making up the index have been previously reported in one fashion or another, analysts generally are able to predict the figure with some confidence.
The consensus estimate, of a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent, was a bit low in part because of an upward revision in building permits. There was no revision, however, of the index itself for October or November, a rare occurrence.
By quarters last year, the index rose seven-tenths in the winter, fell five-tenths in the spring, fell one-tenth in the summer and rose two-tenths in the fall, today's report showed.
The leading index now stands at 145.7, or 45.7 percent higher than its 1982 base of 100.
Two companion economic indexes also gained in December, today's report showed. The index of coincident indicators, which tracks current economic conditions, rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to 134.2, while the index of lagging indicators, which is intended to confirm turning points in the economy after they have occurred, rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to 120.9.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Is Urged to Sell Gold as Hedge Against Bad Loans

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The United States has proposed that the International Monetary Fund sell about three million ounces of gold, which at current market prices could raise more than $1 billion, to buttress the global lending agency against the growing problem of delinquent payments by its members.
Reports that the Treasury had made such a proposal roiled the futures markets, pushing down gold prices. [Page D17.] A Treasury official said tonight that the idea had been put forward in discussions among the fund's members over increasing the capital of the organization to meet expected increases in demand for its resources. 
The American position is that any decision on increasing resources must also address the problem of overdue payments by 15 of the agency's 152 member countries, the official said. The arrears total $4 billion.
 
Broad Support Lacking
Under the American proposal, which does not have wide support on the fund's board, the countries in arrears would bear part of the cost from their failure to fulfill obligations. The nations include some of the poorest countries in Asia, Latin America and Africa.
The plan calls for the gold holdings subscribed by these countries to be ''mobilized,'' the official said. This could mean sales in the market or sales to other governments.
The I.M.F.'s gold resources have accumulated through original membership requirements under which a portion of a country's borrowing rights are paid in gold.
The 15 countries had paid in something less than 3 percent of the 103 million ounces of gold now held by the agency.
The fund last sold gold in the mid-1970's. The agency had disposed of 50 million ounces, half of which was sold in the market and the other half to its members in proportion to their borrowing rights.
The purpose of the transactions was to raise money for a trust fund to help the poorest countries.
The American proposal, the monetary officials said, does not have broad support on the I.M.F.'s board and is opposed by the agency's managing director, Michel Camdessus, a former governor of the central bank of France.
Mr. Camdessus, the officials said, believes the I.M.F.'s gold resources reinforce its financial strength and should be left intact.
 
Administration Sees Problems
But the Bush Administration contends that the agency has not taken strong enough action to clear up the arrears and that the arrears will pose a problem in trying to convince Congress to back a new increase in the agency's resources.
The fund and its sister organization, the World Bank, were formed after World War II in efforts to stabilize the postwar world.
To qualify for the fund's credits, borrowers must meet certain financial conditions aimed at strengthening their economic performance.

HEADLINE: Profits Fall At 2 Steel Companies

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel producer, and Armco Inc. the fifth-largest, reported lower earnings yesterday, reflecting softer demand for steel products and higher operating costs, the companies said.
Bethlehem Steel's earnings dropped by 23.9 percent in the fourth quarter, to $50 million, or 57 cents a share, from $65.7 million, or 77 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. The company's revenues were down by 14 percent, to $1.14 billion from $1.33 billion. 
For the year, Bethlehem reported a net income of $245.7 million, or $2.93 a share, down by 39 percent from $403 million, or $5.32 a share, in 1988. Its revenues were down by 4 percent, to $5.25 billion for last year from $5.48 million in 1988.
Walter F. Williams, the chairman and chief executive, said Bethlehem's production costs were higher for the year, largely because of increased prices for alloys and other raw materials. The results were also affected, he said, by work stoppages by union employees at the company's coal plants.
The company, based in Bethlehem, Pa., said its basic steel operations unit had an operating income of $63 million for the quarter, down by 19 percent from $78 million.
''Domestic steel consumption remained relatively strong in 1989, in spite of a sharp decline in the automotive market during the second half of the year,'' Mr. Williams said. ''Consumption in the construction, machinery, energy-related and rail transportation markets increased moderately.''
 
Armco
Armco, based in Parsippany, N.J., said its fourth-quarter income dropped by 51.6 percent, to $15.5 million, or 15 cents a share, from $32 million, or 34 cents a share. Its sales fell by nearly half, to $416.2 million from $831.3 million.
The sales decline resulted from the sale of 40 percent of the company's Eastern Steel division to the Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Japan.
The quarterly results also included a charge of $3.3 million for work force reductions at a plant in Kansas City, Mo., and a $2.9 million reduction of a previously recorded gain on the Kawasaki Steel sale.
For all of last year, Armco's net income totaled $165 million, or $1.78 a share, up by 13 percent from $145.4 million, or $1.57 a share, in 1988. The company's sales were down by 24 percent, to $2.42 billion from $3.22 billion.
Robert E. Boni, Armco's chairman and chief executive, said the weakness in the second half of last year ''was worse than anticipated, as the fourth quarter never rebounded from the seasonal weakness of the third quarter.''
He said the results were also affected by a slowdown in the economy, particularly in the automotive industry. Mr. Boni also cited ''soft demand, a poor product mix and lower prices.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Seizes Arizona's Biggest Savings Institution

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The collapse of the real estate market in Arizona claimed another victim today when Federal regulators seized control of Merabank, the state's largest savings and loan institution, from its parent company, the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation.
Merabank, with $6.5 billion in assets, is the fourth-largest of the more than 300 institutions seized by regulators as they try to cope with the savings and loan crisis.
Regulators said that Merabank could not meet any of the Government's new standards for financial health and that the institution would record additional losses, plunging it so deeply into insolvency as to leave it no chance of recovery.
 
Effect of Real Estate Market
''This reflects the continued deterioration in the Arizona real estate marketplace,'' said Eric Shand, the deputy district director of the San Francisco branch of the Office of Thrift Supervision. 
The Government's action was not unexpected because Pinnacle West had agreed with regulators in December to inject $450 million in additional capital into Merabank in return for the Government assuming responsibility for any further losses, a clear indication that the Government would eventually take control of the institution.
The collapse of the Arizona real estate market has had nearly as much impact on financial institutions as the collapse in Texas. A number of savings-and-loan institutions in the state, including Western Savings of Phoenix, have already been taken over, and the troubles in Arizona have contributed to the failures of other institutions, including the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which was owned by the Phoenix developer Charles H. Keating Jr. but was based in California.
Banks, too, have suffered because of their exposure in Arizona. Several weeks ago the First Interstate Bancorp reported a $124 million loss for 1989 that it attributed partly to Arizona's woes.
 
End of a Failed Effort
The seizure closed out the failed effort of Pinnacle West, an electric utility company based in Phoenix, to expand and diversify by acquiring Merabank and moving aggressively into real estate development and lending. The utility paid $421 million for the institution in 1986 and then pushed it to grow rapidly just as a long economic boom in Arizona ended and the real estate market turned down.
Merabank lost more than $200 million in 1988 and posted losses of $190.1 million for the first nine months of last year. Mr. Shand said regulators had determined that the institution would suffer further losses of $390 million on its direct real estate investments, land and construction loans and other real estate-related lending.
Regulators said the institution is also losing a substantial amount of money on an operating basis because so many of its loans are troubled that the interest it takes in on its loan portfolio is not enough to cover the interest it pays out on deposits and its other expenses.
 
Negative Capital
Pinnacle West executives said they would proceed with plans to inject the additional $450 million into the institution, which they must do by March 31. Even with the new capital, however, the institution's most basic measure of financial health, the tangible capital, would stand at negative $280 million after accounting for all the expected losses. That situation means Merabank, with its $6.5 billion in assets, would have needed to raise nearly $500 million in new capital over the next few years to bring it into compliance with the new Government standards.
The seizure is a blessing in disguise for Pinnacle West, which has seen its earnings and stock price dragged down by the problems in the savings unit. Last year, Pinnacle West received a takeover offer from Pacificorp, another large utility company, based in Portland, Ore. Pinnacle West rejected the bid as inadequate in December.
A spokesman for Pacificorp, Mike Nelson, said the company had not been aware of the Merabank seizure and that it was too early to say what effect, if any, the action might have on its further interest in Pinnacle West.
The announcement of the Government's action came after the markets closed yesterday. Pinnacle's share price ended the day up 12.5 cents, to $10.875 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Write-Off Planned
Henry Sargent, Pinnacle West's executive vice president and chief financial officer, said the company expects to account for the planned $450 million capital injection as a charge for discontinued operations in its financial results for the last three months of 1989.
He said that charge would result in Pinnacle West posting a net loss for the year in the hundreds of millions of dollars. But he said that Pinnacle West would not have to account for any of the new losses uncovered by the Government following the agreement with regulators in December to inject the new capital.
''We see this as a neutral event for Pinnacle West,'' Mr. Sargent said.

HEADLINE: December New-Home Sales Off 9.6%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Sales of new single-family homes fell 9.6 percent in December, ending the worst year for new-home sales since 1984, the Commerce Department said today.
For all of 1989, sales fell 3.8 percent, to 650,000 units, from 676,000 units in 1988. It was the weakest year since 1984, when sales totaled 639,000 units. 
Analysts attributed the pullback to a sluggish economy, sated demand after a six-year housing boom, relatively high interest rates and climbing prices for homes.
The median sales price for the full year rose 6.7 percent, to $120,000, from $112,500 in 1988. At the median price, half the homes sold in the United States cost more and half cost less.
The Commerce Department revised November sales to show an increase of 9.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted rate of 696,000 units, instead of the previously reported 9.6 percent rise. In December, the seasonally adjusted annual rate was 629,000 units.
The sharpest drop in December sales occurred in the Midwest, where they were down 28.3 percent from November.
Sales fell 9.1 percent in the West from November levels and were down 6.2 percent in the South.
But in the Northeast, December seasonally adjusted sales rose 4 percent from November levels.
In December, sales before seasonal adjustment fell to 39,000 units, from 47,000 in November and 51,000 in October.
The median sales price in December rose 4 percent, to $130,100, from $125,000 in November.
The National Association of Realtors said its index for measuring housing affordability rose to 108.2 in December from 105.5 in November. The measure is based on existing homes, not newly built homes, as was the Government report.
The December reading of 108.2 meant that a family earning the national median income of $33,600 had 108.2 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of a home priced at $92,500.
The association said the affordability index rose because interest rates fell, as did national median home prices, while median family incomes rose.
It said the median price of an existing home fell to $92,500 in December from $93,200 in November, while average mortgage rates were down to 9.96 percent, from 10.12 percent in November.
Median family incomes increased to $33,600 in December from $33,483 in November, the asociation said. And the average monthly payment for principal and interest on a mortgage fell in December to $647 from $661 in November, according to the association.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid To Farmers Increase 2.7%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Prices that farmers get for raw products rose 2.7 percent from December to January, leaving the monthly average 2.7 percent above the level a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.
Higher prices for tomatoes, lettuce and broilers were mostly responsible for the increase from December, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report.
''Tomato prices more than doubled due to short supplies brought on by the freeze in Florida in December,'' the report said. ''Lettuce prices were nearly double for the same reason.'' 
Commercial vegetables as a group were up 68 percent from December and 32 percent from a year ago.
 
Some Declines Posted
Lower prices were reported for soybeans, strawberries and oranges.
Milk prices at the farm, which had risen to record levels late last year, were unchanged in January. Economists at the department have forecast that milk prices would level off this year.
Prices paid by farmers to meet expenses were up 1.1 percent from October, the previous reading, and averaged 2.9 percent above a year ago, the report said. The ''prices paid'' index is revised every three months.
The report said prices farmers paid for feeder cattle and calves, feeder pigs, diesel fuel and liquid propane gas were up from October.
Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989.
 
Income and Expenses
Net cash income is the money that farmers nationally have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes Government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year.
Another method, taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year, shows that 1990 net farm income may be in the range of $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with $48 billion last year.
Consumer food prices are estimated by department economists to have risen about 5.7 percent last year, the sharpest rise since 1981. They project that food prices will rise 3 to 5 percent in 1990.
 
Livestock and Poultry Data
Based on the preliminary figures, the January price index for livestock and poultry was unchanged from December but averaged 7.6 percent more than a year ago.
Crop prices over all rose 6.3 percent from December but averaged 4.3 percent below a year ago. The rise in the price of vegetables caused most of the increase from December, the report said.
The fruit index dropped 9.3 percent from December and was 9.8 percent below a year earlier.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Move Up Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher for the second straight session yesterday, as bargain-hunters bought securities that had been battered over the last six weeks. Gains of as much as a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, were recorded.
Buying was helped by speculation that President Bush would announce additional cuts in American military personnel in Europe - which he did in his State of the Union address last night - and by economic reports during the day that were weaker than anticipated.
Yesterday afternoon the Treasury also announced the size of next week's refunding auctions. It said it would sell a total of $30 billion worth of securities, with auctions of $10 billion each of new 3-year notes on Tuesday, new 10-year notes on Wednesday and 30-year bonds on Thursday. 
 
Signs of Weak Conditions
Some market participants said yesterday that reports that sales of new homes fell by more than 9 percent in December and a survey of purchasing managers in the Chicago area showed that economic conditions remain weak. A weak economy, they reasoned, would discourage the Federal Reserve from tightening credit by raising interest rates. It might even lower rates to spur the economy, thus making current rates relatively attractive.
The Chicago report, which precedes by one day the issuance of the results of a closely watched monthly survey of purchasing managers across the country, suggested that activity in the manufacturing sector declined in January from December.
''The economy is distinctly weak, but that does not mean it is recessionary,'' said William Melton, a vice president and chief economist at IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis.
Mr. Melton said he is currently estimating the economy will grow by an inflation-adjusted rate of 1 percent in the first quarter, but that growth will be almost flat in the second quarter.
''We have revised the second-quarter number down as interest rates have barreled up,'' he said.
In contrast, a report that showed an unexpectedly large eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Government's index of leading economic indicators was largely ignored.
''When the leading indicator number was revised about a year ago it lost most of the vestigal characteristics that made it an accurate predictor of where the economy is going,'' Mr. Melton said. ''We tell our guys to ignore it.''
The bulk of the session's price gains were recorded by longer-term note and bond issues.
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 96 18/32, up a full point from Tuesday, to yield 8.44 percent, compared with 8.54 percent Tuesday.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 15/32, up 5/8 of a point, to yield 8.40 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 97 5/8, up 9/32, to yield 8.32 percent.
Treasury bill rates eased slightly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.72 percent, down 2 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates dipped by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.68 percent.
 
Skeptical on Momentum
Despite the rally, with the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions less than a week away, some market participants said they were skeptical that the firmer tone would be maintained.
''The Street tends to hurt itself when it rallies into supply, but then again this isn't much of a rally,'' said David Green, manager of Government bond trading at Chemical Bank. ''I would be surprised if the market didn't try to sell off as we get closer to the refunding.''
The size of the Treasury's next auction was in line with traders' expectations. In when-issued trading after the announcement, the 3-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.28 percent; the 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.36 percent, and the 30-year bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.40 percent.
A sharp rise in stock prices helped to push up prices of RJR Nabisco securities for the second straight session in the high-yield market for ''junk bonds.'' For example, the company's convertible bonds of 2003 rose by 4 3/4 points, to 73 1/4.
The run-up in Treasury securities spilled over into the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipqal bonds. Corporate bond traders said that prices of most issues rose by anywhere from 5/8 of a point to 3/4 of a point.
Meanwhile, actively traded municipal bond issues were higher by between 3/8 and 3/4 point.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Decline Sharply On Report of Plan for I.M.F.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices tumbled yesterday after word leaked out that the United States had asked the International Monetary Fund to consider using its gold holdings to wipe out past-due loans to some member countries.
Yesterday evening, a Treasury official confirmed the reports, saying such a step could help the I.M.F. meet expected increases in demands for its resources.
Traders feared that such a plan could lead to the sale of several million ounces of gold on the open market. 
Gold futures settled $5.70 to $6.40 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in February off $5.70 at $412.40 an ounce.
Silver futures followed gold, ending 1.1 cents to 1.7 cents lower, with March at $5.228 an ounce.
The plan calls for the gold holdings subscribed by these countries to be ''mobilized,'' the official said. This could mean sales in the market or sales to other governments.
Fred Demler, a metals analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said, ''Even if you use it as collateral, a default could end up being a gold sale.''
Analysts said the gold market's weakness also reflected a strong rally in the stock market and the prospects for steady, rather than lower, interest rates.
On other commodity markets, oil futures were mixed, livestock and meat futures were lower, and grains and soybeans were mixed.
Petroleum futures finished mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange in quiet trading.
Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc., said traders had sold heating oil and gasoline contracts after a report late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute that showed higher-than-expected inventories of those products last week.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 22 cents higher, with March at $22.68 a barrel; heating oil was 0.13 cent to 1.64 cents lower, with February at 58.87 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.02 cents lower to 0.40 cent higher, with February at 61.71 cents a gallon.
Livestock and meat futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with much of the selling linked to weaker spot markets and to positioning by cattle traders ahead of the semiannual Agriculture Department cattle inventory report due tomorrow.
The report is expected to show a continued modest growth in the nation's cattle herd.
Live cattle futures settled 0.30 cent to 1.05 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in February at 79.35 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.20 cent to 0.75 cent lower, with March at 82.52 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.10 cent to 0.72 cent lower, with February at 48.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 0.12 cent to 0.45 cent lower, with February at 50.45 cents a pound.
Grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade, with soybeans up, corn down and wheat nearly unchanged.
Wheat settled 1/2 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher, with March at $3.75 3/4 a bushel; corn futures were 1/4 cent to 1 3/4 cents lower, with March at $2.38 1/4 a bushel; oats were 1 1/2 cents to 2 1/4 cents lower, with March at $1.35 1/4 a bushel; soybeans were 1/4 cent lower to 2 1/2 cents higher, with March at $5.61 a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Down; Jump in Indicators Ignored

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most major currencies in thin trading yesterday after the markets discounted a report that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would resign as chairman of the Soviet Communist Party.
In New York, currency traders said there was little reaction to the Commerce Department's release yesterday morning of the index of leading indicators for December. The figure, regarded as the Government's main economic forecasting gauge, jumped a strong eight-tenths of 1 percent, indicating that the economy might avoid a recession this year.
Walter Simon, a vice president in the New York office of Bank Julius Baer & Company, said traders expected the robust figure. He said the dollar traded in a narrow range most of the day.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.40 Japanese yen, up from 143.25 on Tuesday. In London late Wednesday the dollar closed higher at 144.45 yen. In New York it closed at 144.45 yen, down from 144.65 yen late Tuesday.
 
Pound Climbs
In London, the pound rose to $1.6870 late yesterday from $1.6830 late Tuesday. Later, in New York, it sold for $1.6792, up from $1.6725 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday rates, were: 1.6848 West German marks, down from 1.6990; 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.5005; 5.7250 French francs, down from 5.7600; 1,251.75 Italian lire, down from 1,260.50, and 1.1870 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1865.
Other dollar late rates in Europe, compared with those on Tuesday, were: 1.6800 marks, down from 1.6805; 1.5025 Swiss francs, up from 1.4890; 5.7275 French francs, up from 5.7040; 1.8950 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8880; 1,252.75 Italian lire, up from 1,249.50, and 1.1856 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1902.

HEADLINE: Hollinger Stake In Paper Chain

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The chief executive of Hollinger Inc. said Tuesday that the Canadian newspaper chain wanted to continue raising its stake in United Newspapers P.L.C. but was not planning a hostile takeover bid for the giant British publisher.
 
The chief executive, David
Radler, said, ''We're not launching a hostile bid for United.'' But he added, ''That doesn't mean we couldn't buy United, depending on market and economic conditions.''
Mr. Radler said the Toronto-based Hollinger, whose flagship paper is The London Telegraph, is the largest shareholder in United Newspapers, with about 9 percent of the stock. United publishes The London Express. Hollinger started buying stock in the British company a year ago.
Hollinger, which owns 242 papers with a combined daily circulation of nearly 1.9 million, has $170 million in cash and is interested in making further newspaper acquisitions, especially in Western Europe and the United States, Mr. Radler said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 22, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 3727 words

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION;
Transcript of Bush's State of the Union Message to the Nation

 BODY:
Following is the transcript of President Bush's State of the Union Message to a joint session of Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
Thank you very much. Mr. President, Mr. Speaker, members of the United States Congress, I return as a former President of the Senate and a former member of this great House. And now, as President, it is my privilege to report to you on the State of the Union.
Tonight, I come not to speak about the ''State of the Government,'' not to detail every new initiative we plan for the coming year, nor describe every line in the budget. I'm here to speak to you and to the American people about the State of the Union about our world, the changes we've seen, the challenges we face. And what that means for America.
There are singular moments in history, dates that divide all that goes before from all that comes after. And many of us in this chamber have lived much of our lives in a world whose fundamental features were defined in 1945. And the events of that year decreed the shape of nations, the pace of progress, freedom or oppression for millions of people around the world. 
 
The Revolution of '89
Nineteen forty-five provided the common frame of reference, the compass points of the postwar era we've relied upon to understand ourselves. And that was our world until now. The events of the year just ended, the Revolution of '89, have been a chain reaction, changes so striking that it marks the beginning of a new era in the world's affairs.
Think back, think back just 12 short months ago to the world we knew as 1989 began.
One year, one year ago, the people of Panama lived in fear under the thumb of a dictator. Today democracy is restored. Panama is free.
''Operation Just Cause'' has achieved its objective. And the number of military personnel in Panama is now very close to what it was before the operation began. And tonight I am announcing that well before the end of February the additional numbers of American troops, the brave men and women of our armed forces who made this mission a success, will be back home.
A year ago in Poland, Lech Walesa declared that he was ready to open a dialogue with the Communist rulers of that country. And today, with the future of a free Poland in their own hands, members of Solidarity lead the Polish Government.
And a year ago, freedom's playwright, Vaclav Havel, languished as a prisoner in Prague. And today it's Vaclav Havel, President of Czechoslovakia.
And one year ago Erich Honecker of East Germany claimed history as his guide. And he predicted the Berlin wall would last another hundred years. And today, less than one year later, it's the wall that's history.
Remarkable events, remarkable events, events that fulfill the long-held hopes of the American people. Events that validate the longstanding goals of American policy, a policy based on a single shining principle: the cause of freedom.
America, not just the nation, but an idea alive in the minds of people everywhere. As this new world takes shape, America stands at the center of a widening circle of freedom, today, tomorrow and into the next century.
Our nation is the enduring dream of every immigrant who ever set foot on these shores, and the millions still struggling to be free. This nation, this idea called America, was and always will be a new world, our new world.
At a worker's rally in a place called Branik on the outskirts of Prague the idea called America is alive. A worker, dressed in grimy overalls, rises to speak at the factory gates. And he begins his speech to his fellow citizens with these words, words of a distant revolution:
''We hold these truths to be self-evident. That all men are created equal, that they are endowed by their creator with certain unalienable rights, and that among these are life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.''
It's no secret that here at home freedom's door opened long ago. The cornerstones of this free society have already been set in place: democracy, competition, opportunity, private investment, stewardship, and, of course, leadership.
 
The Challenge for America
And our challenge today is to take this democratic system of ours, a system second to none, and make it better:
A better America where there's a job for everyone who wants one, Where women working outside the home can be confident their children are in safe and loving care, and where Government works to expand child care alternatives for parents, Where we reconcile the needs of a clean environment and a strong economy, Where ''Made in the U.S.A.'' is recognized around the world as the symbol of quality and progress, And where every one of us enjoys the same opportunities to live, to work and to contribute to society. And where, for the first time, the American mainstream includes all of our disabled citizens, Where everyone has a roof over his head, and where the homeless get the help they need to live in dignity, Where our schools challenge and support our kids and our teachers, and where all of them make the grade, Where, where every street, every city, every school and every child is drug-free, And finally, and finally, where no American is forgotten. Our hearts go out to our hostages, our hostages who are ceaselessly on our minds and in our efforts.
That's part of the future we want to see, the future we can make for ourselves. But dreams alone won't get us there. We need to extend our horizon, commit to the long view. And our mission for the future starts today.
In the tough competitive markets around the world, America faces the great challenges and great opportunities. And we know that we can succeed in the global economic arena of the 90's. But to meet that challenge we must make some fundamental changes, some crucial investment in ourselves.
Yes, we are going to invest in America. This Administration is determined to encourage the creation of capital, capital of all kinds. Physical capital: everything from our farms and factories to our workshops and production lines, all that is needed to produce and deliver quality goods and quality services. Intellectual, intellectual capital: the source of ideas that spark tomorrow's products. And, of course, our human capital: the talented work force that we'll need to compete in the global market.
And let me tell you, if we ignore human capital, if we lose the spirit of American ingenuity, the spirit that is the hallmark of the American worker, that would be bad. The American worker is the most productive worker in the world.
 
A Family Savings Plan
We need to save more. We need to expand the pool of capital for new investments that mean more jobs and more growth. And that's the idea behind a new initiative I call the Family Savings Plan, which I will send to Congress tomorrow.
We need to cut the tax on capital gains, encourage, encourage risk-takers, especially those in our small businesses, to take those steps that translate into economic reward, jobs and a better life for all of us.
We'll do what it takes to invest in America's future. The budget commitment is there. The money is there. It's there for research and development, R and D, a record high. It's there for our housing initiative, hope, H-O-P-E, to help everyone from first-time homebuyers to the homeless. The money's there to keep our kids drug-free, 70 percent more than when I took office in 1989. It's there for space exploration, and it's there for education, another record high.
And one more, and one more thing. Last fall at the education summit, the governors and I agreed to look for ways to help make sure that our kids are ready to learn the very first day they walk into the classroom. And I've made good on that commitment by proposing a record increase in funds, an extra half a billion dollars, for something near and dear to all of us: Head Start.
Education is the one investment that means more for our future, because it means the most for our children. Real improvement in our schools is not simply a matter of spending more. It's a matter of asking more, expecting more, of our schools, our teachers, of our kids, of our parents and ourselves. And that's why tonight, and that's why tonight, I am announcing America's education goals, goals developed with enormous cooperation from the nation's governors. And if I might I'd like to say I'm very pleased that Governor Gardner and Governor Clinton, Governor Branstad, Governor Campbell, all of whom were a very key in these discussions, these deliberations, are with us here tonight.
 
Education Goals for Year 2000
By the, by the year 2000, every child must start school ready to learn. The United States must increase the high school graduation rate to no less than 90 percent. And we are going to make sure our schools' diplomas mean something. In critical subjects, at the fourth, eighth and 12th grades, we must assess our students' performance.
By the, by the year 2000, U.S. students must be the first in the world in math and science achievement. Every American adult must be a skilled, literate worker and citizen. Every school must offer the kind of disciplined environment that makes it possible for our kids to learn. And every school in America must be drug-free.
Ambitious aims? Of course. Easy to do? Far from it. But the future's at stake. The nation will not accept anything less than excellence in education.
These investments will keep America competitive. And I know this about the American people: we welcome competition. We'll match our ingenuity, our energy, our experience and technology, our spirit and enterprise against anyone. But let the competition be free, but let it also be fair. America is ready.
Since we really mean it, and since we're serious about being ready to meet that challenge, we're getting our own house in order. We have made real progress. Seven years ago, the Federal deficit was 6 percent of our gross national product, 6 percent. In the new budget I sent up two days ago the deficit is down to 1 percent of G.N.P.
 
Balancing the Budget by 1993
That budget brings Federal spending under control. It meets the Gramm-Rudman target. It brings that deficit down further. And balances the budget by 1993, with no new taxes.
And let me tell you, there's still more than enough Federal spending. For most of us, $1.2 trillion is still a lot of money.
And once the budget is balanced, we can operate the way every family must when it has bills to pay. We won't leave it to our children and our grandchildren. Once it's balanced, we will start paying off the national debt.
And there's something more, and there's something more we owe the generations of the future: stewardship, the safekeeping of America's precious environmental inheritance.
 
Commitment on Environment
As just one sign of how serious we are, we will elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to Cabinet rank. Not, not more bureaucracy, not more red tape, but the certainty that here at home, and especially in our dealings with other nations, environmental issues have the status they deserve.
This year's budget provides over $2 billion in new spending to protect our environment, with over $1 billion for global change research, and a new initiative I call America the Beautiful to expand our national parks and wildlife preserves and improve recreational facilities on public lands.
And something else, something that will help keep this country clean, from our forest land to the inner cities, and keep America beautiful for generations to come, the money too plant a billion trees a year.
And tonight, and tonight let me say again to all the members of the Congress, the American people did not send us here to bicker. There is work to do, and they sent us here to get it done. And once again, in the spirit of cooperation, I offer my hand to all of you. And let's work together to do the will of the people - clean air, child care, the educational excellence act, crime and drugs. It's time to act. The farm bill, transportation policy, product liability reform, enterprise zones. It's time to act together.
 
Pledge on Social Security
And there's one thing I hope we will be able to agree on. It's about our commitments. And I'm talking about Social Security. To every American out there on Social Security, to every, every American supporting that system today, and to everyone counting on it when they retire. we made a promise to you, and we are going to keep it.
We, we rescued the system in 1983, and it's sound again, bipartisan arrangement. Our budget fully funds today's benefits, and it assures that future benefits will be funded as well. And the last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security.
 
New Look at Health Care
There's one more problem we need to address. We must give careful consideration to the recommendations of the health care studies under way now. And that's why tonight, I am asking Dr. Sullivan, Lou Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, to lead a Domestic Policy Council review of recommendations on the quality, accessibility and cost of our nation's health care system. I am committed to bring the staggering costs of health care under control.
 
Living Up to Our Ideals
The State of the Government, the State of the Government does indeed depend on many of us in this very chamber. But the State of the Union depends on all Americans. We must maintain the democratic decency that makes a nation out of millions of individuals. And I've been appalled at the recent mail bombings across this country. Every one of us must confront and condemn racism, anti-Semitism, bigotry and hate. Not next week, not tomorrow, but right now. Every single one of us.
The State of the Union depends on whether we help our neighbor, claim the problems of our community as our own. We've got to step forward when there's trouble, lend a hand, be what I call a point of light to a stranger in need. We've got to take the time after a busy day to sit down and read with our kids, help them with their homework, pass along the values we learned as children. And that's how we sustain the State of the Union. Every effort is important. It all adds up. It's doing the things that give democracy meaning. It all adds up to who we are and who we will be.
And let me say, that so long as we remember the American idea, so long as we live up to the American ideal, the State of the Union will remain sound and strong.
 
Letter From a Medic in Panama
And to those who worry that we've lost our way, well, I want you to listen to parts of a letter written by James Markwell, Pvt. 1st Class James Markwell, a 20-year-old Army medic of the First Battalion, 75th Rangers. It's dated Dec. 18, the night before our armed forces went into action in Panama. It's a letter servicemen write -and hope will never, never be sent. And sadly, Private Markwell's mother did receive this letter. She passed it along to me out there in Cincinnati. And here is some of what he wrote: ''I've never been afraid of death, but I know he is waiting at the corner. . . . I've been trained to kill and to save, so has everyone else. I am frightened of what lays beyond the fog, and yet . . . do not mourn for me. Revel in the life that I have died to give you. . . . But most of all, don't forget the Army was my choice. Something that I wanted to do. Remember I joined the Army to serve my country and insure that you are free to do what you want and live your lives freely.''
Let me add that Private Markwell was among the first to see battle in Panama, and one of the first to fall. But he knew what he believed in. He carried the idea we call America in his heart.
 
Leadership for the Future
I began tonight speaking about the changes we've seen this past year. There is a new world of challenges and opportunities before us. And there is a need for leadership that only America can provide.
Nearly 40 years ago, in his last address to the Congress, President Harry Truman predicted such a time would come. He said, ''As our world grows stronger, more united, more attractive to men on both sides of the Iron Curtain, then inevitably there will come a time of change within the Communist world.'' Today, that change is taking place. For more than 40 years, America and its allies held Communism in check and insured that democracy would continue to exist. And today, with Communism crumbling, our aim must be to insure democracy's advance, to take the lead in forging peace and freedom's best hope, a great and growing commonwealth of free nations.
And to the Congress and to all Americans, I say it is time to acclaim a new consensus at home and abroad, a common vision of the peaceful world we want to see.
Here in our own hemisphere it is time for all the people of the Americas, North and South, to live in freedom.
In the Far East and Africa it's time for the full flowering of free governments and free markets that have served as the engine of progress.
It is time to offer our hand to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe so that continent, for too long a continent divided, can see a future whole and free.
It's time to build on our new relationship with the Soviet Union, to endorse and encourage a peaceful process of internal change toward democracy and economic opportunity.
We are in a period of great transition, great hope, and yet great uncertainty. We recognize that the Soviet military threat in Europe is diminishing, but we see little change in Soviet strategic modernization. And, therefore, we must sustain our own strategic offense modernization and the strategic defense initiative.
But the time is right to move forward on a conventional arms control agreement to move us to more appropriate levels of military forces in Europe, a coherent defense program that insures the U.S. will continue to be a catalyst for peaceful change in Europe. And I've consulted with leaders of NATO. In fact I spoke by phone with President Gorbachev just today.
And I agree with our European allies that an American military presence in Europe is essential and that it should not be tied solely to the Soviet military presence in Eastern Europe.
 
Cut in U.S. Forces in Europe
But our troop levels can still be lower. And so tonight I am announcing a major new step for a further reduction in U.S. and Soviet manpower in Central and Eastern Europe to 195,000 on each side.
This number, this number, this level, reflects the advice of our senior military advisers. It's designed to protect American and European interests and sustain NATO's defense strategy. A swift conclusion to our arms control talks - conventional, chemical and strategic - must now be our goal. And that time has come.
Still, we must recognize an unfortunate fact: in many regions of the world tonight the reality is conflict, not peace. Enduring animosities and opposing interests remain. And thus the cause of peace must be served by an America strong enough, and sure enough, to defend our interests and our ideals. It's this American idea that for the past four decades helped inspire this Revolution of '89.
And here at home, and in the world, there is history in the making, and history to be made. Six months ago, early in this season of change, I stood at the gates of the Gdansk shipyard in Poland at the monument to the fallen workers of Solidarity. It's a monument of simple majesty. Three tall crosses rise up from the stones, and atop each cross, an anchor, an ancient symbol of hope.
 
Freedom, Faith and Family
The anchor in our world today is freedom. Holding us steady in times of change, a symbol of hope to all the world. And freedom is at the very heart of the idea that is America. Giving life to the idea depends on every one of us. Our anchor has always been faith and family.
In the last few days of this past momentous year, our family was blessed once more, celebrating the joy of life when a little boy became our 12th grandchild. When I held the little guy for the first time, the troubles at home and abroad seemed manageable, and totally in perspective.
And now I know, I know you're probably thinking, Well, that's just a grandfather talking.
Well, maybe you're right. But I've met a lot of children this past year across this country, as all of you have. Everywhere from the Far East to Eastern Europe. All kids are unique. Yet, all kids are alike. The budding young environmentalists I met this month, who joined me in exploring the Florida Everglades. The Little Leaguers I played catch with in Poland, ready to go to, go from Warsaw to the World Series. And even the kids who are ill or alone - and God bless those boarder babies, born addicted to drugs and AIDS - and coping with problems no child should have to face. But, you know, when it comes to hope and the future, every kid is the same: full of dreams, ready to take on the world, all special because they are the very future of freedom. And to them belongs this new world I've been speaking about.
And so tonight I'm going to ask something of every one of you. Now let me start with my generation, with the grandparents out there. You are our living link to the past. Tell your grandchildren the story of struggles waged at home and abroad, of sacrifices freely made for freedom's sake. And tell them your own story as well, because every American has a story to tell.
And parents, your children look to you for direction and guidance. Tell them of faith and family. Tell them we are one nation under God. Teach them that of all the many gifts they can receive, liberty is their most precious legacy. And of all the gifts they can give, the greatest, the greatest is helping others.
And to the children and young people out there tonight, with you rests our hope, all that America will mean in the years and decades ahead. Fix your vision on a new century, your century, on dreams we cannot see, on the destiny that is yours and yours alone.
And finally, let all Americans, all of us together here in this chamber, the symbolic center of democracy, affirm our allegiance to this idea we call America. And let us remember that the State of the Union depends on each and every one of us.
God bless all of you. And may God bless this great nation, the United States of America.

SECTION: Section D; Page 23, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1042 words

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE UNION;
Excerpts From Foley Address on the Reaction of Democrats

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of a speech by Thomas S. Foley, Speaker of the House, last night on the State of the Union, as recorded by The New York Times:
Good evening. I'm Tom Foley, the Speaker of the House. Earlier tonight, you may have seen me sitting behind President Bush as he delivered his address.
In the 1990's, and well into the next century, the central challenge for America will be economic, not military. The greatest test of our strength will be our classrooms, not our missile silos. The gravest threat will come not from any nation's attempt at world domination, but from every nation's complicity in the worldwide destruction of the environment. 
This period of vast change will be a period of fundamental choice. Much of what the President said tonight I agree with. Some of what he said, I disagree with.
But my purpose here is not to debate point by point. I'm here to tell you what we as Democrats believe, where we stand, the values we hold, the vision we have and the choices we believe in. ...
As Democrats, we're not satisfied with a trend that has seen this nation drop from first to sixth in the standard of living. We're not satisified to be told that within 10 years the average West German worker may earn 150 percent as much as the average American worker. We're not satisfied to have American students rank near the bottom of the industrial nations in math and science.
We will set a national goal of making our schools once again the best in the world by the year 2000. On this issue the President's words seem to agree with us, but his actions say something else. You can't become the education President, with all the problems we face by proposing a meager 2 percent increase in the education budget. That's a fact. And for all the talk, that's exactly what the President proposes to do.
We also believe that American corporations have the responsibility and should have the opportunity to re-invest in America. We believe that the wave of corporate mergers and leveraged buy-outs is a waste of resources. It leaves Wall Street raiders with large sums of money in their pockets, and it leaves our companies overburdened with debt and weakened in competing for world markets.
This issue represents another real difference between us and the Republicans. For too many years their policies have encouraged debt and quick profit instead of investment and long-term growth. The result: the amount of private resources put into research and development has fallen in real dollars.
It's imperative to reverse this trend and to secure America's place on the frontiers of enterprise and invention.
At the same time, we must demand that nations trading with us give our products an equal chance in their markets. . . .
Make no mistake about it. We favor expanding trade, but we reject the idea of one-way free trade. We believe this nation should be in the business of exporting the goods our workers make, not the jobs our workers need.
 
Encouraging Savings
We also believe in encouraging a rise in savings, which have collapsed to a record low during the 1980's. The Republicans say they want to do this, in part, by cutting the capital gains tax, a cut which would give 80 percent of the benefits to the richest 1 percent of Americans. Instead, we are fighting to restore I.R.A.'s - so middle-income families can save as much as $2,000 a year tax-free. . . . .
We took on the struggle against capital gains when the odds were against us. We won last year, and this year we will do all we can to make sure that the greatest part of any tax cut, of any kind, goes to those of you who live on a paycheck, not just the few who have the highest incomes.. . .
This issue goes to the heart of the reason we are Democrats: above all else, we stand with you, the people who go to work and pay the taxes. It is your cause to which we are committed and your side on which we fight.
So we will also fight for the most effective clean air bill, even though that may offend entrenched and powerful interests.
We will fight for child care, so that working parents don't have to choose between their family's standard of living and their children's standard of care. ...
And there is another issue on which we have only just begun to fight: this Administration's practice of misusing the Social Security trust fund to hide the size of the Federal budget deficit.
 
No Privatizing Social Security
Social Security involves more than a trust fund; it involves the basic bond of trust between our people and our Government. From the beginning, Social Security has been the Democratic Party's proudest achievement. We reject the suggestion of some Republicans to privatize the system. . . .
Finally, as Democrats, we believe that there are areas where the Government simply does not belong. We will continue to defend a woman's right to choose - for we are convinced that politicians cannot and should not attempt to make the choice. ...
The reason we have so many homeless in America today is not because government has cared too much, but because it has cared too little. We have to do better than that - on a whole range of critical needs.
We will seek to secure the right of all our children to learn in better schools and to earn a better life.
We will seek to secure the civil rights of all our people. We can't celebrate freedom abroad and then deny freedom at home.
We are also committed to the strongest possible attack on the drugs that are attacking our society and our families. On this we are all united. Narcotics destroy the children of Democrats and Republicans alike.
Let me say it again. We will work with the President wherever and whenever we can. On some issues, we will have differences because we care deeply about certain principles and about the people who have been the abiding concern of the Democratic Party. Today, we Democrats stand, as we have before, for working families. We stand for both economic justice and economic opportunity. For protecting the environment. For senior citizens and the soundness of Social Security.
And where we must, we will disagree with this Administration. We will stand our ground when that is the only way we can stand for you.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
EAST BERLIN CHIEF PRESENTS HIS PLAN TO UNITE GERMANY

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Prime Minister Hans Modrow today presented for the first time an East German program for the reunification of Germany, which he said should be neutral.
The plan, which the Prime Minister put forward as his personal concept, followed his meeting in Moscow on Tuesday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, during which the Soviet leader for the first time appeared to give his cautious blessing to discussion of reunification.
Mr. Modrow's concept foresaw the process of reunification as advancing in slow stages, during which both German nations would cease to be members of military pacts and become neutral.
 
Kohl Rejects Terms
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany quickly rejected Mr. Modrow's proposal for a neutral German state, saying a reunited Germany could not afford to be isolated in the center of Europe. 
The plan also runs counter to Washington's stand, which specifies that in exercising their right of self-determination, Germans remain firmly tied to the West through membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d presented that view when he visited here in December. Chancellor Kohl emphasized West Germany's continuing links to the West in presenting a 10-point reunification proposal last year.
 
Discussion After Elections
In dismissing Mr. Modrow's vision and agenda, Mr. Kohl declared at a news conference in Bonn today that he would discuss reunification only with the East German government that is to be selected in March elections and that military neutrality was inappropriate.
''Such a proposal contradicts the logic of the pan-European process of unification,'' he said, adding that a single Germany at the core of the Continent could not afford to be isolated.
On Wednesday, West Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, had similarly insisted that a reunited Germany should remain a NATO member. But he suggested that the alliance's military structure would be limited to only that territory that constitutes the present West Germany. Mr. Genscher is scheduled to fly to Washington on Friday for talks with Secretary of State Baker.
Mr. Modrow's vision implicitly rejected such ideas.
In announcing his concept at a news conference, he said: ''In logic and sense, the process of German reunification is closely linked with the construction of the all-European house and European confederation. In this all-European house there must be no place for a policy of force.''
Alluding to the image of a common European house that had first been projected last year by Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Modrow said: ''It must be founded on the idea that already in the stage of confederation, both German states will step by step detach themselves from their obligations of alliance toward third countries and attain a state of military neutrality. The border between the German Democratic Republic and the German Federal Republic will then have ceased to be the dividing line of the two military groupings, with all the consequences that derive from this.''
Mr. Modrow specified four stages leading to reunification and stressed that he was offering his concept for discussion without any timetable.
In the first stage, a treaty of cooperation and good neighborliness would be concluded, with provisions for the melding of the economies, currencies, transport, and judicial systems of both Germanys.
The second phase of the plan would be the establishment of a confederation with common institutions, such as a joint parliamentary committee and joint executive organs in specified areas.
 
The Last Two Stages
The next step in the Modrow concept would be the transfer of some sovereign rights of the two republics to institutions of the confederation.
Mr. Modrow described the final stage as ''formation of a unified German state in the form of a German Federation or German Union through elections in both parts of the confederation, the convening of a unified Parliament, which will decide on a unified constitution and unified government with its seat in Berlin.''
Mr. Modrow presented his proposal under the motto ''For Germany, united fatherland.'' That is a line from the national anthem. Until the overthrow of the old regime last October, this line was the reason why the anthem could only be played or hummed rather than sung. Under the former leaders, Walter Ulbricht and Erich Honecker, it was the official line that the division into two states had become permanent and reunification was ruled out.
The Prime Minister set several conditions that he said would have to be fulfilled on the way to unity. They specified that both states must maintain their respective obligations to other countries or blocs without any interference by either in the affairs of the other.
This was a clear reference to the ever-increasing political activities of West German parties in the present struggle in East Germany leading up to this country's first free elections March 18. The other putative parties in East Germany have not yet formally stated their views on reunification.
Another condition set by the Prime Minister was ''maintenance of the interests and rights'' of the four major victor powers of World War II, which have residual rights in both Germanys. They are the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.
''The four powers should declare their intention to settle finally all questions arising from World War II and the postwar period after the formation of a unified German state, including the presence of foreign troops on German soil and membership in military alliances,'' Mr. Modrow declared.
He said military neutrality of both nations as federation approached was another condition.
Replying to questions, he said that although his concept was in keeping with Mr. Gorbachev's ideas expressed during his Moscow visit and had been discussed with the Soviet leader, he had not put it to him for approval.
 
Public Pressure Growing
A Western diplomat said it was likely that the Prime Minister had told Mr. Gorbachev that growing public pressure in East Germany for reunification made necessary a statement that put his Government on record as favoring it, but only on the conditions that would preclude NATO's gaining a vital military asset.
The Soviet Union bases more than 350,000 troops in East Germany. Even under partial Soviet withdrawals, which began last year, NATO specialists are reported to foresee that that figure will not significantly decrease by the end of this year.
Mr. Modrow stressed that unity should be achieved only under conditions that would still all possible fears among Germany's neighbors.
''Germany shall again become a united fatherland for all citizens of the German nation,'' he said. ''So that never again danger for the lives and property of its neighbors shall emanate from it, a sense of responsibility, prudence and comprehension for what is feasible and what is bearable for Europe are required.''
