HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Bush's Quandary on Forces in Europe

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Bush Administration insisted today that it will maintain American troop strength in Europe at 225,000, the new level proposed by President Bush in his State of the Union address Wednesday night. But the pace of political change at home and abroad seems likely to make that position untenable in short order.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told the Senate Armed Services Committee this morning that even if all Soviet forces left Europe, 225,000 Americans would be needed there, 195,000 of them in central Europe, which means primarily West Germany. Caution is needed, he said, because ''the Soviet Union remains the only nation on earth capable of destroying the United States.''
Administration officials conceded that they had a tough case to sell. But for the moment at least, they said, the President feels that he must mollify the allies and keep the North Atlantic Treaty Organization healthy, with West Germany firmly linked through NATO to the West at a time when East Germany's leaders are talking of a unified Germany linked neither to East nor West. 
 
A Key Qualification
Partly at the insistence of the British and French and partly because of his own concerns, senior officials of several countries reported, Mr. Bush tucked into his speech this key qualification, ''I agree with our European allies that an American military presence in Europe is essential, and that it should not be tied solely to the Soviet military presence in Eastern Europe.''
What then should it be tied to? How should it be justified, when its whole purpose has been to deter or contain a ground attack by the Soviets and their erstwhile allies, which almost everyone now considers improbable? What do ground forces have to do with the nuclear threat to which Mr. Cheney alluded?
James R. Schlesinger, a Democrat who was Defense Secretary in the Ford Administration, called even before President Bush's speech for elimination of all but a ''residual'' American force of perhaps 50,000 troops in Europe. Abandoning his longstanding commitment to a large-scale American deployment in Germany and elsewhere on the Continent, he said that ''the rationale for our European deployments is up for review and debate'' because the Warsaw Pact's ''role as a military alliance and a military threat has been largely broken.''
 
Negotiating Leverage
''American deployments,'' Mr. Schlesinger told the Senate Armed Services Committee, ''have been justified as a symbol of American commitment and, since the 70's, as a part of a stalwart conventional capability intended to help deter Soviet or Warsaw Pact attack. That role for the American forces has now been superseded. The new and substantially reduced role for those forces is to provide negotiating leverage.''
In fact, that leverage may not be very important, at least in getting Soviet troops out of central Europe. The central Europeans are already clamoring for them to go home, and Mr. Cheney conceded that the Soviet Union was likely to comply with that request by 1995.
While Mr. Cheney said that even that would not persuade the Administration to budge from its 225,000 figure, a senior Administration official was considerably less firm at a briefing on Wednesday. He said that 225,000 would stand ''for the foreseeable future,'' but conceded that he didn't know how long that would be.
 
Prospect of Greater Cuts
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, urged Mr. Cheney at a committee hearing not to exclude the prospect of greater troop cuts if Moscow withdraws all of its forces from Eastern Europe and the two Germanys are reunified. After being pressed by Senator Nunn, Mr. Cheney said he would be willing to ''take another look'' at the Administration's troop-cut plans if such dramatic changes occurred. But his response appeared to be intended to avoid the appearance of inflexibility. In addition to the strategic arguments, Mr. Cheney said the United States needed a sizable military presence in Europe to maintain American political ties with Western Europe.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who appeared with Mr. Cheney at the committee hearing, also argued that a force of 195,000 American troops in central Europe was the minimum to carry out NATO's plans to defend itself against attack.
Pentagon officials said the figure of 195,000 troops represents the smallest-size force that the military thinks it could keep in Europe and still be able to fight a defensive war of limited duration if there were an attack on NATO. They said they considered, but rejected, the idea of having a smaller force to use as a kind of ''trip wire'' that could blunt the first wave of an attack but would have to rely on immediate reinforcements.
Senator Nunn said in an interview today that ''we need to be thinking right now about how far down we want to go in troop strength in Europe, and what we want our troops there to do.'' If progress is made toward German reunification, if the conventional arms talks in Vienna are concluded later this year, and if the East Germans and the Czechs ''throw the bums out,'' Mr. Nunn said, ''then we face a complete rebuilding of the policy we've been following since 1945.''
''It could all be happening by this time next year,'' he added.
 
France and Britain Insistent
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and, to a lesser degree, President Francois Mitterrand of France have repeatedly expressed concern about too-rapid shrinkage of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces, not least because of their belief that the best chance of taming a reunited Germany would be to keep it within NATO. Diplomats reported that France and Britain had insisted on setting a floor at 225,000 troops as a condition of their support.
''Forget about any guarantees Bush gave the allies,'' said Daniel Hamilton of the Carnegie Endowment, a leading German specialist. ''He will be under fierce pressure in a matter of months to go farther, at least to 100,000, maybe to 75,000. The real agenda these days is being set by the people in the streets of Eastern Europe, not by the politicians in Washington and Moscow.''
In part, the allies and the Pentagon are concerned about what might happen in central Europe if Mikhail S. Gorbachev were to lose control of events in the Soviet Union, or if economic reform produced extreme social discontent in Poland or Rumania. A British minister said recently that he thought the chances of Mr. Gorbachev's remaining in office a year from now were only 60-40.
In part, they are fearful that the fast pace of change could produce the ''unraveling'' of NATO, weakening Atlantic unity. Some European members of the alliance, including Belgium and the Netherlands, have discussed pulling some of their troops out of Germany.
Those harboring such fears think rapid troop reductions in Europe now would be a mistake. Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, is one such person, and he argued today that ''this is the worst possible time to contemplate changes in strategy.''
Largely unspoken, but at least as important in allied calculations, is the belief that if the United States pulls most of its forces out of Europe, it will revert to its historic isolationist tendencies, at least insofar as abandoning any pretense of guaranteeing the security of Western Europe.
 
A Question of Influence
Likewise, there lurks beneath the surface of American policy the notion that any further pullback would rob the United States of whatever influence it is likely to have in the shaping of the new Germany. Further cuts ''would cost us our place at the table, wherever and whenever the table is set for the big decisions,'' a senior United States policy maker commented bluntly.
The logic of German reunification, or at least federation, which Mr. Bush has repeatedly said he welcomes, works against the maintenance of significant foreign NATO forces in West Germany or of Soviet forces in East Germany. A unified or federated state could hardly exist with rival armies camped within it, and some animosity to American forces has begun to develop in West Germany as the threat from Moscow has seemed to diminish to the vanishing point.
In addition, the logic of the Soviet position works against the maintenance of large forces abroad. Having permitted its former client states to adopt multiparty systems, having in essence blessed an anti-Soviet revolution, there is little justification for forcing Russian troops on those same states.
Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, said that ''events in Europe'' ran ahead of diplomatic discussions and that Mr. Bush's insistence ''that he needs American troops in Europe from here to eternity'' was ''not a good sign.'' The 225,000 figure ''must be the ceiling, not the floor,'' the Soviet official said.

HEADLINE: LEGISLATION EASES LIMITS ON ALIENS

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In yet another sign of diminishing world tensions, the Senate this week gave final Congressional approval to repealing a provision of a McCarthy-era law that bars foreigners from visiting the United States because of their political beliefs.
The restriction has been anathema to civil liberterians and others for decades, but only in recent years have they gathered enough support in Congress to kill it.
The law, the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, was passed in 1952 over the veto of President Harry S. Truman. In that period 38 years ago, conservatives said it was needed to protect American citizens from subversive ideas, mainly communism. 
Over the years, the law has been used to deny entry to such acclaimed figures as the writers Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Graham Greene, the actor Yves Montand, the naturalist Farley Mowat, and Ian Smith, the former Prime Minister of Rhodesia.
 
'Fearful, Muddled, Intimidated'
''For a generation and more these miserable provisions made the United States present itself to other nations as a nation of fearful, muddled, intimidated citizens,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who sponsored the repeal legislation. ''We were not that; we are not that, and now at last our statutes accord with the facts.''
The measure was passed 98 to 0 by the Senate on Tuesday, as an amendment to a State Department spending bill. It was approved by the House in November and President Bush is expected to sign it, Republican Senate aides said.
Legislation temporarily repealing the restrictions was passed in 1987 and again in 1988. The State Department objected, warning that repeal could have ''potentially serious adverse consequences'' for the conduct of foreign policy.
But this time the State Department has raised no objections to permanent repeal of the section of the McCarran-Walter Act that excludes aliens for ideological reasons.
 
Only Short Visits Affected
The Senate action was praised by civil libertarians and advocates of immigration law revisions, but other people contended the legislation does not go far enough.
The measure covers only aliens seeking to enter the United States for short visits. Those seeking permanent status can still be barred because of their beliefs or memberships.
Over the years thousands of foreigners have been barred by the provision in the McCarran-Walter Act. In 1984, for example, the Immigration and Naturalization Service estimated that it blocked 8,000 people from 98 countries because of their beliefs or political affiliations.
Among those who have been denied entry are Hortensia Allende, widow Salvador Allende Gossens, the former President of Chile; Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization; Dario Fo, the Italian satirist and playwright, and Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada, whose attendance at an economic conference in Moscow in 1952 prompted immigration officials to brand him as a Communist sympathizer. Mr. Trudeau's name was struck from the list after immigration officials interviewed him in Montreal in 1954. He wasCanadian Prime Minister from 1968 to 1979, and 1980 to 1984.
''Pierre Trudeau!'' said a theatrically incredulous Mr. Moynihan in a telephone interview. ''Graham Greene! There is not a college in this country that does not assign his book.'' Among the British author's books is ''The Quiet American,'' which was set in South Vietnam.
 
Terrorist Exception
Mr. Moynihan's legislation still allows the Secretary of State to deny entry an alien who is identified as a terrorist or is seen as likely to engage in terrorist activity. Under this section, someone like Mr. Arafat can still be barred.
Another portion of the act, dealing with resident aliens, is under legal attack.
In Dec. 1988, a Federal District Court judge in Los Angeles barred the immigration service from deporting seven Jordanians and one Kenyan. The Government had charged them with being members of a group called the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, which had claimed responsibility for airline hijackings and other terrorist acts.
In preventing the deportations Judge Stephen V. Wilson declared the language of four the sections the act ''unconstitutional on its face'' as a restriction on the right of free speech.
The ruling applied only to the Central District of California and has been appealed by the Government.
 
Little Change Expected
A State Department spokesman said the legislation would not markedly change policy. A 1977 measure sponsored by George McGovern, the former Senator from South Dakota, required that people denied entry based on their beliefs be granted waivers unless it could be shown that they posed a threat to national security. Since then, most people initially turned away have been admitted, officials said.
''It's no longer a practical fact that people are kept out of the United States for their ideological beliefs,'' said the spokesman, Philip Covington.
The McCarran-Walter Act sets up 33 categories for excluding visitors and those seeking to become residents. They range from espionage and drug trafficking to believing in polygamy and practicing ''deviant sexual behavior.''

CORRECTION-DATE: February 3, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the repeal of a provision of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act referred incorrectly in some copies to a novel by Graham Greene. He wrote ''The Quiet American,'' not ''The Ugly American.''

PUB-DATE: February 2, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1221 words

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: U. S. POLICY;
Economic Effect of Cutting Troops in Europe Assessed

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Troop reductions of the type proposed by President Bush would temporarily disrupt the local economy in parts of West Germany, but would have negligible effects on the civilian economy of the United States, experts said today.
The effects in the Soviet Union would depend on how military manpower and resources are redeployed, the experts said.
John P. Hardt, associate director of the Congressional Research Service, said the demobilization of Soviet troops could benefit the Soviet economy ''if military resources - manpower and factory capacity - are effectively redeployed to produce food, consumer goods and housing, and to improve the delivery of food from farm to market.''
But the ex-servicemen could also cause short-term economic problems for the Kremlin if jobs and housing are not available for them, experts said. 
 
Impact on Parts of Germany
In parts of Germany, including the Frankfurt area and the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, tens of thousands of people depend for their livelihoods on the presence of United States military units, which buy some of their supplies in Germany. In addition, service personnel buy large amounts of local beer, clothing and appliances.
If American troops begin to leave Europe, some regions of West Germany would feel the loss, but the national economy is so strong that it would not be damaged to any significant degree, experts said. Clarence Hill, an economist for Deutsche Bank in New York, said the withdrawal of 60,000 to 80,000 American servicemen would probably occur gradually and would have ''a negligible depressing effect'' on West Germany's trillion-dollar economy.
In economic terms, he said, the exodus of American troops would be more than offset by the influx of East Germans and of ethnic Germans from Poland and the Soviet Union. The newcomers arrive in West Germany with few possessions and need to buy many consumer goods, alhtough they have significantly less money with which to make those purchases. In the last year, according to the West German Embassy here, 343,850 East Germans and 377,000 ethnic Germans from Eastern Europe settled in West Germany, and Bonn expects similar numbers this year. #80,000 Troops Could Go In his State of the Union address on Wednesday, Mr. Bush proposed sharp new reductions in the numbers of Soviet and American troops in Europe. American troops, which now total 305,000, would be cut by 80,000, to 225,000. Most of the American troop reductions would come in West Germany. Soviet troops, which now total about 565,000, would be reduced to the same level.
American officials say they hope that Soviet and American troops withdrawn from Europe would be demobilized and released from the armed services.
Stephen M. Meyer, a professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said today that the demobilization of more than 300,000 Soviet troops would, in the short term, have a ''negative impact on the economy of the Soviet Union.''
There would be ''tens of thousands of troops with no place to live, no place to work, no accommodations of any kind,'' Professor Meyer said. ''To release them from the army right away would create social and economic problems.''
In the long run, he said, such troop reductions could save money for Moscow, because the Soviet armed forces would presumably buy fewer weapons and supplies and would have lower operating costs. Soviet officials could minimize the economic problems by keeping soldiers in garrisons for a while after they return to the Soviet Union, said Profssor Meyer, a consultant to American military and intelligence agencies.
 
'Destabilizing Factor' Possible
Mr. Hardt, an expert on the Soviet economy, said that if substantial numbers of Soviet military officers are demobilized, they would lose housing privileges and access to special military stores and might become dissastified. They could then be a ''destabilizing factor'' in Soviet politics, he said.
In any event, he said, money saved in the Soviet military budget would have to be used to build housing and to train army veterans for civilian jobs. ''The peace dividend would be small,'' he said.
In the United States, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the Pentagon would eventually save $7 billion to $8 billion a year if it demobilized 80,000 troops, as Mr. Bush proposed.
For more than a decade, the United States has had a volunteer army, and in recent years, the vast majority of army recruits have been high school graduates. Economists said that most of those recruits could probably get civilian jobs.
With a labor force of more than 125 million, the United States could absorb 80,000 people released from military service without much difficulty, economists say. Their ''effect on the overall economy would be fairly minor,'' said James P. Markey, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 
Jobs for Ex-Servicemen
Sar A. Levitan, a labor economist who serves as director of the Center for Social Policy Studies at George Washington University, said that servicemen might have some difficulty in finding civilian jobs in certain parts of the country with higher unemployment rates, like West Virginia. If the national economy weakens and companies lay off workers, that could make it more difficult for veterans to find jobs, he said.
Others researchers said the American economy was stronger now than when the United States curtailed military spending in the later years of the Vietnam War, from 1968 to 1975. As military spending slows, they said, many companies can be expected to diversify their work and emphasize commercial activities so that the adverse effect, if any, on the gross national product would be temporary.
West Germany benefits financially from the stationing of American troops on its territory, economists say. There are more than 225,000 G.I.'s with perhaps 75,000 dependents in West Germany.
A recent study by the Institute for the German Economy, an industry-supported research center in Cologne, estimated that the American troops generated $5.6 billion a year in economic benefits for West Germany. That includes, among other things, $1.8 billion in goods and services purchased by the military, $903 million in goods and services bought by individual servicemen, $590 million worth of construction and $353 million in rent paid for houses and apartments.
Thomas Vajna, an economist at the institute, said that costs to West Germany resulting from the presence of American troops totaled $1.4 billion a year. That figure includes damage to property resulting from military maneuvers. The net effect, he said, is $4.2 billion worth of benefits for the West German economy.
Robert Gerald Livingston, director of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies at Johns Hopkins University, said the departure of American troops could ''cause dislocations in some of the poorer parts of West Germany.'' In such areas, he said, unemployment has been rising, partly because of the influx of East Germans and ethnic Germans, and some people who lose jobs at American military installations might have difficulty finding work.
On the other hand, he said, the departure of American troops would make housing available for Germans at a time when there is a shortage of low-cost housing.

HEADLINE: BUSH SEEKS A RISE IN AID TO SALVADOR

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Bush met today with the President of El Salvador, Alfredo Cristiani, and offered him a strong statement of support, hoping it would signal to Congress that the United States should not cut back more on aid to the country.
Although the Administration plans to cut its aid this year to Central America while giving more to Eastern Europe, the State Department today proposed an increase of about $50 million for El Salvador next year.
In fiscal year 1989, El Salvador received $185 million in economic aid from the United States. This year, it is getting $130.6 million. The Administration has asked Congress to increase the total to $180 million in the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1. El Salvador is getting $84.6 million in military aid this year, about the same as the $85 million it received last year. 
 
Cristiani's Reaction
Mr. Cristiani said after the meeting with Mr. Bush that he thought a cut in aid to El Salvador would send ''negative signals, especially to the armed groups,'' as he seeks to build up his country.
But he did note that it ''is not necessarily a cut in Salvadoran aid in itself, but rather a cut across the board for the region,'' adding, ''since we have the highest package in the region, we have the highest cuts in the program.''
At a photo session with Mr. Cristiani in the Rose Garden before their meeting at the White House, Mr. Bush defended the Salvadoran from Congressional criticism over the involvement of military officers in the killing last November of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and the housekeeper's daughter. The President praised Mr. Cristiani for pursuing an investigation that recently resulted in the arrest of a colonel, two lieutenants and five lower-ranking military men.
''I know of his commitment to democracy,'' Mr. Bush said. ''The success of democracy in Salvador is a very important thing to us, to this country. And I have been very impressed with the courage he has shown in going after those who have broken the law in his country. And that's been a shining example to all of us.''
 
Walking 'a Very Fine Line'
One Administration official said the message to Congress was that ''Cristiani's walking a very fine line on the investigation and the peace process and right now we have to accept him for what he's doing and not tell him what he should be doing.''
The slayings spurred an international outcry and prompted threats to cut American aid.
Mr. Cristiani said the arrests of the military officers showed that El Salvador was making headway in bringing the military, once immune to prosecution, under the sway of the civilian Government.
But some members of Congress remain dubious about how far the investigation will go in the hands of the criminal justice system in El Salvador.
 
Visit With Democrats
Before going to the White House, Mr. Cristiani tried to mend some fences with Democrats on Capitol Hill, attending a meeting with House Speaker Thomas S. Foley; the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, and Representative Joe Moakley, who is the head of a House task force on El Salvador.
The members of Congress described the meeting as friendly and agreed that Mr. Cristiani had helped his cause with the arrest of the officers. But Mr. Moakley warned Mr. Cristiani that he must pay more attention to human rights, noting that ''votes for El Salvador aid have been diminishing over the years.''
The Salvadoran leader was scheduled to meet with members of the American Catholic community on Friday, also in an effort to calm their fears about his ability to press the case of the Jesuit murders.
In the 45-minute White House meeting, one top Administration official said, President Bush again ''congratulated President Cristiani on the way he's proceeding with the investigation and underscored the fact that it must continue forward.''
 
Talks With Leftists Urged
Mr. Bush spoke of a need to continue negotiations with the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the leftist guerrillas battling Mr. Cristiani's Government, and said the United States would do whatever it could to help the peace process.
The two leaders also spoke of how their countries could cooperate in the war on drugs by sharing information on selling and trafficking.
After the meeting, Mr. Cristiani told the press that he had asked Mr. Bush for financial aid for a new anti-drug program in El Salvador. ''We think that, although it is not a big problem in El Salvador, I think it's better to stop it when it's not big than to wait until it's very big and then it's harder to get rid of.''
He said he was ''willing to open up a dialogue process'' with the guerrillas with the help of the Secretary General of the United Nations, but could not say exactly when that would happen.

Mr. Bush applauded Mr. Cristiani's efforts to apprehend the killers of six Jesuit priests and strongly urged Congress to increase the amount of aid earmarked for El Salvador. (NYT/Paul Hosefros)

HEADLINE: Budget for the Space Agency Sets a Broader Course in Exploration

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
The proposed 24 percent increase in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget, which would be the biggest increase for any major agency, represents a critical step in expanding the nation's civilian space program, opening the way finally to building an orbiting space station, initiating two ambitious efforts in Earth and planetary exploration, and setting the agenda for space flight well into the next century.
The request, for $15.1 billion in fiscal 1991, an increase of $2.8 billion over the current year's spending, is being presented by space agency and Administration officials as a clear signal of President Bush's intention to put money behind his pledge last July to insure American leadership in space. In a speech on the 20th anniversary of the Apollo 11 Moon landing, he spoke of committing the nation to return astronauts to the Moon and to the eventual exploration of Mars by humans.
The officials pointed to the lyricism of the budget message on the subject of space. Besides noting the payoffs in the development of new materials and technologies, the message said ''no quantitative measure of any kind can capture the benefit of expanding human horizons, human dreams, and the human domain.'' 
Congressional leaders and budget experts said the NASA request undoubtedly would be trimmed, perhaps by a billion dollars or so. But they indicated that, as in recent years, both the House and Senate were probably predisposed to approve much of the space budget. Last year Congress cut almost $1 billion from the $13.3 billion budget request.
''This is a most important budget for us,'' said Richard H. Truly, the NASA administrator, in an interview. ''It's going to set our course, if we're successful, for many years to come and over a wide range of programs.''
 
A Steady Rise in Funds
Actually, the space agency has enjoyed a steady rise in financial support since the Challenger accident in 1986; a large share of the support was used to modify the space shuttles and get them back into service in late 1988.
Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University, said: ''The new budget is a continuation and acceleration of the post-Challenger trend. We realized we had expectations in space but were not providing NASA with the resources to fulfill them.''
If the budget request does survive more or less intact, much of the additional money will go for the ''critical transition,'' in the words of the President's budget message, from design to construction of the Freedom space station. Space officials say they are committed to a schedule in which the first components of the modular station would be placed in orbit in 1995 and occupied by astronauts as early as 1997.
The request is for $2.45 billion for the space station, an increase of $700 million. The program, endorsed by President Ronald Reagan in 1984, has suffered repeated budgetary setbacks and has been scaled down in response to Congressional criticism. Even so, the station is expected to cost about $30 billion by the time it is fully deployed in 1999.
The two new programs provided in the budget request include space platforms as the first elements of the Mission to Planet Earth, an ambitious plan to study Earth and its threatened environment from orbit, and the ''human exploration initiative.'' the response to Mr. Bush's call for a long-term program of exploration by humans of the Moon and Mars.
 
Price Tags for New Programs
The Administration is proposing to spend more than $1 billion next year in studies of global environmental change. Of that, $636 million is to be spent by NASA to begin building two unmanned scientific platforms and other research related to the Earth's environment. The program is known as the Earth Observing System.
For the human exploration program, NASA is proposing to spend $1.3 billion on developing new technology for flights to the Moon and Mars, preliminary studies of an aerospace plane and two robot spacecraft to orbit the Moon and investigate the effects of long-duration flight on biological systems. However, space policy experts point out that only about $300 million of this constitutes new undertakings; the rest consists of existing programs included in the new category.
Although the proposed spending in 1991 on the two new programs, for Earth observation and human exploration of the Moon and Mars, is relatively modest, their cost presumably would multiply many times in the years to come. The Earth Observing System could cost as much as $15 billion over the next decade, and sending humans to Mars could carry a price tag of several hundred billion dollars over the next two or three decades.
''The future is starting to arrive,'' said John E. Pike, a space policy analyst with the Federation of American Scientists in Washington. ''There's a danger with all these big projects just getting started. They could just about devour everything else in the space program.''
An Administration official said the strategy for the expanding space program, as developed by the White House's National Space Council, headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, includes developing new launching capabilities; opening up frontiers for manned and unmanned exploration, first by investigating the new technologies required for more distant space travel; using space as a vantage point for studying problems on Earth; taking advantage of the economic and international trade potential of space technologies, and insuring that the space program contributes to the nation's military security.
 
Some Costs Are Secret
The official said that spending on the even larger military space program also would be increased, by about 8 percent. Because many of these programs are classified, budget figures are not published, but the military space budget is believed to exceed NASA's by a large margin.
Mr. Truly, the NASA administrator, acknowledged that the new programs supported in the 1991 budget proposal would require even greater appropriations in coming years.
''Even with these large programs,'' he said, ''our budgets are running only a little more than 1 percent of the total federal budget, and in the Apollo days in the 1960's, the country invested as much as 3.8 percent of the Federal budget on the civilian space program.''

HEADLINE: Schools Plan: Big Goals, Little Money

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Meeting the education goals that President Bush outlined Wednesday night would be as hard a task as any the United States has faced, requiring a commitment to new ideas and new money that many educators say the President has so far failed to demonstrate. By the year 2000, Mr. Bush said, the United States should lead other nations in math and science, drastically reduce dropout rates, eliminate illiteracy, insure that every child is ready to enter school and make sure schools are disciplined and drug-free.
The President won virtually unanimous praise for using his ''bully pulpit'' to proclaim an educational crusade, particularly since his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, began his term in office by trying to abolish the Education Department. Educators applauded Mr. Bush's pledge to increase by $500 million the budget for Head Start, the program founded 25 years ago to help prepare poor children for school. And they praised his proposal to provide more money for educational research. 
 
Daunting Goals, Some Say
But many educators said that most of the goals Mr. Bush set were daunting and that he has offered no blueprint for reaching them. American students usually rank at or near the bottom among industrialized countries in math and science scores; Mr. Bush would have them leapfrog to the top in just 10 years. He wants to see graduation rates of 90 percent by the year 2000; the national average is now 72 percent, with major cities like Baltimore graduating about 55 percent.
Moreover, these educators faulted Mr. Bush for ignoring the connection between poverty and school failure. ''The math and science goal is critical,'' said Marc S. Tucker, president of the National Center for Education and the Economy, ''but reaching it with 20 percent of our kids living in poverty is ludicrous.''
But the educational community was not unanimous in criticizing Mr. Bush's speech. Some school reformers, in fact, believe the President is doing what he should by setting national priorities and that more Federal money is not the answer in a system in which states and cities provide 94 percent of all money for education.
But many educators said Mr. Bush's budget, with the exception of more money for Head Start and educational research, belies his words.
''When we wanted to put a person on the moon, to eradicate polio, and win World War II, we had a concerted approach and a substantial investment,'' said Bill Honig, California's State Superintendent for Public Instruction. ''He has to commit the resources.'' The Problems, the Budget Mr. Bush did propose substantial increases in many school programs. But in the opinion of many educators, experts in Congress and advocacy groups, including the Council of Great City Schools and the American Federation of Teachers, the amounts were so paltry to begin with that those increases will not begin to meet the President's goals.
For instance, some educators said, the Bush budget set aside only $45 million specifically to prevent dropping out of school, and $5 million for research on the dropout problem despite Mr. Bush's call for cuts in the dropout rate. Samuel B. Husk, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, which represents most of the nation's largest cities, said the dropout money should also go to middle schools, where many students decide to leave school.
And some educators noted, the budget includes aside just $239 million for adult literacy programs. While this represents a rise of 25 percent, education groups say it is not nearly enough to meet Mr. Bush's goal of wiping out adult illiteracy. It is estimated that 13 percent of adults in this country cannot read well enough to perform daily activities.
Last year, an international survey ranked 13-year-old Americans last in math and near the bottom in science. The budget allocates $230 million to a teacher training program in math and science, up 70 percent, and $460 million to the National Science Foundation for educational programs, an increase of 28 percent.
Overall, Congressional Democrats calculate that the Education Department's budget would actually expand less than the current inflation rate of 4.2 percent. But Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos argues that when discretionary spending is included, the increase is 6.2 percent, or 2 percent above inflation.
 
Helping Poor Children
But educators said Mr. Bush had gone far toward addressing two of his other goals: preparing poor children for school and measuring students' progress. Head Start, which now reaches about 20 percent of eligible children, could enroll 180,000 more children with the extra money Mr. Bush wants. The budget also allots substantially more money for educational research and for the National Assessment of Educational Progress, which surveys student performance.
Still, several educators said Mr. Bush had missed a chance to lead the way in channeling more money to poor school-age children. Money for Chapter One grants, which go to remedial programs for low-income children, would rise by 8 percent, to nearly $5 billion in the Bush budget. But Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said that total fell far short of the need. ''It's great giving somebody a head start, but then dumping them into an impossible school later on won't do very much,'' he said.
But other educators said they believed the Federal role should be one of inspiration, not largesse.
''The most important thing the President can do he's done - make education a national issue,'' said Jack A. MacAllister, chairman of US West, whose company is one of many businesses giving grants and loaning executives to schools across the country. ''This will encourage creative thinking throughout the nation. I don't want anything more from the Federal Government.''
Chester E. Finn Jr., an advocate of school reform, said those who are clamoring for more money are the same people largely responsible for America's poor educational performance. He and Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, a Denver-based group that coordinates state education reform efforts, praised the President for prodding the nation to reach ambitious goals, even if they seem unattainable.
But they said Mr. Bush should be attacking the complacency of many Americans about their children's mediocre educational performances and offering fresh ideas about how to improve.
''The plain fact is the President of the United States has not put forward clear-cut ideas on how we can move ourselves forward,'' Mr. Newman said. ''The Federal government has a history of new ideas - Head Start, Chapter One, the G.I. bill. I don't think the President is having a transforming effect.''

HEADLINE: New Player in Debate Over National Health Insurance: Bush

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
By calling for a review of the nation's health care system, President Bush has brought the White House into the the debate over national health insurance and raised the possibility that he might offer his own proposal, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
In his State of the Union address Wednesday, the President called for ''careful consideration'' of the recommendations of several health care studies now under way. He assigned Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to lead a review of ''recommendations on the quality, accessibility and cost'' of health care in the United States.
Until now, the Administration has considered such broad questions only at lower levels in the Department of Health and Human Services. The Domestic Policy Council, where this new review will take place, is a White House advisory group that is critical to forming Administration policy. 
 
Report Expected by Fall
A Congressional staff aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said: ''The significance of his statement is that universal health care has been elevated to a Presidential matter. He has put himself out there for the first time, saying that he wants an Administration position on the issue, one that will come from the White House directly.''
In an interview today, Dr. Sullivan said the President intended to give him ''the public and official responsibility and leadership for pulling together all the recommendations and options.'' He said his review would deal not just with cutting medical costs but also with quality of care and access to care, as well as the needs of people who have no health insurance.
Dr. Sullivan said that he was not sure what form his final recommendations would take but that they would be ''intended for specific actions.''
''What we are coming up with is an overview of the entire system,'' he said. ''My position will be to develop real improvements in the health care system and to control costs.''
Several commissions are already studying the issues. The Bipartisan Commission on Health Care, led by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, is expected to issue a report in March. The Advisory Committee on Social Security is expected to report in July. A task force on the health care system led by Constance Horner, Under Secretary of Health and Human Services, is expected to report in October. #37 Million Without Insurance These panels have focused on two issues: the 37 million Americans, most of them employed, who have no medical insurance; and long-term care for the elderly. At least some of the panels' reports are expected to suggest some way of assuring that Americans can get health insurance through their employers.
In Congress, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, are developing a proposal that employers be required to offer health insurance and to pay for a substantial part of it. A public program would cover the unemployed.
Senator Rockefeller said Mr. Bush's comments were encouraging but added, ''I only hope the President agrees that it's time to provide leaderhsip aimed at results and real solutions to our health care problems, instead of spending too much more time studying those problems.''
The United States' health care system is the most expensive in the world. But health care experts say it offers services to far fewer people, in proportion to the population, than do those in most Western countries.
Humphrey Taylor, president of the polling concern Louis Harris & Associates, said that while Americans were satisfied with specific health services, their dissatisfaction with the system was also the highest in the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Modest Medicine for the City

 BODY:
New York's Mayor, David Dinkins, has produced a financial plan that begins to come to grips with the city's troubled finances. But that grip may not be tight enough.
The plan represents a credible effort to deal fairly and humanely with New York City's wilting economy. Mayor Dinkins appropriately calls on everyone concerned - state legislators, the City Council, the business communty, city agencies and the public - to share the onerous burden of diminishing resources. Yet the Mayor's plan looks unfinished; it depends too heavily on unknowns and incompletes. 
To close an estimated budget gap of more than $1 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Mayor relies on a mix of service cuts, productivity savings, higher taxes and one-time revenues. The service cuts are bound to hurt, though Mr. Dinkins tries to limit their impact on the needy. Especially painful, if necessary, will be the slowed growth of the police force.
The tax package is bound to hurt, too, and raising taxes always risks sending the wrong message to business. Still, the proposal is reasonable, given the option of even deeper service cuts; they wouldn't enhance the business climate either.
The problem with the tax package, which includes a property tax increase, a three-year surcharge on personal income tax and a gasoline tax of 8 cents per gallon, is that Mr. Dinkins can't determine its fate. The City Council and the State Legislature have authority over different taxes, and both legislatures traditionally oppose tax increases. To his credit, Council Speaker Peter Vallone this year hasn't ruled out increasing property taxes, which are still comparatively low in New York City.
But even if the Council cooperates, Mr. Dinkins can't count on state legislators, up for re-election this year, to do the same. For instance, the city has tried unsuccessfully to get the Legislature to approve one of his requests - extending the mortgage recording tax to co-ops - for four years. What makes this year different?
Finally, the one-shot revenue raising devices, dubious measures in any case, may generate enough criticism from bond raters or fiscal monitors to kill them. The plan includes $330 million from the sale of the Coliseum, which is still in litigation, and the use of $150 million from the sale of new Battery Park City bonds. That borders on fiscal gimmickry.
The fate of the tax package and the one-shots, the unknown future of the economy and of the city's labor settlements later this year all make this spending plan even more speculative than usual. Mr. Dinkins will present his formal executive budget in April. By then he and his budget advisers will know more about the economy and the probable success of their proposals, enough to give more substance to a basically practical approach.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Every Leveraged Buyout Shakes the Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Robert Campeau's Special Genius'' (editorial, Jan. 17) has as weak a grasp on Robert Campeau as he once had on the Allied and Federated department store chains.
I find it incomprehensible that Mr. Campeau alone exhibited the ''special genius,'' ''overreaching grasp'' and ''oversized ego'' to bankrupt 258 profitable stores. What of the exorbitantly paid Wall Street organizations that advised Mr. Campeau to purchase Allied and Federated, certified for him their ''due diligence'' and transacted the deals? Nowhere did you mention them, let alone find them responsible for the conditions that led to this bankruptcy. For the Federated leveraged buyout, Wall Street investment banks and law firms generated $250 million in fees. In return, they delivered to the Campeau Corporation, as a buyer, and Allied and Federated, as sellers, the largest retail bankruptcy in United States history. 
Robert Campeau did not invent the leveraged buyout. It was a Wall Street product to turn black ink into red ink for tax purposes. Perhaps more important, Wall Street found leveraged buyouts generated enormous fees, while creating for investor groups levels of debt that necessitated divestiture and reorganization programs.
The leveraged buyout ''successes'' of the early 1980's reflected astronomical returns to a very small community of ''investors,'' who ''risked'' other people's money and were rewarded by a fourfold rise in the Dow Jones average. The true ''cost'' of such successes to the United States Treasury and state coffers, to the taxpayer, to employees and American productivity and competitiveness is incalculable.
As the 1980's drew to a close, the Dow quaked, and several billion-dollar leveraged buyout failures gave the public its first hint of the role of leveraged buyout tycoons. They walk away, leaving a pile of corporate and financial junk behind. As with the successes, leveraged buyout failures were paid for by the Treasury, state coffers, taxpayers, employees and American productivity and competitiveness.
Your suggestion that ''the big losers are investors, grown-ups'' and that ''The rest of the public has little at stake'' is dangerously simplistic. We all have a stake in the banks, pension funds and insurance companies that purchased the Allied-Federated debt. We will bear their losses through lower returns, lower taxes, employee cutbacks or destabilized pension or benefit programs.
Equally dubious is your contention that suppliers will be hurt only temporarily, though this may be so for some. More likely, smaller or less sophisticated vendors (those who did not fly out in Lear jets to clear payment checks drawn out of state ahead of the bankruptcy announcement) will go out of business at the cost of more tax dollars and more jobs.
Your argument that cutbacks arising from bankruptcy would have been inevitable contradicts your assertion that the stores are well run and profitable. Well run, profitable stores grow, adding jobs to the economy. Cutbacks in one area are more than offset by gains in another. Contrary to your conclusion, I believe the typical shopper, employee and taxpayer have every reason to feel deep, growing concern about the financial fallout in the 1990's of the overleveraging of corporate America. With their overreaching grasp and oversized egos, Wall Street organizations and the raiders they nurtured have put corporate America in a predicament from which a skyrocketing Dow Jones average is unlikely to rescue it.
 
JOSEPH L. LOUGHRAN JR.
 Nashua, N.H., Jan. 17, 1990

HEADLINE: Every Leveraged Buyout Shakes the Economy;

Your Jan. 17 editorial shows a surprising lack of understanding of the the Campeau Corporation bankruptcy. HEADLINE: In Africa, Democracy Needs Some Help

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There are two unfortunate aspects of the Kenya Government's decision to build a 60-story prestige building (news article, Dec. 29). First, the scarce resources amounting to $200 million slated for this skyscraper can be put to much better purposes, like assisting the credit-starved agrarian sector in Kenya. This kind of conspicuous expenditure on Kenya's urban sector is shortsighted in the extreme. 
An equally unfortunate feature of the proposed 60-story skyscraper is the Kenya Government's systematic repression of voices critical of this fantastic decision. Kenya's leading woman scientist, Wangari Maathai, a professor of veterinary anatomy, lost an environmental impact suit against the skyscraper project. She then appealed to the Kenya Attorney General, whose office said it would not even reply to her.
Subsequently, the President of Kenya, Daniel Arap Moi, attacked Professor Maathai in an independence day speech last Dec. 12. In addition to charging her with being an il-legitimate critic of the government by virtue of her sex, he also called on women associated with the government-linked national women's organization - the Maendeleo ya Wanawake - to ostracize Professor Maathai. Within days, the leaders of the organization requested that the government party, the Kenya African National Union, expel Professor Maathai from membership.
Though this kind of repression of legitimate political dissent is common in the typical African authoritarian state - in Zaire, for instance -Kenya is a relative newcomer to such behavior. With the winds of political change blowing through Eastern European Communist regimes and bringing a resurgence of participatory politics and civil rights, we find it unthinkable that the repression of political rights in African authoritarian states will go unchallenged by the international community. It is now necessary, we believe, that global financial agencies like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, as well as the foreign-aid agencies of major states like our own, Japan, Britain, France and West Germany, be increasingly used to improve participatory rights and practices in African states.
Liberal forces in the United States have long insisted, and rightly, that such pressure be used in South Africa, and we believe it is time to insist that participatory rights be thus improved elsewhere in Africa, Kenya included.
 
MARTIN KILSON
CLEMENT COTTINGHAM
 Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 10, 1990
The writers are, respectively, a professor of government at Harvard University and an associate professor of political science at Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: A Familiar Budget;
Much of Spending Plan From Dinkins Is Reminiscent of the Koch Approach

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Presenting a preliminary New York City budget that would not have struck Edward I. Koch as unfamiliar, the Budget Director for Mayor David N. Dinkins acknowledged yesterday that ''there aren't a whole lot of brand-new, unthought-of solutions.''
That truism - uttered by the director, Philip R. Michael - is a testament to both the inflexibility of a budget that must provide many services most other cities do not, and to a stagnant local economy that has hemmed in the city's spending for new programs for the last two years.
To be sure, there were shifted priorities at the periphery - modest new spending for some health, education and social-service programs. Unexpectedly large shortfalls in tax revenues, the biggest in years, prompted a call for unusually large tax increases, $550 million in all. 
 
Gloomy Forecasts
But in its reliance on some taxes that have repeatedly been sought without success, in its proposed delay in hiring police officers, in its gloomy forecasts to force the City Council and Albany to help, and in its warning that things could get worse, the plan is not so different from those proposed in recent years by Mr. Koch while he was Mayor.
''I don't think this budget document would have been much different if Mayor Koch had been here,'' said Hyman C. Grossman, managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which rates the city's bonds. ''I think that David Dinkins, as far as fiscal policy goes, has built on the track record Koch has made in the last several years, and that is: raise taxes when you've got no choice, cut services where you have to.''
Charles Brecher, director of research for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private monitoring group financed mostly by the business community, said: ''It's similar in the sense that it is realistic. They're facing up to what has to be dealt with.''
The similarities of this plan with those of the past came in part because the Dinkins administration had only a month to prepare it. Actions taken by the Koch administration, like the decision to include $300 million from the sale of the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle in the operating budget, left Mr. Dinkins ''somehwat captured by what had preceded us,'' Mr. Michael said.
At the same time, a marked decline in revenue growth, from an annual average of 9.8 percent from fiscal 1980 through 1988 to 2 percent in the current fiscal year, meant Mr. Dinkins had to worry more about cutting than adding.
 
'Easier to Express'
''It's always easier to express your priorities when you can add,'' said Alair A. Townsend, one of Mr. Michael's predecessors as budget chief and now publisher of Crain's New York Business. ''Frankly, with so much of the budget uncontrollable in the short term, there are only so many places to look for cuts. You can protect some things, but all that's at the margin.''
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan said it is the margin that counts.
''For me, that's only a way of saying the glass is half-empty,'' she said. ''What is full is that with only four weeks to make a budget that reflects perilous times, the Dinkins administration has made some hard choices in revenue proposals and approached the issue of service protection and service reduction with a scalpel.''
About 70 cents of each dollar in city revenue is effectively spoken for by the time it arrives, to pay for programs like Medicaid and welfare and social-service caseworkers and jail guards that are required. That means a mayor seeking to save lots of money must almost inevitably choose options like postponing the hiring of police officers, something Mr. Koch did repeatedly.
The plan announced yesterday would postpone from June until June 1991 the goal of having 28,054 officers on the main city police force, which now has just under 26,000. Even if the 5,000 officers needed to keep pace with attrition and meet that target were hired, Mr. Michael acknowledged, the last of them probably will not be hired until after July 1, 1991, to save money by pushing them into the next fiscal year.
 
'Phantom Cops'
During the mayoral campaign, Mr. Dinkins often accused Mr. Koch of creating ''phantom cops'' by claiming credit for officers included in the budget but never hired. Yesterday, Mr. Dinkins did not even mention the police hiring plans in his speech about the budget, and detailed them only in response to questions.
''I accused the Mayor of counting those when they weren't there,'' he said yesterday. Asked how his approach differed, he said, ''I don't count them.''
In proposing a $150 million bond issue by the Battery Park City Authority to give the city a one-time cash influx to help close a budget gap for the rest of the current fiscal year, Mr. Dinkins is, at best, relying on a one-time revenue source, like the Coliseum sale he faulted Mr. Koch for depending on.
 
A Tax Surcharge
In asking the Legislature for a three-year surcharge on the personal income tax that would cost the city's average resident about $70 a year, the Mayor returned to a measure used from 1982 to 1985, when the city also faced unexpected revenue shortfalls in the wake of a national recession. Mr. Michael said he was confident the current proposal would be equally temporary.
But in asking the City Council to delay cuts in energy taxes, Mr. Dinkins again sought to postpone tax breaks that were delayed two years ago. And in asking the Legislature to extend the mortgage recording tax to the sale of cooperatives, he reached for a chestnut that has been proposed each of the last five years without success.
Perhaps the biggest similarity of Mr. Dinkins's plan with those of the past is that it is only the start of process that will stretch until the Council passes a final budget this summer.
''It's preliminary, a point of negotiation with Albany and the Council,'' Mr. Brecher of the citizens group said. ''As in the past, a lot of things are going to change between now and June.''

LENGTH: 1653 words

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

La Cite
New York is the great magnifying glass. It picks up trends from around the world - in fashion, food, music, art - blows them up into caricatures, attaches high price tags and hawks them to the moneyed elite. Then they are jettisoned to make room for the next fads. This came to mind after repeated visits to La Cite, the new rococo extravaganza on West 51st Street that bills itself as a brasserie.
To be sure, New York could use some authentic brasseries along the lines of Paris's Vaudeville and Bofinger: fast-paced, drop-in, casual restaurants that serve traditional food at economical prices. While La Cite makes some earnest gestures to the genre, this place is to an authentic brasserie what a Citroen is to a bicycle.
The grand, multi-level setting has two main dining arenas and a cozier grill room, which serves essentially the same food at slightly lower prices. The main rooms evoke all the festive garishness of grand European brasseries: Art Deco molding, immense cylindrical chandeliers, tall mirrors, red velvet banquettes and waiters in spiffy black jackets and long white aprons. 
Some attempts at typical brasserie cooking succeed; others don't. And prices are all over the board, from $16 for rubbery-skinned blood sausage and mashed potatoes to $29.50 for excellent sirloin steak and french fries. Count on $100 for two, especially if you dip into the astutely chosen but expensive wine list (of more than 150 labels, only 8 are under $20; even the humble Bourgeuil and Chinon from the Loire are $25). And considering that brasseries are historically built around beer - the word means brewery in French - it is surprising that no beer list is offered.
The much ballyhooed choucroute, made with quality ingredients, has improved over the course of my visits, but it still lacks a deep, integrated flavor. The same goes for the decent if shallow-tasting cassoulet. One of the best entrees sampled is the golden-skinned, spit-roasted chicken with raisins, pearl onions and button mushrooms. Grilled salmon with a fresh dill vinaigrette is better than the roasted monkfish, which came coated with so many green peppercorns we couldn't eat it. At lunch in the handsome grill room, a huge juicy lamb steak came with delicious white beans cooked in chicken stock with basil. As for our side dish, I don't know whether to call it mashed potatoes with butter or butter with mashed potatoes -whatever, it is unrepentantly good. A thick slab of swordfish was deftly turned out, too, embellished with tissue-thin homemade potato chips.
Petit sale, which usually connotes cured pork, is made with breast and leg of duck. The rendition here, served with green cabbage, did not go over big at my table: it lacked a saline-cured flavor and had no perceptible seasonings. Thursday's special is duck confit with sauteed apples and lentils. The crispy-skinned leg is tasty and tender for sure, but not at all complex and buttery like a real confit.
For starters, shellfish of all sorts, especially oysters and intensely oceanic sea urchins, are excellent. A salad pairing confit of chicken with sun-dried cherries is a felicitous combination. I would go back to the grill room just for a sizzling batch of small, incredibly sweet mussels served in a skillet.
La Cite, which is owned by Alan Stillman (of the Post House, Smith & Wollensky and the Manhattan Ocean Club), took off from Day 1, and the service staff has had little time to get its sea legs. Lunch service on one occasion was much too slow for the business crowd, while another time in the grill our waiter yanked away my finished plate while my companion was halfway through her entree.
Desserts are the most consistent course: prune Armagnac ice cream with walnut cake and fruit compote, sublime banana ice cream crowned with a light chocolate mousse and thin coconut cookies, intense chocolate torte with vanilla ice cream and raspberry sauce.
If you only try one, get the cappuccino mousse topped with granite of espresso.
La Cite is not the insouciant, unassuming brasserie one might have hoped it would be - I would call it a brassaurant - but if you take it on its terms, it can be a diverting addition to the midtown dining scene.
 
Siracusa
Five years ago, a friend and I wandered into a little Italian delicatessen near Astor Place and noticed several Formica tables in one corner. From under a door came the deep, rich aroma of something simmering on the stove. When I asked what was cooking, the man behind the counter said his mother was making pasta sauce, and asked if we would like some lunch.
We sat on the flimsy chairs and ate ourselves silly on fettuccine with fresh porcini and ground veal, spaghetti all'amatriciana, fresh mozzarella with sun-dried tomatoes, caponata, glasses of Barbera d'Alba and, for dessert, four kinds of gelati. The bill was under $35. Since then, the Cammarata family - Gino, his mother, Maria, and father, Giuseppe, all of whom share kitchen duties, and Enzo, the maitre d'hotel - has built a cozy 40-seat restaurant in the back room, complete with a long, well-stocked wine bar, antique cupboard, well-spaced tables and soft lighting. The pastas still excel, and, naturally, prices have inflated. But Siracusa is still as warm and genial as ever.
The best way to start is with a sampling from the changing appetizer platters that are on display near the bar. One evening, the platters could have squares of light fennel-filled pastry; wonderful caponata; asparagus wrapped in prosciuttto, and tender baby octopus in a peppery fresh tomato sauce. Another time, the assortments might feature glistening rape in strong olive oil and flecked with prosciutto; mozzarella with sun-dried tomatoes; mussels on the half shell stuffed with rice and peas, and a simple but sublime Sicilian specialty called panelle, which is chick-pea-flour bread filled with ricotta and baked until toasted. Every tidbit was not a winner, though: swordfish carpaccio, which came with the assorted appetizers one evening, was so swamped in capers and vinaigrette that the fish was undetectable. Two specials to watch for are scacciata, a delicious thin-crusted pie filled with fresh spinach, sun-dried tomatoes and capers, and the cleanly fried codfish fritters.
It seems that half of the customers are on a first-name basis with the Cammarata family, which makes for a neighborly atmosphere. Waiters are sincere and professional. Siracusa has a well-rounded Italian wine list, starting at $18.
Main courses are restricted to pastas. Outstanding winter specials include fettuccine with a thick, lusty lamb and potato ragu, and curri curri, which is simply homemade pasta tossed with a clean, fresh sauce of tomato and prosciutto. The seafood pasta is noteworthy, too, combining baby octopus, squid, shrimp and a changing roster of other ingredients in a light, oregano-scented tomato sauce.
The Sicilian specialty of spaghetti with fresh sardines, raisins, pinenuts, dill and toasted breadcrumbs is extremely rich and assertive from the abundance of sardines: too rich to my taste. And cappellini puttanesca - olives, capers, anchovies and olive oil - suffered only from undersaucing.
Mrs. Cammarata still makes the tiramisu, and it is relatively light and dusted with chocolate powder. Lemon sorbet is a fine cleanser, but most regulars go for the marvelous homemade gelati, either ricotta, hazelnut, espresso or vanilla (Siracusa sells its gelati to many Italian restaurants in town and has a gelateria next door that is open from spring to fall).
In a way, I still miss that obscure little delicatessen with the Formica-topped tables and Mom in the galley kitchen. To the Cammaratas' credit, the setting has changed but the spirit remains.
 
La Cite
*
 
120 West 51st Street, 956-7100.
Atmosphere: Big, bright and garish brasserie; grill room more sedate and tranquil.
Service: Can be slow at lunch, otherwise professional.

 BODY:

Economy
The nation's biggest retailers reported generally good sales gains in January, mostly on the basis of apparel clearances. But Sears, Roebuck, the largest retailer, reported a sales gain of only 2.2 percent for the month. [Page D1.] 
The nation's purchasing managers said the economy had declined sharply in January for the ninth consecutive month despite strength in orders for exports. [D2.] Construction spending advanced last year at its slowest pace since the 1982 recession. [D2.]
 
 
 
Markets
John J. Phelan Jr. is retiring as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. He said he would step aside at the end of the year to pursue other interests. [D1.] There was almost universal praise on Wall Street for Mr. Phelan's leadership abilities. [D6.]
Stock prices ended narrowly mixed in a quiet session. The Dow slipped 4.28 points, to 2,586.26. [D6.]
Gold prices roared back after falling sharply on Wednesday after word leaked out that the Treasury had asked the I.M.F. to sell at least a million ounces of gold. [D13.]
The dollar finished mixed amid bearish sentiment as the West German mark continued to dominate trading. [D13.]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in fairly active trading. [D12.]

Chrysler will close its suburban St. Louis car assembly plant, laying off about 3,700 workers in a surprise move that will reduce its car-making capacity by about 20 percent. [D1.]
Gillette has tentatively agreed to build a $50 million factory capable of making 800 million blades a year, or 80 percent of the total exported annually to the Soviet Union. [D1.]
Thomas S. Murphy will step down as chief executive of Capital Cities/ABC, but will remain as chairman. Daniel B. Burke, the chief operating officer, will be his successor. [D1.]

A Federal task force has recommended that President Bush nullify a transaction under which the Chinese Government bought an American company that manufactures parts for commercial aircraft, Administration officials said. [A9.]

HEADLINE: Is Campeau Himself Bankrupt?

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Robert Campeau's audacious, but characteristic, move in betting his financial empire on the value of his Campeau Corporation stock now seems to have been his undoing. By most available accounts, his personal fortune of $500 million has all but evaporated before his eyes as the stock, worth $41 a share (Canadian) two and half years ago, is now at $2.40 on the Toronto exchange.
Yesterday there was another indication of the troubles the Toronto real estate developer faces: The Bank of Montreal said it was suing Mr. Campeau for defaulting on $21.2 million remaining on a $25 million personal loan. The bank said he borrowed the money two and a half years ago to help buy Campeau voting shares and debentures. To secure the loan Mr. Campeau had pledged 425,000 shares of stock from his personal account and the principal of millions of dollars in debentures.
That default follows a very similar but much larger loan default in January to the Montreal-based National Bank of Canada. That bank said Mr. Campeau had failed to make an interest payment on an estimated $160 million loan. 
The result is that along with the retail chains in bankruptcy - the Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores owned by his company - Mr. Campeau may himself be insolvent, according to public information about his holdings and to people who have long tracked his finances.
They calculate that Mr. Campeau's assets in stock and personal property total about $35 million, against loans and other liabilities of at least $120 million.
''Bob is as broke as his company,'' said Ira Gluskin, a Toronto money manager who has followed Campeau financial dealings for 25 years.
To be sure, Mr. Campeau is hardly destitute, and the precise depth of his financial wounds is impossible to determine. Since the multibillion-dollar financial collapse of the American department store companies was disclosed, he has become a virtual recluse. He declined to be interviewed for this article, and like other private citizens he does not have to disclose information about his personal affairs.
Still, these are some things that are known about his situation:
Mr. Campeau owns 6.6 million Campeau Corporation shares worth about $15.8 million (Canadian). He and his wife, Ilse, own a baronial, Norman-style estate in the exclusive Bridle Path district of Toronto that is their primary home and is worth at least $10 million. They also have a home in Tequesta, Fla., near Palm Beach, assessed by local tax officials last year at $462,400, and a recently acquired large home in Austria.
Property records show that Mrs. Campeau has sole title to the Toronto estate and the Florida vacation home. While that gives Mr. Campeau no claim to the property, it also means his creditors cannot lay claim to it.
But even ignoring who holds the house titles, the properties are worth at most $20 million, real estate experts say, making Mr. Campeau's personal property and stock assets total around $35 million.
On the other side of the ledger are the loan defaults to at least the two Montreal banks by his personal investment companies, which serve largely to manage his stock portfolio.
 
Stock Seized
Although the National Bank, with the larger default claim, will not disclose the terms of the loan, banking experts say that in all likelihood Mr. Campeau is personally liable.
On declaring him in default, the National Bank seized 13 million Campeau Corporation common shares and 4 million convertible preferred Campeau shares that Mr. Campeau had posted as collateral. But since the collateral, along with notes and bonds Mr. Campeau also posted, is now worth only about $60 million, the developer still probably owes the bank $100 million.
''If Bob is on that National Bank loan with his personal covenant, he is bankrupt,'' said Harry Rannala, a Toronto-based stock analyst who has followed Mr. Campeau for years.
Since the troubles at Federated and Allied arose, Mr. Campeau has shunned the limelight and is not the social butterfly he once was, those who know him say.
''It's safe to assume he has not been out partying,'' said a spokesman, Richard Wertheim.
It is quite possible that Mr. Campeau has squirreled away substantial wealth in foreign banks, where it would be hard to track, or through private investment partnerships, which would also be difficult to trace.
But business associates, family members and analysts who know Mr. Campeau find that unlikely. And National Bank officials suggested that he failed to make his payment simply because he did not have the cash.
''Otherwise he would not have defaulted and relinquished control of his company,'' said Leon Courville, a National Bank executive vice president, in a telephone interview last week. $1 Million Salary Halted Just a few days after Mr. Campeau defaulted on his loan, Campeau Corporation directors moved to establish a voting trust that would manage the affairs of Allied and Federated, which operate the Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and Abraham & Straus chains, among others. That not only removed Mr. Campeau from the seat of power, but also halted his $1 million-a-year salary.
How could such a hugely successful entrepreneur be broke? After all, his real estate company built 20 percent of the new houses in Ottawa in the last 25 years and owns 40 percent of the office space leased by the Canadian Government. The answer appears to be that Mr. Campeau believed in himself and his company to such an extent that he never hesitated to put most of his money back into Campeau Corporation stock. At one point he owned more than 75 percent of the outstanding common.
 
Several Private Companies
Incorporation certificates at the Ontario Ministry of Consumer and Commercial Relations show that in the last 20 years Mr. Campeau has established several private investment companies. But Ontario Securities Commission records show that the companies were formed to hold Campeau securities and have virtually no outside investments.
Analysts who have followed Mr. Campeau are not surprised by his view that there could not be a better investment than Campeau stock. They say that since its early days of building modest single-family homes in Quebec, the company and Mr. Campeau have been almost indistinguishable, even after the corporation went public in the late 1960's.
''I'm not saying he did not have other investments,'' said Michael Babad, a Toronto-based journalist who wrote a biography of Mr. Campeau. ''What I am saying is that Campeau Corporation was Bob Campeau's life and that the great bulk of his wealth has been tied up in the company's stock.''
Even as recently as last September, Campeau shares traded at $18.625. Since then, as the company's troubles grew and the stock was handed out to various parties lending financial aid, the family's ownership has slipped to 30.3 percent worth $35 million, down from 51 percent worth more than $500 million.
''He gambled almost everything: his own personal stuff plus the children's trusts,'' said Robert Archambault, Mr. Campeau's son-in-law. ''It is quite devastating.''
Mr. Archambault should know. His wife, Rachelle, Mr. Campeau's daughter, received at the age of 35 a total of 1.6 million Campeau shares held in trust. Those shares are now worth $3.8 million, compared with $65.6 million two and a half years ago.
Two of Mr. Campeau's sons, Robert Jr. and Daniel, still have Campeau shares in trust that are worth $10.6 million, down from $180.4 million. A third son, Jacques, who received 1.9 million shares before his father sued him for the right to vote the stock, has seen the value of his holdings decline to $4.6 million from $77.9 million.
Making matters worse for the family is that their shares have not paid dividends since the Campeau Corporation suspended them last fall when its American retailing operations had to be bailed out by Olympia & York Developments Ltd., a Toronto-based real estate giant.
''Robert Campeau was being squeezed even before the National Bank of Canada called its loan,'' said Frank Mayer, an analyst at BBN James Capel, a securities firm with offices in Toronto.
Mr. Campeau still has some income. He receives a salary as chief executive of the Campeau Corporation, which is not disclosed. As chairman of Campeau's board, he is paid $12,000 a year in directors' fees plus $750 per meeting. Balanced against that, Mr. Campeau owes the Campeau Corporation $4 million on a $5 million interest-free loan he received to buy personal real estate.
Mr. Campeau has not filed for personal bankruptcy, although speculation is rising in Toronto that he might have to do so to keep creditors from closing in on his remaining assets.
Despite the setbacks no one is saying that Mr. Campeau's career is over. Friends believe that Mr. Campeau, who rose from a hardscrabble existence as a factory worker in a nickel plant, has simply put his ambitions on hold.
''Bob's irrepressible, so, yes, he'll be back,'' said a friend of the developer and a former Campeau Corporation director. ''Bob will always find something interesting to do and a way to make money. He's a survivor.''
