HEADLINE: Good Gains For Stores Last Month

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Many of the nation's biggest retailers reported yesterday that their fiscal year ended with generally good sales gains in January.
Two exceptions to the strong showing were Sears, Roebuck & Company, which posted a 2.2 percent increase in sales for the month, and Montgomery Ward, where sales showed a decline of 3.8 percent.
In other reports on business activity, the nation's purchasing managers said that the economy declined in January for the ninth consecutive month. And the Commerce Department reported that construction spending fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in December, ending a year that saw the slowest growth since 1982. [Page D2.] Apparel Sales Up Clearances of apparel were a big factor in January retailing, and chains that emphasize clothing, like the Limited Inc., Charming Shoppes and the J. C. Penney Company, had a better January performance than the retail industry in general. 
But the percentage gains of sales at stores open at least a year, known as same-store sales, increased less in January than for the fiscal year.
The January sales trend was seen as evidence of continued economic growth but at a moderate pace. ''There will be no recession; that's the overwhelming conclusion we get now,'' said Monroe Greenstein, senior analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. ''But the evidence of a continued sluggish pace of consumer buying augurs for a relatively tough year in 1990.''
 
Outlook Called Sluggish
Jeffrey Feiner, retailing analyst at Merrill Lynch, said, ''Weakness in both the housing and financial markets makes the outlook for consumer spending in retail stores likely to be quite sluggish, at least over the near term.''
As Mr. Greenstein noted, ''Where there was strength in January, it was in apparel, where clearances included deep discounts.'' But there was some evidence, too, that price-cutting of clothes and related items had been so prevalent in recent months that consumers had already snapped up many goods and did not need many more, analysts said.
Sears, the nation's biggest retailer, said its merchandise group had revenues in January of $2.16 billion, up from $2.12 billion the year before; same-store sales were up 3.3 percent. For the 52 weeks ended Jan. 27, sales rose 3.7 percent, to $33.5 billion, from $32.3 billion the year before, and same-store sales rose 2.5 percent.
Michael Bozic, the chairman of Sears's merchandising group, said double-digit gains were recorded in children's and junior apparel, home appliances, sporting goods, lawn mowers and business equipment. But the increases were largely offset by soft sales in other lines, he said.
The K Mart Corporation, the second-largest retailer, said sales in January totaled $1.79 billion, up 13.3 percent from $1.58 billion the year earlier; same-store sales rose 3.1 percent. For the year, sales rose 6.6 percent, to $29.1 billion from $27.3 billion; same-store sales increased 2 percent.
''We are encouraged by the continued sales increases in both the hard-line and apparel businesses,'' said Joseph E. Antonini, chairman and chief executive of K Mart.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which has been the nation's fastest-growing retailer for several years, registered bigger sales in January than K Mart, moving closer to capturing the No. 2 position. Wal-Mart's January sales rose 24.3 percent, to $1.84 billion from $1.48 billion; same-store sales were up 10 percent. Sales in the year increased 25.2 percent, to $25.8 billion from $20.6 billion; same-store sales rose 11 percent.
Penney reported an 8.5 percent sales gain for January and said its sales for the year rose 8.4 percent.
Following is a list of the sales of other large retailers:
 
Ames Department Stores down 4.2 percent, to $230 million. Same-store sales rose 1.9 percent in the Ames' discount stores but dropped about 16 percent in the Zayre stores acquired in October 1988.
Dayton Hudson Corp. up 12.2 percent, to $711 million; same-store sales rose 5.2 percent.
For the 52 weeks, sales rose 14 percent, to $12.7 billion; same-store sales up 6.4 percent.
The Limited up 11 percent to $285.6 million; same-store sales rose 9 percent. For the 52 weeks, sales rose 12 percent, to $4.57 billion; same-store sales up 9 percent.
May Department Stores Co. up 5.2 percent, to $471.7 million; same-store sales rose 2.6 percent. For the 52 weeks, sales rose 12.1 percent, to $9.42 billion; same-store sales up 5.7 percent.
Montgomery Ward down 3.9 percent, to $278.2 million. For the 52 weeks, sales rose 2.8 percent, to $5 billion.
J. C. Penney up 8.5 percent, to $779 million; same-store sales rose 7.3 percent. For the 52 weeks, sales increased 8.4 percent, to $15.1 billion; same-store sales rose 7.2 percent.
Woolworth Corp. up 8.5 percent, to $283 million; same-store sales rose 4.5 percent. For the 52 weeks, up 9.5 percent, to $5.12 billion; same-store sales rose 5.3 percent. Including foreign operations, sales rose 9 percent, to $8.76 billion for the year.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Four Pathways Japan Might Take

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THE traffic jams here beat anything New York has to offer, and so does the concentration of capital. Japan's investors, having bid the prices of buildings, land and stocks to stratospheric levels, are going overseas for cheaper assets, cheaper labor and higher rates of return than they can earn at home. Lenin said, ''Imperialism is the final stage of capitalism,'' and the Japanese, bursting forth from their resource-poor islands, seem to be acting out Lenin's script.
With incredible speed, Japan has already built up huge holdings abroad. Its net external assets, the amount by which Japanese holdings abroad exceed foreigners' holdings of Japanese assets, have increased 25-fold during the last decade and will reach $380 billion this year. Kenneth S. Courtis, a professor at the University of Tokyo and Deutsche Bank's chief economist here, estimates that Japan's net external assets could well reach $1 trillion by the end of the 1990's. 
Having risen from the ashes of World War II to become the world's most capital-rich nation, the Japanese face a spectrum of accusations, from arrogance and ethnocentricity to materialism and insecurity; they seem obsessed with the question of what their role in the world of economics and politics should be.
They can choose among four basic scenarios. The first is to become the world's dominant power, replacing the ''Pax Americana'' with a ''Pax Nipponica.'' But a hegemonic strategy would encounter many problems. The Japanese could scarcely expect to achieve world dominance without the military means of enforcing control over other areas; one would have to assume that in the brave new world of the future, peace would be automatic and self-enforcing, with military strength counting for naught, or that economic strength could buy mercenaries elsewhere to enforce the peace.
Even if Japan were to renounce its constitutional restraints on military power, other nations, in Asia or the West, would not permit a militarily dominant Japan to emerge. Setting aside the question of force, a Japanese bid for hegemonic power through economic means alone would doubtless provoke strong political resistance, protectionist moves against Japanese exports and barriers against investment.
The second scenario would be for Japan to join forces with the United States to assume a joint hegemony. Working closely together, Japan and the United States would constitute a formidable team, economically, militarily and technologically. But the strong rivalry between the countries is likely to persist. The relationship has long been a strained and troubled one, especially after Japan discarded its early postwar humility and self-abasement. Even if Japan and the United States established some sort of duopoly in the Pacific, they would encounter powerful resistance from Europe, the Soviet Union and whatever remains of the Soviet bloc - the vast domain that George Orwell, in his novel ''1984,'' called Eurasia.
That leads to a third scenario, which some economists think is already emerging: a world divided among three major blocs paralleling Orwell's Eastasia, Eurasia and Oceania. But a brave new world split into such blocs could be as unstable and dangerous, economically and politically, as the old world of blocs between World Wars I and II. As Prof. Paul Streeten of Boston University has observed: ''The exclusion of the Japanese from South and Southeast Asia by the British, French and Dutch was a major cause of Japanese aggression. The exclusion of Germany from the Western blocs contributed to World War II.''
Groups of three tend to break into coalitions of two against one. Some of the Japanese one encounters in Tokyo voice fears that a ''white Christian'' America and Europe would form a coalition to contain Japan. But this fear appears to underrate the importance the United States attaches, for the sake of its own economic and political interests, to maintaining close relations and two-way trade and capital investments with Japan and the other rapidly growing nations of the Pacific.
Hence, though it may seem visionary, the scenario that appears to make the most practical sense for Japan, the United States and the rest of the world is the fourth one: a global strategy. This was the strategy the United States and its allies pursued at the end of World War II through the creation of the United Nations, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and what was to have been a World Trade Organization, now reduced to a rather ineffectual General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. With the Communist empire breaking down, there may be an opportunity to rebuild the global system in larger terms.
The Japanese are coming to see their interests as global - and best served by an open system of world trading and investment. That is why they are investing so heavily abroad: Last year direct Japanese investment in North America totaled $44.3 billion; in Europe, $24.9 billion; elsewhere in Asia, $12.9 billion, and in other areas, $17.9 billion.
The global strategy is emerging as Japan's prime scenario for the 21st century. It is why Prime Minister Tashiki Kaifu went to Eastern Europe last month, and was criticized at home for not visiting China and other parts of Asia.
But the global strategy will have to involve greater aid, not just trade and private investment. In Tokyo last week, Robert S. McNamara, the former president of the World Bank, criticized Japan for devoting only 0.31 percent of its gross national product to aid for developing countries during the last five years. Although Japan has said it will double its aid to the third world during the next five years, Mr. McNamara said Japan's level of aid would continue to fall below that of most other industrial countries, though the country's per capita income is 20 percent greater, on average, than the others'.
''Surely,'' he said, ''Japan will feel a responsibility to carry a larger share of our common burden.''

HEADLINE: Construction Spending Off 0.6%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Construction spending advanced last year at its slowest pace since the 1982 recession, the Government said today as it released December data showing that spending declined by six-tenths of a percent that month.
Analysts said high interest rates, overbuilding and a sluggish economy contributed to the weakness last year.
The Commerce Department said residential, nonresidential and government construction spending last year totaled $414.7 billion, a 1.2 percent increase over 1988 but the weakest performance since a 5.1 percent decline in 1982. 
 
Offsetting a Gain
For December, spending was at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $414.6 billion, a decline that nearly erased the gain of seven-tenths of a percent in November.
The December activity, the worst monthly performance since a decrease of 1 percent last June, was affected by record cold weather in most of the nation east of the Rockies.
As for the year, analysts said actions by the Federal Reserve that kept interest rates relatively high through most of 1989 not only made construction more expensive, but also slowed the economy and thus made sales more difficult.
''Plus, you had a number of good years of construction'' leading up to 1989, said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. ''Eventually, you have all the houses and office buildings that you need. You run out of pent-up demand.''
Because of the lessening demand and the state of the economy, Mr. Berson said, ''1990, at best, will be about what it was in 1989 and could even fall a little bit.''
 
Worries About Financing
Another factor beginning to worry builders and analysts is the effect that the Government's bailout of the savings and loan industry will have on the availability of construction financing.
''The law limits the amount that savings and loans can lend to any one construction company,'' said Steven Cochran, an economist at WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., who added that efforts were under way to change that aspect of the bailout law.
Analysts said the nonresidential sector continued to grow last year even though widespread vacancies in office buildings provide evidence of overbuilding.
Nonresidential spending rose 2.4 percent, to $99.4 billion, in 1989, and 4.3 percent, to an annual rate of $96.7 billion, in December.
 
Slump in Housing
Residential spending, representing 50 percent of construction spending, was off 1.1 percent, to $195.9 billion, last year, and down seven-tenths of a percent in December, to an annual rate of $191 billion.
But single-family construction rose four-tenths of a percent, to an annual rate of $144.3 billion, in December, the third straight advance after falling for eight months. Multifamily spending, which has fallen every month since July, was down 2.8 percent, to a $20.6 billion annual rate.
The usually volatile government sector rose 3.8 percent, to $84 billion, in 1989, and 2.9 percent, to a $91.1 billion annual rate, in December, when it was bolstered by a 9.3 percent gain in highway and street projects. Government projects account for about 20 percent of construction spending.

HEADLINE: Confidence Index Down

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Consumer confidence in the United States fell in January for the third straight month, but buying plans remained virtually unchanged, the Conference Board, a private business research group, said Wednesday. 
The January consumer confidence index fell about 8 points from where it stood in December, to 105.1, its lowest level since November 1987, just after the October stock market crash.
In the latest survey, people were less comfortable with current conditions and less optimistic in their expectations for the next six months, but their buying plans were little changed. The monthly survey covers 5,000 households throughout the United States.
In January, 18.5 percent of the respondents said business conditions were bad, a slight increase from December.

HEADLINE: Dow Slips In Slower Trading

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday amid sharply slower trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average, slipped 4.28 points, to 2,586.26, but advances on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded declines by 881 to 651. Yesterday's performance was in sharp contrast to Wednesday's 47.30 gain.
Traders said that news of a drop in an economic index of the National Association of Purchasing Management to 45.2 percent in January from 46.7 percent in December had little impact on stock prices. A reading below 50 percent means the economy is declining, while a reading above that figure means the economy is expanding. 
A report by the Commerce Department that showed construction spending fell six-tenths of 1 percent in December also had little impact on traders.
 
Phelan Resignation
Perhaps the biggest news coming from the Big Board today was the announcement that John J. Phelan Jr. would retire as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange at the end of the year. Mr. Phelan denied rumors that he might be named Treasury Secretary, saying that he had no interest in going into Government service.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 0.29, to 328.79, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index edged up 0.02, to 181.52.
Volume on the Big Board shrank to 154.6 million shares, from a heavy 189.7 million on Wednesday.
The Dow transportation average continued to rebound from its recent weakness, with UAL, making another strong showing. The parent of United Airlines soared 8 3/4, to 129 3/4, and was one of the biggest net gainers on the Big Board.
Traders said that company was meeting with commercial bankers, Coniston Partners and others who are believed to be forming a new bid for the company at about $180 a share.
Among individual issues, USX rose 3/8, to 33 7/8. Charles A. Corry, the company's chairman, said this week that USX had altered its bylaws to require anyone planning a proxy contest at the company's annual meeting to give USX 60 days' notice. Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who controls more than 13 percent of USX's stock, has said that he would like to buy 25 percent.
Hilton Hotels dropped 3 1/4, to 58 1/2. Traders linked the decline to disappointment that the company has made no decision on spinning off certain assets or restructuring.
Johnson & Johnson rose a point, to 53 3/8. Analysts said that the rise was helped by hopes that the pharmaceutical company could be developing a rival product to Wellcome P.L.C.'s anti-aids drug.
QMS, a Mobile, Ala., software manufacturer, rose 1/2, to 13 1/8. The company announced that it had authorized the repurchase of 500,000 of its more than 11 million shares outstanding.
 
Other Exchanges Advance
Chase Manhattan, in dividend-related activity, was the most active stock, slipping 1/8, to 30 5/8, on a volume of 5.4 million shares. The stock went ex-dividend on Jan. 26.
Other active glamour stocks included Texaco, off 1/4, to 58; Philip Morris, up 1/8, to 38, and A.T.& T. off 5/8, to 38 3/8. I.B.M. dropped 7/8, to 97 3/4, and American Express added 1/4, to 30.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 1.43 points, to 351.50, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index advanced 1.95 points, to 417.76.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed yesterday in fairly active trading.
A report from the nation's purchasing managers indicating that activity in the manufacturing sector declined for the ninth straight month in January tended to bolster bond prices somewhat. But prices of short- to intermediate-term securities eased modestly.
Market participants attributed the lack of reaction to the fact that traders were looking beyond the purchasing managers' survey to the employment report that will be released this morning. 
''The purchasing managers' number was important, but the employment data are critical,'' one Government bond trader said. ''That provides a very hard look at the economy and is the sort of number the Fed pays attention to.''
Because of a number of special factors, including layoffs in the auto industry and the expected return of large numbers of construction workers after an exceptionally frigid December, estimates vary widely on what the January employment report will show.
 
Various Forecasts
Most analysts are projecting that non-farm payroll employment rose by 150,000 last month. But forecasts of an increase as low as 75,000 and as high as 400,000 have also been made.
''An increase of more than 300,000 accompanied by a rise in wages of half a percentage point or more would be a pretty bad combination for the market,'' said James A. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities.
Treasury bond prices, which rallied by a full point on Wednesday, moved slightly higher again yesterday. By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 96 23/32, up 6/32, to yield 8.42 percent.
But short to intermediate Treasury notes were little changed. In late trading, for example, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 1/2, up 1/32, to yield 8.40 percent. Meanwhile, the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes dipped by 1/32, to a late offered price of 97 5/8, to yield 8.32 percent.
Treasury bill rates were little changed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent late yesterday, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills were unchanged, at 7.69 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.52 percent.
 
At Least One Pessimist
Despite the recent run-up in interest rates, at least one noted portfolio manager remains pessimistic about the bond market's prospects over the next few months.
Earlier this week, Stanley D. Salvigsen, chairman and chief executive of Comstock Partners, which manages $2.3 billion in assets, advised the firm's clients to cut their bond holdings in half.
As of now, the portfolio mix recommended by Comstock is 30 percent invested in stocks, 35 percent in bonds and the remaining 35 percent in cash.
''We got into bonds in the summer of 1987 and have had a pretty good run,'' Mr. Salvigsen said. ''Long term we are still very bullish, but over the short term we are concerned.''
Rising interest rates in Western Europe and Japan, a factor that has already pushed up rates in this country, remain a major worry, Mr. Salvigsen said.
 
Quarter-Point Rise Seen
Mr. Salivigsen declined to predict how high interest rates might go. But he said that ''obviously, at this late stage of the day, we think they will go up by more than one-quarter of a percentage point.''
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very light, dealers said, with little or no change in prices. Prices of high-yield ''junk bond'' issues were also little changed.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most actively traded issues rose by 1/8 of a point to 1/4 of a point, traders said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Jan. 22. The report had no impact on prices.

HEADLINE: Mexico's President Urges Latin Investments by West

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico urged the industrialized nations of the West today not to forget Mexico and the rest of Latin America as they move to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.
Addressing the opening session of the World Economic Forum, an annual gathering of political and business leaders, Mr. Salinas said Mexico had already carried out many of the painful changes, including economic deregulation and privatization of state entities, that still lie ahead in Eastern Europe.
''We know that any economic reform takes time and demands sacrifices,'' he said, ''because if hopes are thwarted, the sense of future can be lost, only to be replaced by nostalgia for the past.'' 
 
Main Theme of Message
Turning to the main theme of his current five-nation European trip, he said, ''May these splendid signs of change not cloud Europe's global vision, nor turn its attention away from our continent - particularly Mexico - and from other regions of the world.''
So far, Mr. Salinas has carried this message to meetings with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London and Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Bonn and to the headquarters of the European Community in Brussels. Mexican officials said his domestic economic program had been praised in all three capitals.
But his audience today was made up largely of senior executives of big European, Japanese and American corporations. And here he stressed that Mexico has relaxed its rules for foreign investment and warmly welcomed outside participation in new growth resulting from completion of the latest talks on its foreign debt.
 
Forum Focuses on Shift in East
This year's weeklong World Economic Forum seems likely to be dominated almost entirely by the challenges facing Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union as they gradually move from centrally planned to market-oriented economies.
Probably no Latin American country is currently better positioned to speak for the third world to this audience than Mexico. Since taking office a year ago, the Salinas administration has not only obtained the best foreign debt restructuring deal to date, but has also taken steps to control inflation, reduce the budget deficit and trim the state apparatus.
Mr. Salinas said that development differences advised against linking Mexico to the United States in a common market in the foreseeable future. But he added that sector-to-sector agreements with the United States were working well and that similar arrangements would soon be worked out with Canada.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Session Mixed; Mark Dominates Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday amid generally bearish sentiment.
Currency trading was active in Europe, although the dollar held to a narrow range. Dealings slowed considerably when activity shifted to United States markets, and the dollar closed near its lows of the day against several currencies.
Traders were awaiting the release today of United States employment figures for January. The consensus is that the unemployment rate will register around 5.4 percent.
The figure ''is going to be a real key on the market,'' said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader at Bank of Boston's office in New York.
''We're looking for a fairly neutral number,'' he said, ''but if there is a jump in unemployment - an indication that the economy is slowing - we could see the dollar much lower.''
Traders said they expected American interest rates to decline further. Such a drop, coupled with relatively high West German interest rates, would put further pressure on the dollar.
The West German mark continued to dominate trading, dealers said, noting that the Japanese yen and the British pound lost ground against the mark.
In New York, the dollar closed at 1.6765 West German marks, down from 1.6848 marks on Wednesday. But the dollar gained slightly against the yen, closing at 144.89 yen, up from Wednesday's 144.45 yen.
And the pound closed at $1.6840, up from Wednesday's $1.6791.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.4920 Swiss francs, down from 1.5010; 5.6940 French francs, down from 5.7215; 1,245.75 Italian lire, down from 1,251.75, and 1.1866 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1870.

HEADLINE: Two Media Companies Post Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Gannett Company reported yesterday that its profit rose 8.1 percent in the fourth quarter, and Knight-Ridder Inc. reported a 36 percent increase in net income.
McGraw-Hill Inc. reported a loss of $98.3 million for the quarter as a result of previously disclosed plans to take unusual charges.
Gannett said that despite a weakening economy, its earnings increased partly because of its diverse holdings. 
The Arlington, Va., company, which publishes USA Today and 81 other daily newspapers, said it earned $127.4 million, or 79 cents a share, for the 1989 quarter, compared with $117.8 million, or 73 cents a share, for the 1988 period.
Fourth-quarter revenue rose 7 percent, to $968.6 million, from $905.3 million in the 1988 quarter.
For the year, Gannett earned $397.5 million, or $2.47 a share, up 9.3 percent from $364.5 million, or $2.26 a share, for 1988. Operating revenue for 1989 rose 6 percent, to $3.52 billion, from $3.31 billion for 1988.
The company said advertising revenue from USA Today rose 13 percent for the quarter. It did not report earnings results from the newspaper, but Sheila Gibbons, a spokeswoman, said it had an unspecified loss. She said the newspaper expects to post its first annual profit in 1990.
Shares of Gannett fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $40,125, on the New York Stock Exchange,
 
Knight-Ridder
Knight-Ridder, based in Miami, said its net income totaled $62 million, or $1.18 a share, up from $45.6 million, or 82 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter. Earnings from continuing operations rose to $55.1 million, or $1.05 a share, from $42 million, or 76 cents a share.
Fourth-quarter revenue rose 5.8 percent, to $607.8 million, from $574.7 million a year earlier.
For the year, the newspaper and information services company said its earnings totaled $247.2 million, or $4.71 a share, up 58 percent from $156.4 million, or $2.76 a share.
Earnings from continuing operations rose to $179.8 million, or $3.43 a share, up from $146.8 million, or $2.59 a share. The 1989 results included a gain of about $30 million from the sale of a Pasadena, Calif., newspaper. The income reflected extraordinary credits of $7 million, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $66.9 million, or $1.27 a share, for the year.
Knight-Ridder owns 29 daily newspapers, including The Miami Herald, The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Detroit Free Press.
Knight-Ridder's shares rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $53.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
McGraw-Hill
McGraw-Hill said its fourth-quarter loss was in contrast to earnings of $55 million, or $1.13 a share, in the comparable period of 1988.
The latest loss reflects a charge of $152 million after taxes, reflecting a realignment of operations, write-downs associated with Data Resources and other units, the shutdown of its general books unit and reserves for severance payments associated with the elimination of more than 1,000 jobs.
Fourth-quarter revenue rose 8.2 percent, to $518 million, from $479 million for the 1988 quarter.
For the year, McGraw-Hill said it earned $47.8 million, or 98 cents a share, down from $185.5 million, or $3.83 a share, for 1988. Revenue for 1989 rose 6.9 percent, to $1.79 billion, from $1.67 billion for 1988.
McGraw-Hill shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $56.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Herbert Whyman, 76, A Real-Estate Lawyer

 BODY:
Herbert Whyman, a Manhattan lawyer for more than half a century, died of bladder cancer on Wednesday at his home in Roslyn Heights, L.I. He was 76 years old.
Mr. Wyman, who specialized in real-estate law, was a graduate of City College and the Fordham Law School. He became a partner in the Manhattan firm of King, Frank & Whyman in 1939 after serving for three years as a staff attorney to the board that drafted a new administrative code for New York City.
The firm, later Frank & Whyman, was dissolved in 1980 and Mr. Whyman became counsel to Moroze, Sherman, Gordon & Gordon, where he remained until his death.
In the late 1970's Mr. Whyman was counsel to the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, an antipoverty organization in Brooklyn. Earlier, when he lived on the West Side of Manhattan, he was a director of the Councl for Community Action. After moving to Roslyn in 1949, he was a director of the Roslyn Economic Opportunity Council, which sponsored urban renewal.
Mr. Whyman is survived by his wife, the former Betty Price; two sons, Dr. Andrew, of San Francisco, and Dr. John, of Wellesley, Mass; a brother, Martin, of Hollywood, Fla., and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Bennett Doubts Value of Drug Education

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
William J. Bennett, the nation's drug policy director, raised questions today about the effectiveness of drug education programs and said children were more likely to respond to aggressive law enforcement and assured punishment.
In testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Mr. Bennett rejected the argument espoused by leading Democrats and many outside experts that education was the major solution to the nation's drug problem. He offered an unsparing portrait of young drug abusers as knowing users, not innocent victims.
 
Position Is Challenged
''Should we have drug education programs or should we have tough policy?'' asked Mr. Bennett, who was Secretary of Education in the Administration of Ronald Reagan. ''If I have the choice of only one, I will take policy every time because I know children. And you might say this is not a very romantic view of children, not a very rosy view of children. And I would say, 'You're right.' '' 
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, one of several committee members who challenged Mr. Bennett's position, said: ''I continue to be deeply concerned that the Administration underestimates the importance of treatment and education. We know that education can inoculate children against drug abuse.''
In response, Mr. Bennett asserted: ''I do not agree with Senator Kennedy's statement that you can inoculate children against drug abuse by education. I think that statement is refuted every day of the week. If there were a seminar or course which could inoculate, we would have put it in long ago.''
Acknowledging his very strong feelings on the subject of drug education, Mr. Bennett went on to say that the problem was not a failure to inform children about the drug problem.
''Look,'' he said, ''if ignorance is the problem, knowledge is the cure. I don't believe that for a large number of kids out there who use drugs, that ignorance is the problem.''
Some drug experts argue that there has been too little scientific evaluation of drug education programs to learn their value, and they say the Bush Administration has not provided enough money for such research.
 
Sought a Cut in Funds
Mr. Bennett sought a cut in drug education funds when he was Secretary of Education under Mr. Reagan, and he has sometimes been skeptical about the value of such programs. But his comments today were among his bluntest on the topic. Despite that, the drug plan proposed by President Bush last week called for increased spending on drug education programs.
At one point in his appearance before the committee, Mr. Bennett described drug education as ''a helpful auxiliary,'' but he said a better deterrent would be ''some palpable reason in front of them that something will happen if they take drugs.''
Responding to that, Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, said: ''You, today, have described education as a helpful auxiliary in the battle against drugs. I think it is much more than a helpful auxiliary.''
The debate over drug education came at the first of a series of Congressional hearings on the Bush drug strategy. The hearing was marked by an angry clash between Mr. Bennett and Mr. Kennedy, who criticized the drug chief for failing to advocate the prohibition of semiautomatic pistols favored by drug dealers.
Mr. Kennedy repeatedly pressed Mr. Bennett on why the Administration had not clamped down on importing of semiautomatic pistols. Last year, he noted, Mr. Bennett played a major role in barring the import of many foreign-made semiautomatic assault rifles.
''Has the White House told you to be quiet?'' Mr. Kennedy asked.
''No,'' Mr. Bennett replied sharply.
''Well,'' the Senator said, ''why are you quiet then with regards to these semiautomatic weapons that have all of the fire capability of those which are being banned at the present time?''
 
'Don't Know About Guns'
At one point, an agitated Mr. Bennett conceded, ''I don't know a damn thing about guns.''
In response to Mr. Kennedy's repeated questions, Mr. Bennett replied: ''The world is awash in guns, Senator. This is a cheap symbolic victory you're interested in. It has nothing to do with the real world.''
Mr. Kennedy replied: ''I reject that. You advocated the ban, and now you're saying it's a cheap trick!''
Despite his bitter exchanges with Mr. Kennedy, Mr. Bennett's appearance before the Judiciary Committee was relatively cordial. The committee chairman, Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, who last week released his own drug plan, complimented Mr. Bennett's approach. But he said there needed to be more emphasis on hard-core drug users as well as ridding the Andean nations of their economic dependence on the coca crop from which cocaine is derived and offering more comprehensive drug education.
Mr. Bennett responded that the Administration had proposed more than ever for drug education. The Bush drug plan for the fiscal year 1991 calls for $617 million for drug prevention and treatment programs in the Department of Education, an increase from $562 million this year and $376 million in the fiscal year 1989. By contrast, Mr. Biden has proposed spending $1.135 billion in the fiscal year 1991 for drug education.
While he agreed that sanctions were important, Mr. Biden said that with current spending, no more than 40 percent of the grade school students can be in drug education programs on a regular basis.
''So this isn't arguing about whether we should have the sanction side,'' he said. ''It's a question whether education works at all.''
''Yes, it works some,'' Mr. Bennett replied.
Although he raised doubts about the effectiveness of drug education, Mr. Bennett was unusually optimistic about prospects for progress in fighting drugs.
''The war is by no means over,'' he said, ''but it is clearly winnable.''

HEADLINE: Jackson Asked Help for Donor, U.S. Aides Say

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson repeatedly sought meetings with Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp last year on behalf of an important Jackson fund-raiser and housing financier whose company has become the subject of an investigation by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, agency officials said today.
The officials said Mr. Jackson pressed Mr. Kemp to meet with A. Bruce Rozet, a California housing investment executive, who was under pressure from H.U.D. to clean up slum conditions. ''There were lots of phone calls; there was a full-court press,'' , a senior H.U.D. official said, as Mr. Jackson sought to help Mr. Rozet clear up mounting problems with two of Mr. Rozet's federally subsidized projects in Tulsa, Okla.
 
Crucial Time for Jackson
On Thursday, H.U.D. suspended the company of which Mr. Rozet is president, the Associated Financial Corporation of California, from future dealings with the housing agency. The agency said the company and affiliates were under investigation for ''irregularities of a serious nature'' involving their operations. 
The details of Mr. Jackson's effort on behalf of Mr. Rozet at H.U.D., which were disclosed today in The Washington Post, came at a crucial time, just as the former Democratic candidiate for President was engaged in deliberations over his political future.
Mr. Jackson left today for South Africa, which last month granted him permission to enter the country for the first time. Mr. Jackson, who hopes his visit will coincide with the release from prison of the jailed black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, is leaving behind a storm of speculation over whether he will run to succeed the District of Columbia's beleaguered Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr. The Federal Election Commission is reviewing Mr. Rozet's role in financing Mr. Jackson's 1988 Presidential campaign. The Post reported today that Mr. Jackson's campaign ''was released from a $30,000 debt'' at a Los Angeles hotel in which Mr. Rozet had an ownership interest and that the Jackson campaign had failed to report this as required by law.
 
Reduction Called a Discount
A Jackson aide, Frank Watkins, said in a statement that the Presidential campaign organization had not taken improper contributions from the hotel, the Hollywood Roosevelt.
Mr. Watkins declined to respond to questions about Mr. Jackson's dealings with the housing department.
Mr. Rozet, in a telephone interview from California, said The Post's account failed to make clear that the $30,000 reduction in the Jackson campaign's hotel bill was actually a discount.
The campaign incurred about $75,000 in bills at the hotel, Mr. Rozet said, but the bill was ultimately settled for $45,000.
The campaign had orginally been charged a full rate but was entitled to a bulk or corporate discount rate in line with the hotel's normal policy for such customers, Mr. Rozet said.
Questions about Mr. Rozet's role as a Jackson fund-raiser arose as Mr. Rozet's troubles increased at H.U.D. Since last summer, department investigators have been examining the agency's relationship with Mr. Rozet's company ''from every angle,'' a senior H.U.D. official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
 
Nation's Largest
Associated Financial Corporation has headquarters in Santa Monica and is the nation's largest investor in federally subsidized projects for low- and middle-income residents. The company has sold limited partnerships in about 45,000 apartments backed by H.U.D. and manages some of those units through a separate company.
Senior officials of the housing department, all Republican political appointees, confirmed today that Mr. Jackson sought meetings on Mr. Rozet's behalf both in letters and by telephone.
The officials said they were unaware of Mr. Rozet's problems with the housing department until last summer, when Associated Financial's name surfaced in Federal investigations into political abuses of the department's Moderate Rehabilitation program for subsidized properties under Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Housing Secretary under Ronald Reagan.
Many properties controlled by Associated were enrolled in the program, which was intended to resuscitate low-income projects that had encountered financial problems.
''Jackson kept wanting to come in and meet with him,'' one official said. ''It wasn't until we got into the mod rehab stuff and this name Rozet came up that we said to ourselves, hey, wasn't this the guy Jackson was pushing?''
Mr. Rozet said today that he accompanied Mr. Jackson to one hand-shaking session with Secretary Kemp last spring. But he said he ''never requested Jesse to discuss anything with Kemp'' at that session, and said little if anything while he was there.
 
Asked Tulsa Involvement
He confirmed that he asked Mr. Jackson to become involved in one of the Tulsa apartment projects. Tenants there opposed plans by H.U.D. officials to raze it, he said, and he appealed to Mr. Jackson ''for the tenants' benefit.''
But H.U.D. officials said Mr. Rozet hired an Oklahoma lawyer for the tenants, who then asked H.U.D. to grant new subsidies to Mr. Rozet's company so the apartments could be remodeled.
Mr. Rozet, a 61-year-old Los Angeles resident, has held fund-raising affairs for Mr. Jackson's campaigns and said today that he had also given a birthday party for the candidate.
In 1969, Mr. Rozet resigned the top post of a Beverly Hills conglomerate, the Commonwealth United Corporation, after entering a series of unsuccessful business deals.
 
Barred From Securities Dealing
His next venture, the Income Equities Corporation, sold more than $60 million in subsidized housing tax shelters before being accused of fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission and California regulators. The Federal housing department foreclosed on several of the company's projects in the mid-1970's. Mr. Rozet signed an agreement in 1977 that barred him for life from acting as a broker-dealer of securities.
Mr. Rozet later amassed thousands of units of subsidized housing during Jimmy Carter's Presidency and came under H.U.D. investigation at the time but was not charged with wrongdoing.
The company revived its ties with H.U.D. under the Reagan Administration, when it built its current base of 45,000 units. H.U.D. records show that Mr. Rozet had used the Thomas T. Demery, the Assistant Secretary for Housing at that time, as a reference.
Although Mr. Jackson pressed the President Bush's housing chief, Mr. Kemp, to meet with Mr. Rozet, Mr. Kemp refused, and Mr. Rozet and an aide eventually did meet with the housing department's general counsel, Francis A. Keating, to review the projects.
Mr. Keating said today that he was ''unimpressed'' with their presentation and later ordered H.U.D. to take over the projects.
H.U.D. officials in Oklahoma barred a subsidiary of Mr. Rozet's company from doing business in the state.
Mr. Keating, who said that he visited the projects and that they looked ''like the battle of Verdun,'' added that to his knowledge, Mr. Jackson played no role in arranging his meetings.
 
Role in Hotel Ownership
The hotel involved in the assertions about campaign contributions is owned by a partnership, and a corporation that is half owned by Mr. Rozet has a 2 percent interest in the partnership, Mr. Rozet said. The corporation, one of two general partners, oversees the operation of the hotel. Hotel officials, including John Eleftheriou, the controller, referred questions about the matter today to Mr. Rozet's company.
It is not uncommon for suppliers and campaign organizations to have disputes over billings, and businesses like hotels or telephone companies can provide discounts to campaigns as long as similar discounts are available to other customers, said Fred Eiland, a spokesman for the Federal Election Commission.
Even if the matter proves to be a violation of Federal regulations, it is unlikely to be judged major by itself. Campaigns often report their tangled finances inaccurately, and violations generally are regarded as serious only when repeated errors or large-scale fraud are discovered.
A statement by Mr. Jackson's Presidential campaign said that the ''committee reaffirms that to the best of its knowledge it has always operated within the spirit and letter of Federal Election laws.''

CORRECTION-DATE: February 3, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - FinalFebruary 5, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday, and a correction in this space yesterday referring to it, misstated the measurement by which the 286 computer chip processes data. It does so in bundles of 16 bits, not bytes or characters. A bit is the smallest unit of information; eight bits equal one byte, the minimum necessary in a computer to define a character (like a letter or a number). The more powerful 386 chip processes data in 32-bit bundles.
A front-page article in some copies on Saturday about the Rev. Jesse Jackson and one of his campaign fund-raisers misstated the history of Mr. Jackson's requests for permission to visit South Africa. The error also appeared in an Associated Press report published on Jan. 9 about a proposed visit by Mr. Jackson. South Africa granted Mr. Jackson a visa for a two-week visit in 1979.

HEADLINE: Chancay Journal;
Where Ancient Infants Lie, Grave Robbers Thrive

BYLINE: By James Brooke, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHANCAY, Peru

 BODY:
Dressed in safari shorts and a bikini top, the young Italian tourist could barely conceal her disappointment as she stood on a sand dune.
''A baby won't have any necklaces,'' she predicted, watching two Peruvian laborers as they lifted a small cotton-wrapped mummy from its centuries-old resting place.
Indeed, after unwrapping the ancient burial shrouds, the diggers found only the tiny yellowed bones of an Indian child who probably lived in this coastal valley 800 years ago.
''Maybe the next one will have a necklace,'' a grave digger said as his colleagues turned to a more promising spot, leaving the wind to scatter fragments of ancient baby bones across the desert like potato chips. 
 
A Growing Market
Cursed with one of Latin America's lowest standards of living and blessed with one of its richest archeological lodes, Peru has emerged as major center for grave robbery.
The practice, which has existed since the Spaniards arrived seeking gold almost 500 years ago, has gained momentum in recent years with a growing international market for pre-Columbian ceramics.
''The search for treasure in the tombs - for an El Dorado - really started with the Spanish in the 16th century,'' Federico Kauffmann Doig, a leading Peruvian archeologist, said in an interview in Lima, Peru's capital, 40 miles south of here.
''But as the prices of ceramic antiquities have gone up on the international markets, the practice has become widespread.''
In the most famous recent case, grave robbers protected by sentries and working round the clock looted a trove of gold and ceramics from a 1,500-year-old pyramid tomb in Sipan, about 450 miles northwest of here.
 
Appeared in United States
By the time an archeological expedition sponsored by the National Geographic Society discovered the theft, in early 1987, the grave robbers had tunneled within three feet of what society experts now call the richest tomb in the Western Hemisphere: dozens of finely crafted jewelry pieces and more than 1,200 ceramic vessels with painted scenes of the Moche people, who lived along the desert coast about 1,500 years ago.
Since then, however, pieces from the Sipan tomb and from the Moche culture have appeared in the United States. Last June, David Rand Swetnam, a California dealer in Peruvian pre-Columbian antiquities, was convicted in a Federal court of fraudulent customs declarations and sentenced to six months in jail.
The United States signed a United Nations convention banning the international transfer of cultural property. In addition, the Peruvian authorities hope that President Bush will shortly sign an emergency measure banning the import of looted Sipan artifacts.
To encourage American collectors to return Peru's antiquities, a six-room museum of pre-Columbian textiles, ceramics and jewelry will open this April in the residence of Peru's Ambassador in Washington.
 
Seeking Lost Treasures
''It will be an instrument for the recuperation of lost treasures,'' Cesar G. Atala, the Ambassador, said of the new Peruvian Cultural Center.
The trail starts in places like this small down-at-the-heels coastal city, a one-and-a-half-hour drive from Lima on the Pan American Highway. Most residents derive their income, maybe $800 a year, from offshore Pacific currents, rich in fish.
Some residents grow corn, cotton and flowers on fertile river valleys, which have been a source of sustenance for millenniums. Others turn to the Lauri desert valley, mining the ancient Indian tombs as if they were a God-given natural resource.
Grave robbing has become so common that the practice has entered the vocabulary of Spanish spoken here. From the Quechua word ''huaca,'' or ''holy burial site,'' Peruvians now call ancient ceramics ''huacos.'' A grave robber is a ''huaquero.''
 
'Cordless Mummy Detector'
''This is my cordless mummy detector,'' a local huaquero said before throwing his weight on the wooden handle of a five-foot-long iron rod, pushing it deep into fine sand. ''When it hits hollow, it's a tomb.'' The rods frequently pierce ceramic pots, but the prospectors find that the system is more rewarding than the painstaking approach of professional archeologists. Working the outer edge of the valley, which has become pockmarked from digging, the team of four prospectors found three graves in six hours.
Local residents cannot remember when rain last fell in the desert. Consequently, freshly opened tombs often reveal remarkably well preserved textiles, tree leaves and human hair.
 
Swallowed Up by Incas
''The fabrics are conserved as if they were woven yesterday,'' said Francisco Iriarte Brenner, a Peruvian archeologist who excavated in the Chancay area in the 1960's.
Dating from 1200 to 1400 A.D., the graves are of a people who were later swallowed up by the Inca Empire. Chancay pieces are to be displayed in Peru's new Museum of the Nation, which is to open in Lima this spring.
''Today, the huaqueros practice archeology as if it were a sport,'' Mr. Iriarte said. ''Each tomb is like a sheet of paper in a history book. Once it is torn out, it cannot be replaced.''
In the past, the police regularly broke up antiquities markets that the huaqueros held every weekend at the edge of the expanse of tombs here. But in recent years, the police have been stretched thin to fight the rising threat from leftist guerrillas.
 
Tourism Has Dropped
''You would need two Peruvian armies to protect all our sites,'' said Mr. Iriarte, general director of patrimony at the National Institute of Culture, the state committee that has the legal responsibility for registering all pre-Columbian antiquities to prevent their export. ''It's like cocaine - if there were no buyers, there would be no huaqueros.''
Tourism has dropped here in recent years, meaning that there are fewer buyers in Peru for the antiquities.
''The terrorism has destroyed tourism here,'' a huaquero said.
The main guerrilla group, the Shining Path, is a highly violent movement marked by a deep streak of xenophobia. Recruiting largely from impoverished Indian and mixed race Peruvians, Shining Path leaders charge that outsiders have not respected Peru's indigenous culture.

HEADLINE: South Africa's New Era;
Excerpts From Address By de Klerk on Change

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an address by President F. W. de Klerk today before the South African Parliament, as provided by the South African Consulate in New York. The official Government translation was used for portions of the speech that were delivered in Afrikaans.
The general election on Sept. 6, 1989, placed our country irrevocably on the road of drastic change. Underlying this is the growing realization by an increasing number of South Africans that only a negotiated understanding among the representative leaders of the entire population is able to insure lasting peace.
The alternative is growing violence, tension and conflict. That is unacceptable and in nobody's interest. The well-being of all in this country is linked inextricably to the ability of the leaders to come to terms with one another on a new dispensation. No one can escape this simple truth. On its part, the Government will accord the process of negotiation the highest priority. The aim is a totally new and just constitutional dispensation in which every inhabitant will enjoy equal rights, treatment and opportunity in every sphere of endeavor - constitutional, social and economic. ... 
 
Relating to the World
The Government is prepared to enter into discussions with other southern African countries with the aim of formulating a realistic development plan. The Government believes that the obstacles in the way of a conference of southern African states have now been removed sufficiently.
The season of violence is over. The time for reconstruction and reconciliation has arrived.
Recently there have, indeed, been unusually positive results in South Africa's contacts and relations with other African states. During my visits to their countries I was received cordially, both in private and in public, by Presidents Mobutu, Chissano, Houphouet-Boigny and Kaunda. These leaders expressed their sincere concern about the serious economic problems in our part of the world. They agreed that South Africa could and should play a positive part in regional co-operation and development. ...
 
Limiting Death Penalty
The Government decided . . . that the death penalty should be limited as an option of sentence to extreme cases, and specifically through broadening judicial discretion in the imposition of sentence; and that an automatic right of appeal be granted to those under sentence of death.
Should these proposals be adopted, they should have a significant influence on the imposition of death sentences on the one hand, and on the other should insure that every case in which a person has been sentenced to death will come to the attention of the Appellate Division.
These proposals require that everybody currently awaiting execution be accorded the benefit of the proposed new approach. Therefore all executions have been suspended and no executions will take place until Parliament has taken a final decision on the new proposals. In the event of the proposals being adopted, the case of every person involved will be dealt with in accordance with the new guidelines. ...
 
Committing to Talks
I committed the Government during my inauguration to giving active attention to the most important obstacles in the way of negotiation. Today I am able to announce far-reaching decisions in this connection. ...
The steps that have been decided are the following:
The prohibition of the African National Congress, the Pan-Africanist Congress, the South African Communist Party and a number of subsidiary organizations is being rescinded.
People serving prison sentences merely because they were members of one of these organizations or because they committed another offense which was merely an offense because prohibition on one of the organizations was in force will be identified and released. Prisoners who have been sentenced for other offenses such as murder, terrorism or arson are not affected by this.
The media emergency regulations as well as the education emergency regulations are being abolished in their entirety.
The security emergency regulations will be amended to still make provision for effective control over visual material pertaining to scenes of unrest.
The restrictions in terms of the emergency regulations on 33 organizations are being rescinded. The organizations include the following: National Education Crisis Committee, South African National Students Congress, United Democratic Front, Cosatu, Die Blanke Bevrydingsbeweging van Suid-Afrika.
The conditions imposed in terms of the security emergency regulations on 374 people on their release are being rescinded and the regulations which provide for such conditions are being abolished.
The period of detention in terms of the security emergency regulations will be limited henceforth to six months. Detainees also acquire the right to legal representation and a medical practitioner of their own choosing. ...
On the state of emergency I have been advised that an emergency situation, which justifies these special measures which have been retained, still exists. . . .
It is my intention to terminate the state of emergency completely as soon as circumstances justify it and I request the co-operation of everybody toward this end. ...
 
Releasing Mandela
With the steps the Government has taken, it has proven its good faith and the table is laid for sensible leaders to begin talking about a new dispensation, to reach an understanding by the way of dialogue and discussion.
The agenda is open and the overall aims to which we are aspiring should be acceptable to all reasonable South Africans.
Among other things, those aims include a new, democratic constitution; universal franchise; no domination; equality before an independent judiciary; the protection of minorities as well as of individual rights; freedom of religion; a sound economy based on proven economic principles and private enterprise; dynamic programs directed at better education, health services, housing and social conditions for all.
In this connection Mr. Nelson Mandela could play an important part. The Government has noted that he has declared himself to be willing to make a constructive contribution to the peaceful political process in South Africa.
I wish to put it plainly that the Government has taken a firm decision to release Mr. Mandela unconditionally. I am serious about bringing this matter to finality without delay. The Government will take a decision soon on the date of his release. Unfortunately, a further short passage of time is unavoidable.
Today's announcements, in particular, go to the heart of what black leaders - also Mr. Mandela - have been advancing over the years as their reason for having resorted to violence. The allegation has been that the Government did not wish to talk to them and that they were deprived or their right to normal political activity by the prohibition of their organizations.
Without conceding that violence has ever been justified, I wish to say today to those who argued in this manner:
The Government wishes to talk to all leaders who seek peace. The unconditional lifting of the prohibition on the said organizations places everybody in a position to pursue politics freely. The justification for violence which was always advanced no longer exists.
These facts place everybody in South Africa before a fait accompli. On the basis of numerous previous statements there is no longer any reasonable excuse for the continuation of violence. The time for talking has arrived and whoever still makes excuses does not really wish to talk.
Therefore, I repeat my invitation with greater conviction than ever: Walk through the open door, take your place at the negotiating table together with the Government and other leaders who have important power bases inside and outside of Parliament.
Henceforth, everybody's political points of view will be tested against their realism, their workability and their fairness. The time for negotiation has arrived.

HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA'S NEW ERA;
BUSH WOULD WEIGH EASING SANCTIONS

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 2

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he would consider a relaxation of American sanctions against South Africa provided that the Pretoria Government follows through on promises to free Nelson Mandela and remove restrictions on the black population.
''I think when people move in the right direction, it's certainly timely to review all policy,'' Mr. Bush said. ''But we haven't gotten into any specifics on that at this point. I mean, we want to see the policy initiatives go forward, and the release of Mandela. But I think everybody's viewing it now as positive.'' 
The President made his remarks to reporters as his plane took off from Andrews Air Force Base this morning. Mr. Bush spent the day visiting university laboratories in Raleigh, N.C., and Knoxville. The trip was meant to highlight the Administration's interest in competitiveness and technology.
Democrats in Congress have been pushing for tougher sanctions against South Africa and are unlikely to accept relaxation of the existing restrictions on trade and investment unless the South African President, F. W. de Klerk, takes further steps to dismantle apartheid in the very near future.
 
Sanctions Date to 1986
The sanctions were written into law in 1986, when Congress approved them over President Reagan's veto. In the 1988 Presidential campaign, Mr. Bush defended Mr. Reagan's position, saying, ''The political and economic effects of the sanctions have been marginal to negative.'' Today he said: ''I am one who has not favored additional sanctions, and so I'm perfectly willing to review things as new developments take place.
''I'm sure that we'll have a lot of debate and discussion inside the Administration as to what the next move by the United States ought to be.''
The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said the steps announced today by Mr. de Klerk were ''positive signs of change in South Africa.''
''I commend President de Klerk for his statement that negotiations are the only route toward a lasting peace,'' the Maine Democrat said. ''While the legal pillars of apartheid remain firmly in place, it is my hope that President de Klerk's speech represents a true first step toweard meaningful negotiations.''
 
Disappointment on Prisoners
Representative Howard Wolpe, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa, also welcomed Mr. de Klerk's speech. He said it would improve the climate for negotiations in South Africa.
But Mr. Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat, expressed disappointment that at least 1,000 political prisoners would remain in detention. He also said it was unfortunate that Mr. de Klerk was retaining ''major elements'' of the state of emergency declared in 1986.
Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Wolpe both said South Africa had not satisfied the statutory conditions for repeal of the American sanctions. Under the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act of 1986, sanctions will terminate if Pretoria releases all political prisoners, ends rule by emergency decree, lifts the ban on leading anti-apartheid groups, ends residential segregation laws and agrees to enter ''good-faith negotiations'' with South African blacks.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;
Baker and West German Envoy Discuss Reunification Issues

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
With the momentum seeming to build for unification of the two Germanys, the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, met today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to coordinate positions on the German question before Mr. Baker meets with Soviet officials next week.
After their two hours of talks Mr. Genscher said tonight that he and Mr. Baker agreed that a unified Germany would have to continue to be aligned with NATO, but that no NATO troops would be extended into what is now East Germany.
''We were in full agreement that there is no interest to extend the NATO area of defense and security toward the East,'' Mr. Genscher said as Mr. Baker stood by his side.
Mr. Genscher's meeting with Secretary Baker reflects the speed with which the German unification issue is evolving now that East Germany's Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, after meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has proposed a reunited German state, provided that it is neutral. That proposal, made on Thursday, has already drawn a cool response from Bonn and Washington. 
And today the Soviet leaders, perhaps worried that the drive for unification is proceeding too quickly, proposed an international referendum on the issue by the World War II Allies.
Administration officials are concerned that with East German elections set for March 18, East Germany will soon have a democratically elected government that will almost certainly begin seeking unification. They want to be certain that West German policies are meshing with their own.
 
'Faster Than We Anticipated'
One Administration policy maker said: ''Obviously things have started moving faster than we anticipated last November, when everyone was talking about a measured pace. History just didn't give us that. It looks like we're heading down the fast track. We had hoped to see deeper economic and political integration of West Germany within the European Community before all this happened, but that just is not going to be.''
Administration officials are not taking a public position on the form of German unity, in part because they still have no consensus and in part because they do not want to get ahead of the East German elections, or appear to be imposing a blueprint before the German people themselves have voted.
Nevertheless, Administration officials say they are are looking closely -and, it appears, quite sympathetically - at Mr. Genscher's latest unification proposal, which aims at countering Mr. Modrow's plan for a ''united fatherland,'' governed from Berlin but removed from both NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
Mr. Genscher has suggested that a reunited Germany would remain a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization but that the territory of East Germany would not be drawn into the Western alliance's military structure. In that East German territory, where the Soviets currently have 390,000 troops, Moscow would be able to continue its military presence.
 
Reunited but Still in NATO
Mr. Genscher's proposal, though, envisions much lower levels of both Soviet and American troops and suggests that they would engage in regular confidence-building exchanges.
While not endorsing the Genscher proposal, Administration officials acknowledge that the idea would take into account the security concerns of both the Soviets and Germany's other neighbors. It would also strengthen the ability of a new Germany to remain in NATO.
''The problem,'' said one State Department official, ''is that the plan sounds great on paper but how do you actually get it implemented - especially when you are dealing with a nervous and potentially unstable Soviet Union?''
Regarding Mr. Baker's trip next Wednesday to Moscow, the State Department announced today that the Secretary had been invited to testify before the International Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet on Feb. 10. It will be the first time an American official has ever testified before a committee of the Soviet Parliament.

HEADLINE: BUSH APPOINTS 13 TO SCIENCE PANEL

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 2

 BODY:
President Bush, citing the challenge posed by foreign technological competition, today appointed the 13 scientists and engineers who will make up his long-promised President's Council of Advisers on Science and Technology.
The council, which Mr. Bush vowed to create in a campaign speech two years ago, will report directly to him and is intended to function on the same high level as, for example, the Council of Economic Advisers.
Chosen as its chairman was D. Allan Bromley, who was already serving as Assistant to the President for Science and Technology. 
The appointments came on a day when Mr. Bush flew to university laboratories here and in Raleigh, N.C., to highlight the Administration's hopes for enhancing national technological performance.
In Raleigh, at North Carolina State University's Surface Science Laboratory, Mr. Bush said: ''Competiveness. Education. We've got to keep our competitive edge. It all boils down to that.''
 
U.S. as 'the Defending Champion'
Later, in a speech before students at the University of Tennessee, where he toured the school's Environmental Biotechnology Program, Mr. Bush mused that ''some wonder if America has lost its competitive edge.''
Citing Japan's launching of a lunar rocket last week, the President noted that ''they forget that 26 years ago today - long before you were born - America's Ranger 6 landed on the moon.''
''The United States is the defending world champion,'' he added. ''But we have to defend our title day by day, week by week, year in and year out.''
In his budget for the 1991 fiscal year, sent to Congress this week, Mr. Bush proposed $71 billion for research and development, an increase of $4.5 billion over the 1990 level.
Science policy experts in Washington noted that with his new council, Mr. Bush has now raised science policy advice to the highest level since the Kennedy Administration. But they said it remained to be seen whether the new advisers would have any real influence on policy matters.
The President is to meet with the council for the first time at Camp David this weekend.
In addition to Mr. Bromley, the members are:
 
Dr. Norman E. Borlaug, a Nobel laureate and professor of agriculture at Texas A & M University.
 
Dr. Solomon J. Buchsbaum, senior vice president for technology systems at Bell Laboratories.
 
Dr. Charles L. Drake, a professor of earth sciences at Dartmouth University.
 
Dr. Ralph E. Gomory, President of the Sloan Foundation, and formerly vice president for science and technology at I.B.M.
 
Dr. Bernadine Healy, a cardiologist of the Cleveland Clinic Foundation.
 
Dr. Peter W. Likins, an engineer and president of Lehigh University.
 
Dr. Thomas E. Lovejoy, a conservation biologist and assistant secretary for external affairs at the Smithsonian Institution.
 
Dr. Walter E. Massey, a physicist and vice president of the University of Chicago.
 
Dr. John P. McTague, a physicist and vice president of research for Ford Motor Company.
 
Dr. Daniel Nathans, a Nobel laureate and molecular biologist at the Johns Hopkins Medical School.
 
Dr. David Packard, an engineer and chairman of the board of Hewlett-Packard Company.
 
Dr. Harold T. Shapiro, an economist and president of Princeton University.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports a Slight Decrease in the Jobless Rate

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Aided by exceptionally mild weather, job growth quickened in January and the unemployment rate edged down one-tenth of a point to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
Combined with some other recent data, this first broad look at economic performance last month suggested that the seven-year business expansion is intact despite a persistently weak manufacturing sector.
The Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress that she saw ''no evidence'' in the employment figures to signal recession. The only signficant job losses, she said, were in automobile production, and many of these workers have already returned to work at plants that have reopened after temporary shutdowns. 
 
Jobs Increase of 275,000
The number of jobs, as determined by the department's monthly survey of business payrolls, increased by 275,000 in January, considerably more than expected.
In all, according to the department's survey of households, which is separate from the payroll survey, 119,560,000 Americans had jobs last month - 117,863,000 civilians and 1,697,000 domestically stationed members of the armed forces. The unemployed numbered 6,535,000 people, for a jobless rate of 5.2 percent. The unemployment rate for civilians alone was unchanged, at 5.3 percent.
The initial reaction to this news in financial markets was that the economy might be rebounding so smartly from a fourth-quarter growth rate of just five-tenths of 1 percent that further cuts in interest rates were unlikely. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, contended that the chance of near-term recession had waned to 10 or 20 percent. Next week, the Federal Reserve is to hold a key strategy-setting meeting.
On closer inspection, however, the employment figures are considerably less robust.
About 80 percent of the increase was accounted for by unusual surges in construction and retail trade. Construction benefited from unseasonably warm weather and retailing from a post-Christmas decline that was less than normal, apparently because fewer salespeople were hired for the holidays. Construction gained 104,000 jobs last month and retailing gained 117,000; the changes were greater than those the department normally takes account of in its adjustments for winter weather and post-holiday slumps.
 
Auto Jobs Off by 90,000
This was partly offset by a drop of 90,000 automobile-manufacturing jobs that spilled over into fabricated metals, rubber and other related industries. The fact that many of these people have already gone back to work mitigated fears that might have been set off by a 112,000 decline in overall factory jobs, the 10th monthly decline in a row.
Another bit of reassurance came from the department's diffusion index, which registers the percentage of industries increasing employment. Last month, 59.5 percent of 349 industries were increasing jobs, up from 52.6 percent in December. For 141 manufacturing industries, there was a rise to 48.2 percent from 45.7 percent.
Nonetheless, some analysts remained concerned, especially about manufacturing. Akira Akiyama, chief economist at Sanwa Bank, described the January figures as ''worse than expected'' and predicted the Federal Reserve would move to cut the overnight interest rate one-quarter of a point by month's end. But while the data reflect what he called a ''weakening economy,'' Mr. Akiyama said a recession was not in sight.
Rudy Oswald, director of economic research for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., agreed that weakness was largely confined to manufacturing while most other sectors ''show continued growth'' in employment.
 
Gains in Service Employment
Once again, it was services that provided the job gains, with 50,000 added in health, 25,000 each in transportation and wholesale trade and 10,000 in finance, insurance and real estate in addition to the gain in retail trade.
The total of 282,000 new service jobs, however, was slightly offset by a loss of 7,000 goods-producing jobs.
A month ago, jobs for December were estimated to have climbed 142,000, as measured by the survey of businesses, but this has now been revised to a gain of 96,000.
Meanwhile, the survey of households, on which the overall jobless rate is calculated, showed few significant changes as the labor force, people with jobs or actively seeking them, fell 152,000 while employment fell 28,000. This cut the ranks of the jobless by 124,000, to 6,535,000.
At 5.2 percent, the overall unemployment rate has returned to the level of September and October after edging up to 5.3 percent for November and December. The Labor Department considers monthly changes of less than two-tenths of a point statistically insignificant.
The number of people working part time because they could not find full-time jobs rose 180,000 last month to 5 million, the report showed. A year ago, the number of partly unemployed was 5.1 million.

HEADLINE: It's Time That Winds of Change Reached India

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Violent Protests Growing in Kashmir'' (news article, Jan. 10) and ''A Vale of Tears and Anger: Anti-Indian Militancy Is on the Rise in Kashmir'' (news article, Jan. 14), regarding Pakistan's ''alleged involvement'' in Punjab and Kashmir, tell only part of the story. More than a territorial dispute between India and Pakistan, the problems of Punjab and Kashmir have important human dimensions. The Muslims of Kashmir, approximately 76 percent of the state's population, and the Sikhs, who make up 70 percent of Punjab, have been struggling for freedom, an inalienable human right enshrined in the United Nations Charter and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. 
Punjab and Kashmir were integral parts of the Sikh Commonwealth, which was annexed by the British in 1848. Their independence would usher in an era of a South Asian commonwealth of free nations, replacing the imperial systems that India and Pakistan inherited from British colonialism in 1947. Those systems have been reinforced with lethal military machines, which consume scarce economic resources of the subcontinent and unleash massacres.
Pakistan used brute force attempting to crush Bengali nationalism in 1971, but failed. India is repeating the attempt in the Punjab and Kashmir. If the winds of freedom could shatter the Berlin Wall and rock the foundations of the Soviet Empire, the imperial systems of the subcontinent - more brutal than British colonialism - are not likely to last out the 20th century.
The Western news media and academia can help a great deal to prevent genocide in the subcontinent. South Asians have experienced a series of bloodbaths - the partition of the subcontinent in 1947, the two Kashmir wars in 1947-48 and 1965, the Bangladesh war in 1971, the massacres in Nagaland, Punjab, Assam, Kashmir and Sri Lanka, to mention a few.
It is time for the ruling establishments of India and Pakistan to stop this insane military response to national aspirations in the subcontinent. They should learn from Mikhail S. Gorbachev and understand that the era of colonial empires and dynastic rules is coming to an end along with the 20th century. We have a golden opportunity to enter into the 21st century as free nations, respecting one another's rights to fundamental freedoms and human dignity. True, idealism is easier said than done, but cynicism provides no hope for the future of humanity.
 
GURCHARAN SINGH
 New York, Jan. 14, 1990
 
The writer teaches international relations and law at Marymount Manhattan College.
