HEADLINE: It's Time That Winds of Change Reached India;
Start With an Election

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The political crisis in Kashmir, a strategically situated region that shares borders with India, Pakistan and China, must be of concern to all who care about human rights and freedom. In the last month alone, more than 30 civilians are reported killed, hundreds are in jail, most cities and towns are under curfew.
In 1947, when India became independent from British rule, it made a commitment to the people of Kashmir for a United Nations-supervised plebiscite. Before Kashmir's annexation by India, it was a princely state with a majority Muslim population ruled by a Hindu king under the protection of British colonial rule. The Kashmir issue has been debated in the United Nations many times. India and Pakistan have fought wars over the territory. In the United Nations, though all parties to the dispute agreed to a plebiscite, it never took place. Instead a United Nations observer force and about 50,000 Indian troops are stationed in Kashmir, much against the will of the people. 
India, the largest democracy in the world, continues to govern Kashmir undemocratically. Free elections do not take place in Kashmir; leaders and governments have been created and removed by India without regard for the popular will. Kashmir, once a breadbasket for the neighboring areas, is now a net importer of consumer and agricultural products. The real economic base of the area has not expanded.
What has expanded is the depth and breadth of corruption and nepotism. Whenever a voice is raised against such governance, it is dubbed traitorous, separatist and fundamentalist. The Government of India, and some in the news media, continue to portray the events in Kashmir as an uprising of religious forces against secular India.
India has a moral obligation, which it must fulfill, toward the Kashmiris. We must urge the United States Government to take steps to insure that pledges made by responsible governments in a world forum are honored. Kashmiris must have their human rights, beginning with free and fair elections.
 
RAFIQUE A. KHAN
 Los Angeles, Jan. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1990

 BODY:

The Savings Industry
 Bright Banc Savings Association was acquired by Banc One in a deal that is expected to cost the Government an estimated $1.4 billion. [Page 37.] Federal regulators seized Centrust Savings Bank in Miami, saying management was operating irresponsibly and had dissipated assets by buying art, yachts and Oriental rugs. [37.] American Savings Bank reported a healthy profit for 1989, providing the Robert M. Bass Group that acquired the unit with a good return on its $400 million investment. [37.] 
 
 
 
The Economy
 The nation's unemployment rate fell one-tenth of a point, to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported. The unemployment rate for civilians alone was unchanged, at 5.3 percent. Business payrolls jumped 275,000 in January, considerably more than expected.
About 80 percent of the increase was accounted for by unusual surges in construction and retail trade. Construction gained 104,000 jobs last month and retailing gained 117,000. This was partly offset by a drop of 90,000 in automobile manufacturing jobs. [Page 13.] Factory orders posted a second straight increase in December, rising 1.9 percent because of a surge in orders for civilian aircraft, the Commerce Department said. [41.]
 
 
 
Companies
 Genentech will sell a 60 percent stake to the large Swiss health-products company, Roche Holding Ltd., for $2.1 billion. [1.] Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores have a new chief executive. Allen I. Questrom, the president and chief executive of Neiman Marcus, has decided to give up those posts to head the two retail chains. [37.] Chrysler shut the doors of its crumbling Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in downtown Detroit for the last time amid an atmosphere of uncertainty among laid-off auto workers. [37.] Harold C. Simmons raised his stake in Lockheed to 18.94 percent and said he might try to acquire the military contractor. [38.]
 
 
 
Markets
 The stock market finished the week on a strong note on moderately higher volume. The Dow jumped 16.44 points, to 2,602.70, after being more than 30 points higher about 1 P.M. For the week, the Dow rose 43.47 points, or 1.7 percent. [40.] Treasury bond prices tumbled, while notes and bills posted smaller losses. [40.] The dollar closed higher in light, uneventful trading. [45.] Oil futures prices rallied, with gasoline leading the way. [45.]
 
International
 President Bush nullified the sale of an American company that manufactures airplane parts to a military-related agency of the Chinese Government. [1.] Economists and business executives warn that Mexico's fragile economic recovery is threatened by Government spending on new social programs and a scarcity of private investment funds. [37.] Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady predicted that similar debt agreements like that structured for Mexico would soon be devised for other developing nations. [39.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 A patent that prevents the browning of fresh shrimp may work on apples, bananas and potatoes. Patents. [38.]
 Taxpayers should see what changes they can make in their personal finances to reduce their tax bill next year. Your Money. [38.]

HEADLINE: Chrysler Workers Skeptical On Detroit Plant's Last Day

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation shut the doors of its crumbling downtown Jefferson Avenue assembly plant for the last time today, amid an atmosphere of uncertainty among laid-off auto workers. The 3,500 workers are awaiting completion of a factory less than a mile from the old one, and many hope to get jobs there.
Until recently, many of the workers at the Jefferson Avenue factory, which was built in 1907, had expected to continue on the job until the new plant opens in late 1991 and then move to fill the roughly 2,500 job openings there.
But the subcompact Omni and Horizon cars, built for a short while in the old plant, have sold poorly during the last year. And Chrysler served notice that it would no longer continue to produce what it could not sell. 
Last week, representatives of the United Automobile Workers made a final plea to Chrysler managers to let them help search for a way to revive the subcompact sales, but to no avail. The Omni and Horizon design is 12 years old, and most analysts regard it as technologically outmoded.
Now, faced with the reality of 18 months and possibly longer without a job, many workers are wondering whether the new $1 billion assembly plant will ever provide significant employment, even though Chrysler insists it will begin assembling a new line of utility vehicles by 1992.
One reason for worker skepticism is that Chrysler's future has been clouded recently by slow sales and plunging profits. The sales slump, to be sure, is an industrywide problem. But its impact is magnified at Chrysler, because it is weaker financially than its principal domestic rivals, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.
Chrysler's latest troubles, reflected in Thursday's announcement of a permanent shutdown of a car plant in Fenton, Mo., only deepen the gloom among Jefferson Avenue workers. The experienced work force, accustomed to Detroit's streamlining, tends to be skeptical that there will be jobs for them in the new plant.
''With 23 years of seniority I don't think they're going to want us,'' said Tony Young, who is 44 years old. ''They think we're too set in our ways. Right now, though, I can't take a pay cut. I'm going to school and I'm going to wait'' for the new plant to open. Mr. Young, who has been laid off for a year, collecting about 95 percent of his pay as unemployment benefits, said he earned about $30,000 annually.
Chrysler officials insist that doubts about the the company's future are exaggerated. Lee A. Iacocca, chairman and chief executive, begins a six-city national tour on Feb. 21 to meet with analysts, dealers, suppliers and others in an effort to ''show there is a bright future full of innovative products,'' a spokesman said.
The Jefferson Avenue work force has a great emotional, as well as financial stake, in seeing the company and the new plant thrive, said Charles Ryan, 64, vice president of U.A.W. Local 7. ''Chrysler wouldn't have survived in 1980 without the U.A.W. working to secure the loan guarantee,'' he said. ''I spent 38 years here, the best part of my life, and I want to see the plant through to make sure it's built in the city, not in some cornfield in Ohio or Kentucky.''
 
Japanese Methods
 In recent years, Japanese auto makers have opened plants in this country, called transplants, that have hired younger, nonunion work forces and located in rural areas of the Midwest. The transplants have used production systems similar to those used in Japan, which stress worker involvement in decisions concerning quality control, productivity and business issues such as parts design.
Following in the footsteps of the Japanese, Chrysler workers at Jefferson Avenue for the last few years have been introduced to innovative work-place practices, such as more exacting quality-control procedures and the elimination of restrictive work rules. But all too often, some workers said, Chrysler supervisors have continued to stress speed and meeting production goals at the expense of quality.
''They say they want everything to be right, but if you stop the line to fix it you're fired,'' said Ted Grant, an assembler with 20 years' experience.
With the closing of Jefferson Avenue, only one car plant remains in the city of Detroit - the Hamtramck assembly plant operated by G.M.

HEADLINE: Bass-Owned California Unit Has Big Profit

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The once-troubled American Savings Bank today reported a large profit for 1989. The California savings and loan institution was acquired by the Robert M. Bass Group just over a year ago in one of the Government's biggest bailout deals.
American Savings said it earned $214.2 million for the year, giving the Bass group a healthy return on its $400 million investment.
The results provided fresh evidence of the improving business climate for savings institutions that have emerged in good health, by dint of Government rescues or superior management, from the industry's crisis. 
But American's profits are also likely to provoke renewed complaints in Congress that regulators gave away too much in selling a number of troubled institutions in California, Texas and other states in late 1988.
The Bass group acquired American Savings at that time by putting $350 million into the institution as fresh capital and spending another $50 million in acquisition costs. In return, the Government stripped the bank of nearly all of its troubled assets and provided tax concessions.
As part of the deal, the Government effectively retained a 30 percent stake, allowing it to share in any earnings or in profits from any eventual sale of the institution. At the time of the deal, the Government estimated its aid to American Savings at $1.7 billion.
The profits of American Savings are not actually being distributed to the Bass group or the Government. Instead, the company is retaining most of its earnings to add to its base of capital, which is its cash buffer against losses. Some of the earnings will be set aside for the Government under an arrangement that frees American Savings, which must report its profits to the Government each year, from paying Federal taxes but requires it to make payments to an arm of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
Before the acquisition, the institution, then known as the American Savings and Loan Association, was the nation's largest troubled savings unit. It had a huge portfolio of foreclosed real estate and billions of dollars of mortgage-backed securities that were worth less than they cost.
Healthy institutions are now able to attract deposits at lower interest rates than in previous years as public confidence in their financial strength and in the Government's insurance fund slowly returns since tougher regulations were imposed. The takeover of hundreds of insolvent institutions has also reduced competition.
American Savings finished the year with $16.3 billion in assets, up 6 percent from a year earlier.
Mario J. Antoci, chairman and chief executive of American Savings, attributed the strong earnings to the sharp drop in interest rates the institution must pay to attract deposits and to deep cuts in operating expenses. The results were also helped by falling interest rates last year that allowed the company to sell many of its loans at a profit.
 
'Junk Bond' Setback
 But the gains were partly offset by an ill-timed program to buy $500 million worth of high-yield ''junk bonds.'' After the purchases last spring, before Federal legislation barred such investments, the market dropped sharply and a number of the bonds' issuers had trouble paying interest. American Savings set aside $65 million for possible losses and was forced to write down the value of its holdings by $100 million.
Of the $214 million in profits, about $53 million came from gains on sales of loans. In a telephone interview, Mr. Antoci said the company sold most of its fixed-rate mortgages, which had exposed the company to a high degree of interest-rate risk, and replaced them with adjustable-rate mortgages, which are less risky.
Mr. Antoci said the company had reduced the rate it pays for deposits to the same level as the state's healthiest savings units. Before the Bass deal, American Savings, like other troubled institutions, had been forced to offer more for its deposits than its healthy competitors.
Mr. Antoci said that reducing its interest rates to depositors had caused significant net reductions in deposits last year but that the situation was now stabilizing.
 
Lower Operating Expenses
Mr. Antoci, who was hired away by the Bass group from Home Savings of America, the nation's largest savings institution and one considered among the best managed, said American Savings had reduced its operating expenses by consolidating duplicate functions into single offices and cutting personnel.
Expenses as a percentage of total assets, he said, declined to 1.82 percent, from 2.23 percent a year earlier.
After accounting for the profits it made last year, American Savings now has enough capital to meet all three tests of financial strength mandated by the industry bailout legislation signed by President Bush in August.

HEADLINE: Ohio Bank Buys Unit In Texas

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Bright Banc Savings Association, one of the largest troubled savings institutions controlled by Federal regulators, was acquired today by the Banc One Corporation of Ohio, regulators announced late today. The deal is expected to cost the Government $1.4 billion.
The addition of Bright Banc would give Banc One's Texas unit $11 billion in assets, strengthening its fourth-place position in Texas banking, behind top-ranked NCNB Texas, Texas Commerce Bancshares, which is No. 2, and the First City Bancorporation of Texas.
Bright Banc, once a giant with more than $5 billion in assets, was controlled by H. R. (Bum) Bright, the former majority owner of the Dallas Cowboys, until it became insolvent a year ago and was taken over by the Government. 
In the deal announced today, Banc One agreed to pay $45 million in cash for $1.7 billion of Bright's assets. It will assume all $2.7 billion of Bright's deposits and other assets, which include 48 branches, mainly in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.
 
Federal Agency Involved
 The Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency dealing with insolvent savings institutions, agreed to advance $1.1 billion to Banc One's Texas unit, called Bank One, Texas. The agency will also keep $1.4 billion of Bright Banc's troubled assets.
In a similar deal, NCNB Texas agreed last October to pay $129 million in cash to acquire $3.5 billion in deposits from University Federal Savings in Houston, and assume $750 million in assets.
That transaction gave NCNB the option to return to the Federal agency any assets in the $750 million portfolio that NCNB considered too risky to own. In fact, NCNB handed back most of the properties.
In the Bright Banc deal, Banc One accepted a review period of 45 days that limits its option to return undesirable properties.
Steven Katsanos, a spokesman for the trust agency, said Banc One was able to accept a more limited option to return assets because it and other bidders had more time to analyze the loan portfolio at Bright Banc than bidders had in the auction for University Federal.
Protection from acquiring bad assets is important to bidders like NCNB and Banc One. The companies relied on large sales of their common shares to help finance their expansion into Texas, and they want to assure investors that they have not assumed huge new risks in adding to their deposit base and retail network, said Frank W. Anderson, an analyst with Stephens Inc., in Little Rock, Ark.
 
A Special Procedure
 Bright Banc is one of the largest institutions the Resolution Trust agency has sold using its ''clean bank'' procedure, in which troubled assets are retained by the regulators for sale to private bidders.
Mr. Bright, a devoted believer in the Texas economy, formed Bright Banc through the merger of Dalllas Federal Savings and Loan and Texas Federal Savings late in 1985. Before the deal was completed, loan losses mounted and oil prices plunged, but Mr. Bright did not withdraw.
 
Powerful Ohio Bank
 Banc One, a strong regional banking company based in Columbus, Ohio, had assets of $26.6 billion at the end of 1989. Today's transaction is the second deal within the last year in which it has acquired a large Texas financial institution that had been brought to its knees by mounting losses on real estate loans.
Last June, Banc One acquired 20 banks controlled by Mcorp, then a large Dallas-based banking company. The deal gave Banc One the fourth-largest banking network in the state, with $13.1 billion in assets, and a pledge of an estimated $2 billion in Government aid.
Under the ''clean bank'' procedure, Banc One's Texas operation has transferred more than $2 billion in troubled loans to a separate subsidiary, with collections managed by it but losses covered by the Government. Such loans are not counted among the assets of Bank One, Texas.
Robert D. Rieke, an analyst at Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc., a brokerage in Dallas, said that other bidders for Bright Banc included NCNB Texas; First Gibraltar Bank; a group headed by Lewis Ranieri, chairman of United Savings in Houston, and Citicorp.
 
Plans for Expansion
 John B. McCoy, chairman and chief executive of Banc One, said, ''This acquisition will allow us to expand our retail distribution system immediately, which is a primary objective.''
In addition to the 48 branches, Banc One acquired a loan portfolio that includes $900 million of residential mortgages; $659 million in cash and securities; $145 million in consumer loans to 15,000 customers, and $20 million in various assets.
Some analysts have said that the Government should encourage bidders to acquire troubled assets, even though it would mean committing bilions of additional taxpayer funds, because private owners have proved more adept at selling depressed properties than the Government.
Paul M. Horvitz, a finance professor at the University of Houston, said such actions by Resolution Trust could eventually save taxpayers more money than the agency's plan to sell what analysts estimate will eventually amount to $300 billion in problem assets.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Planning Now For '90 Taxes

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
As taxpayers go over their financial records in this tax season, they should see what changes they can make in their personal finances to reduce their tax bill a year from now.
''Don't wait until the end of the year to do tax planning,'' said George E. L. Barbee, executive director of Price Waterhouse's Consumer Financial Institute, ''because opportunities will slip by you.'' He cited five areas where, he said, many taxpayers should focus their attention immediately.
Children. ''If you have kids over 14, consider transferring money to them'' to be used for their college educations, he said. If assets are put in the names of children under age 14, the first $500 is tax-free and the next $500 is taxed at 15 percent -meaning there is a total tax of only $75 on the first $1,000 of income - but anything over that is taxed at the parents' marginal rate, usually 28 percent or 33 percent. 
Once the child becomes 14, however, any interest, dividends or capital gains are taxed at the child's rate, rather than the parents', generally meaning college funds can accumulate with a lower tax bite. There is one important caveat: Children have legal control over assets in their names. So transfers should be made only to responsible children.
Alternative Minimum Tax. ''There are more and more surprises here,'' Mr. Barbee said. ''Even middle-income people'' are finding themselves subject to the A.M.T. since the Tax Reform Act of 1986 narrowed the spread between the A.M.T. rate of 21 percent and the top regular tax rate, he said. Particularly affected are people in states with high taxes like New York and Massachusetts, and it is important to assess the situation early in the year, when finances can be reorganized to work within the A.M.T. rules, if necessary.
The A.M.T. is actually a parallel tax system that is intended to insure that everyone with fairly substantial income pays some tax. While the rate is lower than regular tax rates, the A.M.T. denies a number of tax breaks that are allowed in the regular system. For example, some municipal bonds become taxable. And when appreciated securities are donated to charity, unlike the regular tax system, deduction is allowed only for their cost, not their market value.
''Make your calculation now and see if you are likely to be in the A.M.T. for 1990,'' he said, ''and then go over strategies with your accountant. You may want to do the opposite from normal,'' accelerating income into a year when it will be subject to a lower rate and deferring deductions like the charitable contribution to a year when they will do more good. 401(k) Plans. People who work for companies that match employee contributions should make the maximum contribution allowed to these tax-deferred retirement plans, Mr. Barbee said. ''Even if there is not a match, it should still be a high priority,'' he said. For 1990, the legal maximum will be just short of $8,000, he added, and many companies allow employees to make quarterly adjustments. Similarly, people with self-employment income should put money into tax-deferred Keogh retirement plans, he said.
Schedule C. This part of the tax form is for self-employment income - and related deductions. ''There are lots of family situations in which money is being expended because people want to get back into the work force or start their own business,'' Mr. Barbee said, ''but they think of it as an extension of the household expenses'' and fail to take advantage of Schedule C deductions.
A business has a couple of years to begin earning money, he said, ''so characterize it as a business as soon as possible,'' when money is spent to enroll in relevant courses, for example, or to buy a computer or to entertain potential business contacts. He cautioned that the home office was often a signal for auditors, and that business deductions would have to be well documented and legitimate.
Debt Management. Four types of interest are recognized by current tax law - mortgage interest, which is deductible for primary and secondary residences; business interest, deductible for those who materially participate in the business; investment interest, generally deductible to the extent it is offset by investment income, and consumer interest, which is only 20 percent deductible for 1989 and will be only 10 percent deductible for 1990.
As taxpayers assemble their 1989 interest expense records, they should try to eliminate consumer interest expenses in 1990, Mr. Barbee said. One way, if they have sufficient dividend and interest income, is to use a margin loan to pay off consumer loans or credit cards. Because interest on home equity loans of up to $100,000 is fully deductible, many people take out home equity loans to pay off credit card balances or auto loans.
''I'm cautionary about home equity loans,'' Mr. Barbee said. ''It's risky to put your home into play to pay for a fun trip or even a car.''

HEADLINE: Orders Rose At Factories In December

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Factory orders posted a second consecutive increase in December, rising 1.9 percent because of a surge in orders for civilian aircraft, the Commerce Department said today.
Orders had grown by 2.4 percent in November and were down one-tenth of a percent in October.
A key component, durable goods orders, gained 3.2 percent in December after an increase of 4.8 percent in November. Aircraft orders were sharply higher in both months, partly because a long strike at the Boeing Company ended in late November. 
 
Various Categories
 Excluding transportation, factory orders rose two-tenths of 1 percent in December after an increase of 1 percent in November.
For all of 1989, factory orders grew 6.4 percent, to $2.83 trillion, after a 9.7 percent 1988 rise, department officials said.
The 1.9 percent December rise was above the expectations of economists, who had generally foreseen a 1.1 percent increase from November levels.
The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, told Congress this week that a healthy backlog of orders for aircraft was one of the bright spots for the economy at a time when business activity was generally weaker.
Mr. Greenspan said the economy was experiencing a ''temporary hesitation'' before continuing to grow, but he conceded there was a risk that a recession could develop.
The department said orders in December for nonelectrical machinery fell 4.7 percent after rising 5.6 percent in November. Electrical machinery orders were up 5 percent after a 7.3 percent rise in November.
Transportation equipment orders rose by 11.2 percent in December and 10.8 percent in November. Within that category, orders for aircraft and parts soared 23.6 percent in December and 22.8 percent in November.
 
A Loss of Factory Jobs
 Earlier today, the Labor Department said in its January report on unemployment that there were 112,000 fewer manufacturing jobs in January than in December.
It was the 10th consecutive monthly drop in factory jobs and one more sign of waning vigor in the industrial sector.
Economists said they expected the Federal Reserve Board to monitor the employment report closely for signs of more economic weakening. The Fed can act to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates.
Excluding the volatile military category from both months, total factory orders rose 2.5 percent in December after a 1.8 percent gain in November.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Prices in Strong Rally As Gasoline Sets the Pace

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Expectations of strong gasoline demand early this summer fueled a strong rally in oil futures prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
On other commodity markets, copper and precious metal futures rose; livestock and meat futures were mixed, and grains and soybeans were mixed.
Gasoline futures posted the sharpest gains, settling 0.83 cent to 1.9 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in March at 64.22 cents a gallon; West Texas Intermediate crude oil finished 0.32 cent to 0.44 cent higher, with March at 23.02 cents gallon; heating oil was 0.77 cent to 1.52 cents higher, with March at 58.26 cents a gallon. 
Yesterday's strong rally after modest gains on Thursday suggests the petroleum markets are beginning a new upward push, analysts said. The strongest gains yesterday were in contracts for April and May delivery, indicating that petroleum dealers are locking in supplies for the late spring and early summer, when the vacation season begins and gasoline consumption swells.
Strong gasoline demand tends to spur United States crude futures prices because West Texas Intermediate crude, the type traded in New York, is more easily refined into high-quality gasoline than some other varieties, Randolph Donney, a research analyst with Elders Futures Inc. in New York, said.
Copper futures rose sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York amid signs of tightening supplies. The Comex reported a decline of 561 tons in its warehouse stocks of copper from Thursday to yesterday, bringing the level down to 6,621 tons, the lowest this year.
Warehouse stocks reported weekly by the London Metal Exchange have also been falling recently, and Monday's report is expected to show a further decline of 2,000 to 5,000 tons, analysts said.
Demand for copper is apparently picking up after slackening in December.
Some buying may also have stemmed from brighter economic perceptions because of the stock market's recent gains and yesterday's U.S. unemployment report, which showed no change in the jobless rate.
Copper is heavily used in the construction industry, making the market extremely sensitive to economic news.
Copper finished 1.9 cents to 2.35 cents higher, with February at $1.015 a pound.
Gold futures settled 10 cents to 20 cents higher on the Comex, with February at $418.20 a troy ounce; silver was a cent higher across the board, with March at $5.338 a troy ounce.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading While Gold Also Advances

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher yesterday in light, uneventful trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices rose, with most of the gains in overseas dealings. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold gained 20 cents to close at $418.20. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $418.50 a troy ounce, up 85 cents from late Thursday. 
The dollar rose after the release of a Labor Department report showing the nation's unemployment rate fell slightly to 5.2 percent in January. The Government said nonfarm payrolls increased by 275,000, but the manufacturing sector lost 112,000 jobs.
''It was a mixed bag,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at Chicago-based MMS International. ''People who remain bearish on the dollar cite the manufacturing number; people who are bullish look at the payroll gains.''
Traders reason that a steady unemployment rate will keep the Federal Reserve from easing interest rates. High interest rates make United States securities more attractive to foreigners, who need dollars to make such investments.
Most of the day's activity centered on the dollar and the West German mark, both of which moved in a wide range. When the dollar reached a high against the mark at around midday in New York, ''the market took profits in the dollar and immediately bought marks again,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
''Every time the dollar goes up'' against the mark, he said, ''people jump right in and buy marks.''
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.95 Japanese yen, up 0.45 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 145.35 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 145.50 yen, up from 144.89 yen Thursday.
In London, the British pound was unchanged at $1.6820. The pound was also unchanged in New York, where it finished at $1.6840.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.6830 West German marks, up from 1.6765; 1.4920 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.7160 French francs, up from 5.6940; 1,251.00 Italian lire, up from 1,245.75, and 1.1885 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1866.

HEADLINE: A Reward Fit for a King

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2

 BODY:
Wayne Gretzky has paid off handsomely for Bruce McNall, and the Los Angeles Kings' owner is going to return the favor to the National Hockey League's career scoring leader.
McNall has extended Gretzky's contract by two years, at $4 million a year. The extension runs through the 1997-98 season. All told, Gretzky's 10-year deal will be worth $31.32 million.
McNall also increased Gretzky's salary in the final two years of his original eight-year pact by $500,000 a year and added $3 million in deferred salary.
''It's something we've been working on a long time,'' McNall said Thursday night. ''Last year was a spectacular year; this year's even better economically for us. We've done virtually twice as good as I had anticipated.''
McNall said the club lost $5 million in 1987-88, the season before acquiring Gretzky, and made $6 million in 1988-89. The Kings finished fourth in the Smythe Division the season before Gretzky was acquired from the Edmonton Oilers and were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs. Last season, they finished second and advanced to the second round.
Besides trading two players and three No. 1 draft choices, McNall paid the Oilers $15 million for Gretzky.
''My job is to play hockey, not to worry about the contract,'' said Gretzky, who is 29 years old. ''All I had to do was sign it and I did.''
The new deal increases his base pay to $2.5 million in 1994-95 and 1995-96. He will receive $1 million in deferred salary for this season through 1995-96. McNall said Gretzky would receive a flat $4 million for the 1996-97 and 1997-98 seasons.

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
New Politics of Social Security May Lead to Sharper Scrutiny

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security tax and Richard G. Darman's counterproposal to shield the pensioners' nest egg from the hungry gaze of Congress have so far generated more shock than debate.
President Bush probably expressed the only deeply felt view in official Washington when he stated flatly, ''The last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security.''
But even analysts who see the controversy as political theater at its most cynical, as a game over who will take the blame for the size of the Federal deficit, believe that a re-examination of the economic underpinnings of Social Security is overdue. No budgetary sleight-of-hand, they agree, can assure a comfortable retirement for American workers now in their 30's and 40's. Unless Americans manage to build a more productive economy, the Government's promise to pay generous pensions to that generation will be difficult to keep. 
 
Greatest Strength and Weakness
The great political strength and economic weakness of Social Security, notes Henry J. Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution, is that ''people treat it as if it were a giant version of the Prudential Insurance Company.'' And nowhere is that misconception better illustrated than in the changes to the Social Security system in 1983.
Until the late 1970's, Social Security covered all its outlays from payroll taxes. Robert J. Myers, a former deputy Social Security commissioner, notes that the system instituted in the Depression and amended by Congress a half-dozen times since was never quite sound. The average single male retiring in 1975, for example, had paid in just a third of the taxes needed to finance his pension, even counting accumulated interest on his payroll taxes.
But to the casual observer, Social Security seemed self-financing because many workers were supporting few retirees. In 1950 there were 16 jobholders for each beneficiary, and as late as 1965 the ratio was as high as 4 to 1.
The demographic worm turned in the 1970's; for the first time, revenue fell behind outlays and the specter of insolvency loomed. Congress could have resolved the ensuing political crisis overnight by abandoning the pay-as-you-go principle and financing social insurance from general Government revenue the way most affluent nations do. But that would have violated the deeply felt belief that America's retirees had paid their own way in the past and should continue to pay in the future.
The bipartisan 1983 fix, largely engineered by Senator Moynihan, a New York Democrat, and the former Senate majority leader, Robert Dole of Kansas, accelerated scheduled payroll tax increases, delayed cost-of-living increases and raised the age at which today's young workers would be eligible for tomorrow's pensions. The package, it was believed, would make the system self-financing through the middle of the 21st century.
 
Little Thought About Surplus
But to cover future obligations, the Social Security Trust Fund would have to take in far more cash than it paid out for many decades. The Trust Fund balance, accumulated in Government bonds, would rise to six times the annual outlay by the year 2030 - an incredible $4 trillion in 1990 dollars. And at the time of the 1983 compromise, Senator Moynihan admits, little thought was given to the political or economic implications of the surplus.
Even before surplus payroll revenue started pouring in, Congress and Ronald Reagan's Administration had committed the Government to returning most of the money in the form of large income tax cuts enacted in 1981. Total Federal revenue as a percentage of national income remained virtually unchanged.
But the proportion of revenue coming from the regressive payroll tax rose from 23 percent in 1981 to 29 percent in 1989. Three out of four families with a taxpaying breadwinner now pay more in Social Security taxes than Federal income taxes, when employer Social Security contributions are counted along with the deduction that shows on the paycheck.
To Senator Moynihan, this increased tax burden on lower- and middle-income families is ''totally unacceptable.'' But it is another consequence of the Reagan tax shuffle - what Mr. Moynihan calls ''the dirty little secret'' - that most worries economists and perplexes the public.
The Social Security Trust Fund is a bookkeeping concept. Surplus revenue, $55 billion in 1989 and climbing, is indeed credited to the fund and used to buy Government bonds that pay interest. But the fund owns no tangible assets, no gold or factories or office buildings that could someday be traded for the goods and services pensioners need.
That fact in itself, Mr. Aaron of the Brookings Institution argues, should not be troubling. The most conservative private pension systems and insurance companies operate the same way, accumulating paper claims on future income. What troubles Mr. Aaron and others is that productive assets are not being set aside elsewhere in the economy to ease the burden of caring for people now in their 30's and 40's when they reach retirement age. ''What you should care about,'' Mr. Aaron says, ''is national savings. If you were getting it somewhere else, it would not matter.''
 
Deficits Are Masked
In fact, the annual Social Security surplus masks chronic deficits in the rest of the Government's budget. That has reduced the pressure to raise income taxes or cut Federal spending, which could make available the money to meet the needs of retirees who are now in their 30's and 40's.
It is hard to imagine that Washington would turn a cold shoulder to the righteous claims of 80 million retired voters. But it is also hard to imagine how the politics of paying out more a $700 billion annually in pension benefits would play out in a world of slow economic growth and tight government budgets.
Senator Moynihan's response to the low-savings predicament is to roll back the payroll tax to a level that would maintain about a balance of just one year's outlays. If future generations are rich enough to afford generous pensions for their parents, he reasons, they will finance them on a pay-as-you-go basis. Meanwhile, Washington will be stripped of the budgetary fig leaf provided by rapidly accumulating surpluses in the Social Security Trust Fund.
Robert Ball, a former Social Security commissioner who helped devise the 1983 compromise, sees nothing wrong in principle with this approach. But he said he ''would like a reserve with a real cushion'' - perhaps one and a half year's projected outlays rather than just a year's worth.
But to Ralph Bryant, a specialist in economic stimulation at the Brookings Institution, the Moynihan approach is ''like being stuck in three feet of mud at the edge of a swamp, and driving in deeper to dramatize the seriousness of the problem.'' Any additional tax cuts, he argues, would further increase private consumption at the expense of savings and investment.
 
Darman Offers Alternative
Mr. Bryant estimates that the payroll tax rollback would raise long-term interest rates between one and a quarter and one and three quarter percentage points and increase the Federal deficit by $120 billion by 1994. If that reduced the growth rate of the economy by a modest one-quarter percent, annual national income would be about a trillion dollars smaller by the year 2030.
Mr. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, offers an alternative, the Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund, which would seemingly meet everyone's concerns. The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law would be extended beyond 1993. But starting in 1993, Congress would also be required to make deposits into a separate fund. The annual deposit, equal to the Social Security surplus after a three-year phase-in, would be put toward reducing the Federal deficit.
In essence, the law would obligate Congress to run an overall budget surplus equal to the Social Security surplus. And that would free equivalent value of economic resources for private investment and growth.
But Senator Moynihan is not impressed. How convenient, he says, to ''start having integrity after the next Presidential election.'' Others wonder whether a Government that has wrestled in vain with a chronic budget deficit for years could be trusted to honor an agreement to run a $4 trillion dollar budget surplus over the next 40 years.
For the moment, however, the only proposal in the form of a bill is the Moynihan payroll tax cut. Mr. Aaron's ''nightmare'' is that Congress will pass it and make up the modest first year revenue loss of $6 billion by also cutting the capital gains tax, which is intended to promote business investment and economic growth .
Would Congress respond to fears that big budget deficits are imperiling Social Security by increasing the deficit still more? As Senator Moynihan says, ''People who pierce the veil of money rarely return with their senses intact.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid Just Dribbles In to Nicaragua Opposition, but the Sandinistas Profit

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
A $9 million program to assist the opposition in Nicaragua's presidential election has encountered so many delays and bureaucratic obstacles that a Nicaraguan Government agency has received more money than the coalition of opposition parties supported by the United States, American officials say.
The problems are attributable to obstacles put up by the Sandinista Government and to the caution of American officials in the aftermath of the Iran-contra scandal, the officials say.
Nicaragua, unlike the United States, permits foreign contributions to political parties in national elections. But under Nicaraguan law, foreign contributors must pay a 50 percent tax to the Nicaraguan election agency, the Supreme Electoral Council.
 
'Considerable Irony'
Roger F. Noriega, the official at the United States Agency for International Development who supervises the Nicaraguan election program, said the electoral council had access to $1,371,000 in American money. But he said the National Opposition Union, a coalition of 14 parties opposing the Sandinista Government, has received only $278,000. 
The opposition alliance, known as UNO, includes parties ranging from right-wing conservatives to socialists and Communists. Its presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, is publisher of the chief opposition newspaper, La Prensa.
''There is considerable irony,'' Mr. Noriega said. ''The Sandinista authorities have blocked UNO's access to this money, but the Nicaraguan Government has access to its share. That was the worst nightmare of many people.''
After a visit to Managua this week, former President Jimmy Carter said the Nicaraguan authorities agreed to release American funds to the opposition coalition. But only three weeks remain before the Feb. 25 election, and American officials say the Sandinistas have reneged on similar promises in the past.
 
The Program's Objective
The purpose of the aid program, as described by Congress, is ''to provide assistance for free and fair elections in Nicaragua.'' In September, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said there was an urgent need for such assistance to help register voters. But none has been used for that purpose. By the time the President Bush signed the bill into law on Oct. 21, there was only a day remaining in the the registration period.
There are two basic reasons for delays since then. The Agency for International Development and various intermediaries, including the National Endowment for Democracy and foundations associated with the Democratic and Republican Parties in this country, have been extremely cautious.
Before disbursing money, they wanted to establish strict financial controls and procedures to verify and audit all payments. A dozen auditors from Price Waterhouse and three from the United States General Accounting Office are in Nicaragua.
That caution is a legacy of the Iran-contra scandal, in which Reagan Administration officials diverted money to opponents of the Nicaraguan Government in defiance of restrictions imposed by Congress.
In addition, people involved in the election aid program say the Sandinistas have deliberately tried to block or delay the delivery of American money to opposition groups.
J. Brian Atwood, president of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, which is affiliated with the Democratic Party, said that ''in view of bureaucratic hurdles in Managua and delaying tactics by Nicaraguan authorities, we can only conclude that political decisions have been made to slow down the program.''
 
'One Delay After Another'
Paul S. Reichler, a lawyer for the Nicaraguan Government, denied that. ''The Sandinistas have not blocked or delayed receipt of the funds, but on the contrary have created special exceptions to their own laws and procedures to facilitate the timely receipt of these funds by the intended Nicaraguan beneficiaries,'' he said.
But Ted D. Morse of the Agency for International Development said the response from Managua had been ''just one delay after another.''
American officials offered these examples of problems they have faced. Wire transfers of money from the United States did not get through to Nicaragua. Checks deposited in Nicaraguan banks take weeks to clear. The Central Bank of Nicaragua told opposition groups that they could not withdraw dollars needed to pay suppliers because the currency was in Panamanian bank accounts frozen as a result of the United States invasion of Panama on Dec. 20.
Opposition groups have used American aid to buy cars, Jeeps, pickup trucks and motorcyles, but the vehicles have been held up by the Nicaraguan Government for payment of customs duties. Government offices were closed in a crucial period, from Dec. 23 to Jan. 2.
 
A Circuitous Route
American officials say that 1.7 million people are eligible to vote in Nicaragua, so the $9 million represents more than $5 for every potential voter.
The American aid follows a circuitous route to Nicaragua, through a maze of intermediaries beginning with the National Endowment for Democracy, a private, nonprofit corporation created in 1983 to promote democracy around the world.
The Federal Government has given $7.7 million to the endowment, which in turn has given a total of $5 million to the National Democratic Institute and the National Republican Institute. Of that amount, $1.8 million is for Mrs. Chamorro's coalition and $1.5 million for the Institute for Electoral Promotion and Training, which is supposed to use it for nonpartisan ''civic education'' expounding the virtues of free elections.
Nicaraguan officials argue that the separation between the 14-party coalition and the electoral institute is a subterfuge to avoid payment of the 50 percent tax on money given to the institute. The tax applies to political parties and alliances with candidates in the election.
 
What the Charter Says
The statutory charter of the endowment says, ''Funds may not be expended, either by the endowment or by any of its grantees, to finance the campaigns of candidates for public office.''
George R. Vickers, an associate professor of sociology at Brooklyn College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, who has studied the election aid program, said: ''This prohibition, while real, is more a legal distinction than a practical limitation. The distinction between nonpartisan civic and voter education programs and campaign activities is extremely difficult to discern in practice.''
The five directors of the electoral institute are all leaders of parties in Mrs. Chamorro's alliance, the National Opposition Union. Documents prepared as part of the Nicaraguan aid program say that the institute may ''employ individuals who are associated with or partisans of UNO,'' may use the coalition's equipment and may share its office space in nine regional offices outside Managua.
The American money can be used to buy typewriters, telecopiers and other office equipment; to conduct certain public opinion surveys; to hire poll-watchers; to transport voters to the polls on election day, and to encourage people to vote.
In addition to the $7.7 million given to the endowment, the Government has earmarked a total of $1.1 million for four organizations that will monitor the fairness of the campaign and the election. They are Freedom House, the Center for Democracy, the Center for Electoral Assistance and Promotion and an observer delegation led by former President Carter. The Government retains the remainder, about $200,000, to finance reviews by the inspector general of the Agency for International Development.
To date, Mr. Vickers said, the opposition has gained few tangible benefits from the American aid program. But, he said, the program has caused conflict among opposition parties vying for control of the money, has made it difficult for the opposition to raise money inside Nicaragua because of the perception that it well-financed, and has provided a campaign issue to the Sandinistas, who argue that Mrs. Chamorro would be a client of the United States.

HEADLINE: New Delhi Moves to Rein In Its Technology Chief

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The new Indian Government has moved to curb the influence of a former resident of Chicago who returned to India to give a push to the nation's modernization drive and who is now chief of India's telecommunications network.
The official, Satyen Gagaram Pitroda, has been removed from his post as Adviser on Technology Missions to the Prime Minister.
And an official investigation has begun into allegations that a technology center that he started five years ago to reduce India's reliance on foreign technology for telephone exchanges has failed.
Mr. Pitroda gave up his American citizenship to give his time and technological skills to the land of his birth. 
He is regarded as close to former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, who strongly supported his ideas and plans for modernizing telecommunications and other areas. At one point he conducted a computerized study of how Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party should be run.
''It has come as a shock to me because I see myself as a professional and not a politician,'' Mr. Pitroda said in an interview last month at his office, referring to the changes in his career.
He is still chairman of the Indian Government's Telecom Commission and Secretary of the Department of Telecommunications. His responsibilities include the development and operation of the country's telecommunications services, which have improved vastly in recent years with new technology but which still draw angry complaints of inefficiency and delays from users.
Other officials and critics said Mr. Pitroda had gone into areas with the technology missions where his work overlapped with other authorities, setting off interdepartmental tensions. The technology missions were asked by the previous Government to identify problems and advantages in its programs relating to drinking water, literacy, oil-seeds production and environment.
But it is not clear whether Mr. Pitroda, a high-profile technologist and businessman from Chicago who had prospered from developing telecommunications patents, will last a full three-year term in those posts. He is facing hostility from Cabinet Ministers who are suspicious of his assertions of success and his access to Rajiv Gandhi, whom they hold as primarily responsible the country's economic woes.
The new Government, which has held power for about a month, has not yet clearly spelled out its long-term views on high technology, although it has said it favors technology that is most appropriate for India's villages.
One of the projects that Mr. Pitroda first worked on was the development of indigenous rural telephone exchanges and city exchanges. His critics say that program has not gotten off the ground. But telecommunication officials say that more than 1,700 of those exchanges have already been installed and that 40 industrialists have been given licenses to produce them.
 
'Burned My Bridges'
''I have burned my bridges, this is my home, I have a job to do and I am not running away from my moral responsibilities,'' said Mr. Pitroda when a visitor asked him if he planned to resign his posts. He said one of the aims of his department was to increase the number of telephones in India, from the current level of 5 million to 10 million by 1995. India has a population of more than 800 million.
Under Mr. Gandhi, Mr. Pitroda said, he was sure of support. ''Now it is hard to say,'' he said. He said the option of returning to private life was always there but that he did not plan to return to the United States. Mr. Pitroda has renounced his American citizenship and resumed his Indian nationality.
Mr. Pitroda said the setbacks to his career could discourage professionals who wanted to play a specific role in the modernization of India.
''I am an outsider, I don't belong to any cadre, I am in no man's land,'' said Mr. Pitroda, who wears a grey, bushy mane of hair and a neatly trimmed beard. ''I never felt it before but now I feel it to some extent. I just want to continue doing my job until the Government decides otherwise.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: West Germany;
Bonn Balks at Soviet Plea For Vote on German Unity

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, today rejected a Soviet proposal for an international referendum on German unity and said his Government expected Moscow to help ease the process of German reunification.
''German unity is a German question,'' he said, adding that West Germany is ready to start talks ''on the specific steps leading to German unity'' immediately after free elections are held in East Germany on March 18.
Speaking to reporters after a 90-minute meeting with the East German Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, Mr. Kohl made it clear that the question of German unity had assumed greater urgency because of what he called the continuing ''mass exodus'' of East Germans to the West.
 
Effort to Slow Migration
Noting that his Government was willing to provide help ''on a new scale'' to stabilize the East German economy even before the elections, he said that ''East Germans must have the conviction that something will be resolved if the flow is to stop.'' 
In brief remarks to reporters, Mr. Modrow merely noted that the coalition government due to be formed in East Germany next week could be more broadly based than the one to emerge from the upcoming elections, but he did not address the reunification issue.
The two leaders held their third-ever meeting here today on the occasion of the World Economic Forum, an annual gathering of political and business leaders. They have scheduled fresh talks for Feb. 13 in Bonn. They are expected to announce new economic aid for East Germany at that time. Among measures reportedly being considered is adoption by East Germany of the West German currency.
 
Neutrality Plea Rejected
Addressing the World Economic Forum today, Mr. Kohl reiterated his rejection of Mr. Modrow's call last week for the neutrality of a single German state, noting that ''a united Germany in the heart of Europe should not have any special status which would isolate it.''
''We are not an island; we're not in a corner of Europe,'' he said. ''We're in the heart of Europe and we can only solve this if we see our position as a bridge. But if we make it a bridge, it must be fully integrated with Europe and not isolated.''
Asked about a proposal made Friday by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, that a referendum on German reunification be held in Europe, the United States and Canada, Mr. Kohl said this was a matter for Germans to decide. ''Nonetheless, if all Europeans were to decide, the result would be the same,'' he said. Fear, or Economic Jealousy? But while noting in his address that West Germany expected Moscow to respect ''the right of the German people to free self-determination and to facilitate the process of unification,'' Mr. Kohl seemed to emphasize in his remarks today that the world had nothing to fear from a united Germany.
''There is a difference between understandable misgivings and fears and what is disguised as fear but is really economic jealousy,'' he said. ''Anyone who talks today of a Fourth Reich in Germany has either not learned the lessons of history or is deliberately slandering the Germans.''
Mr. Kohl said West Germany unswervingly supported the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ''To us and our friends, the security alliance between Europe and North America remains indispensable,'' he said. ''This is something clearly recognized in Moscow. This also applies to the continuing major role of the United States in enhancing security on this continent.''
But he added that both NATO and the Warsaw Pact would have to review their strategies as a result of developments in Europe, focusing more on political objectives. He said a proposed summit meeting of the 35 signatories of the Helsinki Accords would be an opportunity to move toward establishing pan-European security institutions.
 
A Commitment to France
Just as he emphasized the United States role in NATO, the Chancellor underlined West Germany's close ties to France within the European Community, to which, he added, Bonn ''is and will remain firmly anchored.''
Regarding Eastern Europe, Mr. Kohl dismissed those who equated the status quo with stability. ''Nothing is more destabilizing than denial of reform,'' he explained. ''In the Europe of today, stability can be achieved only by means of consistent, forward-looking reforms.''
He said the West should channel investments and credits to Eastern Europe and relax rules on the transfer of technology to Soviet-bloc countries. The European Community should also seek new forms of association with Eastern European countries, he said.
Asserting that ''like it or not'' the question of German unity is now on the agenda, Mr. Kohl said he had no doubt that East Germany would freely choose reunification. But he stressed: ''The road to German unity is not a mechanical process that can be arranged with the help of a timetable and a stopwatch. Least of all can the rate of progress be accelerated.''
 
A Warning to Unity Opponents
Echoing positions already adopted by NATO and the European Community, Mr. Kohl said reunification should take place within the context of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which negotiated the Helsinki Accords in 1975, and of continuing arms control talks.
But he also warned that East Germans were defending the right to reunification ''with growing impatience,'' adding that it would be ''just as unhistorical and irresponsible to try to oppose their interests and wishes.'' The alternative, he said, could be a major crisis and continuation of the exodus that is ''sapping the human and economic potential of East Germany.''
Noting that 55,000 East Germans have moved to the West in the last four weeks, he said, ''What we can do now -and this is easy to say and difficult to do - is to instill hope that there will be change soon and not just when their children have grown up.''
In his address, Mr. Kohl said West Germany would never forget the role played by Hungary and Czechoslovakia last fall in allowing East German refugees to pass through their territory. He pledged that, in moments of crisis, Budapest and Prague could count on West German help.
The dominant role of Bonn throughout Eastern Europe was underlined by the fact that Mr. Kohl also met privately here today with Prime Minister Marian Calfa of Czechoslovakia and Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia, who are among government leaders attending the economic forum.

HEADLINE: CAMBODIA FACTIONS SAID TO LINK ARMIES

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 3

 BODY:
A memorandum prepared by the Cambodian Defense Ministry says the two non-Communist factions opposing the Phnom Penh Government are increasingly cooperating on the battlefield with their dominant ally, the Communist Khmer Rouge.
The document, provided to The New York Times by an opponent of American policy toward Cambodia who recently visited the country, says the three opposition factions took part in attacks on Pailin, Varin and smaller towns in Banteay Meanchey Province.
The document offers details of how Phnom Penh says the three guerrilla groups are working together tactically on the battlefield and tends to support the assertions of Western diplomats who say cooperation between the non-Communist factions and the Khmer Rouge is increasing.
Spokesmen for one of the non-Communist factions, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, deny such cooperation. But Western diplomats say the front coordinates strategy with the Khmer Rouge on battlefield objectives and shares military intelligence. 
 
Sihanouk Explains Move
Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who leads the other non-Communist faction, acknowledged coordination of military activity with the Khmer Rouge in an interview with The New York Times in Beijing in December. ''The world may condemn us,'' he said, adding that the military weakness of the non-Communists made cooperation with the Khmer Rouge necessary, however distasteful, because the world valued military strength more than moral purity.
The issue of non-Communist cooperation with the Khmer Rouge is important given a Congressional ban on the use of American funds for even indirect aid to the Khmer Rouge. American diplomats in Bangkok are sensitive to the problems raised by the cooperation and have objected to it, fearing that Congress may cut off funds for the non-Communists.
The United States, other Western nations and the non-Communist countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations support the three-party opposition coalition, but provide support only to the two non-Communist factions. The United States provides some $5 million in overt, non-arms aid to the non-Communists and $20 million to $24 million more in secret, non-arms aid, Western diplomats and American officials say. Weapons are formally paid for by Singapore.
The Cambodian memorandum was provided by Jeremy J. Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists, who recently visited Vietnam and Cambodia. Mr. Stone, an outspoken opponent of American involvement in the Cambodian war and of any arms aid to the non-Communists, requested the memorandum from the Defense Minister, Gen. Tie Banh.
 
Recognition of Hun Sen Urged
Mr. Stone advocates American recognition of the Phnom Penh Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, as the only obstacle to a return to power by the Khmer Rouge, under whose rule more than a million Cambodians died.
The American Government shuns Mr. Hun Sen's administration, which was installed by Vietnam 11 years ago after Hanoi drove out the Khmer Rouge. Washington supports Prince Sihanouk as head of state and wants a comprehensive settlement resulting in free elections supervised by the United Nations in which Mr. Hun Sen would not have an unfair advantage.
The Defense Ministry document asserts that Sihanouk forces have sometimes paid Khmer Rouge soldiers for help on the battlefield. In last month's battle for Varin, which both the Sihanouk forces and the Khmer Rouge claimed to have captured, Sihanouk forces paid $80 in Thai baht to each Khmer Rouge soldier, the document says. In a battle for the commune of Nimit, the memorandum says, Sihanouk forces paid $3,000 to Khmer Rouge division 450 for battlefield help.
A spokesman for the Sihanouk faction in Bangkok denied these assertions, calling them ''rubbish'' and ''defamation.''
''The Khmer Rouge don't need any money from us,'' he said. ''They're a lot richer than we are.''
 
More Cooperation Reported
Western diplomats said cooperation between the Sihanouk forces and the Khmer Rouge was increasing, especially because of ammunition shortages as supply lines lengthen. They said the Khmer Rouge, better organized and financed by China, has more ammunition porters and supplies. The two forces have been sharing ammunition, intelligence and artillery support, the diplomats said, and have sometimes fought alongside each other for the same objective.
All the factions are trying to control as much territory as possible before a new round of negotiations on a Cambodian settlement. Any settlement will probably call for a cease-fire in place, the diplomats said.
Mr. Hun Sen and Hanoi have moved closer to Washington's position by agreeing to a significant United Nations role in Cambodia, Mr. Stone said, ''while Sihanouk is drifting closer to the Khmer Rouge.''
''The contradictions in the U.S. position are surfacing so rapidly that it will be unpalatable for Congress to openly support the killing of more Cambodians by continuing to provide virtually all the funding to the non-Communists,'' Mr. Stone said. ''It's getting much harder to live with the contradiction that you could support the non-Communist factions without supporting the Khmer Rouge indirectly, which is against the law.''

HEADLINE: U.S. FIGHTS COLORADO FOR ROCKIES WATER

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREELEY, Colo., Feb. 2

 BODY:
In a trial that could help determine the pace of economic development across the West, the Federal Government is battling the Colorado authorities over control of the water from the Rocky Mountains.
For the first time, the United States Forest Service has filed a water claim in an attempt to set overall limits on water that others can draw from the creeks, streams and rivers that run through its vast properties.
Instead of relying on its water permit power to prevent abuses, the Government wants to assert a broad historical claim over water in mountain streams. It says that will insure long-term use of the water by safeguarding watersheds and stream channels. 
Led by the Colorado Attorney General, 48 local governments and water developers have objected, calling the Federal assertion unlawful and excessive.
 
Status of Water Rights at Issue
The case is being argued before a state water judge in this town 50 miles from Denver, and all sides say it will be carried to the United States Supreme Court. A final ruling will set a new legal status for the Federal Government's most important water rights.
''This may be the most significant water case ever tried in Colorado, and it has implications for all the Western states,'' said Deputy Attorney General Lois White of Colorado. ''It is an attempt by the Federal Government to set a new precedent which would allow it to make very substantial claims, and it would put serious limitations on the rights of other users.''
Andrew F. Walch, the Justice Department lawyer defending the Federal claim, said, ''At some point there will be a limit on how much use can be made of the water in national forests, and that limit comes when the destruction of the watershed and the channels infringes on the long-term public good.''
 
Flow in Stream-Bed Channels
The Federal claim would not take a drop of water out of the streams and rivers. Instead, the Government is trying to make sure that the flow of water follows natural rhythms sufficiently to keep stream-bed channels from clogging.
The Forest Service says maintaining the tributary system that has been etched into the mountains over untold years is the best way to make sure water is collected and sent down, and to limit erosion and flash floods.
Insistence on following natural rhythms, or mimicking nature, is a radical concept in a region where water has been so thoroughly manipulated that the levels in some rivers like the Cache la Poudre in northern Colorado actually fall in a heavy summer rain. When the farmers on the plains do not need water for irrigation, highland sluice gates are shut to build up reservoirs.
In Colorado the Forest Service owns 20 percent of all the land. Across the West more than half of all the available water either originates or flows through national forests.
 
'Social, Philosophical, Political'
''This is even more than a Forest Service water issue,'' said W. H. Miller, manager of the Denver Water Department, ''it is a social, philosophical, political question.''
The huge Federal land holdings in the West take the form of everything from wilderness areas to missile test ranges. They are already a source of resentment, and the new water claims would greatly increase Federal influence in an arena where it had been one player among many.
Water rights in most of the West are determined by the seniority principle - ''first in time, first in right'' - and those rights are bought, sold and bartered in an increasingly complex and sometimes vicious scramble.
Conflicting claims are resolved in state courts on the basis of case law rather than any overriding legislation or development plans. ''It is every man for himself out there,'' said Gary E. Cargill, chief of the Forest Service's Rocky Mountain Region, ''and every claim has to be settled on a case by case basis.''
 
The Power of Seniority
This culture of individual rights so intrinsic to the West is now disturbed by what Mr. Cargill termed ''the first scientific and comprehensive effort to set requirements for minimum instream flows across an entire water system.''
The Forest Service not only wants to insert systematic limits into an open, unregulated market. It also wants to invoke the power of antiquity for those limits. The key legal issue involves the service's assertion that it has ''reserved rights'' dating to 1897 when the service was created by Congress. That would provide nearly a century's worth of seniority.
The Forest Service has tried but failed to assert this privilege before. In 1978, the Supreme Court denied the Forest Service the rights to control minimum flows for esthetic, recreational or wildlife purposes. The Justices said that Congress had not created the Forest Service to pursue those ends.
 
U.S. Emphasizing Maintenance
Instead, the ruling in United States v. New Mexico was that Forest Service's water rights deriving from the 1897 law were for the ''principal purpose of securing favorable conditions of water flow.''
The service now argues that securing those favorable conditions requires keeping the watershed and tributary system in good condition. With scientific data collected over a decade at a cost of nearly $1 million, the service is trying to show that it has worked out the most efficient system.
The plan would set a schedule for minimum water flows throughout the year. In the spring runoff, there would be a vigorous flow to flush the channels clean, enough to prevent silting and vegetation growth in the streambed for the rest of the year.
The Federal case argues that excessive diverting of water has caused some streambeds to clog and harm the water flow.
 
Ruling Expected in a Year
In a battle of experts that is expected to last through the summer, the State of Colorado and other critics of the Federal plan say they will show that the Forest Service is misconstruing Congressional intent, that natural flows are not necessary to preserve channels and that, in any case, the service is claiming much more water than it needs for that aim.
District Court Judge Robert A. Behrman is expected to rule about a year from now in the case, which concerns one of the seven Colorado water districts.
How much the Forest Service plan would infringe on future development is being hotly debated. The issue is so complex that officials on both sides of the case admit that specific restrictions resulting from the Federal claim can only be calculated one stream at a time.
Mr. Miller of the Denver Water Department said, ''This could really hurt us because in a dry year their minimum flows could amount to 100 percent of the water.''
Mr. Cargill acknowledged that there will be problems for some users, but he argued, ''It seems common sense that the best way to insure continued development is to make sure that the system that collects and conveys the water remains healthy.''
