HEADLINE: Base Closings Seen as Opportunity Inside Problem

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 31

 BODY:
Instead of just single-mindedly fighting the proposed closing of five Bay Area naval bases, local officials here are also considering how to acccomplish the historic task of converting to a peacetime economy with the least immediate pain and the most long-range promise.
Certainly, they are asking, ''What is the price of peace in my neighborhood?'' and worrying about unemployment and the failure of small businesses near the bases, if and when they close.
But they are also excited about redeveloping prime real estate and attracting new industry, and mindful of the many studies that show that employment increases after base closings. They sense they may be on the cutting edge of history, with their region likely to be the first to face the massive changes of a post-cold-war economy. 
No region would lose more bases than the Bay Area, according to the list released Monday of 35 domestic and 13 overseas installations the Department of Defense is considering closing. No county would be harder hit than Alameda, home of the Alameda Naval Air Station and Aviation Depot, the Oakland Naval Supply Center and the Oakland Naval Hospital, which together employ more than 8,000 civilians and pour hundreds of millions of dollars into the local economies. The Moffet Naval Base in Santa Clara County would also be closed.
 
Earlier Battle Recalled
The relative equanimity about the proposed base closings, which would not take place before 1992, stands in sharp contrast to the reaction last year, when the Presidio Army Base in San Francisco was on a list of 86 bases chosen for closure by a Congressional commission. Representatives Barbara Boxer and Nancy Pelosi, both California Democrats, fought feverishly to preserve the Presidio, a 1,400-acre wooded bluff overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge, and wound up with a compromise sparing the Army hospital and some reserve activities.
Representative Ron Dellums, a Democrat from Oakland who is a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said he intends to press the Department of Defense for a detailed explanation of why so many Bay Area bases are on the list. But if sound military reasons can be given, Mr. Dellums said, he will then devote himself to fostering intelligent conversion of the installations for civilian use.
''I don't believe you can ask them to give consideration to the needs of a particular community,'' said Mr. Dellums, who advocates reduced military spending. ''We have a serious budget crisis. We have a changed world because of Eastern Europe. We know that expenditure of defense money is not a good expenditure for most people.''
Like Mr. Dellums, many local officials here and in neighboring counties seem more interested in planning for the closures than fighting them. ''We'll do what we can to forestall this,'' said Don Perata, president of the Board of Supervisors of Alameda County, where the Navy is the second-biggest employer, after the county itself. ''But the trend internationally is to de-militarize, so we have to wrap our minds around the problem and be creative about the solutions.''
 
Alameda Mayor Worries
Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco, faced with the loss of the naval base on Treasure Island, at the midspan of the Bay Bridge, said that considering shutting bases here ''makes sense in view of the changing conditions around the world.'' He said the land that may become available ''offers extraordinary opportunity for development.''
More predictably provincial in his outlook is Chuck Corica, the Mayor of Alameda, an island city across the estuary from Oakland. Alameda is a quintessential Navy town. The downtown shopping strip, with nine bars and a tattoo parlor, virtually shuts down when the sailors are at sea.
''It's a terrible blow,'' said Mayor Corica.
While the Navy is ''family'' in Alameda, the relationship elsewhere in the region is a matter of jobs, not love. Here in Oakland, the employment issue is especially important because of the steady erosion of industry that has cost Oakland 25,000 manufacturing jobs in the last decade.
 
Hopes for 'Humane' Process
Local leaders say they will look to the Federal Government for help in retraining displaced workers. ''They created the problem, and they can't walk away from us,'' said Representative Pete Stark, a Democrat from nearby Hayward. ''They must make this as humane a process as they can.''
Replacement industry must be labor intensive, planners say, and offer a similar ratio of skilled and unskilled jobs. Already there is debate here as to whether more jobs would be created by an industrial park or expansion of the Port of Oakland, by a high-technology manufacturing plant like those spreading from Silicon Valley or a pharmaceutical company.
But even under ideal circumstances, some of those laid off will be hard-pressed to find new jobs. ''You will not see people at the lower pay scales absorbed,'' said Mark Friedman, the director of the Plant Closures Project in Oakland, a local advocacy group.
The workers at the bases are alarmed. A receptionist at the Alameda Naval Air Station said this week that she was readying her resume to seek employment with the state. A mechanic at the Oakland Naval Supply Center anticipated that his next job would be ''dog work'' compared with the one he had repairing assembly lines.
 
Recovery After a Decade
Local officials are brushing up on studies regarding earlier base closings nationwide, which uniformly show a marked increase in employment 10 years after the military has pulled out. One such study, by the Pentagon's Office of Economic Readjustment, looked at 100 bases closed from 1961 to 1977. In place of the bases, there are now 75 industrial parks, 58 educational institutions and 42 airports, with 138,138 jobs where there had once been 93,424.
But Bruce Kern, the director of economic affairs for Alameda County, worries that the Bay Area presents special obstacles that discourage new industry, primarily housing costs -the most expensive in the nation - and stringent local environmental regulations. And Mr. Perata worries that new jobs will more likely be in the service sector than in manufacturing, the trend in recent decades. Such jobs, he said, often have lower salaries and inadequate benefits, thus shrinking the county tax roles and increasing its social service burden.
According to various experts, the key to successfully converting a military base is careful planning and enough time to get new job sources in place. Typically, cities and towns respond with panic, then try to block the closing, said Michael Closson, director of the Center for Economic Conversion in nearby Mountain View, which advises states and cities on this transition. ''They waste valuable time, sometimes years,'' he said.
This is why Mr. Perata and others have chosen to plan rather than fight. When the workers who lose jobs come banging on the county's door for help, Mr. Perata said, he wants to have more to tell them than ''I tried to prevent this from happening.''

HEADLINE: New Orleans Mayor Is Easy Victor in Bid for a Second Term

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won a second term in a primary today, capturing well over the 50 percent of votes he needed to avoid a runoff against his challenger, Donald Mintz.
With 425 of 465 precincts reporting, Mr. Barthelemy had 71,716 votes, or 55 percent, to 57,066, or 44 percent, for Mr. Mintz. Two other candidates had 1 percent or less. 
Mr. Barthelemy, New Orleans's second black Mayor, smiled broadly as he began his victory statement, then called on the citizens to join together after a divisive campaign. ''We are in difficult times,'' he said. ''We have laid the foundations for the future. But we cannot build a great city divided. We all must work together.''
Earlier, Mr. Mintz conceded defeat, saying: ''Sidney, to you, congratulations and best wishes. If permitted, I look forward to working with you in the days ahead.''
The 47-year-old Mayor, who has spent 16 years in politics without losing an election, faced a strong challenge from Mr. Mintz, 46, who was making his first run for elective office.
The campaign included allegations of race-baiting on both sides. Mr. Barthelemy accused Mr. Mintz, who is white, of being behind fliers depicting him as an Uncle Tom. One shows him with a half-white face; the other shows him robbing the grave of the late Ernest (Dutch) Morial, New Orleans's first black Mayor.
Mr. Mintz, who wears a lapel pin showing black and white hands linked, vehemently denied the allegations and cited his own civil rights record, which includes an Urban League award to his law firm.
The challenger, who is Jewish, said some of Mr. Barthelemy's radio advertisements catered to anti-white racism, and he accused the Mayor of anti-Semitic campaigning because of a flier saying Mr. Mintz's civil rights credentials apparently did not apply to blacks.
Mr. Barthelemy called those allegation ridiculous, noting that he had appointed Jews and received a B'nai B'rith award.
Despite the sharp disagreements, the campaign drew relatively little attention in New Orleans and there was little interest in the issues: the city's high crime rate, unemployment and the candidates' experience and competence.
Until late December, most of the interest was focused on Mr. Morial, who served from 1978 to 1986 and was widely expected to run. But on Dec. 14, he announced that he would not. He died nine days later, never having endorsed either Mr. Mintz, a protege, or Mr. Barthelemy, who as a City Councilman often battled with the Mayor.

HEADLINE: Many Are Encouraged by Bush's Arts Budget

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The modest budget increases requested by President Bush for the arts and humanities in fiscal 1991 are regarded by top members of Congress as significant because while they do not keep pace with inflation they reverse a nine-year trend of declining or flat budgets in these areas.
The total request of $364 million for the three agencies that administer Federal grants to the arts, humanities and museums would be, if enacted by Congress later this year, an overall gain of $13.1 million from the fiscal 1990 budget.
Major beneficiaries in the President's proposals are the arts-in-education program of the National Endowment for the Arts (designed to advance the arts as part of basic secondary-school teaching) and the humanities education, research and preservation projects of the National Endowment for the Humanities.
Representative Sidney R. Yates, the Chicago Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee that originates the budgets for the three agencies, said last week: ''It's wonderful! This is the first time either the Reagan Administration or the Bush Administration has given the recognition to the arts, humanities and museums that is properly theirs.'' 
 
'A Balancing Act to Do'
Asked if his subcommittee would follow the President's lead when it prepared an appropriations bill, Mr. Yates said: ''My wish is to support the Administration's proposals, but I have to be aware of the fact that our bill is one which is vitally concerned with environmental matters. If those programs have not been given what they deserve, I think we will have a balancing act to do.''
Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat whose subcommittee on Education, Arts and Humanities will be holding hearings on reauthorization of the endowments later this year, said: ''I'm pleased with the increase because it indicates that the President and the Administration have positive thoughts about the endowments. It does not keep up with inflation, but at least it goes in the upward direction rather than the downward or flat direction as it has in the past.''
Senator Pell added that he thought the increase reflected ''great credit'' on John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the arts endowment, ''because the areas targeted are arts education and administration and those are areas that interest him.''
''It's a vote of confidence for Mr. Frohnmayer and Lynne Cheney,'' he said, referring also to the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.
Of the total figure of $364 million, $175 million is to go to the National Endowment for the Arts, an increase over fiscal 1990 of $3.7 million, or 2.2 percent; $165 million is earmarked for the National Endowment for the Humanities, an increase of $8.1 million, or 5.2 percent; and $24 million is to go to the Institute of Museum Services, an increase of $1.3 million, or 5.7 percent.
Both endowment chairmen expressed pleasure with the proposed increases in their budgets.
Mr. Frohnmayer said the biggest gain among arts endowment programs was a $2 million increase for the arts-in-education project, which channels money through state arts councils to support art education in public schools from kindergarten through the 12th grade.
He also emphasized that one of his personal goals - that of serving multi-cultural and rural arts services - would receive increased support, although it was not reflected in the budget request.
Other increases, he said, would be used to broaden the membership of the grant-making panels, and to provide increased travel money so that panel members could be better informed about arts activities throughout the nation.
Ms. Cheney said that major increases would go to finance such projects as the Teacher Institute at New York University, which is designed to help teachers learn more about the subjects they are teaching; research to help scholars produce editions of the papers of important figures in American history, and preservation projects like the microfilming of deteriorating books and newspapers.

HEADLINE: World Markets

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer;
A Boom on Vienna's Bourse

 BODY:
While the Frankfurt Bund has been the focus of this year's excitement over investing in the future of Eastern Europe, the Vienna Bourse has quietly crept higher and higher, setting nine new record highs. And this after 1989, a year it outperformed every other major market.
Both markets are on the edge of an economic revolution and have been swept up in the whirlwind of change. While Austrian stocks have paid off as an entree to hoped-for profits from the Eastern bloc, the small Vienna market does pose some worries. 
Its size can make it volatile. It fell almost 7 percent from its mid-January high before rallying to four new highs last week, partly on the announcement of East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow's proposal for the reunification of the two Germanies.
In addition, analysts say, far less information is available on stocks in the Austrian market than in larger markets. This makes it harder for an individual, or even fund managers, to follow the market.
As in West Germany, the easiest access to the market is through a single-country fund traded in the United States. Like the two German funds, the Austria Fund, at about 77 percent, is trading at a high permium to the underlying value of the stocks it owns.
The run-up in Austria means that the market may be close to overpriced, if it is not already. That could set it up for a big drop.
Still, the Austrian gain is far ahead of West Germany's. The market is up 26.7 percent this year, according to the Financial Times World Indices, while West Germany has risen just 7.3 percent, even with large gains on Thursday and Friday that sent it to a record high. In the last 12 months, West Germany was up 51.5 percent, but the Austrian market rose 130.4 percent. Austrian stocks have benefited more than West Germany's from the moves toward economic reform in the Eastern bloc. That is because Austria has a long-time relationship with the East, and Austrians have had important roles in many joint ventures there.
Some analysts also argue that the longer-term commitments some large investors make in the Austrian market means the Vienna Bourse is less volatile than other markets of a similar size.
The market's boom has been built on its tiny size, - Vienna's market capitalization is 7 percent that of Frankfurt and 1 percent the size of the United States markets. Because the market is so small, purchases that would barely cause a ripple elsewhere, can send a stock soaring in Austria. Conversely, large sales can send prices falling, making investors reluctant to take their money out. This reduces some volatility.
''This is not a trading market,'' said Marko Musulin, the head of the securities and investment banking division of Creditanstalt in Vienna, the country's largest bank. ''It is not easy to exit this market in large volumes.''
When these factors were added to the rising demand for Austrian stocks, the trend had to be up. Part of the demand came from the fact that Austria was so underrepresented in many international equity funds before the Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9. After that, Morgan Stanley & Company recommended that the weighting given to Austrian shares be increased to 6 percent from 1 percent. In addition, several new closed-end mutual funds, including the Austria Fund, have added to the demand for stocks.
David C. Roche, the international strategist for Morgan Stanley in London, said that in addition to the attraction of Eastern Europe, Austria is benefiting from the possibility that it now, finally, has a chance to join the European Economic Community.
He also said that because Austrian accounting requirements with regard to disclosures are not too demanding, many companies and banks are loaded with hidden assets of land and stock that are just now being seen by many foreign investors.
But the strong rise in the market has caused concerns. One analyst said shares in have become ''ridiculously overpriced.''
An Austrian analyst, who asked not to be named, said a good downward move right now would be nice. It would, he said, lower prices enough ''so we could make some more attractive sales to our customers.''

HEADLINE: Business Diary

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson/February 4-9

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
A New, More Subdued, Mood at Shearson Lehman
 
An era of daring and deal-making at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. undoubtedly ended Tuesday night with the resignation of Peter A. Cohen as chairman and chief executive. His replacement, Howard L. Clark Jr., has been chief financial officer at the American Express Company, Shearson's corporate parent. Though Mr. Clark was once an investment banker himself, he is likely to have Shearson adopt the conservative ways of American Express, where traveler's check receipts are invested in safe, short-term municipal securities. Riskier activies - merchant banking, real estate and bridge loans - might be trimmed. Analysts say Shearson will gradually devote more effort to retail brokerage. American Express, after all, is a consumer company.
 

The Exchange After Phelan
 
Now comes the New York Stock Exchange's chance to see how well it can get along without John J. Phelan Jr. He announced Friday that he would retire as exchange chairman by the end of the year. Mr. Phelan has won credit for turning an exchange that was becoming anachronistic and conflict-ridden in the 1970's into one capable of trading hundreds of millions of shares a day with no strain. Balancing the rival interests of floor traders and investment houses, he convinced the exchange to invest hundreds of millions on computer technlogy. And after the 1987 crash, he gave investors reassurance and calm. A former floor trader himself, he began at the exchange as a runner. 
 
 
Whipping Up the Product Mix
 
The Philip Morris Companies sold more food than tobacco for the first time in 1989. But even after buying Kraft and its food brands - Jell-O, Cheez Whiz - in December 1988, the company still finds that tobacco accounts for about 65 percent of annual earnings. Philip Morris reported last week that fourth-quarter profits more than doubled to $863 million.
 
*
 
Coca-Cola profited from leaving the movie business. A $509 million gain from selling its interest in Columbia Pictures more than tripled fourth-quarter earnings, to $757 million.
 
*
 
The nation's largest steel company had a fourth quarter that appeared to repay its diversification into oil. Higher energy prices helped USX increase earnings 54 percent to $244 million.
 
*
 
Caesars World, it seems, got slaughtered at the baccarat tables. The company predicted sharply lower earnings for the quarter ending Jan. 31, and blamed bad luck in the casinos. As Henry Gluck, the company's chief executive, said, ''The laws of probability work in strange ways.''
 
*
 
 At Boeing, a 48-day strike cut fourth-quarter earnings 56 percent to $77 million.
 

One of Europe's largest drug companies said Friday it plans to buy a majority stake in Genentech Inc., the pioneering American biotechnology company. Roche Holding Ltd. of Switzerland is to invest $2.1 million for a 60 percent share of the company, with an option to buy the rest. As part of the agreement, Robert A. Swanson, Genentech's chief executive, would become chairman and G. Kirk Raab, president, would replace him.
 

 An Optical Computer?
 
It looks like the runner-up in a high school science fair. But the first optical computer, displayed last week, already has the ability to perform some operations as quickly as huge supercomputers. Researchers at A.T.&T.'s Bell Labs who developed the device hope that in several years optical computers will far surpass conventional machines. Instead of electric currents and silicon chips, the new computer uses laser beams, mirrors and lenses. Some scientists scoff at its commercial potential, while others foresee an optical computer on the market in a decade.
 

Executives on the Move
 
A five-year, $10 million package convinced Allen I. Questrom to become chief executive of Allied Stores and Federated Department Stores on Friday. Questrom had initially turned down the job in favor of remaining chief executive of Neiman Marcus.
 
*
 
The Campeau Corporation might not sell Bloomingdale's after all. Federated Stores Inc., the company's American subsidiary, plans to spend the next month or two deciding whether to accept one of several bids. Meanwhile, Robert Campeau himself might be joining his stores in insolvency. Available records indicate that his $500 million fortune has shrunk with the plunge in Campeau stock, and he is in default on two major bank loans.
 
*
 
Thomas S. Murphy, who built Capital Cities/ABC Inc. from a bankrupt UHF television station in Albany into a $5 billion media empire, said Thursday that he will step down as chief executive May 31. Daniel B. Burke, the company president, is to succeed him.
 

S.&L.'s - It's Not Over Yet
 
Savings and loan news: Federal regulators seized Centrust Bank, Florida's largest savings and loan, on Friday. They said that management had wasted assets on yachts, art and oriental rugs. The regulators also announced on Friday the sale of Bright Banc Savings Association, one of Texas's largest S.&L.'s, to the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio. On the brighter side, American Savings Bank, of California, sold to the Robert M. Bass Group more than a year ago, reported a $214.2 million profit for 1989.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 

Greenspan on Recession
 
Don't count on the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates soon. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, told Congress last Tuesday that, based on the Government's index of leading economic indicators, his staff sees only a 20 percent chance of a recession in the next six months. The economic index, released Wednesday, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, the largest gain since April, even after accounting for the end of the Boeing strike in late November. But another figure last week pointed to continuing weakness. New home sales fell 9.6 percent in December and 3.8 percent for all of 1989, making it the slowest year since 1984.
 

Job Data, the Good and the Bad
 
Unemployment edged down one-tenth of a point to 5.2 percent in January. But Friday's unemployment report may not be as healthy as it seems. Manufacturing jobs fell for the 10th straight month, with the auto industry hit hardest. And Richard B. Freeeman, for one, a Harvard economist, argued that stagnant real wages are a more accurate guide to the economy than low, stable unemployment. ''If we hold the same unemployment rate for the next 20 years and do not have any real wage growth, that would be a disaster,'' he said. Recent wage improvements have only matched inflation, he added.
 
 *
 
Renewed aircraft business after the Boeing strike contributed to a 1.9 percent rise in factory orders for December. But excluding transportation, orders rose just two-tenths of 1 percent.
 

The Bush Budget
 
President Bush gave Congress a budget last week that would restrain military spending, lower capital gains taxes, expand some domestic programs while cutting others and sharply reduce the budget deficit. Democrats dismissed it as an impossible, impractical relic of the Reagan years. They reacted more warmly Wednesday night when the President, in his first State of the Union message, proposed sharp new reductions in Soviet and United States troops in Europe. Behind the budget battles this year will lie a fight over economics. The Bush Administration assumes a healthy 2.6 percent economic growth rate; the Congressional Budget Office, 1.8 percent. If the President is right, the deficit will meet his target of $63 billion; if Congress is right, the deficit will be $100 billion. The consensus of private economists is on the side of Congress. But the Administration was more optimistic than Congress and the economists last year - and the Administration turned out to be right.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 

ast and East, Head to Head
 
The opening of Eastern Europe and the availability of its low-wage labor force could hobble some Asian economies. Asia may be able to produce textiles and shoes more cheaply, but Eastern Europe offers better-educated workers to handle technology and electronics. As Ed Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, put it, that Asia's ''four tigers'' - South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong -have less to fear than their poorer neighbors around the Pacific. With Eastern European workers available for capitalism, he said, ''It's almost as if you suddenly created a Philippines in the middle of Europe.'' But Eastern Europe's situation is ''like the Philippines in other ways,'' Mr. Hewett cautioned. ''Troubled.''
 

McDonald's in Moscow
 
The workings of digestible materialism culminated Wednesday in the opening of the Soviet Union's first McDonald's. The chain's largest restaurant, smack on Moscow's Pushkin Square, was mobbed with customers eager for ''Beeg Meks.'' For McDonald's, the toughest task was drilling Soviet farmers and counter help in the ways of standardized production and relentless good cheer.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Taking Mr. Greenspan in Stride

 BODY:
The yen lost its punch this week, falling back to its level of 145 against the dollar. As for the West German mark, it continued strong, but the dollar only moved down a little against it. Suggestions from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that there was less chance of a recession seemed to have little impact. A strengthening in the economy would mean that the Fed is unlikely to ease interest rates, which could push the dollar lower. But the market did not think Mr. Greenspan's remarks hinted at a new bias toward raising interest rates. Indeed, Manuel H. Johnson, the Fed's vice chairman, said late in the week that he does not rule out lower interest rates in the future.

HEADLINE: G.M. Europe: How to Get Something Right

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: ZURICH

 BODY:
Intense pride radiates from Robert J. Eaton, president of the General Motors Corporation's European car operations. Intense fear, too.
The pride is easy to understand. At a time when the problems plaguing the North American operations of G.M. are approaching crisis proportions, a dramatic revival of the European business - reflected in its hot product line and its strong profits - shows that G.M. can get something right.
The revival also shows that success does not necessarily require vast sums of money: G.M.'s European factories are not nearly as automated as those in America. 
Bob Eaton's fear is also understandable. Japanese car makers, among others, have set their sights on Europe. And there are widespread predictions that the bloodbath that occurred in America in the 1980's because of overcapacity and the arrival of the Japanese will be replayed in Europe in the 1990's.
The attractions of the European market are obvious. One is the prospect of the 12-nation European Community becoming a single, barrier-free market of 325 million consumers. Whether that happens by 1992, as planned, or somewhat later, as is probable, the assumption is it will come to pass, and that will make it easier to sell cars throughout Europe.
The Western European market for passenger cars is already the world's largest (35 percent bigger than the market in the United States), and it is also expected to grow faster in the 1990's - 2 percent or more a year on average, versus 1 percent or less in the United States.
In addition, there is the tantalizing prospect, assuming those countries continue down the road toward market-oriented economies, that demand for cars will soar in Eastern Europe.
''There isn't one large manufacturer in the world that can afford not to be here,'' Mr. Eaton, a 49-year-old American, said in an interview in G.M. Europe's headquarters in Zurich. ''We are going to be facing a tremendous amount of competition that does not exist today.''
Even more frightening to Mr. Eaton, an engineer who was a corporate vice president in charge of G.M.'s engineering, design and research staffs before taking over in Europe in June 1988, is the thought that G.M. Europe may not be ready for the new challengers. Although it has made great strides in the last five years in its cost-competitiveness, G.M. Europe's manufacturing costs are still only about average in the industry. Ford's and Fiat's are much lower, analysts say. And G.M. Europe's costs are nowhere near those of the highly efficient Japanese.
The pressure on Mr. Eaton to close the gap is tremendous because the European operations have never been more important to G.M. The fat profits from Europe are important to both Ford and G.M., which are virtually neck and neck in the market, ranking fourth and fifth, respectively, in share behind Volkswagen, Fiat and Peugeot and just ahead of Renault. But they are especially crucial to G.M.
 
A Growing Dependency?
 Though G.M. sold only 1.5 million cars in Europe last year (versus 3.44 million in the United States), the division earned an estimated $2 billion, or half of G.M.'s estimated total; most of the rest of the parent's profit came from nonautomotive operations. Unless G.M. can reverse its slide in the United States, where its market share has dropped 10 points since the early 1980's, to about 35 percent, the dependency on Europe is only likely to grow.
''I don't think one can overestimate the importance of G.M. Europe to the entire G.M. organization,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst at Furman Selz Mager Deitz & Bernie Inc., a New York investment firm. ''This is where the cash is coming from for investment in G.M. North America.''
Indeed, one risk over the next few years is that so much cash will have to go to North America that G.M. Europe will lose its momentum.
''The temptation will be enormous to bleed Europe dry and postpone model programs,'' said Daniel T. Jones, a professor at the Cardiff Business School at the University of Wales. ''That's G.M. Europe's major worry.'' As G.M. executives acknowledge, Detroit starved the company's European operations in the 1970's. Even in the 1980's, there was a limit to Detroit's generosity.
Mr. Eaton says he would have liked to have had more production capacity last year, when his division could not satisfy the demand for its cars. A source close to G.M. said executives in Europe pleaded for more money to expand production, but were turned down by Detroit.
Even so, G.M. Europe managed to thrive: Its market share rose to 11.2 percent, from 10.5 percent in 1988, the largest increase in the industry. In Britain, G.M.'s Vauxhall brand overtook Rover for the No. 2 spot behind Ford. On the continent, where G.M. cars are sold as Opels, G.M. is No. 2 in five nations, including West Germany, and No. 1 in the Netherlands and Norway. And the company could not come close to meeting the demand for its newest midsized car - sold as the Opel Vectra and the Vauxhall Cavalier. Consumers in many countries still have to wait five to six months for delivery.
''They're the most profitable of the European car manufacturers,'' said John K. Lawson, an analyst at the Nomura Research Institute Europe, a unit of the Japanese investment firm. He estimates that G.M. Europe has a profit margin of 14 to 15 percent, or at least two points better than each of its five major competitors.
Not bad for a division that was in such poor shape in the mid-1980's that G.M. considered selling or drastically shrinking it. That was when it was generating huge losses and everything from weak consumer demand for cars to the declining value of the dollar was going against it.
 
'A Success Strategy'
 ''We took a survival strategy and turned it into a success strategy,'' said Louis R. Hughes, chairman of the West German-based Opel.
The strategy for reviving G.M. Europe differed greatly from the one that G.M. has pursued in North America. Unlike its big brother, G.M. Europe did not try simply to throw money at its problems when it decided to enter the growing European market for very small cars, revamp the rest of its product line and renovate its factories.
''It turned around because, without mammoth investments, it developed good products that are efficiently built,'' said Ms. Keller, the analyst, of G.M. Europe. ''It is an organization that came together with a purpose. There are enormous lessons for North America and it is really astounding they have not been taken to heart.''
As strong as G.M. Europe now is, major challenges lie ahead. Those with the broadest product lines and geographical reach are expected to have the best chance of achieving the economies of scale needed to survive in a more competitive Europe.
In the geographical distribution of their sales, G.M., Ford and Volkswagen (helped by its acquisition of SEAT, the Spanish car producer) are in the best shape. Italy's Fiat and France's Peugeot and Renault are still heavily dependent on their protected home markets. As for market reach, Fiat and VW, which also owns Audi, have had the advantage of sporting a variety of distinct brands.
Ford and G.M.'s biggest weakness is in the luxury car market. Despite some good cars, they have had limited success using their own brand names to compete against the likes of BMW and Mercedes-Benz.
This explains Ford's $2.38 billion acquisition of Britain's Jaguar last year and G.M.'s $600 million purchase of a half interest in Saab, the Swedish car maker. It was the snob appeal of the two nameplates that Ford and G.M. were after. They plan to expand Jaguar's and Saab's product lines and make the small companies much bigger producers.
But it remains to be seen whether G.M. and Ford - and the rest of the industry, for that matter - will be able to defend their market shares against the Japanese. By exporting to Western Europe, the Japanese have already grabbed about 11 percent of the market. Undoubtedly their share would be even higher were it not for the protectionism of countries like Italy, France, Britain and Spain. As part of the program to turn the European Community into a single market, individual national barriers to the Japanese are expected to be eliminated over the next 5 to 10 years.
 
Crowded Future
 A related threat is that while there is not a huge amount of excess capacity now in Western Europe, there soon could be. Most of the big manufacturers in Europe are expanding. Nissan, Honda and Toyota are expected to be producing as many as 750,000 cars in Europe within five years. And others are on the way.
By 1995, all these factories will be capable of producing at least two million more cars than anticipated demand, Mr. Eaton predicts. And that does not include those that American, Japanese and European companies plan to build in Eastern Europe.
G.M. has entered into one of the biggest deals in the East: on Jan. 14, it announced the formation of a venture with RABA, a state-owned Hungarian company, that will initially produce 15,000 small Kadett cars a year for Eastern Europe.
While there is widespread optimism about Eastern Europe becoming a booming car market, that may take time. For that reason, and because of the need to earn hard currency, there will be pressure on many of the new ventures to export some cars to Western Europe.
Mr. Eaton also worries that increasing overcapacity in the United States will mean factories there also will try to export more to Europe.
With so many concerns, it is little wonder Mr. Eaton feels that G.M. Europe cannot be content with its accomplishments and he makes it clear that his greatest priority is slashing costs. ''We know we're not there yet,'' he said.
In fact, some analysts believe Ford has made as much if not greater progress in reducing its components costs, and Ford has more of its production and sales in Britain, where car prices are high and labor costs relatively low. Industry experts also say Ford has been more successful in persuading unions to agree to reductions in job classifications, which gives Ford more flexibility in how it uses its people.
But in persuading unions to allow it to expand production schedules at some plants, ''G.M. is really the pioneer,'' said Karl E. Ludvigsen, a Ford alumnus who heads a London-based automotive consulting firm bearing his name.
 
24-Hour Shifts
 An assembly plant in Antwerp, Belgium, operates six days a week, with two 10-hour shifts a day. The company's factory in Zaragoza, Spain, was the first car assembly plant in the world to go to three shifts, enabling it to run around the clock.
G.M. Europe executives constantly question the need for expensive automation. Manufacturing complexes like those at Luton near London and at Russelsheim, West Germany, G.M.'s largest worldwide, boast state-of-the-art paint plants and their fair share of robots. But they are not nearly as high tech as many G.M. factories in the United States or as Fiat's in Cassino, Italy.
Paul J. Tosch, chairman of the British-based Vauxhall, talks of automation sometimes ''standing in the way of continuous improvement'' in productivity. Unlike G.M. domestically, Vauxhall uses people, not robots, to put in windshields and backlights.
In all, during the 1980's, G.M. Europe spent only about $7.4 billion on capital expenditures, a relatively small amount considering the dramatic changes that were being made.
One big reason G.M. executives in Europe embraced this spend-less gospel is they had no choice: Detroit's priority was North America, and it would not write the money-losing European operations a blank check. But that decision pushed the technical development center at Russelsheim to design ease of manufacturing and quality into new cars.
Still, plenty remains to be done. G.M. Europe is still too dependent on its plants in West Germany, where workers are pushing for a shorter work week - even though they already work 600 to 800 fewer hours a year than the Japanese. And it takes Japanese companies just three years to develop a new car from scratch, versus about four for G.M. Europe. Herbert Oberhaus, Opel's director of product engineering, worries that with the Japanese setting up development centers in Europe, G.M.'s advantage in design could be eroded.
Clearly the battle is far from over for G.M. Europe, notwithstanding its remarkable turnaround. And from the way things look right now in North America, it is a battle that General Motors just as clearly cannot afford to lose.
 
LEADERS OF THE TURNAROUND
In many ways, there were two main heroes of the General Motors turnaround in Europe.
 One was Ferdinand P. J. Beickler, who headed Opel, the company's profitable West German-based division, until 1986 and served as G.M. Europe's first president until he retired in March 1987. G.M. Europe was formally created four years ago, in the hope of finally uniting what had been two bickering divisions - Opel and the struggling British-based Vauxhall.
The other hero was John F. Smith Jr., who was executive vice president for European operations before succeeding Mr. Beickler in the top job. In mid-1988, he was named corporate executive vice president for international operations in Detroit. Mr. Smith is seen by many as a man who could one day head G.M.
Mr. Beickler, who is 67 years old, was one of the chief architects of G.M.'s product revival in Europe, which began with the introduction of the tiny Corsa Nova in 1982. Until then, G.M. had not done well in many countries because it did not sell very small cars. By building the Corsa Nova in a new plant in Zaragoza, Spain, G.M. also got a foothold in what has become one of Europe's fastest-growing car markets. And in 1984, G.M. came up with a radical redesign of the Kadett Astra, a model that is the next size up from the Corsa Nova and is now G.M. Europe's biggest-selling car.
Jack Smith, 51, gets much of the credit from analysts for turning what had been a divided enterprise into a truly pan-European operation - in terms of marketing and distribution, cost structure and a united management.
When Mr. Smith and Mr. Beickler created G.M. Europe, they purposely located it in Zurich, outside of the fiefs of Opel and Vauxhall. Only then was it possible to challenge Opel's dominance over G.M.'s European operations and the company's dependence on manufacturing in West Germany, where costs are high.
The leadership torch has now been passed to Robert J. Eaton. Before succeeding Mr. Smith, Mr. Eaton was involved in the development of the recently unveiled electric car as well as the new Saturn division, G.M.'s boldest attempt to rethink how it makes cars in the United States.
In Europe, Mr. Eaton has already impressed outsiders by his ability to move fast - something for which bureaucratic G.M. is not famous. Perhaps the most obvious example was the way he snatched Saab away from a surprised Fiat. He also gets high marks for hammering out the recent deal to build cars and engines in Hungary.
 
DESIGNING HIGH-TECH GOOD LOOKS
Largely through the work of its engineers at the company's huge technical development center at Russelsheim, West Germany, G.M. Europe has shown that it can produce competitively priced cars that are technologically advanced on the inside and appealing on the outside, with a modern, aerodynamic look.
The aim has been to create cars that are reliable and functional. All have back seats, for instance, that fold down so that items can be loaded through the trunk up to the front seat.
''Vauxhall/Opel has been very adventurous in its new model programs,'' said Bob Murray, editor of the London-based Autocar and Motor magazine. ''Even their bread-and-butter cars like the Vectra/Cavalier are a cut above other cars in their class. Ford is being very safe in Europe with styling and Vauxhall is taking risks that are paying off.''
Analysts and car enthusiasts also heap praise on G.M.'s engines, which they consider superior to Ford's and at least the equal of those made by all the other big-volume manufacturers in Europe.
The performance of G.M.'s new three-liter, 24-valve, six-cylinder engine is one reason Autocar and Motor thinks the sporty, midsized Vauxhall Carlton GSi3000 24v is a better buy than BMW's 535i.
''It's quicker, it's much roomier and it's also 7,000 cheaper,'' Mr. Murray said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH

BYLINE: By Sarah Bartlett;
The January Effect: Just a Few Good Days

 BODY:
Investors would have done well to have dabbled in the stock market the first and last trading days of January, but to have taken to the ski slopes in between. The gains of 56.95 and 47.30 points, respectively, on those two days formed handsome bookends around what was otherwise a discouraging trounce.
The decline in January of 5.9 percent in the Dow Jones industrial average marked the worst monthly performance since the post-crash doldrums of November 1987. Investors blamed the usual suspects: disappointing corporate profits, lack of takeover speculation and the prospect of stable or rising interest rates. 
Last week, investors seemed determined to cut through some of the gloom and retraced some of their steps, sending the Dow up 43.47 points, to close at 2,602.70.
That rebound occurred despite an array of discouraging economic news. The Chrysler Corporation kicked February off with a bang with its announcement that it intends to close one of its St. Louis plants, reducing its car-making capacity by 20 percent and laying off 3,700 workers. That may have raised hopes in Hollywood for a new movie called ''Lee and Me,'' but it only served to remind investors of the wobbly state of manufacturing, and the jobs and income that that important sector provides.
The Government's employment report, which was released on Friday, provided the first solid evidence that the economy in January remained weak. In manufacturing, 112,000 jobs were lost.
Strong job-growth in the retail and construction industries was largely due to statistical quirks and good weather. And construction is likely to succumb to rising mortgage rates. For the first time in months, homebuyers now face rates of over 10 percent on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, according to HSH Associates in Butler, N.J.
Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank USA, thinks higher mortgage rates bode ill for consumer spending generally, a key prop to the economy, and thus, to the prospects for a rising stock market.
Perhaps it is not altogether surprising, then, to find that the Conference Board's consumer confidence index for January also sank to its lowest level since November 1987. ''What people are saying is not so much that things are bad right now, but that they are noticeably less optimistic about the future,'' said Jason Bram, an associate economist at the board.
Of course, all that could change if interest rates were to decline. But Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan dampened hopes for that when he testified before Congress last week.
He and his secretive colleagues will have a chance to change their minds when the Federal Open Market Committee meets this week. But since that meeting coincides with an auction of $30 billion of Treasury securities - and many traders are worried about lukewarm Japanese interest and the possibility of a sharp jump on Friday of the producer-price index - few think that the Fed officials will be so daring. That is not, after all, their strong point.

HEADLINE: The Classic Conglomerate Wades Into the 90's

BYLINE: By FROMA HARROP; Froma Harrop covers the defense industry for The Providence Journal-Bulletin.

 BODY:
It has a reputation for business aplomb, but Textron Inc., the Providence, R.I., conglomerate, is also a company that's found itself on the crest of trends. Back in the early 1950's, when single-mindedness was American corporate gospel, Textron's founder, Royal Little, decided he needed a strategy to protect his cyclical textile business, so he invented the modern conglomerate. In the 1960's, a Textron subsidiary, Bell Helicopter, rode the Huey, the signature aircraft of the war in Vietnam, to record profitability.
Now, conglomerates no longer seem visionary and Textron, the nation's 17th-largest military contractor, is out on the edge of a trend - toward global peace - that's problematic for defense-sector companies. President Bush's new budget avoids the deep cuts feared by the military, but his determination to pare away defense money over the next several years bodes ill for contractors.
Many of Textron's military projects have survived the cuts so far, but two of its pet projects - the M-1 tank, for which a subsidiary is making gas turbine engines, and the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor helicopter-cum-plane - have dicey futures. Textron has for years been conservative about allowing any one of its business segments to dominate the others, but between 1984 and 1989, its military component grew to 28 percent, from 19 percent, of revenues. Now, Textron appears to be inching back from the military. 
''We're used to thinking about changing markets,'' said Beverly F. Dolan, Textron's chairman and chief executive officer, during an interview in Providence, his soft Georgia accent an incongruous contrast to the icy panorama of Colonial and industrial New England outside his window. ''That's certainly one of the strengths of a conglomerate.''
Textron's deliberate strategy of spreading its earnings and investments among aerospace technology, commercial products and financial services gives it more flexibility than some of its behemoth competitors in defense. The General Dynamics Corporation, for example, realizes 85 percent of it sales from Government contracts; at the Northrop Corporation, that figure is 91 percent.
But contracting problems at Bell and a slowdown in the auto industry helped send third-quarter earnings down 5 percent, to $59.5 million or 66 cents a share. Mr. Dolan does not argue with analysts' estimates that operating earnings for all of 1989 will be around $3 a share, down from $3.10 in 1988. Revenues may show only a slight increase.
Textron's style of diversification was virtually unknown in 1952 when Royal Little, of Massachussets, founded the company. Seeking a way to counter the periodic booms and busts that plagued his textile mills, Mr. Little bought a slew of companies in unrelated industries.
Under Mr. Little, who died a year ago at age 92, Textron was soon producing eyeglasses, bathroom fixtures, motor castings, machine tools, poultry and lingerie. His acquisition spree culminated in the 1962 purchase of the Bell Aircraft Corporation for $32 million. Today, the company's 33 divisions employ 57,000 people in five countries and every state except Alaska. Textron has 142 manufacturing plants in North America.
Recent changes in the executive suite suggest that Textron is, if not backpeddling from defense, at least trying to bring the company into harmony with its conglomerate philosophy. In December, Textron hired James F. Hardymon, 55, president and chief operating officer of the St. Louis-based Emerson Electric Company, to fill the same positions at Textron. Mr. Hardymon is regarded as the likely successor to Mr. Dolan, 62, who is expected to retire in three years. Mr. Hardymon's strength, according to Mr. Dolan, is his experience in operations at Emerson, where defense contracts account for 10 percent of revenues. ''He was the guy who ran the train,'' Mr. Dolan said. Mr. Dolan came up through the ranks at Textron after it took over a golf-cart company he and his brother had founded, E-Z-Go in Augusta, Ga., in 1960. His familiarity with the factory floor contrasts with the more austere financial orientation of some of his predecessors, including Rupert C. Thompson, a Providence banker, and G. William Miller, a lawyer who became Secretary of the Treasury under President Carter. (Mr. Miller was recently named head of Federated Stores Inc., to help guide Robert Campeau's bankrupt American department store chain.) Howard A. Rubel, an aerospace analyst with Cyrus J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. in New York, says Mr. Hardymon's appointment sends a strong signal to stockholders that Textron intends to arrest the slide in its return on investments. Return on equity has slid, from 13 percent in 1987 to an estimated 11 percent this year. The appointment may also counter a perception that the company is unfocused. ''Hardymon looks like a crackerjack manager,'' Mr. Rubel said. Textron's faith in conglomeration is not universally shared, of course. ''Conglomerates create confusion,'' said Lawrence Lytton, a multi-industry companies analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''Investors prefer to make their own portfolio, as opposed to hiring a C.E.O. and being one step removed from the process.''
To dispel any notion of wild diversification, Textron has typically sliced its pie charts into just three segments: aerospace-technology, which currently accounts for 44 percent of revenues; commercial products, 26 percent, and financial services, 30 percent.
The recent increase in the defense segment is largely the result of two acquisitions: the Avco Corporation, an aerospace and financial services giant bought in 1985 for $1.4 billion and the Ex-Cell-O Corporation, a maker of aerospace and automotive products, bought in 1986 for $1.05 billion.
To finance the deals, Textron sold more than two dozen nondefense operations, including Shaeffer Eaton, a maker of pens and paper products; Bridgeport Machines, a machine tool maker, and the Ex-Cell-O packaging systems division. These sales still left Textron with long-term debt of $2.23 billion, uncomfortably high, according to analysts.
The financial services' strong showing, starring Avco Financial, has offset some of the problems in aerospace-technology. The ratio of bad loans is now under 2 percent, putting the financial segment, Mr. Rubel said, ''near the top'' in the industry.
Some older members of the Textron commercial products clan, are also doing well. E-Z-Go, Mr. Dolan's home base, has benefitted from a surge in golf's popularity. Homelite, a Charlotte, N.C., maker of chain saws and generators, enjoyed a $3 million sales boom after Hurricane Hugo struck last fall.
Meanwhile, Bell is having ''a very good year'' overall, according to R. Jackson Blackstock, a conglomerates analyst at First Boston in New York, because of its robust foreign military sales and a strong commercial business. Over the first nine months of the year, operating earnings at Bell rose 24 percent over last year's levels. Textron reports an 18-month wait for deliveries on its light commercial helicopters, the 206B Jet Ranger and 206L Long Ranger. And because more than half the helicopters now in use in the non-Communist world were made by Bell, the company does an ''enormous'' parts business, according to Mr. Dolan.
Textron's biggest disappointment continues to be the Defense Department's refusal to fund production of the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor, on which it has spent 30 years of research and some $200 million. But cancelled weapons programs typically flutter rather than plummet to ground, and the Osprey may well be headed for a reincarnation, with help from allies either on Capitol Hill or foreign markets. Cancellation domestically would force the company ''to go offshore to look for money,'' said Jack Horner, Bell's president. ''With that goes rights to building airplanes overseas and selling them back to the United States.''
That threat aside, Textron is already looking to the economic unification of Western Europe in 1992 as an opportunity for commercial products. Last summer, Textron's Davidson Instrument Panel division formed a joint venture to supply auto parts to a Ford Motor Company plant in the Netherlands. Textron also plans the $250 million acquisition of Avdel, an English rivet maker, now stalled by the Federal Trade Commission.
Despite areas of unsteadiness, Mr. Dolan seems to view the future with equanimity: ''This is a damn good time to be a conglomerate.''
 
COMING IN ON A WING AND A PRAYER
Even before recent events in Europe and the Soviet Union prompted discussion of deep cuts in the military budget, the defense-sector dollar was growing more elusive.
Several of Textron's military products - for example, the re-entry system for the MX missile, from Textron Defense Systems in Wilmington, Mass., and air-cushioned landing crafts, made at Textron Marine Systems in New Orleans - seem to be flourishing or holding steady.
But the effects of slowing Government funding were clear last year, when Textron Aerostructures in Nashville, which had employed 7,300 people during its 1986-88 heyday, laid off more than 4,000 employees after completing contracts to build wings for the B-1 bomber and the center wing section for the C-5 transport. New contracts for parts of the Airbus A330 resurrected only a few hundred jobs.
Defense Secretary Richard M. Cheney has so far spared another Bell program, the LHX (Light Helicopter Experimental), a new Army attack helicopter still in the demonstration stage. Bell is developing the LHX jointly with McDonnell Douglas Helicopter in Mesa, Ariz., in competition with a team from two other contractors.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould;
The Flight to Safety

 BODY:
The flight to safety is on. Investors, worried about skittish stock and ''junk bond'' markets and lured by high interest rates, are shifting their cash to money-market funds. And fund experts say that investor nervousness shows no sign of clearing.
''Interest rates are hard to resist, and people are afraid of the market,'' said Brian S. Mattes, a vice president of the Vanguard Group in Valley Forge, Pa. More than $1 billion flowed into Vanguard's money funds in January, double the amounts from one year ago. Right now, Vanguard's money-market fund pays 8.16 percent. 
At Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, money-market sales in December were stronger than they had been in any month in the last three years, said Michael J. Hines, vice president of marketing. January sales rose a hefty 42 percent, bringing money-market assets at the Boston-based fund group to an all-time high, he said.
January's activity was a big shift from December's investment behavior, which was detailed last week in a report by the Investment Company Institute, a trade group.
The report, which showed strong yearend inflows of cash into stock funds, solid gains in international funds and growing investor disenchantment with junk-bond funds - $664 million flowed out of junk-bond funds - was clear evidence of just how volatile the markets have been.
The difference between December and January investor behavior may be most pronounced in equity funds. While fund managers reported a strong outflow of money from stock funds in January, in December, according to the trade-group report, investors slapped down $9 billion for shares in stock funds, more than double November's total.
Over all, investors poured more than $15 billion into stock and bond mutual funds in December. That was a $3 billion jump over November sales and the largest monthly inflow since just before the October 1987 market crash.
There has been a clear move away from stocks in January, but fund experts say that many investors who want to stay in the market are looking abroad. International funds rang in almost $650 million in December sales, making it one of the hottest mutual-fund investment categories. And fund experts say the January numbers promise to be strong, too.
Last month, sales took off in T. Rowe Price's International Stock Fund, which invests in large companies in well-established international markets, according to Steven E. Norwitz, a vice president at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. The group's International Discovery Fund, which invests in small-capitalization stocks in established and emerging markets around the world, did almost as well, he said.
Recent events in Eastern Europe have sparked investor interest there, of course, and the consensus seems to be that the economic environment will be stronger abroad this year. And the foreign markets weathered a tough January much better than we did here.
Despite gains overseas, international turbulence has fueled new interest in gold in recent weeks. The price of gold has been strong, and more people are looking at gold funds now, portfolio managers say.
Edmund Serfaty, portfolio manager of the United Services' Gold Shares Fund in San Antonio, said interest in his fund has been rising. ''People are hedging their bets because of the uncertainty in the financial markets, and because performance has been so good,'' he said.
In December, there was some evidence of the conservatism that would grow deeper in January. At yearend, growth-and-income funds - considered a conservative play because they pay hefty dividends but let investors keep one toe in the market, just in case - captured the lead as the fund category that showed the biggest percentage gain, said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services Inc., which tracks fund performance.
Over all, sales of bond and income funds totaled $6 billion in December, a small dip from the preceding month, according to the institute. Long-term municipal bond funds, including national and single-state funds, rang in December sales of $2.1 billion, cementing a minuscule rise for the entire year.
Part of investors' dissatisfaction with fixed-income funds is carrying over into corporate bonds.
''You're seeing a shift to safety,'' Mr. Norwitz of T. Rowe Price said. ''People are concerned about rising interest rates, so we're seeing definite shifts from long-term bond funds into money-market funds.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Mr. Bush, You Must Raise Taxes

BYLINE: by LEE H. HAMILTON; Representative Lee H. Hamilton is a Democrat from Indiana.

 BODY:
At the end of 1989, as chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, I issued a report that concluded our top economic policy priority in 1990 should be eliminating the Federal budget deficit. Unfortunately, the budget proposed by President Bush last week breaks no new ground in dealing with the deficit.
The Office of Management and Budget director Richard G. Darman makes a compelling case against the deficit and its attendant erosion of our economic future. But the Administration proposes only a tired list of tried-and-failed tax ''incentives'' that give away more than they get; tried-and-rejected spending cuts that have failed to garner a majority of votes from even the President's party in Congress; and $13.9 billion of ''revenue enhancements.'' 
The letters I received after the report was issued indicate that most Americans are seriously concerned about the deficit. They have an intuitive understanding of how the deficit has soaked up savings and eroded our economy over the long term by pre-empting domestically financed investment. However, the same Americans question the need for any kind of tax increase.
Why must a tax increase be part of a workable deficit reduction plan? In part, this conclusion is an economic judgment - we cannot grow our way out of the deficit. It is also a political judgment - other approaches to reducing the deficit, including relying on spending cuts alone, have not worked in the past and will not work in the future.
The deficit has been stuck at over $150 billion for the last three years, despite forecasts that were far lower. In fact, Congress and the Administration claimed to meet the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction targets in each of those three years, but the actual deficits turned out to be far higher. The deficit has not faded away, contrary to the forecasts, because economic growth has been slower than predicted and interest rates have been higher, which reduces the Government's revenues and increases its interest costs. Future growth is unlikely to match the Administration's rosy forecast, in part because the Federal Reserve has clearly signaled its resolve to hold growth at about its current level to control inflation.
We have not reduced the deficit through spending cuts, despite the determination of the Reagan Administration. That is because there are not sufficient opportunities to cut spending without harming important national interests. Interest on the national debt - which is the fastest growing single item in the budget and cannot be cut - along with Social Security, Medicare for the elderly and defense spending, accounts for approximately 70 percent of total spending. This leaves little else to cut. And because these four programs are so large and have grown so fast over the last decade, the rest of the budget has been squeezed.
Many of the programs often thought of as targets to balance the budget are in fact quite small. Our deficit in 1989 was $152 billion. Against that figure, total American foreign aid was less than $7 billion, and much of that assistance comes back to the United States as expenditures for American farm products and manufactured goods. The total Congressional budget (which includes maintenance of the buildings and grounds, the Capitol Police, the Library of Congress and other activities that are often forgotten) was less than $2 billion. No cuts in these small programs, however desirable, could possibly eliminate the deficit.
The ''peace dividend'' that is expected to follow from reduced tensions in Eastern Europe is welcome, but it will be years in coming.
There were many good ideas about cutting the deficit in the 1984 Grace Commission report to the Reagan Administration, and most of them have been adopted. However, although the Commission claimed to have found enormous potential savings in the budget, a review revealed that the savings would be only one-third of what was originally claimed and that 16 percent of those savings would come as a result of higher taxes rather than spending cuts. In addition, much of the rest of the savings would come not from eliminating inefficiency or waste, but from cutting actual services delivered.
Likewise, procedural tools proposed to reduce the deficit - budget-process reforms and balanced budget amendments - would have limited effect. You cannot solve a substantive problem with a procedure; hard decisions must still be made, and in the absence of the will to make them, a way will be found to circumvent the procedure. Our experience with Gramm-Rudman proves this. A line-item veto would apply only to a small fraction of spending; it could not reduce Social Security benefits, Medicare payments, the interest on the debt, or defense or other costs involving long-term contractual obligations. Further, a President with a line-item veto would be likely to bargain for spending for a program he wants,like Star Wars, by offering not to veto a program that a member of Congress wants, like a new dam or Federal building in his or her state or district. The result would be more spending.
My best political judgment, on the basis of the experience of the last decade, is that we are unlikely to eliminate the deficit either through spending cuts or tax increases alone. Neither course is politically acceptable. Therefore, the only realistic solution is a package deal that includes both spending cuts and a moderate tax increase. There are many options for such a moderate tax increase that would not involve increases in income tax rates.
The deficit is so large that everyone will be unhappy with at least some elements of any program to eliminate it. We will never break the political gridlock unless we all agree to accept some changes that we do not like, in order to improve our economic future.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lee H. Hamilton (NYT/George Tames); drawing

HEADLINE: Wall Street

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES;
Rite Aid's Silver Lining

 BODY:
The cover of the 1988 annual report of the Rite Aid Corporation, the nation's largest drugstore chain, seems oddly prophetic today. It showed a workman in a hard hat buffing one of the company's giant red-white-and-blue signs. Last April, almost exactly a year after the report was issued, the company's president stood accused of attempting to bribe a member of Ohio's pharmacy board, a giant-sized smudge that is still clouding the market's view of the company.
But in the eyes of at least a few bargain-hunters, the bad news about Rite Aid is good news for investors interested in buying a quality stock at a bargain price. 
The last year's headlines have been lurid enough to scare away all but the fearless. After a flamboyant raid at a Cleveland airport hotel in April, local prosecutors arrested Martin L. Grass, the company's president and the son of Rite Aid's founder and chairman, Alex Grass, on charges of attempted bribery. In August, a judge unsealed the indictment that accused Mr. Grass and the company of offering a bribe to secure the resignation of the pharmacy board member, who was also a consultant to a chain of stores Rite Aid had purchased.
Lawyers for the defendants deny the bribery charge and characterize the payment as simply the company's buyout of the consultant's contract with the acquired company. The case is scheduled to come to trial in Ohio's Cuyahoga County on April 16.
Even the stalwarts who were unperturbed by the news out of Ohio apparently lost heart in December, when the company reported third-quarter results. Rite Aid earned only a dime a share from its continuing operations, down from 38 cents in the same period of 1988, but the 1989 figure reflects adjustments for the costs of closing the video rental departments in its stores.
The company's stock, which had slipped on news of the April arrest but recovered to nearly $41 a share in July, tumbled once again; its price has hovered around $31 in recent weeks.
To look at the stock's performance, one would think that nothing is going right at Rite Aid. But that view is simply wrong, said Scott M. Black, president of Delphi Management Inc. of Boston and one of the pickiest value-hunters around.
Mr. Black manages $900 million in assets for a roster of clients that includes Yale, Stanford and several other major universities. He shuns any company that does not consistently earn at least 15 percent on shareholders' equity, or that cannot generate abundant amounts of cold cash from ongoing operations. And he absolutely refuses to buy a stock unless its price is less than 10 times the company's estimated per-share earnings for the coming year.
Mr. Black started buying Rite Aid stock a few weeks ago and is still at it. ''We really don't get many chances to buy a retail drug chain at this price,'' he explained. ''I mean, any idiot can buy Wal-Mart at 20 times earnings. I have to take good companies with good records when they've fallen on hard times.''
Rite Aid's record for the last decade certainly stacks up well, even when compared with the Walgreen's chain, the current favorite among most drugstore analysts. Figures compiled by Bart Schneider, an analyst for the Value Line Investment Survey, show that Rite Aid's cash flow per share has climbed steadily, from $1.13 in 1980 to an estimated $4.50 last year. Cash flow at Walgreen's, by contrast, was just 88 cents a share in 1980 and $3.59 a share last year.
Rite Aid's reliable river of cash has helped the company to grow considerably and to diversify a bit. In the last two decades, it has accumulated nearly 2,400 drugstores in 22 states - more than any other major chain - and added the Encore Books chain, a discount auto parts chain and a fleet of dry-cleaning outlets.
Helped by those acquisitions, its sales have grown an average of 15 percent a year since 1980; Walgreen's average sales growth for that period was 13 percent. And Rite Aid's profit margins have been equal to or stronger than Walgreen's during this time.
Mr. Black concedes that Rite Aid's margins were slimmer in 1989, when the company bought new computer equipment to speed shoppers through the checkout lines and improve record-keeping - steps that will ultimately benefit earnings. He said he expects margins to improve this year, pushing 1990 earnings up to $3.20 a share.
The share of Rite Aid's profits derived from drug sales and health and beauty items, as opposed to general merchandise, is high by industry standards. This profit mix, Mr. Black explained, is both a blessing and a safety net for the company. General merchandise sales generally suffer more in a recession than sales of drugs or other health-related products. And prescription drug sales are likely to get a substantial boost as the nation's population grows older.
As for the dramatic developments in Ohio? Both Mr. Schneider and Mr. Black are distinctly unconcerned. ''We think the bad news related to the trial may actually present investors with a buying opportunity from time to time,'' wrote Mr. Schneider in a recent review of the company's long-term prospects.
Mr. Black agrees. ''The business is going to do well, irrespective of this Mr. Grass,'' he explained. ''It's not like the company is falling apart. You can look at the numbers.''
In Mr. Black's view, this is a case where turmoil creates opportunity. ''By the time everything straightens out and the earnings come through and the stock is at a 15 P/E,'' he said, everybody on the Street will be recommending Rite Aid.

 
L.A. GEAR'S INVESTORS ARE FEELING THE BURN
It was just a typical week for investors in L.A. Gear, a high-flying California clothing manufacturer whose stock has taken more bounces than a Malibu aerobics class.
On Monday, after the stock opened at $27.125, the company announced profits of $3.01 a share for the fiscal year that ended Nov. 30. The market had been hoping for more. The stock fell $2.75, or more than 10 percent.
''Enough,'' said Jay J. Meltzer, a Goldman Sachs analyst. On Tuesday, he recommended L.A. Gear to his firm's traders. The stock steadied somewhat.
On Wednesday, the company named Kevin J. Ventrudo, a young investment banker, as its new chief financial officer - perhaps reminding the market that the post had been vacant for a year. By Thursday night, the shares had sunk to $23.375.
But Friday brought reports of stronger January orders, rumors that the company is adding a new celebrity to its endorsement roster, and a stock rebound to $25.25 a share. ''It's just very hard to call the moves on this stock,'' sighed Brenda Gall, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.
