HEADLINE: MODEST DREAMS;
The President Looks On the Bright Side, And It's in Europe

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is hard for most of the world to focus these days on anything other than Europe, as events there tumble forward, pell-mell, and last week President Bush proved to be no exception. Not only did he propose, in his first State of the Union address, radical new cuts in Soviet and American combat forces, but he also gave Mikhail S. Gorbachev another salute, as he described it, for encouraging peaceful change in what used to be called the satellite states.
That's what was new, so that's what made the news, even if it tended to emphasize again that the main action is elsewhere, despite Mr. Bush's bold assertion that ''America stands at the center of the widening circle of freedom.'' Washington is more and more aware that the President and the United States are secondary players in this drama that is transforming a continent, day by day and week by week. 
But the speech and the new Federal budget, which preceded it by two days, had other, subtler messages, which were all but lost in the shouting. At the end of his first year in the White House, Mr. Bush marked out some trails that he intends to follow.
All in all, he showed a marked preference for foreign policy over domestic, to no one's surprise. This President, after all, held three major foreign-policy posts earlier in his career. What is more, the questions of foreign affairs are more tractable just now than the questions of domestic affairs, with the single, notable exception of China. Having barely escaped humiliation by Congress over his insistence on keeping close links to Beijing, Mr. Bush elected not to press the issue last week. He did not mention China once in reporting on the state of the union.
Foreign policy is also relatively cheap. The prospect of reducing American troop strength in Europe to 225,000 (and if the Democrats and the eastern Europeans have their way, well below that) will eventually mean money saved, even if some of it will be spent on economic aid to Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and the rest. And saving money is in with politicians of both parties.
There were standing ovations Wednesday night when Mr. Bush called for an end to bigotry in the United States, and when he announced the troop cuts, and when he proclaimed his military triumph in Panama. But what really brought whoops of pleasure from the assembled Senators and Representatives, the Republicans and some Democrats, was the President's reiteration of his pledges not to raise taxes.
Yet hewing to that policy, and also striving to reduce the deficits that he inherited from Ronald Reagan, leaves Mr. Bush with little room to maneuver.
''The money is there,'' he said, in sharp contrast to his comment on taking office a year ago that ''we have more will than wallet.'' Clearly, he has been reading the poll-takers' findings as the nation enters an election year in which the Republicans hope to lay the groundwork for regaining control of Congress. The voters are worried about education and drugs and the environment, the polls say, so Mr. Bush offered increased funds for Head Start and more work on global warming and an intensified war on cocaine.
There was something, in other words, for almost everyone. But there was no suggestion that national calamities lurked or that national sacrifices were needed; indeed, Mr. Bush seemed consciously to have avoided picking any one or two or three problems - the homeless, say, or competitiveness - as cause for warning.
Most Presidents feel that they must act boldly, must innovate, in the first year or so of their terms, while they have a new mandate and their teams are full of the energy that Washington eventually saps from even the most vigorous.
Mr. Bush clearly does not intend to do that, at least in the domestic field. As in his invasion of Panama, and in his speech on Europe at NATO headquarters last summer, he showed in the troop-reduction plan the capacity to surprise those who have criticized him as too passive, but that capacity has been confined to foreign affairs.
He sees a modest role for himself and the Government at a time when difficult problems - AIDS, the homeless, medical costs, industrial decline, poverty, child care - seem to need fresh and, some would argue, huge attention. Instead of stirring calls to the nation to follow him in solving problems, Mr. Bush asked grandfathers and grandmothers, fathers and mothers, to talk to the younger generation. The thousand points of light were back: ''We've got to step forward when there's trouble, lend a hand, be what I call a point of light to a stranger in need.'' It was all very nebulous.
In a way, this budget and this State of the Union address represented a gamble. Clearly, Mr. Bush thinks the country is basically satisfied. Clearly, he believes that however many ills it sees, it believes that government is only a part, and probably only a very small part, of a solution. Clearly, he thinks that limited government action, combined with ample reassurances that he feels and cares, will prove politically adequate.
Hence the plethora of symbolic actions of which he spoke - planting a billion trees, transforming the Environmental Protection Agency into a full-fledged department with a seat at the Cabinet table, asking Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, to ''review'' the already voluminous studies about how to get soaring medical-care costs under control.
Hence, also, the evocative, emotional talk at the end about holding his 12th grandchild - ''the little guy'' - in his arms, and of the centrality of faith and family. If there had been pictures and music with it, it would have made a great campaign commercial.
Which is, to be fair, what the State of the Union address has become in this age of television. Once, Congress was the principal audience, and the talk was technical, a presentation by a professional to professionals; that was what the Founding Fathers had in mind when they provided for periodic reports by Presidents. But now the ''target group,'' to use the language of marketing, is the whole country, and images and moods count, not numbers and analysis.
And in 1990, as in 1988, the mood that George Bush seeks to project is nostalgic, warm, safe, steady.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For the Sudan, Famine Is Almost As Certain As Civil War

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan

 BODY:
POTENTIALLY one of the most prosperous agricultural spots in Africa, the Sudan is facing yet another famine, this time caused not by weather but by war.
Unlike in 1988, when Western relief officials insisted that they had been unaware of the hunger that caused 250,000 deaths in the country, international plans have been made to alleviate the suffering that is sure to come. But the junta in Khartoum and its southern rebel opponents are putting military and political tactics first as they push for battlefield victories before the annual rains that begin in May. Both sides are refusing to allow the humanitarian work that the southern Sudan depends on because fighting or fear of fighting prevent planting and harvesting. 
With travel so precarious in the southern region and the flight of so many displaced to the north and into Ethiopia, neither the United Nations nor the International Committee for the Red Cross has an accurate picture of the number of people left in the southern Sudan. Those likely to be affected by famine could range from one million to three million.
In neighboring Ethiopia, also locked in a civil war, an even larger famine is in the making with more than four million people needing food aid because of widespread drought. Both the Ethiopian Government and the rebels are bargaining with Western powers for donations of food, knowing that the side with the most relief can also be the most powerful.
Hopes are somewhat higher that starvation can be averted in Ethiopia. In the province of Eritrea, there has been a long lull in fighting and the relief effort appears well run.
The Government of Mengistu Haile Mariam, wanting to impress Western donors, has offered to allow Ethiopian church groups to take food to Tigre, a province entirely controlled by rebels, where at least one quarter of the four million Ethiopians who are at risk live. The Tigrean rebels have yet to agree. But even if they do not, peasants moving to the border between Tigre and parts of Eritrea controlled by the Government could pick up food now arriving in large quantities at Massawa, an Ethiopian port.
The difficulties in the Sudan seem more intractable. The leader of the military Government, Maj. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir, has said that he favors continuing the United Nations relief operation that went into full swing last year. But the Government's actions suggest otherwise. Planes carrying food, medicine and relief workers to rebel-held territory were banned last November, two-way radios used by relief workers in isolated areas to keep in contact with their headquarters in Khartoum have been taken by the army, and aid officials are having difficulty getting travel permits. The snarling tone of a top Government official, Abu Geziza, who recently asserted that humanitarian aid helped the rebels, also cast severe doubts on the junta's sincerity.
 
A Trickle of Aid
Against this hostility, the United States, the chief financial backer of last year's United Nations relief effort, appears virtually impotent. Economic aid to the Sudan, once one of Washington's best-kept clients in Africa, will end this month under a Congressional law halting aid to a junta that toppled a democracy. A trickle of military assistance still flows, but not enough to hold any leverage over the Government.
Washington is increasingly frustrated as aircraft paid for with American funds to transport food, medicine and relief workers stand idle. A plane that had permission from Sudanese officials to fly after the ban took effect was shot down, killing three workers of Doctors Without Borders, an organization that specializes in medical aid. Aid workers believe that Government soldiers fired on the plane to deter other flights.
The rebels, whose group is known as the Sudan People's Liberation Army, have their own tactics for stalling relief work. Last month, the Khartoum Government said it might reconsider allowing supply planes into the southern Sudan if Sudanese officials could check all flights for weapons before they left for the rebel-held areas. The guerrillas said they wanted nothing to do with the plan. In the meantime, they have urged the residents of Juba, most of them displaced peasants, to move to the countryside, where there is no food, so the rebels can have a free hand to bomb the town.
The looming famine and the collapse of the relief operation are perhaps nowhere more evident than in the hamlet of Abyei, in the region that divides northern and southern Sudan. Last year shipments of food were plentiful and the village had a hospital with medicine and doctors. But a few weeks ago, the last foreign aid worker, stranded without radio communication, drove out of the town after shooting broke out. The hospital is without supplies, and what dwindling food is left in Abyei for its 40,000 people is under the control of the army commander from the north. The International Committee of the Red Cross estimates that up to 100,000 southern Sudanese will try to trek toward Abyei in coming weeks. Because there was relief food in Abyei last year, the southern Sudanese will expect it again and will be shocked to find there is not enough this time.
The refusal of both sides to take part in serious peace talks to end the seven-year war, the growth of the Government-backed militia and the successful push by the rebels across the southwestern swath of the country suggest that war will persist as famine relief fades away. And once again, residents of the southern Sudan - despised by the junta, neglected by the rebels who are supposedly fighting for them and seemingly beyond the reach of the international community - are likely to face starvation.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Farm Economy Is Fine, And Can Expect More Aid

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the first farm subsidy law on May 12, 1933, he promised it was a temporary measure. At a time when people were hungry, he remarked, the Government had no business propping up prices by paying farmers to hold back their harvests. Now, nearly 60 years later, the payments are as much a part of American agriculture as the sun and rain, and tremendously expensive as well.
This year, Congress is again reviewing what has become as much an entitlement program as an industrial policy. Grain farmers have come to depend on the subsidies for a substantial portion of their incomes, and urban voters have not protested the high costs. 
Lawmakers also credit the programs for helping end the worst farm depression in half a century. As a result, few changes in the law are expected; the restiveness in rural America has been calmed by the new prosperity, and now more attention is being given to other issues in agriculture, particularly the use of pesticides.
In the 1980's, crop subsidies cost the Treasury $133.5 billion. Most of the money was spent after 1985, when Congress enacted amendments to the farm law that President Reagan said were gallant attempts to reduce the Government's role in agriculture.
 
The Controlling Hand
The farm subsidy program, which applies to 14 farm products, is a voluntary social contract between the Department of Agriculture and farmers. The Government pays cash to farmers for every bushel they produce - the payment for corn, for example, is about $1 a bushel - in exchange for a promise that they will leave a specified amount of their land fallow. The goal is to control production from year to year and to prevent huge surpluses. What the 1985 legislation did was lower the per-bushel price that the Government paid the farmers.
As if to mock the President, the farm economy worsened, and spending on subsidy programs reached a peak of $25.8 billion a year later. In 1986, the Government spent $11.9 billion - or the equivalent of the budgets of the Departments of State, Justice and Interior combined - just to reduce supplies of one crop, corn.
But in the last two years, farmers have earned record incomes. In large part because of the drought in 1988 and poor weather in other nations, surpluses have decreased, market prices have gone up, and demand around the world for American grain, soybeans, cotton and rice is increasing.
At the same time, the 1985 farm law lowered the Government-set prices of American commodities for overseas buyers and gave them generous subsidies. Farm exports reached $40 billion last year, the highest since 1981, and spending on the farm program is expected to fall to $8.1 billion this fiscal year, the lowest since 1984.
As a result, Congressional leaders now consider the 1985 farm law, which expires this year, a rousing success.
So pervasive is the subsidy program's presence in American agriculture, particularly in the grain belts of the Middle West and Great Plains, that small changes in policy can lead to huge consequences for hundreds of thousands of farmers. In no decade was this clearer than in the 1980's. In 1981, Congress acted to increase steadily the subsidies paid to farmers, encouraging more growers to join the programs. But the Government did not require farmers to take enough land out of production. Production soared. The corn harvest in 1985 was a record 8.9 billion bushels, 1.4 billion bushels more than it was last year.
At the same time, the high value of the dollar and a deepening world recession sharply reduced exports, filling storage bins with surpluses that caused prices to collapse and plunging agriculture into the worst depression since the 1930's.
The fundamental change that Congress made in the subsidies in 1985 was to lower the target prices set by the Government to guarantee farmers a certain income per bushel produced. In addition, the legislation took record amounts of land out of production.
Lower production helped to cut surpluses. Reduced target prices made American grain more competitive with foreign crops. Gradually American farm exports have climbed. Sales of corn overseas in the last two years have been higher than at any time since 1981.
Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter has made it clear that he is not looking for much change in the subsidy programs beyond an attempt to reduce their cost. Members of Congress from both parties say that a small drop in the target prices is possible and would help to cut the deficit, but that large price decreases would be unfair to farmers. Since 1986, the Government's target prices for grain have fallen 10 percent even as inflation increased by 20 percent.
A result of the strongest farm economy in a decade is that other agricultural issues have begun to command attention in Congress. The most important of these is a debate over the extent of pollution caused by modern cultivation practices and of the threat to food safety from pesticides and drugs used in agriculture.
For the first time, consumer organizations and environmental groups, such as the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Audubon Society, are poised this year to join the debate on farm policy. Both groups are looking for new provisions in the law that would reduce the use of toxic chemicals and drugs in farming.
 
Friends on the Hill
How successful they are likely to be is difficult to predict. The big environmental groups command respect on Capitol Hill because of their scientific expertise and their wide public support. They also have an ally in Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat and chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, one of Congress's leading environmentalists.
The House Agriculture Committee and its chairman, Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, Democrat of Texas, have not been nearly as friendly. Out of concern that farmers would lose too much, the House committee has consistently blocked legislation to restrict pesticides.
The ideological difference between the two chairmen, members of both committees say, will almost certainly result in separate farm proposals that will be similar in the economic provisions but differ substantially in programs that affect food safety and the environment. If the divisions are so deep that they could not be resolved, the 1985 law would simply be extended for a year.
The committees are beginning the debates this month. Mr. Leahy and Mr. de la Garza have assured farmers that they intend to produce new legislation this year, and both set ambitious schedules to conclude deliberations well before the elections in the fall.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Dinkins's First Budget Has Some Hard Edges

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
DAVID N. DINKINS, who once was dismissed by a critic as ''Mr. Smoothie with no position,'' proved last week what dividends such derision can bring. Presenting his first preliminary New York City budget as Mayor, he won praise partly for taking an unpopular stand.
''I will not allow tough times to become an excuse for foolish choices,'' Mr. Dinkins said as he proposed a $27.8 billion plan that would amount to the worst of both worlds: $550 million in new taxes and at least $226 million in cuts, from fewer police officers to shorter library hours. 
That phrase sounded so familiar that some people wondered if Mr. Dinkins's predecessor, Edward I. Koch, had used it. No proof was found, but the fact remained that Mr. Dinkins's cautious fiscal posture looked much like Mr. Koch's.
Still, the new Mayor's approach was his own. When a television commentator demanded tersely why it was not foolish to add to some programs but delay the hiring of some police officers, Mr. Dinkins replied, ''Perhaps if we educated our children better, if we provided opportunity and jobs, police might have less work to do.''
Now Mr. Dinkins faces the harder task of selling his plan to close a budget gap of more than $1 billion for the fiscal year that starts July 1. He wants to persuade the Legislature to pass a $200 million three-year tax surcharge on personal income that would cost the average city resident $70, and the City Council to raise property taxes by $180 million, or about $33 for a typical homeowner. But with state legislators staring at huge budget gaps of their own in an election year, and Council members reluctant to hurt their homeowning constituents, asking will not guarantee getting.
''We will leave no stone unturned,'' Mr. Dinkins pledged, adding that he believed he could be a cheerleader for New York, albeit in his own subdued way. ''We are going to travel the length and breadth of the city, to Albany,'' he said. ''I know how to say please and to plead our case, and I think that we will be successful.''
 
Many Uncertainties
Mr. Dinkins's plan depends on other uncertainties, including $300 million for the sale of the old Coliseum site at Columbus Circle, which is being held up by a lawsuit. And any plan for more taxes must avoid driving away businesses, which could further weaken the economy.
Because he is new, Mr. Dinkins will undoubtedly benefit from some good will that the combative Mr. Koch could not count on toward the end of his tenure. At the same time, Mr. Dinkins will also have to contend with the high expectations of a constituency eager for change.
But he said: ''I think that we have some credibility. I think that people generally believe that the economy is where we say it is, that the revenue picture is where we say it is.''
Asked if his warning of even deeper service cuts if taxes are not passed was intended as a bludgeon to get the Legislature and Council to act, Mr. Dinkins said he preferred to call it a ''mild entreaty.'' His challenge is to make his quiet approach work.

LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Soviet Oil Industry Has Two Decades' Worth Of Progress to Be Made

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
AS the Soviet Union strives to modernize its economy and match the performance of countries with free markets, it begins with an energy industry that missed the important events of the last 20 years. The Soviets are the world's largest producers of oil, but they were never driven to the productivity advances required in the West by years of competition and the price collapse of 1986. And on the demand side, both the industry and consumers missed the conservation lessons of the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979.
The challenge now is to produce enough oil to meet domestic needs - which presumably will rise with more consumer demands - and enough to sell abroad for vitally needed hard currency. Fuel exports account for about 40 percent of the country's foreign exchange. 
Instead, production has started to slip, experts say, probably to below 12 million barrels a day, about half a million barrels below the peak in 1987. The trouble in Baku, the center of the country's oil service industry, presages worse to come. These difficulties are watched closely by outsiders; this week the OPEC News Agency quoted an official of the cartel who suggested that Eastern Europe would be unable to rely on the Soviets for future energy needs.
A stumble in the Soviet Union's energy production would be felt worldwide, because it is currently the world's biggest energy producer and because it is likely to remain a huge source for decades to come. The Soviet Union has about 8 percent of crude oil reserves, more than double the United States level, and more than any other country except Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. In natural gas, the Soviet Union is first in production and potential, with about 43 percent of the world's reserves.
United States Government and private experts describe a Soviet oil production picture similar to that in the United States: deposits that are easily reached have largely been found and exploited, leaving the smaller, deeper targets.
''The underlying problem is a shortage of really good prospects,'' said Thane Gustafson, a professor of government at Georgetown University and a consultant on Soviet energy for Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Massachusetts.
''The Soviets have been going at it with the technology of the 40's and 50's,'' he said. ''When Western oil companies come on the scene, they find the sweetest part of the cake nibbled out, but all around the edges are places the Soviets have passed by.''
Without the competitive urge, Soviet engineers have not developed advanced techniques, now common among Western multinationals, for finding and drilling in harsh environments, or recovering a larger portion of the oil in underground reservoirs. ''The opportunities over there are probably so significant that nobody would believe you if you described them,'' said Herbert M. Ryan, a spokesman for Dresser Industries, a Dallas-based oil field service company. ''They are mammoth.''
Dresser and other American companies would love to have access to the Soviet market. The oil companies have a well-developed way for dealing with countries with no capital: in exchange for permission to drill, they split the oil that is produced. Dresser now sells about $100 million a year worth of equipment and services to the Soviet Union but believes the potential is far larger. But the country may prove less eager than third world hosts; a rising tide of environmentalism and Russian nationalism could mean trouble for projects that would industrialize pristine areas for the benefit of foreigners. Labor shortages and worker disgruntlement may be other obstacles to drilling in the most remote areas.
In addition, some practices have reduced the possibilities of expanding production, even with advanced technology, experts say. An example of this is the large-scale pumping of water into the ground to make the oil flow toward the wells. Though this method increases the amount of oil recovered, companies say, it also reduces efficiency, because at some point the water starts coming back up with the oil.
In American fields, the practice is used mainly at sites where most oil has already been extracted. The Soviet producers, on the other hand, flood even new fields with water. This allows them to reach high production levels faster, experts say, but decreases the total amount that can be recovered over the life of the sites. Now many Soviet wells are recovering mostly water. ''There is no way of assessing efficiency, and no incentive for enterprise,'' said Mehdi Varzi, an analyst with Kleinwort Grieveson Securities in London. ''All they can talk about is volume.''
Inefficiency also shows up on the the consumption side. ''Moscow is full of overheated buildings, with the windows wide open in the dead of winter,'' said Thomas McHale, an energy economist with Drexel Burnham Lambert and a frequent traveler to the city. ''It's the most inefficient economy you can imagine.''
Soviet energy use has roughly paralleled economic activity. In contrast, the American economy has grown one-third faster than energy use, because of rising efficiency, and even greater gains have been achieved in Western Europe and Japan.
In theory, a centrally planned economy should have some advantages in addressing this problem: it could simply order factories to make fuel-efficient cars and better-insulated refrigerators, rather than relying on consumer preference, which may be shortsighted.
But such a world has never materialized. The result is an industry in deep trouble, at the very time that its productivity is needed to fuel the stagnant economy into prosperity.
On the global scale, a Soviet oil shortage could temporarily disrupt the international market, by contributing to a shortage that could cause a major price swing. When the world is short of spare production capacity, the market is sensitive to even small changes in the supply-demand balance. And production capacity has disappeared in recent years in many non-OPEC countries, because producers, confronted with low prices since the mid-80's, have found little reason to invest heavily in drilling.
Tighter supplies, of course, mean higher prices, which will encourage more drilling, in the West and probably in the Soviet Union. The Central Intelligence Agency predicted, wrongly, in 1977 that production would peak in 1980, and many experts doubted that the Soviets would achieve the high level of natural gas production and exports that they managed in the 1980's.
As with other developments in Moscow in recent months, Western analysts may now find themselves rooting for Soviet success.

HEADLINE: Almost Peace. Why No Dividend?

 BODY:
President Bush knows good politics and knows how to be a world leader. He showed that when he abandoned his reluctance to support Mikhail Gorbachev and reached out dramatically to end the cold war. He could now act with equal force at home if only he would seize the opportunity to transform the emerging peace with Moscow into a peace dividend for American society. 
While Mr. Bush still rejects the term peace dividend, it must surely be his aim. With one voice in his State of the Union address last week, he proposed big troop cuts in Europe. With another voice, he proclaimed his commitment to schools, cities, the environment, a war on drugs and a real decline in the Federal deficit.
But the two voices are disconnected. In his new budget, the President offers little money to meet his social goals. The dissonance will reverberate unless he recognizes that assembling and using a peace dividend is good politics and good policy.
No one expected Mr. Bush to propose new taxes. Yet there was some hope he would find savings in the Pentagon budget - well beyond his projected cut of 2 percent or $6 billion yearly in the next four years. His proposed reductions in Europe could, in time, save $10 billion yearly. But he could do better than a 2 percent cut next year. More important, he could lay the groundwork for phasing in far deeper cuts thereafter.
Where is the threat to justify a $300 billion defense budget? Mr. Gorbachev is dismantling Soviet military might. As that continues, Mr. Bush can prudently follow suit. This is true especially for strategic nuclear arms. Yet he and Defense Secretary Cheney resist cuts in this area above all. The Administration could save $20 billion a year or more if it gave up plans for missiles and bombers and pulled back on ''Star Wars.'' Even hard-liners concede that thousands of warheads and bombs are enough to deter nuclear war.
And what of the Navy? Mr. Cheney has barely touched its budget. He admits to ''difficulty explaining'' to the Navy that it might not need 14 aircraft carrier battle groups. There are billions more here to be saved.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney are politicians and bargainers. They want to keep the defense faith with their conservative backers and put the onus for deeper cuts on the Democrats. Politics is politics -up to a point.
That point comes when the inevitable defense cuts are made helter-skelter by Congress. Then, rational reductions in defense will have been forfeited and domestic needs will go unattended, leaving the President to pay a political price.
Mr. Bush enjoys a remarkably high approval rating, 76 percent in the last New York Times/CBS News Poll. His handling of foreign affairs attracts about the same approval. But not other sectors. Only 49 percent approve of his economic performance, for instance. Is Mr. Bush, who styles himself the Education President, improving education? No; 68 percent of respondents say he's mainly talking. Is he helping the environment? No; 62 percent say he's mainly talking.
President Bush will be measured, ultimately, by how much he does, not how much he talks. By grasping the full possibilities of a peace he's helping to build abroad, he can rebuild a strong America. The connection is there, if only he would make it.

HEADLINE: We Can't Take More of This 'Reagan Boom'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Martin Anderson's exultant celebration ''The Reagan Boom - Greatest Ever'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 17) cannot be left to stand without rebuttal.
True, the long recovery from the deep depression that brought President Reagan to power carried this country to the high point of the usual cyclical wave characterized by a low rate of unemployment and a high gross national product. It is most likely that wholesale tax cuts inaugurated by Mr. Reagan have made the level of the G.N.P., as measured by the Government statisticians, several billion dollars higher than it would otherwise have been. But at what a cost! 
Drastic cuts in public spending (except for military purposes) left the physical infrastructure of this country in ruin. City streets and transportation facilities, water supply and sewage systems, particularly in large metropolitan areas, are collapsing; the once glorious interstate highways are crumbling, and cramped airports are incapable of handling the rapidly increasing traffic. Despite the valiant effort of the underfinanced, underpowered Environmental Protection Agency, our lakes, rivers and forests are succumbing to deadly acid rain.
What is even worse, the intellectual, cultural and social infrastructure of the country has suffered even more during this greater-than-ever boom than its physical counterpart. Primary and secondary schooling have been so weakened that a whole generation of boys and girls can hardly read, write or count, while the soaring price of higher education (which, in contrast to the United States, is free in most other advanced countries) makes it impossible for many young people to take advantage of it.
No wonder the competitiveness of the United States is rapidly declining; many of our high technology industries are losing one battle after another in the struggle for their share of the foreign and even their own domestic market. At the same time, the rich are getting richer, and the poor are getting homeless.
Let us hope that contrary to Mr. Anderson's expectations the ''Reagan boom'' will not continue in its present form for four or eight more years. If it does, the United States will find itself entering the 21st century as the richest country (in total value of stocks and bonds traded on the stock exchanges), but culturally and socially less advanced than other developed countries.
 
WASSILY LEONTIEF
 New York, Jan. 19, 1990
 
The writer, professor of economics at New York University, won the Nobel Prize for economics in 1973.

HEADLINE: We Can't Take More of This 'Reagan Boom';
If Things Are So Good

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Reagan Boom - Greatest Ever'' by Martin Anderson (Op-Ed, Jan. 17) is the latest attempt by Reagan partisans to convince us how well off we are. If things are so good, how come I, and I suspect many others, feel so far behind? 
At my age, 35, my father owned a four-bedroom house and supported a wife and three children (with one more to come). In a few years, he will retire comfortably, having put all four of us through private colleges. Though my father and I have similar jobs, and I have no children to support, it will be a few more years before I have saved enough for a down payment on a small apartment. I made different choices from my father, but those alone cannot account for the vast differences in our economic positions. To me, owning no stocks or bonds, the 1980's has meant watching the prices of the big-ticket items - housing, education, health care - take a greater and greater percentage of my budget.
I don't spend a lot of time bemoaning these facts. In some ways I am grateful for the simpler, less materialistic life style it forces on me. But I don't appreciate being constantly told how much better off I am when the facts of my life tell me quite otherwise.
 
BILL VALENTINE
 New York, Jan. 17, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 457 words

HEADLINE: We Can't Take More of This 'Reagan Boom';
Unemployment Does It

 BODY:
To the Editor:
An Economic Scene column by Peter Passell (Business Day, Jan. 17) focuses on the ''devastating financial setbacks'' suffered by ''young, male, blue-collar workers'' - high school dropouts had a decline in earnings of 15 percent from 1979 to 1987, while those who managed to graduate absorbed cuts of 9 percent - on the very day that Martin Anderson's adulatory tribute to Reaganomics (''The Reagan Boom - Greatest Ever'') appears on the Op-Ed page.
Mr. Anderson, once a Reagan adviser and now a senior fellow of the Hoover Institution with a mind-set seemingly informed by the Guinness Book of Records, characterizes the creation of 18.7 million jobs since 1982 as a ''world record'' (avoiding both percentage growth figures that show lower rates of increase in the 1980's over the 70's and the losses of jobs in the devastating recession of 1981-82).
If we combine the two articles, and add the recession, we have a much different picture. Recession brought both interest rates and wage pressures down - unemployment does it every time! By breaking the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization strike, President Reagan helped accelerate the decline in unions, which Mr. Passell lists as a main cause of the decline in blue collar pay. Desperately attempting to maintain family living standards (a partial explanation for lower rates of personal savings), wives with children entered the labor force in ever greater numbers. 
Many found low-level part-time and full-time jobs, and thus are world records made. Mr. Anderson gloats that ''the stock market took off like a giant skyrocket.'' Perhaps in the rarefied atmosphere of the Hoover Institution it goes unnoticed that the same may be said of the number of homeless.
Why has the expansion Mr. Anderson is so proud of lasted so long? Partly, the Federal Reserve System has managed it better than is usually the case. Mainly, inflation has been kept in check by the high unemployment of the Reagan years, as well as by the negative effect on wages of increased international competition.
At the risk of Mr. Anderson's labeling, and thereby dismissing, me as a ''left-wing faculty member,'' I would suggest that whether our economy is better described as a ''guiding beacon'' for Eastern Europeans, as he suggests, rather than one, in the words of Mr. Passell, in which ''President Reagan's chickens may, at long last, be coming home to roost,'' may ultimately depend on whether one identifies with capitalists and the rich and powerful or with blue collar workers and others whose lives have been devastated by the ''Reagan boom.''
 
DAVID MERMELSTEIN
 New York, Jan. 17, 1990
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Polytechnic University.

HEADLINE: Chinese Know What Human Rights Mean

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leo A. Orleans's criticism of the Chinese student leader Li Lu (letter, Jan. 24) suggests an almost heartbreaking insensitivity. One can only assume Mr. Orleans knows very little about this thoughtful and principled student and his perspective on the China spring of 1989. 
The assertion that ''unthinking and arrogant students'' are responsible for having caused an ''unnecessary setback'' to China's economic growth and political liberalization shows not merely blindness to the 1989 democracy movement, which unquestionably had broad popular support, but also a dangerously corrosive cynicism. Mr. Orleans would have liked the Chinese students to abandon ''unrealistic rhetoric about democracy and human rights.'' But they should have ''continued to combat corruption, inflation and the many other ills now plaguing China.'' How should they have gone about this? On what resources should they have drawn?
One of the inescapable lessons to emerge from the worldwide democracy movements of 1989-90, to which China's democracy movement contributed even in defeat, was that freedom of expression is essential to political and economic development alike and that press freedom, for which the students appealed, is a key to the exposure and reform of official corruption. The events of the last year have also made clear that human rights concepts, while deriving from Western sources, find clear resonances in other traditions and growing relevance in other societies. We are privileged to have Li Lu among us as a student at Columbia University.
 
IRENE BLOOM
 New York, Jan. 25, 1990
 
The writer is an assistant professor of Oriental studies, Barnard College.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY

 BODY:

Florida Imposes Fees for Fishing In Saltwater
Florida has begun, as of Jan. 1, requiring a saltwater fishing license for residents and visitors. Freshwater anglers in Florida have long needed a license. The cost of the saltwater license for visitors is $30 a year or $15 for a seven-day license. A stamp for the taking of crayfish (sometimes referred to as Florida lobster) is an additional $2 as is a stamp for catching snook. Children under 16 are exempt from the fees.
The licenses are available at all county tax collector's offices and at many bait and tackle shops. The counties tack on a 50-cent service charge and the tackle shops can add another $1.50. 
Most captains of the charter fishing fleet have licensed their vessels for saltwater fishing, and guests on those boats do not need a license. It is a good idea to check with the captain regarding licensing as infractions carry a $500 fine.
The new law applies to all fish brought into Florida by boat even if the fish were taken in international waters.
The law applies to all saltwater fishing, whether from the beach, a pier or a canoe. Money collected from the licenses will go for saltwater marine research and for marine law enforcement.
Freshwater fishing license for nonresidents is $30 a year or $15 for seven days.
 
Egyptology Plus Kenya
On one tour travelers can study Egyptian history with an Egyptologist by their side. On another they may not examine ancient sites in such depth but they will do some sightseeing and cruise along the Nile - and do some game viewing in Kenya as well.
The 15-day tour with the Egyptologist John Anthony West, the author of ''The Traveler's Key to Ancient Egypt'' (Knopf), is called ''Sacred Sites and Sacred Science in Ancient Egypt.'' Mr. West will speak at length on sites including Giza, Sakkara, Abydos, Dendera, Luxor, the Valley of the Kings (with Karnak, Edfu and Komombo), Aswan, Thilae Tempe and Abu Simbel.s A March 16 trip costs $2,695 a person, double occupancy, and is available through Sphinx Tours (721 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022; 212-832-3120). A trip leaving April 20 and costing $2,700 can be booked with Vicki Doyle Tours (1700 James Payne Circle, McLean, Va. 22101; 703-241-2241). Rates include round-trip air fare from New York and most meals.
Mr. West (518-678-9580) doesn't make the reservations but he's happy to talk to travelers about their trips. AFRICAN TRAVEL (1000 East Broadway, Glendale, Calif. 91205; 800-722-7755 or, in California, 800-252-0493) offers the tour combining Kenya with Egypt, a 17-day trip. After flying to Cairo and spending a day there, the party flies on to Nairobi for game-viewing excursions in the Abderdare Forest, the Masai Mara and other areas, and a stay at the Treetops resort. Then there's a flight to Luxor, Egypt, and a four-day cruise down the Nile aboard the Sonesta Nile to Cairo. The price is $2,995 a person, including air transportation from New York. The first of several departures is on April 27.
 
Faster Trains In Europe
The planned start of new high-speed rail service in West Germany and improvements to Britain's high-speed system will mean shorter rides and more conveniences for rail travelers on some European routes.
GermanRail will introduce its new InterCity Express trains along its Hamburg-Munich line on June 2, 1991. The trains, which can reach speeds of 165 miles an hour, will take about two hours off the eight-and-a-half-hour journey, according to a GermanRail spokeswoman. Service along the 512-mile route is expected to operate daily. One-way fares will be $149 for first class and $99 for second-class.
Passengers on most GermanRail long-distance routes can now enjoy uninterrupted telephone service, even inside tunnels. The improved phones can be found on all new InterRegio trains - they run every two hours and connect smaller cities - and most hourly InterCity trains. With the addition of on-board lockers, passengers may also store luggage and other valuables free of charge.
BritRail placed the first batch of its new high-speed trains, the InterCity 225, into service on the London-Leeds line in October. The trains, which currently average 98 miles an hour, can cover the 186-mile route in about 2 hours and 5 minutes, which is as much as 15 minutes less than regular trains. Rail officials expect that figure to improve once the completion of electrification along the line allows the trains to operate at their top speed of 140 miles an hour.
BritRail offers InterCity 225 service three times a day from London to Leeds with one return trip. One-way fares are $88 for first class and $60 for economy.
 
Yankee Weekend In Massachusetts
OLD STURBRIDGE VILLAGE, the living history museum in Massachusetts that reflects rural life in the early 1800's, and the Publick House historic inn are collaborating in a series of Yankee winter weekends through March. Guests at the inn are welcomed on Friday evenings by a host in frock coat and a hostess in long Colonial gown who usher them into the parlor for some syllabub - a traditional New England drink combining white wine, cream and a dash of apple brandy - by the hearth. Then the party moves to the taproom for roasted chestnuts and buffet and musical entertainment.
After what is described as farmhand's breakfast on Saturday morning, visitors can get some exercise by strolling through the village, a mile from the Publick House, stopping to chat with costumed interpreters who re-enact the daily activities of 19th-century homesteaders. The 200-acre village has some 40 buildings from all over New England, including a meeting house on the common, school house, general store and the Bullard Tavern.
Various activities are promised.The package ends after Sunday breakfast.
The packages cost $225 a person, in double occupancy, or $195 for those who stay in the Country Motor Lodge next to the inn or the Colonel Ebenezer Crafts Inn just over a mile away; children 5 and under are $50, 6 to 15, $100.
Prices include welcome party, meals, entertainment, taxes and tips and admission to Old Sturbridge Village. Reservations: Publick House on the Common, Sturbridge, Mass. 01566 (508-347-3313).
THE WAUWINET, a 40-room beachfront inn on Nantucket, Massachusetts, has designed a package for romantics that it says would make an ideal gift for Valentine's Day. The package is of three, four or five days and includes a dozen long-stemmed roses in guests' rooms, which look out on Nantucket Bay or the Atlantic, breakfast in bed (on one morning), breakfast on other days, and a dinner by candlelight in the inn's restaurant, Topper's. Champagne on arrival, use of tennis courts and tips are also covered by the price: from $990 a couple for two nights to $1,530 for four nights from April 4 through June 14 and Sept. 24 through Dec. 3.
 
French Vineyards On Tour Series
A series of Wine Discovery Tours is planned for wine lovers who wish to combine sightseeing with visits to many of France's small family-run vineyards. The Wine Society of America (800-367-2675), a 20,000 member organization devoted to wine appreciation, and the tour operator Abercrombie & Kent (800-323-7308) are sponsoring four tour packages in late summer and early fall. They include the Loire Valley (Aug. 20 to 30), the Bordeaux Region (Sept. 2 to 10), Champagne and Alsace (Sept. 30 to Oct. 7), and a barge tour through Burgundy (Oct. 8 to 16).
Tour groups will be limited to 17 to 20 people to allow participants to meet the winemakers and vineyard owners, according to David Banford, president of the Wine Society. These sessions will feature lunches at growers' estates, wine tastings and cellar tours. The tours will be led by Steven Spurrier, a wine merchant and the head of the Academie du Vin, a Paris institute that focuses on wine education.
All wines, including those served at lunches, dinners and tastings, are included in the packages, which cost from $3,130 to $3,320 a person in double occupancy and do not include air fare. The Wine Society requires that all participants purchase memberships, which are $19.95.
 
Philosophy In Ski Country
THE HAWK INN AND MOUNTAIN RESORT (800-451-4109 or 802-672-3811) in Plymouth, Vt., is offering a three-day winter package aimed primarily at the mind rather than the ski slopes. The Vermont Inquiry program is a series of seminars on topics, including ''Re-evaluating the Eisenhower Years'' (Feb. 9 to 11), ''Haydn's Sonatas'' (Feb. 16 to 18), ''The Real and Unreal in Everyday Life'' (Feb. 23 to 25) and ''Conceptions of Happiness'' (March 2 to 4).
The program, organized by faculty members at New England colleges, including Dartmouth and Williams, continues through early April; a summer program is scheduled to begin in June. Rates are $395 a person in double occupancy, which includes two dinners, two breakfasts, two nights' accommmodations, books (mailed in advance to participants) and use of the resort's recreational facilities.
THE CORTINA INN (800-451-6108 or 802-773-3331) at Killington, Vt., is offering a five-night package that allows skiers to ski a different Vermont mountain every day. Along with nearby Killington and Pico, Okemo is about 20 miles from the inn. For $579 a person, double occupancy, guests get five nights' lodging, five dinners and breakfasts, five days of lift tickets for any ski area in the state (except Mad River Glen), a sleigh ride and $25 credit on any piece in the Cortina Inn's art gallery.
Agents Predict Australia Boom
Australia is likely to be the favored overseas destination for the 1990's, at least among clients of American Express travel agents, according to a survey of 450 of the company's travel agents. The poll, conducted between Sept. 16 and Oct. 13, 1989, also found that Orlando is the most popular domestic vacation city among American Express customers and that cruises continue to rise in popularity as a favorite type of vacation. The findings are part of the company's 1989-90 Winter Travel Forecast, a survey based on the advance bookings of the company's agents across the country.
Florida was named as the most popular domestic destination, with Disney World-Epcot most often cited as a major objective.
After Florida, the top winter destinations at home were Hawaii, Colorado, California and Nevada. Britain is the most popular foreign destination this winter, according to the survey, which listed Mexico, the Caribbean, France and Austria, Spain and Switzerland - tied for fifth place - as runners-up.
In addition to Australia, the most popular overseas destinations for the next decade, the agents reported, are likely to be the Caribbean, Mexico, New Zealand and the Soviet Union.
 
Visa Help In London
For travelers to London who decide to visit another country on short notice, a business that expedites visas is a good place to know about. The Visa Shop supplies current information on visa requirments and turns around visa applications for any country in the fastest time possible. It can also supply new passports and extended visas. The charge for obtaining a visa is about $21 above the required application fees.
The Visa Shop also advises on work permits for businessmen, students and others. For a fee starting from about $259 it can obtain permits within two weeks, as long as it has the right documentation, as opposed to the 10 weeks that it usually takes. It also offers advice on setting up business in Britain.
The Visa Shop (Charing Cross Shopping Arcade, London WC2. telephone 379 0419 or 379 0376) is in the Charing Cross shopping arcade near the Charing Cross Underground and main-line stations.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4238 words

HEADLINE: MARTIN AMIS: DOWN LONDON'S MEAN STREETS

BYLINE: By Mira Stout: Mira Stout is an American writer living in London. Her work has appeared in The Financial Times, The Spectator and The Paris Review.

 BODY:
MARTIN AMIS IS probably fiction's angriest writer. In Britain, with its long and decorous literary tradition, his voice stands out discordantly from the rest like a boom box at a harpsichord recital. His urban satires have provoked extreme reactions in Britain, none more so than his latest, most ambitious novel, ''London Fields.'' Although mysteriously absent from this year's nominations for the Booker Prize, England's most prestigious literary award, the book is in the midst of a long run near the top of the best-seller list and has triggered phenomenal media attention. In recent years, Amis has become an outright literary star - an anomaly in Britain. But then, his prose is probably more American than British in its energy and raucousness. For many critics, Amis's comic talent is unrivaled, but for others, mostly older and conservative readers, he is a malevolent harpie, with morbid, vaguely unpatriotic interests. Intriguingly, his father is Kingsley Amis, one of Britain's original Angry Young Men of the 1950's, now a Thatcherite Conservative. Martin sees a fouler England than his father does. 
''London is a pub,'' he declares, looking disgustedly out of his study window into the gray street below. ''Not the pub with the jolly butcher and the smiling grannies; it's the pub of eight or nine alcoholics, a handful of hustlers and nutcases and a few token regular people. It's a stew,'' he declares. ''The whole idea of the pub as a place for the working man has vanished. Who's working? Now the pub is where you go all day. We're in a gentle, deep decline,'' he says quietly. ''Not as frenzied as America's, but perhaps even more poignant, more tragic.''
Shoppers at London's chic Burlington Arcade or tourists queueing for tickets to the latest Andrew Lloyd-Webber extravaganza may disagree with him; the British look richer than they did a decade ago. BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes jam the bus lanes, the Royal Family soap opera is better than ever, and Thatcher's Government is enjoying its 10th consecutive year of Tory rule. On the surface, all looks well indeed, and for many it is. As in most things English, London's malaise is subtle, and class-inflected. ''London Fields'' - to be published in America next month - floodlights the sagging underbelly of Thatcherite consumerism.
Now 40 years old, Amis has written six novels, a collection of short stories and another of articles. Where his early, more self-gratifying novels were a pungent brew of sex, drugs and murder, his recent work (fiction and nonfiction) has ambitiously opened out into junk culture, nuclear weapons, America, and now the destruction of the environment. He traces his characters' destructive behavior to the overwhelming shadow of the bomb. Says a jaded character in ''London Fields'': ''If at any moment nothing might matter, then who says nothing didn't matter already?''
Talking politics with Amis, it's easy to forget that he is a satirical writer; his pitch-black humor springs from a bristling arsenal of outrage, despair and fear. ''If you laugh at it, it evens things out, makes it easier to live with,'' he says. Amis's laughter is vengeful; vigilante humor.
His last few novels have buried the myth of a decent, gentle, pastoral England, paving over the site with cement-hard observations of a seedy, queasy new Britain, part strip-joint, part Buckingham Palace. If 10 years of Thatcherism have materially bolstered Britain, there is a grudging national consensus that prosperity has hardened her spirit. Amis's mean London streets are litter-strewn, vandalized; morality is nudged toward bankruptcy by ''market forces.'' His characters are close to the edge, more like New Yorkers than traditionally stoic Londoners. Amis's sharp social ear prompts some comparison with Tom Wolfe, but he's more literary, idiosyncratic, closer to Nabokov in his primary, sensuous delight in language. ''London Fields'' is not a chronicle of London in the way that Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' is a tale of New York; Amis's is a more personal, oblique urban vision. Plot is always subordinate to language in his fiction, to the frustration of some readers. Even aficionados find his work nearly unreadable in places, and routinely painful. He demands absolute unsqueamishness as far as expletives, body secretions, psychological cruelty and even sadism are concerned. He has an extortionist's talent for knowing people's secret fears, creating a climate of danger and paranoia. ''London Fields'' is a meditation on the millennium - disguised as a murder mystery. Narrated by a young American writer living in the trendy West London neighborhood of Notting Hill Gate, most of Amis's tragicomedy of sleaze and death takes place in a sinister pub called the Black Cross, a locale that epitomizes the squalor hidden behind London's posh facade.
British novelists, from Iris Murdoch to David Lodge, have closed ranks against the new unpleasantness, ignored its consequences and settled in marginal enclaves of finer sensibility. With few exceptions, British fiction reflects the sovereignty of cozy, self-examining middle-class life: second-marriage angst, dinner-party betrayals, university-tenure feuds. Where his colleagues' writing is spare and cerebral, Amis is an unabashed maximalist: his work is refreshingly emotional, even carnal. He feels that ''good readers'' don't want to be shielded. ''My stuff is fairly sentimental; it's a lot worse out there,'' he says sadly.
I SPENT SOME TIME with Amis not long after he had finished his new novel. We met several times in his bachelorish writing flat in Westbourne Park, a bleak outpost of Notting Hill Gate. He explained apologetically that his wife did not allow interviewers in the house, a mile away.
Amis opened the front door of the forbidding Victorian rectory, greeting me with a sympathetic combination of professional wariness and animal curiosity. He has already been the subject of an extraordinary number of British interviews. Having read quite a few of them, I expected him to be small (around 5 feet 6) and clever, but what doesn't emerge from press clippings is his youthfulness, a quality of jaded teen-age swagger. The combination of his shortness and his bunchy, athletic build gives him the look of a boy-man. He wears nondescript clothes, except for a pair of raunchy black ankle boots with cowboy heels.
In the kitchen Amis clumsily made some tea, chatting companionably as he struggled with the kettle. His high, bulging forehead and single dark eyebrow give him a moody air even when he's laughing, and his deep-set eyes and pouting mouth are cold in repose. His treacle-brown hair, cut short, is thinning slightly. He has a powerful, attractive presence.
The first thing you notice in the flat is the pinball machine parked in the kitchen. Amis is a famous pinball nut. Perhaps he cultivates a bad-boy image to counter the seriousness and stridency of his writing. Altogether the flat resembles an all-male clubhouse, a sanctuary from grown-up pressure and parental taste. It's vaguely organized around typing and books, but the dart board, scruffy stereo, video and television set seem equally important. The odd children's book and woman's straw hat are the only jarring evidence of his family-man status.
In the newspaper-strewn study Amis spoke in a relaxed, candid way about his work. He was not the egomaniac that other journalists have described, but his self-assurance occasionally veered into profound self-satisfaction. He gives off complex signals; despite his worldly, wised-up manner Amis's natural curiosity makes him appear unexpectedly open and vulnerable, but also capable of sudden and vicious attack. His speech is enjoyably close to his narrative style - peppered with vivid adjectives and American slang, but the accent is standard Oxford issue. I ask him about his childhood. ''Childhood? What childhood?'' he exclaims. ''When Nabokov said a writer's childhood was his treasure chest, I thought, 'Christ, what do I do? I haven't got one.' '' He claims not to regret its absence.
Amis's paternal grandfather was a mustard clerk from Clapham, and his mother's father was a suburban shoe millionaire. Kingsley Amis is twice divorced, and Martin's mother is on her third marriage; in a fairly bizarre family arrangement, Kingsley, now divorced from the novelist Elizabeth Jane Howard, lives as a lodger with Martin's mother and her third husband.
Martin was the middle child of three, including an older brother, Philip, now a graphic designer, and a younger sister, Sally. ''I was the steady one.'' Amis attended approximately 14 different schools during the 1950's and 60's, due to the great success of his father's masterly picaresque novel ''Lucky Jim,'' which swept Kingsley broadly around the university circuit, including a year at Princeton, which introduced Martin to America.
The home atmosphere was permissive. ''Something out of early Updike, 'Couples' flirtations and a fair amount of drinking. They were all 'at it.' '' Amis speaks of his mother, Hilly, adoringly, stressing that her generous philosophy influenced him as strongly as his father's humor. He was devastated, at 12, by his parents' divorce.
''I had a passionate street life; going to pubs and betting shops, smoking dope a bit. My parents were lax about girls, too,'' he remembers happily. He mainly read comic books until his stepmother, the novelist Elizabeth Jane Howard, urged Jane Austen upon him. He was a mod, briefly (''too many scooter crashes''), and then a hippie (''flowered shirt, velvet suit, far more relaxing''). But it was all a pose, he admits. He reformed academically before too much damage had been done, and went off abruptly to Oxford, where he earned a first-class degree from Exeter College.
A seemingly effortless journalistic-literary career followed: entry-level job at The Times Literary Supplement; literary editor of The New Statesman at 27; feature writer for The Observer, author of sensationally reviewed novels at roughly two-year intervals. Writing seemed a natural path for Amis, growing up in a literary household. He was 20 when he began, but Kingsley famously displayed negligible interest in his son's work. Martin's reputation may now supersede his father's: an uncomfortable but not an acrimonious situation, both claim. Their ''rivalry'' is of such interest in Britain that when the National Portrait Gallery invited father and son to pose together for a double portrait, Kingsley's touchy refusal made the front page of The Sunday Telegraph. According to Martin, his father later regretted the fuss. Their relationship is unusually close - they even kiss cheeks un-Englishly, upon greeting - but they disagree about virtually everything: politics, people, literature. ''Several times he has even dumped on me in print,'' Martin laughs smartingly. His fondness for his father is such that he has never publicly retaliated, nor objected to Kingsley's opinions of his work. Martin takes it sadly, makes light of it. Apparently, Kingsley liked the beginning of his son's last novel, ''Money,'' a hectic tour of lowlife New York, London and Los Angeles, but didn't finish it. ''I can point out the exact place where he stopped and sent the book twirling through the air; that's where the character named Martin Amis comes in. 'Breaking the rules, buggering about with the reader, drawing attention to himself,' '' Martin says wearily, reciting his father's litany of complaints.
The novelist Julian Barnes explains: ''They do love one another. That established, Kingsley feels that he doesn't have to hold back in any other area, so he makes no pretense. Scandalously, I think, when it comes to the press. For Martin, it's a hurt that will never go away. The good side is, it's acted as a form of vaccination for Martin. If his father, whom he loves, dislikes his books, then it really doesn't matter what any critics say.''
I spoke to Kingsley Amis on the phone at home in North London. Reworking a new novel, he seemed glad to break and talk about Martin. He spoke gruffly, and with an enormous fondness that he occasionally sacrificed for a good cutting remark. He began cautiously: ''I think that if anyone's reading us both in fifty or a hundred years' time, we shall seem like very much the same kind of writer. We're more similar than we seem in some ways; we have a similar sense of verbal, spoken humor. We compete with each other on that, always have, in a family-joke way.''
One of Kingsley's main reservations is Martin's constant surveillance of his characters' bedrooms and bathrooms, which he feels is misguided and ''in poor taste.'' He modifies: ''Sex is a fascinating area, but it's harder than he thinks. Nobody says that fiction should be able to discuss everything; he thinks he can do it, but I wonder if he can.'' Kingsley Amis is upset when accused of being hard on his son. ''To be 'hard' on someone is to be unfair, inappropriate. What I would describe is a strong, even furious opposition of views.'' He pauses. ''I'd like to say this about him: I admire him very much as a man. He's responsible, and above all sane. I like sanity.'' And Martin's political views? ''They're a lot of dangerous, howling nonsense,'' he thunders, ''but apart from that I regard him as one of my best and closest friends.'' He's explosive on Martin's view of Thatcher: ''If London has gotten more dirty and squalid and violent in Thatcher's day, she hasn't done that - I think it would be much worse without her. Anyone with Martin's income has no right to complain. I say that very, very loudly, and rather crossly.''
Abruptly returning to writing, Amis says unexpectedly: ''But apart from Martin Amis, new British writers are disappointing. They should be doing what Martin's doing. When you get to be my age, a writer ought to be saying, 'Can't see what these young fellows are on about!' But with this lot, I can see only too well, and it's not very interesting. I'd rather read detective novels.''
Saul Bellow is another admirer from the older generation. He's a sort of hero to the younger Amis, who quotes him both in his novels and in conversation. I spoke to Bellow on the phone in Chicago. He and Amis had met when Martin interviewed him several years ago, and a master-apprentice friendship was struck. Bellow was amiable, and charming. I asked him what he thought of Martin's controversial prose style.
''There are two ways for fiction to go - one is to use an uncharged language which subordinates itself to the story and characters entirely, and the other is to use a charged language. Martin certainly uses a charged language. Anyone with that much of a feeling for words is bound to be accused of putting words first,'' he says equably. ''This was the case with Flaubert and Joyce, to begin with. Some critics felt that the poetry monopolized everything. I understand this intoxication with a new way of writing. The discovery is an overpowering one when it happens; you find you have a new way to write about modern life. And that's pretty heady.''
Does Bellow think that Martin Amis has the inventive genius of a Joyce or Flaubert? ''Yes, I do. I see signs of a very large outline.''
ONE DAY AMIS launches headlong into his pet topic, decline:
''The 19th-century British novel was, if you like, a superpower novel. It was 800 pages long, about the whole of society. With decline, the novel has shrunk in confidence, in scope. In its current form, the typical English novel is 225 sanitized pages about the middle classes,'' he says. ''You know, 'well-made' with the nice color scheme and decor, and matching imagery. I almost try and avoid form. What I'm interested in is trying to get more truthful about what it's like to be alive now.''
Amis bemoans the escapist, nostalgic leanings of the British toward their own country. He's bemused by foreigners' dated view of Britain as the land of tweedy aristocratic grandeur and dominance, the world of P. G. Wodehouse and Evelyn Waugh. His own focus is the brash ascendancy of tabloid England, the downmarket world of Page Three pinups, Bingo greed and soap stars' abortions. He finds a rich source of comedy in contrasting the resentment-fueled economic rise of the working class against the slump of the largely ineffectual, burned-out upper class. ''Dead Babies,'' ''Success,'' ''Money'' and ''London Fields'' all feature bulldog-tenacious, kicked-around Cockneys barely triumphing over haughty, stunned aristocrats. Amis is sometimes criticized for caricaturing rather than characterizing his subjects, but he's quick to point out that he places no value judgments on his characters' actions (no matter how rotten); he's hardly a champion of the working classes, but he considers Thatcher's formula that money equals democracy ''facile.'' Unlike America, Britain has been a traditionally modest, even money-scorning culture, and its quick transition to a brass-knuckled state has been rather graceless, Amis feels, unaccompanied by inner generosity or fraternal spirit: ''I think Thatcher has done a lot of harm. The money age we're living through now is a short-term, futureless kind of prosperity that will last as long as there are public institutions to sell off, and as long as North Sea oil lasts. But it's really a 'live now, pay later' thing. Money is a more democratic medium than blood, but money as a cultural banner - you can feel the whole of society deteriorating around you because of that. Civility, civilization is falling apart.'' Keith Talent, the protagonist of ''London Fields,'' embodies the spirit of his age. A witless, wife-beating darts enthusiast, ''Keith cheated people with his limousine service at airports and train stations; he cheated people with his fake scents and colognes at the pavement stalls of Oxford Street and Bishopsgate . . . he cheated people with non-pornographic pornography in the back rooms of short-lease stores. . . . Keith earned three times as much as the Prime Minister and never had any money, losing heavily every day at the turf accountants on Portobello Road. . . . Sometimes he would ponder this on alternate Thursday lunchtimes, in his sheepskin overcoat, his head bent over the racing page, as he queued for his unemployment benefit. . . .''
Rolling himself a lumpy cigarette from a ratty-looking tobacco pouch, Amis readily talks about how the new book expresses his preoccupation with becoming middle-aged; it's a forced, angry farewell to selfish pleasures.
''It's a little death, middle age. Romantic possibility . . . changes,'' he strains, looking a bit dreamy. ''It's calmer waters now, windless seas - if not the doldrums,'' he says, unable to squash a note of petulance in his voice. ''You always thought it was a hilarious secret that while everyone else got old, you weren't. But children redefine everything for you. A lot of the self is lost, thank God; the internal gibber of wants and need dies down,'' he lectures, not very convincingly.
In 1984, Amis married Antonia Phillips, a widowed Bostonian philosophy teacher. Without prompting, he goes over to his desk and with classic pride shows me a snapshot of his sons, Louis and Jacob (5 and 3), a couple of towheaded boys plying a pair of giant milkshakes. The sight cheers him. ''That's beer,'' he jokes.
Despite being sidelined by married monogamy, Amis is still a keen observer of the sexual arena. His fascination with its dark side reaches a new low - or high, depending on one's taste - in ''London Fields.'' It's his blackest statement yet in a canon of black statements about sexual love. If his life has become G-rated, his work now earns an X. Amis insists that he uses sex as a vehicle for revealing characters ''when they're not just going through the motions.'' It's an area where need and greed converge, and where tenderness is accidental, a rare thrill.
Amis's early notoriety as a famous (Continued on Page 48) writer's son, and later as a successful author in his own right, provoked mixed but intense attention well before the publication of ''London Fields.'' He says journalists' often hostile jabs don't affect him, but his sensitivity is obvious in his sneering, humorless television appearances and in the crucifying glares he gives to publicity photographers.
His open contempt for the press has fed his spoiled reputation. His arrogance so disgusted Private Eye that the paper referred to him for many years as ''Smarty Anus.'' The press has also resented his literary connections. From his father's milieu to his Oxford friends and premarital girlfriends, Amis's close contacts number practically the whole of ''quality'' British publishing, and an upmarket chunk of New York's as well. (He's associated with The Observer, Tatler, Granta, The New Statesman, Viking Penguin, Jonathan Cape, The Nation, Esquire, Vanity Fair, to name a few.) ''His mixture of precocity, great intelligence, and wide sexual success is bound to provoke envy,'' says Julian Barnes. ''People try to write like Martin. There's something very infectious and competitive about it.''
Unlike many Englishmen, Amis doesn't apologize for his success. He now lives in a respectable family house in leafy Ladbroke Grove, but his work remains faithful to the esthetics of squalor. He's aware of leading something of a double life, and isn't completely comfortable with his new padding of wealth or the vantage de haut en bas. Never poor, Amis has become very well off. His advances have skyrocketed from a Dickensian $400 to a Hollywood-ish $150,000. According to friends, his wife, Antonia, is rich in her own right. Fame has not made him ''grand,'' as some claim, but ''busy,'' he corrects. His curtailed appearances on the London party circuit have given him a snobbish profile, but an old friend says: ''Martin's actually quite bad at parties, so he doesn't go to them anymore. He usually ends up talking to the waiter.''
In contrast to his allegedly wild younger days, Amis now leads a disciplined life. He breakfasts at 8:30 with the live-in nanny and children (his wife sleeps on), drives to the office via the boys' Montessori school, works until 2 or 3 (telephone off the hook). He is a serious tennis player; he drives to the Paddington Sports Club for his daily game. He is home by 6:15. When his wife attends the opera, Amis baby-sits, ''earning brownie points so I can play snooker later in the week. Marriage with children is all credit and debit, you know. My wife is a strong character, and I don't get away with much,'' he confesses. ''Some wives are rivals, muses, agents. My wife is just a wife. You don't get special treatment,'' he says in a rebuked tone. Amis is a hardened snooker addict. He joined a smart Pall Mall club not for prestige, he contends, but for its pool table. Sunday night is his regular snooker night.
FOR OUR FINAL RENDEZVOUS, I accompanied Amis to a book party for environmental causes. He picked me up in a taxi around 6 P.M., clutching a furled copy of Tennis magazine. His hair neatly combed, he was dressed almost smartly in a Prince of Wales plaid suit and dark coat - his white shirt bore a prominent stain. It was a rare, beautifully clear evening, and Amis was in a relaxed mood. South Kensington's facades flowed regally past the taxi window, transformed by sunlight. Kensington Gardens were overflowing with fresh summer foliage. London looked startlingly clean.
I asked Martin casually about his involvement with environmental issues. ''Paradise is a toilet!'' he exploded in a rehearsed way. ''It's as if the planet had aged four billion years in the last two centuries. If this had happened to a human being, you'd say, 'Jesus, what's he been up to? He looked like Apollo yesterday, now he looks like Methuselah!''
So is it all over? Is everything for sale? I asked at a traffic light.
''The theme that the good is gone is as old as literature. Everything has been cheapened; the accumulation of experience is causing decay,'' Amis replied gravely, sounding like a skeptical dentist. And man's capacity to love? ''Romantic love will always be there, but it's harder for it to flourish. As Bellow says, ours is a sclerotic Eros. I think there's a lot of romanticism in my work'' - my eyebrows shot up involuntarily - ''but it's thwarted by distortion and perversity, false commercial images in TV, literature, porn. The fact is, my satire wouldn't work if what I'm satirizing were not valued. Like Philip Larkin's poetry, love is conspicuous by it's absence.''
Martin Amis's instincts are chivalrous. By imagining the worst possible scenarios - addictiveness, child abuse, urban decay, nuclear holocaust - he seems to want to avert the impending disasters by giving us a test run, sending in his fictional characters to show the damage we'll run up. He knows he can't save anyone, but he wants us to see the danger and to experience fear squarely, not drunk on cheap deferral or delusion. But most of all he wants to deflate fear with laughter.
His prose style may shock, but the values behind it are surprisingly traditional: truth, love, compassion, integrity, family. ''But it's no fun to read about, and no fun to write.'' He grinned and climbed out of the taxi. Some photographers were waiting by the party entrance, and a television crew stood nervously by; Martin Amis stood tall and scowled for the cameras.

(Dudley Reed) (pg. 33); Kingsley Amis, Martin's father and one of Britain's Angry Young Men of the 1950's, working at home in 1974. Today he is a Thatcherite. The two men are close, but they disagree on nearly everything; the father has on occasion publicly criticized the son's novels. (Fay Godwin) (pg. 34)
