The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 34, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1209 words

HEADLINE: DIPLOMACY VS. DEMOCRACY

BYLINE: By ALAN TONELSON; Alan Tonelson is completing a book for the Twentieth Century Fund on redefining United States foreign policy interests.

 BODY:

THE ROCKETS' RED GLARE
When America Goes to War:
The Presidents and the People.
By Richard J. Barnet.
476 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $24.95.
If anything has united American foreign policy makers and thinkers throughout our history, it's their contempt for the people. And the view that their countrymen are (depending on the accuser) too bellicose, xenophobic, selfish, naive or just plain stupid to know their true interests has driven American leaders to try to conduct foreign policy on the sly for more than 200 years. 
As Richard J. Barnet, a well-known leftist critic of contemporary American foreign policy and the author of ''Real Security'' and other books, argues in ''The Rockets' Red Glare,'' there are at least three things wrong with this approach: first, the United States is supposed to be a democracy; second, many of these secret policies have concerned paramount questions of war and peace; and third, the record compiled by our statesmen and experts is nothing to brag about.
His study of public opinion and American diplomacy contains ample evidence to document the gap between democratic rhetoric and the reality of foreign policy making since the Revolutionary era and the problems repeatedly created by it. What is largely missing, however, is the theoretical and philosophical discussion needed to figure out the proper role of public opinion in American foreign policy, let alone to support his grand conclusion that ''popular participation [in foreign policy making] is becoming more necessary but also more possible.''
Despite Mr. Barnet's plain sympathies and the string of official foul-ups and disasters stretching back to the War of 1812 that he colorfully recounts, few will finish ''The Rockets' Red Glare'' confident that the public's preferred foreign policies would have served American interests better - that is, when clear preferences could be discerned at all. The first four Presidents, for example, spent much of their terms desperately trying to restrain or defuse public demands to attack one or another European power for all manner of real and imagined insults, despite the young republic's military weakness. The elitists, in other words, tended to be peaceniks. And even in 1968, Mr. Barnet acknowledges, more Americans wanted to end the Vietnam War by escalation than by unilateral withdrawal.
Ironically, the author scores his most telling points in favor of more power to the people while examining the period in which public irresponsibility allegedly peaked: the 1920's and 30's. As Mr. Barnet astutely observes, the divine right still claimed today by foreign policy and public opinion elites even after Vietnam rests on the view that the public permanently disqualified itself from a lead foreign policy role by pigheadedly ignoring the fascist threat. But Mr. Barnet builds a credible case that ''the American people were ready to be educated by events and to follow the president whenever he chose to lead.'' Tragically, President Franklin D. Roosevelt sold his own powers of persuasion short.
Still, the debate over democratizing our foreign policy ultimately turns on questions that are not empirical. How, for example, can the public's desires be determined in the first place? Do we want government by Gallup poll? Even if some foolproof way of sampling public opinion were found, who would decide which alternatives should be presented? What if only small minorities register strong opinions? What if no clear winner emerges? How would the tie-breaker work? More broadly, must all decisions require explicit public approval? If not, when should official discretion be permitted? And should leaders ever rely on their consciences or their expertise? These issues, whose centrality Mr. Barnet recognizes, are hardly insuperable. But they are practically ignored. His overemphasis on the narrative flow of history makes for a book that is fun to read but also inconsequential for anyone interested in changing policy.
More troubling is the fact that part of his failure to address such questions clearly reflects a belief that the stunning international changes of the late 80's have rendered most of them moot. After all, the built-in conflict between foreign policy needs and democratic processes assumes a world of nations unavoidably locked in a struggle for security and advantage. Nations that cannot act secretly and speedily may have two strikes against them.
Mr. Barnet is obviously correct in suggesting that if traditional international power politics is rapidly fading in importance, and if true security now requires greatly expanded international cooperation, then speed and stealth count for much less. Indeed, in such a world, the openness, adaptability and unchallengeable legitimacy of genuine democracies could be foreign policy assets, not liabilities. But if, as is equally plausible, power politics is also simply taking new forms - for even global problems such as environmental destruction can affect different states in different ways, and the quick and the strong are still likeliest to see their preferred solutions chosen - the tension between democracy and foreign policy effectiveness will resurface.
The only way out of this bind may be to take a cue from the Founding Fathers. They confronted a choice between national security and the intrinsic inefficiencies of democracy. But rather than bow to national security (as the architects of our cold war strategy were to do a century and a half later) or pretend that the competition between the two concerns could be wished away (a la Mr. Barnet), they chose democracy - or, more precisely, republican government. They determinedly divided political power and produced a Constitution that, as Clement Attlee once ruefully observed, was designed for an ''isolationist state.'' Either the Framers were hopelessly naive or they knew something about America's latent strength, natural wealth and potential geopolitical security that indicated the new nation could afford a thoroughly democratic foreign policy much more than most other countries if it took advantage of its good fortune.
Two hundred years later, the possibilities for detachment from foreign conflicts are narrower, but they have by no means vanished completely. If Americans truly want to regain firm control over their foreign policy, they may well have to shift away from the broad internationalist approach followed since Pearl Harbor.
This change would rule out many policies that Mr. Barnet does not like, chiefly the focus on ''traditional war planning and war-prevention strategies,'' the maintenance of military alliances and reflexive opposition to third-world revolution. But it would also rule out many policies that he has long supported - e.g., massive aid for the third world and deep United States involvement in a new set of global economic planning agencies. In this post-cold war era, Mr. Barnet's call for democratizing American foreign policy is worth heeding and might be feasible. But he may well find himself just as unhappy with the resulting new priorities - chiefly, a vigorous search for opportunities to enhance our freedom of action and self-reliance - as he has been with the old ones.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 950 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:

CROOKED HEARTS, by Robert Boswell. (Laurel/Dell, $9.95.) For the members of the Warren family of Yuma, Ariz., disappointment is such an expected part of life that they throw parties to celebrate their latest failures. This novel is ''rich and vivid, an intriguingly busy view of the human adventure, the impossible family of man,'' Sharon Sheehe Stark said here in 1987. '' 'Crooked Hearts' is an insightful, nicely turned, amazingly agile piece of work.''
 
INNUMERACY: Mathematical Illiteracy and Its Consequences, by John Allen Paulos. (Vintage, $8.95.) One symptom of mathematical illiteracy is a tendency to believe in what Jung called synchronicity. But as John Allen Paulos demonstrates, even the eeriest coincidences are not as statistically unlikely as they seem. For example, the chance that two strangers have an acquaintance in common is about 1 percent; and 99 out of 100 times one of them will know someone who knows someone the other knows. ''What mathematics the book contains does not go beyond simple arithmetic and very basic probability theory,'' Morris Kline said here last year. ''The innumerate will surely profit from this entertaining book.'' 
 
WHEAT THAT SPRINGETH GREEN, by J. F. Powers. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $8.95.) A priest who has finally been assigned his own parish tries to maintain idealism and humor in an ever more secular world. ''No eye has been sharper, no ear finer than that of J. F. Powers at discerning the nuances of service to God and mammon,'' Amy Edith Johnson said here in 1988. '' 'Wheat That Springeth Green' is funny on every page.'' Washington Square has also reissued Mr. Powers's MORTE D'URBAN ($8.95), the story of a worldly priest sent to the Minnesota wilds for a spiritual overhaul. It won a National Book Award in 1963.
 
TRADING PLACES: How We Are Giving Our Future to Japan and How to Reclaim It, by Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr. (Basic Books, $12.95.) A former United States trade negotiator tells how the country can learn to equate economic well-being with national security and match the Japanese at their own game. ''He writes about hand-to-hand combat between the United States and Japan with great clarity and spirit,'' Jeffrey E. Garten said here in 1988. ''And in the best tradition of insider reflections, the book combines some of the passion surrounding events as they happened with the balanced perspective of a thoughtful post-mortem.'' In a new postscript to YEN! Japan's New Financial Empire and Its Threat to America (Fawcett Columbine, $9.95), Daniel Burstein updates his argument that Reaganomics hurt the United States and helped Japan. In 1988 our reviewer, Edward Boyer, said, ''The most helpful prescription Mr. Burstein comes up with is his plea for a recognition that Americans, like the British before them, live in a world that is no longer entirely theirs.''
 
THE SUNNE IN SPLENDOUR, by Sharon Kay Penman. (Ballantine, $12.95.) In a 936-page historical novel set during the War of the Roses, Sharon Kay Penman upgrades Richard III's image from a villainous humpback to a sensitive, misunderstood ruler whose only handicap is an injured shoulder. '' 'The Sunne in Splendour' is very well researched and sticks closely to real historical details, where they exist,'' Mona Simpson said here in 1982. But she said she was unconvinced by the psychological interpretations of this new incarnation of the last of the Plantagenet kings.
 
LOYALTIES: A Son's Memoir, by Carl Bernstein. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) The former Washington Post reporter tells what it was like growing up with a family of Communists during the McCarthy era. Last year our reviewer, Elinor Langer, said these are ''honest memories, and they offer a useful corrective to the romantic image of 'red diaper babies' commonly held on the left.''
 
RITUAL, by William Heffernan. (Signet/New American Library, $4.95.) A series of copycat murders, inspired by an ancient Toltec sacrificial ceremony, casts suspicion on Kate Silverman, a young Metropolitan Museum curator. ''The suspense is excruciating,'' one reviewer said last year, ''and should keep readers in a state of frenzy to the last page.''
 
UNDERCOVER: The Secret Lives of a Federal Agent, by Donald Goddard. (Dell, $4.95.) A Federal agent with a theatrical bent goes undercover to trick narcotics dealers into betraying themselves. This is ''an exciting account of one agent's obsessive fight against drug traffickers,'' Charles Salzberg said here last year.
 
LOOK INTO THE SUN, by James Patrick Kelly. (Tor, $3.95.) An earthling architect hired by aliens to build a tomb for a dying goddess must overcome a difficult case of culture shock. ''His struggle to maintain his identity while shifting his point of view is treated with admirable seriousness,'' our reviewer, Gerald Jonas, said last year.
 
AT HOME: Essays 1982-1988, by Gore Vidal. (Vintage, $9.95.) Gore Vidal tells why he still thinks the American empire is homophobic, overarmed and ridden with other defects. ''As well as being virtuously subversive, Mr. Vidal is witty about everything from America's cultural forgetfulness to Nancy Reagan's attitude toward the proposed equal rights amendment,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times in 1988.
 
MURDER IN LITTLE EGYPT, by Darcy O'Brien. (Onyx/New American Library, $4.95.) John Dale Cavaness, an Illinois doctor, was convicted of killing one son and is suspected in the shooting death of another. Last year our reviewer, Wendy Kaminer, called this ''a meticulous account of Cavaness's life and crimes [and] an implicit indictment of a culture that condones and encourages violent behavior in men.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 901 words

HEADLINE: THE STR WARS MESS

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE J. KORB; Lawrence J. Korb, a former Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Reagan Administration, is the director of the Center for Public Policy Education at the Brookings Institution.

 BODY:

A SHIELD IN SPACE?
Technology, Politics, and the Strategic Defense Initiative: How the Reagan Administration Set Out to Make Nuclear Weapons ''Impotent and Obsolete'' and Succumbed to the Fallacy of the Last Move.
By Sanford Lakoff and Herbert F. York.
409 pp. Berkeley:
University of California Press. $35. 
On March 24, 1983, Paul Thayer, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, convened a meeting of the top civilian and military leaders of the Defense Department. The purpose was to discuss a nationally televised speech President Ronald Reagan had given the night before, in which he had challenged American scientists to create ''the means of rendering these nuclear weapons impotent and obsolete.'' The Deputy Secretary opened the meeting with words that proved to be prophetic. He asked his colleagues, ''What are we going to do with this mess?''
In ''A Shield in Space?'' Sanford Lakoff, a political scientist at the University of California, San Diego, and Herbert York, a physicist with long Government experience, outline how we got into ''this mess,'' and what the American and international political communities have done with it over the past six years. In a very readable, comprehensive and balanced book, the authors outline the history, the politics, the economics and the technology surrounding the Strategic Defense Initiative (S.D.I.), or ''Star Wars.'' In addition, they discuss the impact of S.D.I. on strategic stability, arms control, the Western alliance and relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.
Their thesis is both simple and persuasive. Because S.D.I. is not just a man-against-nature problem (like going to the moon) but also a man-against-man contest, there will always be a countermeasure or another move. To suggest that effective strategic defenses can be developed and installed at a particular time is both dangerous and misleading.
This is the best book written about S.D.I. to date. Though it is clear from their subtitle that Mr. Lakoff and Mr. York are not sympathetic to the program, they do bend over backwards to present the strategic, technical, economic and military rationales used by supporters of S.D.I. ''A Shield in Space?'' makes it understandable why a renowned scientist like Edward Teller would propose a program like S.D.I., why a master politician like Ronald Reagan would embrace it and why James A. Abrahamson, the director of the Strategic Defense Initiative Office, and Caspar Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense, would support it so zealously and at times excessively. (Indeed, Mr. Abrahamson, an Air Force lieutenant general and a respected career officer, was denied promotion to full general by the Congress in part because of his excessive zeal for the program.) From a scientific and technical point of view, the book is superb. The authors make comprehensible even to the nonspecialist such technical concepts as space-based defense, layered defenses, kinetic energy weapons and directed energy weapons. Moreover, they present excellent summaries of the reports of the scientific groups that have analyzed S.D.I.
From a political point of view, however, the book is not quite as good. On the one hand, Mr. Lakoff and Mr. York do a fine job of describing such things as why S.D.I. became a litmus test of support for Mr. Reagan and his legacy, and why Senator Sam Nunn, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, reacted so strongly against the broad interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty that the program required for deployment.
But the overall political analysis is weak, primarily because the authors did not supplement their research with interviews. In at least two places, Mr. Lakoff and Mr. York fail to see the essence of the politics of S.D.I. First, they ignore the corrupting impact of the program on some of those who become involved with it. For example, Paul Nitze, a great statesman, virtually had to repudiate his own work on the Antiballistic Missile Treaty to endorse the broad interpretation of that treaty supported by Mr. Reagan's followers.
Second, the authors have apparently missed the euthanasia of S.D.I. perpetrated in 1988 by Vice President George Bush and Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci. In an interview with The New York Times, conducted when he was running for the Presidency, Mr. Bush revealed that the emperor had no clothes when he said S.D.I. was very expensive and had technological problems. Later in the year, in a bloodless coup, Mr. Carlucci summarily replaced the flamboyant General Abrahamson as head of the program with the low-keyed George Monahan. Although the move was billed as a routine transfer, General Abrahamson was more than just another Pentagon program manager. The authors seem unaware that he was to S.D.I. what Victor Kiam is to Remington or Lee Iacocca to Chrysler. Finally, after taking office, Mr. Bush recommended cutting the S.D.I. budget he inherited from the Reagan Administration by $1 billion, knowing full well that Congress would make further reductions (which it did).
The mess has been cleaned up and S.D.I. has come back to where it belongs, and where it was before Mr. Reagan's speech - that is, to being a robust research program. Even though they do not recognize that outcome, Mr. Lakoff and Mr. York should be happy with it, and so should the American and international political communities.

AND BEAR IN MIND
 (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
DADDY, WE HARDLY KNEW YOU, by Germaine Greer. (Knopf, $19.95.) Ms. Greer's enormous digressions and rambles are as entertaining as the principal action in this account of her quest to learn the origins of her own father, a man who, she finds, never knew his birth name or parents and lied about what little he knew.
 
A PRESENT OF THINGS PAST: Selected Essays, by Theodore Draper. (Hill & Wang, $25.) Informed, argumentative observations by the hardest-headed of liberals, taking on cold-war bungling, American Communism and journalistic ethics.
 
HELL-BENT MEN AND THEIR CITIES, by Susan Dodd. (Viking, $17.95.) Short stories, intelligent, sympathetic and sometimes satirical, whose brave though unheroic late-20th-century characters endure while keeping one another's spirits up.
 
OCTOPUS: The Long Reach of the International Sicilian Mafia, by Claire Sterling. (Norton, $19.95.) Ms. Sterling's Palermo-based bosses are credited with the creation of a multinational empire whose principal target has long been the United States.
 
VOICES OF FREEDOM: An Oral History of the Civil Rights Movement From the 1950s Through the 1980s, by Henry Hampton and Steve Fayer with Sarah Flynn. (Bantam, $25.95.) An intimate survey sprung from the ''Eyes on the Prize'' television series.
 
HENRY JAMES AND EDITH WHARTON. Letters: 1900-1915, edited by Lyall H. Powers. (Scribners, $29.95.) The delightful record of a friendship between two very high literary pinnacles.
 
THE DAME IN THE KIMONO: Hollywood, Censorship, and the Production Code From the 1920s to the 1960s, by Leonard J. Leff and Jerold L. Simmons. (Grove Weidenfeld, $22.50). What couldn't happen on screen: a virtual negative history of sex in America.

HEADLINE: BASEBOOK NOTEBOOK;
Bo Jackson: He Knows Kids and Family and the Art of Hitting

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Bo Jackson is one player who could have benefited from the threatened lockout if only he had been able to plan for it. No, Bo doesn't need the extra rest between football and baseball seasons. Had he known he might have more time before spring training, he could have planned for more school work.
The remarkable Mr. Jackson is not simply a baseball star, a football star and a television commercial star. He is also a student. In the vernacular his Nike commercial has spawned, Bo knows family and child development.
Jackson is short 23 credits - slightly more than one-quarter's worth of work - of his degree in family and child development at Auburn University. In the third abbreviated off season of his jam-packed professional career, Jackson is taking a required five-credit internship in the school of human sciences. As one of his projects, he is making a videotape aimed at young students about the importance of education. 
The Kansas City Royals wish Jackson had understood the importance of instructional league education, but he opted to play football instead.
''My feeling is he'd be much further ahead as a baseball player, but that's not his agenda,'' John Schuerholz, the Royals' general manager, said.
Even without the extra course work in curveballs and sliders, Jackson has made intriguing progress for a fellow who played only 53 games in the minor leagues after an abbreviated college baseball career. All families and children should develop as well as Jackson has with the Royals.
In his three full seasons, Jackson has raised his average from .235 to .246 to .256, his home runs from 22 to 25 to 32, and his runs batted in from 53 to 68 to 105.
The improvement is also seen in his production per time at bat. He has gone from hitting one home run every 18 times at bat to 17.6 to 16.1 and from driving in one run every 7.5 times at bat to 6.5 to 4.9.
Jackson's 1989 performance becomes even more impressive when he is compared with other hitters. Among 183 players who had 400 or more plate appearances, Kevin Mitchell had the best run production average, .352 (runs scored plus runs batted in divided by plate appearances). Jackson was second at .340, 11 percentage points ahead of third-place Kent Hrbek, 17 ahead of Eric Davis and 21 ahead of Will Clark and Ruben Sierra.
Among American League hitters, Jackson was the most damaging on the road. He led the league in road runs batted in with 59 and slugging percentage with .554 and tied Mark McGwire for most road home runs with 21.
In spite of all of those achievements, Bo appears unimpressed.
''He doesn't make anything out of it,'' Richard Woods, Jackson's agent, said. ''He never talks to me about anything but maybe throwing a guy out. He likes that. It fires him up. That's better than a touchdown run. He knows he can do that, but he was criticized for his defense. Assists are something he's proud of.''
Jackson had 11 assists in each of the last two seasons, although his fielding average slipped slightly, from .973 to .967.
Proving that he can play baseball and football, Jackson intends to continue that routine.
''There are no plans to change,'' Woods said. ''He's got two years left on his football contract. Al Davis has never implied he would like him full-time. He's kept his word. He signed Bo as a part-time player.'' The Royals earlier this winter were said to be considering offering Jackson a lusty enough contract to induce him to retire from the National Football League.
''That wasn't exactly a rumor,'' Schuerholz said. ''We did consider that.'' The Royals, though, apparently didn't make a concrete offer.
That was all right with Bo. He knows what he wants to do, and he doesn't want to stop running just yet.
 
Debating the Size of Raises
 In debating his 1990 salary in arbitration with the Royals last Friday, Jackson sought a $1,290,001 raise. It sounds like a big raise, but Mark Davis, Will Clark and Dave Stewart could sneer at it. Based on the average annual value of his new multiyear contract, each has received a raise of more than $2.5 million from his previous contract. Davis's raise is the biggest, $2.65 million, followed by Clark, $2,625,000, and Stewart, $2,541,667. Until someone comes along next week or next month or next year, Davis's raise will stand as the biggest in baseball's economically dazzling history.
 
Bringing Up the Bottom
 If Mitchell and Jackson were at the top of the 183-player run production average list, who was at the bottom? Felix Fermin of Cleveland, whose league-leading number of sacrifices (32) exceeded his total of runs batted in (21), was 183d with a .126 r.p.a.
Infielders, in general, and shortstops, in particular, not surprisingly dominated the bottom. Jose Uribe of San Francisco (.129) was 182d, Alfredo Griffin of Los Angeles (.143) was 181st, Omar Vizquel of Seattle (.151) was 179th and Garry Templeton of San Diego (.155) was 176th: shortstops all.
The other three members of the bottom nine were Mike Pagliarulo (.148), Frank White (.153), Willie Randolph (.155) and Jose Lind (.157).
Jose Canseco of Oakland, the 1988 leader with a .346 r.p.a., did not qualify for the list last season because he had 258 plate appearances. Nevertheless, his r.p.a. was a whopping .376.
Dave Henderson of Oakland tumbled from second to 53d (.340 to .244), and Kirby Puckett of Minnesota plummeted from third to 70th (.333 to .234). Mitchell climbed to first from 56th (.247 to .352) while Jackson reached the second spot from 23d (.280 to .340).
Most consistent of the highest-ranked players was Eric Davis of Cincinnati, who in 1988 was sixth at .320 and last season was fourth at .323. Darryl Strawberry of the Mets skidded from seventh to 26th (.316 to .270), but Don Mattingly of the Yankees was consistent, moving from 24th to 22d, although his average slipped (.280 to .277).
 
Rosen Defends Clark Pact
 George Steinbrenner, of all people, recently criticized Al Rosen, the San Francisco Giants' general manager, for giving Will Clark a four-year, $15 million contract, even though Clark couldn't have been a free agent for two more years.
''I'd never take offense at anyone for criticizing me,'' Rosen said in his best diplomatic effort. ''But I'd never criticize anybody else for doing what they did. If we all had to go before a judge, all 26 clubs would be found guilty for excesses with player salaries. We all do it.
''But I'm more concerned about how my boss feels than how someone else feels. Clark is a proven winner. I'd hate to think Will Clark could become a free agent during my tenure as general manager.''
Rosen, who once served as Steinbrenner's general manager, added: ''If you knew there would be no further escalation, if you knew there would be a rollback, we wouldn't do these things. But in my experience, there's always been escalation.''
In other words, Rosen was saying, in two years, Clark's contract may be a good deal for the Giants. Steinbrenner, of course, was thinking of Don Mattingly, another fair first baseman, when he criticized Rosen. Mattingly has one year left on his contract, then can be a free agent.
 
Sides Appear Planets Apart
 What happens after the owners lock out the players? The players will no more accept the owners' revenue-sharing plan while spring training camps sit silently in the sun than they have until now.
Where does a compromise lie? If at all, probably somewhere out in a galaxy far, far away because the owners and the players have been negotiating from two different planets. The real problem, if the owners refuse to open camps, could be how do they then open them. Is there an agreement out there near Pluto or Uranus that can be achieved without revenue sharing or with revenue sharing made immensely more palatable to the players? Do the owners have a Plan B?
The owners, it seems, would abandon their pay-for-performance salary system for players between years one and six in the major leagues if the players could produce an alternative plan. Whatever plan is proposed, though, it would by necessity involve fixed salaries, just as the owners' proposal has to include some sort of limit on payrolls. Revenue sharing sets a fixed amount of money that would go for player salaries and benefits; therefore, the system must assure that salaries, in total, do not exceed the amount shared.
The players do not like fixed salaries. The contracts given players this winter could not exist in a fixed-salary system. Unless, of course, the owners were to offer the players a large enough share of their revenue that could accommodate the kind of salaries that exist now and are expected to continue rising.
Under the current proposal, the players would receive 48 percent of 82 percent of the owners' revenue. National Basketball Association players receive 53 percent of approximately 98 percent of the revenue. To match that 53 percent, the baseball owners would have to offer the players 63 percent -not the 48 percent currently proposed - of the segment of revenue they want to share: ticket sales and national and local radio and television.
Based on the owners' estimated $1.3 billion revenue for 1990, the difference between a 48 percent share and a 63 percent share would be $163 million. The owners would presumably raise the percentage, though not to 63 percent and certainly not until they have some indication that the players could, as they say, bite into revenue sharing.
The problem is whenever the players think of taking a bite, they remember what happened in another time when a fellow was induced to take a bite.

LENGTH: 1329 words

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Midtown Recycling;
From Dowdy to Sleekly Handsome on Park Avenue

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
WHY would the Reichmann family of Toronto, developers of such enormous projects as the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan and Canary Wharf in London, go to all the bother of rebuilding a mediocre, 29-year-old tower on Park Avenue, particularly when the cost may equal that of new construction?
Quite simply because the reconstructed 320 Park Avenue will be almost one-and-one-half times larger than current zoning rules allow - a financial boon achieved without special permits, variances, public hearings or votes by government bodies.
And that is because the extra space is already contained in the 660,000-square-foot building, known as ITT Corporation World Headquarters, which was begun before the 1961 Zoning Resolution took effect. Its floor-area ratio is 19.5, in contrast to current zoning for the site, between 50th and 51st Streets, which calls for 15 on the avenue and 12 on the side streets.
In a zone with a ratio of 15, a 30,000-square-foot lot is allowed to have a building with 450,000 square feet of space. 
Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.), the Reichmanns' New York-based subsidiary, expects to begin reconstruction early next year and finish in 1994. The developers would not discuss the project cost, but it may turn out to be as expensive as new construction. John E. Zuccotti, president of the American subsidiary, said there were already ''some very aggressive tenant inquiries.'' Rents may exceed $60 a square foot.
Although the shape and style of the building will be transformed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill - from a fat, wedding-cake-style structure into a sleeker 34-story tower, flanked by 18-story pavilions - the steel framework will remain largely unchanged, the foundations will be undisturbed and the overall dimensions will not increase.
Therefore, in the view of municipal authorities, the project amounts to no more than an alteration, meaning that the floor space can stay the same and that the development need not be reviewed by the community board, City Planning Commission or Board of Estimate.
Much of 320 Park Avenue is occupied by ITT, which moved uptown from 67 Broad Street in 1961, when it was known as International Telephone & Telegraph. At its height as a corporate conglomerate, ITT occupied the entire building, with some 4,000 employees. Now, the company has about 400 employees at its headquarters, using 275,000 square feet. Among its best known divisions are the ITT Sheraton Corporation and the ITT Hartford Insurance Group.
This fall, ITT expects to create a dual headquarters with staff on both sides of the Hudson River. Some 250 employees will move to the former ABC Building - 1330 Avenue of the Americas, at 54th Street, owned by the Shuwa Corporation of Tokyo. It will be renamed the ITT Building. The other employees will move to 100 Plaza Drive, at the Harmon Meadow office park in Secaucus, N.J.
When it became clear that 320 Park Avenue was going to lose its principal tenant and that other leases in the building would expire at about the same time, Olympia & York executives knew an opportunity was at hand.
At first, they thought simply of renovating the lobby. But they figured that a new lobby would have no impact on anyone but those who actually used the building. They thought about recreating the lobby as a two- or three-story atrium. And then they decided to exploit fully their unusual situation.
''YOU don't frequently have a whole empty building on Park Avenue to deal with,'' said Meyer S. Frucher, the executive vice president for development at Olympia & York. ''It's like a new site.''
The project affords the chance to do several things at once, including removing asbestos, although Olympia & York executives said it does not pose an immediate health hazard. ''You could rent the space tomorrow as is,'' Mr. Zuccotti said, ''but it isn't good marketing to offer a building that has asbestos.''
Reconstruction also allows floor plans to be changed. The project manager for Olympia & York, J. Dean Chavooshian, said that seven different configurations would be reduced to three basic plans. Tower floors, which command a premium rent, would grow larger. Floors at the base would shrink. Although most floors have relatively low ceilings, some have enough height to accommodate the raised floors necessary for large computer installations, depending on the tenants' needs.
''What we don't want to do is start all over again,'' said David M. Childs, a partner in Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. ''There is a lot of value in what's there. What needs to be changed are the civic gestures that the building makes to the street. By reproportioning the masses, the building will take on - rather than a dowdy bustle - a sleeker, more pinstriped, handsome appearance.''
FOR now, the ITT headquarters is the middle one of three remarkably similar towers on the west side of Park Avenue, between 49th and 52d Streets. The others are the Colgate-Palmolive Building at No. 300 and the former Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company Building at No. 350. All three were developed by Percy and Harold D. Uris and designed by Emery Roth & Sons.
''It was very important to make this building different than the bookends that surround it,'' Mr. Chavooshian said.
In addition to new proportions, 320 Park Avenue will get a new facade. It is clad in ribbons of silvery reflective-glass windows and black panels. Mr. Childs envisions walls of stone and glass, but final plans have not been drawn.
''It would be nice to give some crown, some conclusion to the building,'' he said. ''Perhaps it would be a piece of sculpture. We don't want it to be arbitrarily clipped off where the floor area ran out.'' Renderings show a deep cornice at top, but Mr. Childs is not sure that is the answer.
Asked whether Olympia & York had considered giving the architects at Emery Roth a second chance at designing the structure, Mr. Frucher said only: ''We've done work with David Childs and felt that he'd be the ideal architect.''
Olympia & York's decision to spend the money on rebuilding 320 Park Avenue was considered important enough to warrant a news conference last month in City Hall, at which Mayor David N. Dinkins called it ''the first new building project on Park Avenue in more than a decade.''
''What everyone says today is that the real estate market is flat, if not very weak,'' Mr. Zuccotti said. ''We believe that there is a strong market for quality space in New York City and that is what fired our decision. It is a reasonable risk to go ahead, given the location and what we believe to be the demand.''
''As we said to Dinkins, 'Recycling is in,' '' Mr. Frucher recounted.
Some other reconstructions of recent years are the Bank of America Plaza on Madison Avenue, between 43d and 44th Streets, which was the Biltmore Hotel; the Chemical Bank building at Broadway and Exchange Place, which was the Exchange Court Building; Park Avenue Court on Lexington Avenue, between 86th and 87th Streets, which was the Gimbels East department store, and Park Avenue Atrium, between 45th and 46th Streets, which Olympia & York rebuilt from the 466 Lexington Avenue office building.
More is being recycled at the ITT site than the old headquarters. Like other Park Avenue buildings north of Grand Central Terminal, No. 320 sits on concrete foundations and steel columns through which the tracks of the subsurface rail yard are threaded.
The foundations first supported a 12-story apartment house known as 320-30 Park Avenue. Part of the original Terminal City complex that radiated from Grand Central, it was described in promotional literature as ''a distinguished residence, richly finished in fine taste.'' The foundations were used again for the ITT building. ''After we're through,'' Mr. Childs said, ''there will be another level of structure.''
And given the accretions represented by this and other reconstructions, he added, ''New York is looking more and more like Rome.''

 BODY:

 
BROWSERS' BOUTIQUES
While nothing is for sale at the new ''Born to Shop'' exhibition in New Canaan, browsers will have a field day. Conceived and arranged by Deborah Bede, conservationist at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, the show consists of six boutiques dating from the mid-1800's to the 1930's, set up in vignettes throughout the New Canaan Historical Society Town House at 13 Oenoke Ridge. Many of the items were donated or lent by area residents.
An establishment called Annabelle's Accessories features items that include a red and blue silk shawl, circa 1850, and an ivory-framed mauve silk fan spangled in silver. At Madame Cherida's, the proprietor and mannequin in Victorian dress is realistically stationed at her desk near a dress form draped with maroon silk velvet, taffeta, fringe and beads, and a luxurious brown silk outfit made for a bride. Mannequins dressed as 1900's customers are poised on the stairs en route to the next shop. 
At Wee Blessings a collection of christening gowns and baby clothes is on display, and Eastern Outfiters, Rockwell Brothers, Proprietors, has a tailor on his knees measuring the hem of a green faille gown from 1913. Shoes are the only merchandise at J.& T.W. Benedict, dating from World War I and featuring bronze slippers with cut-steel trim, maroon and gold kid shoes and other elegant footwear. The Modern Shop offers a display of 1930's lingerie and gala evening gowns, including one from Fortuny, and a copy of Ginger Rogers' silk and feather gown from ''Top Hat.''
Hours are 9:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and 2 to 4 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday until June 10, free of charge. Call 966-1776 for more information.
STRING QUARTET
Peter Schickele's ''American Dreams,'' and ''Quartet No. 6 the Audubon,'' composed by Ezra Laderman, dean of the Yale School of Music, for the Audubon Quartet, will be on the string ensemble's program at 7:30 P.M. Thursday in the Mattatuck Museum.
The group, formed in 1974 in Virginia, is made up of David Ehrlich and David Salness, violinists, Doris Lederer, violist, and Thomas Shaw, cellist. They have performed at the International String Competition in Evian, France, and at the Portsmouth International String Competition in England as well as throughout the United States.
Tickets are $10, and an additional $5 will admit the ticket holder to a champagne reception following the concert. The museum is at 144 West Main Street in Waterbury. Call 753-0381 for reservations.
 
MOVIE MUSIC
''A celebration of Afro-American originality on celluloid'' is the way Yale describes its film series called ''Black Music at the Movies,'' beginning at 9 P.M. Thursday in the Art Gallery Lecture Hall on Chapel Street with ''Cabin in the Sky.'' The 1943 film, starring Ethel Waters, Eddie Anderson and Lena Horne, with John Bubbles, Louis Armstrong and Duke Ellington, concerns a musical battle between God and the Devil for the soul of Eddie Anderson as Little Joe.

CHINA TRADE
The Bruce Museum and the Greenwich Antiques Society have mounted an exhibition opening at the museum today called ''The China Trade: Decorative Art From the Connecticut Collections.'' The exhibition, which draws on the private collections of 28 Connecticut residents, consists of more than 70 Chinese export objects of various vintages, including porcelains, paintings, lacquerware, silver, paper fans, furniture, and several pieces of Armorial Ware from the Mottahedeh collection of made-to-order porcelain designed around a family crest, monogram or motto.
The show will run until March 25 and the museum, which is just off Exit 3 of Interstate 95, is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday and from 2 to 5 P.M. Sunday. Admission is by donation.
Two lectures are scheduled in connection with the exhibition. At 10 A.M. Monday, David Howard will present a talk titled ''Chinese Export Porcelain for Merchants and Noblemen on Both Sides of the Atlantic'' in the Riverside Yacht Club.
On March 5, Peter Rosenberg, owner of the Vallin Galleries in Wilton, will discuss the origins of the China trade and its economic, political and cultural ramifications from ancient times through the 19th century. The program will be held at the Bruce Museum at 10 A.M. Admission to each talk will be $5, including a coffee hour at 9:30 A.M. Call 869-0376 for reservations or more information. $90ELEANOR CHARLES

LENGTH: 1363 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
The Methodical Ways of a Collector

 BODY:
THE toothpaste tubes should have sent up a signal. When I began dating my husband, his friends chided him about being forthright and honest. I wondered what deep, dark secrets he was hiding. Did he have a criminal record? Was he suffering from some dreaded disease? As it turned out, his affliction was, and is, obsessive collecting.
When he finally realized our relationship was getting serious, he decided to come clean. In the upstairs bathroom of his house was an old-fashioned bathtub overflowing with empty toothpaste tubes. There must have been hundreds of them and not just any kind; they were all Crest toothpaste tubes.
When I asked the obvious question - why he had such a collection - he really didn't have much of an explanation, other than to say it seemed such a waste to throw away articles that so skillfully displayed the art of American advertising. 
Once he confessed, he found it easier to acknowledge some of his other unusual collections. In his early teens, transistor radios were the craze and he found it difficult to part with the dead batteries from them. Remnants of those were present in shoeboxes scattered about his bedroom. He was sure that if he waited long enough, someone would come up with a use for them. He's still waiting.
A bit later in our courtship, I was introduced to his then-current fanaticism, postmark collecting. His goal was to obtain the postmark of every city and town in the United States, which meant an inordinate amount of traveling whenever time and money permitted. Many of our dates were spent searching out well-hidden tiny buildings in small towns that doubled as general stores and post offices.
''It's a great way to see parts of the country we'd never see,'' he would say when I expresed a desire to see a mall I'd never otherwise see. He was also sure that such a collection would one day be extremely valuable.
In his inimitable, methodical way he catalogued the postmarks and placed them in those invaluable shoeboxes, being sure not to confuse them with those that were battery laden. His photographic memory came in handy when people asked him what marks he needed, and he could spout off quickly the gaps in his collection, which finally reached 8,000.
Anyone planning a trip across the country would be given instructions on how to secure a clear, hand-canceled postmark, and often my husband would receive a blank card bearing intriguing names like Bumble Bee, Ariz., or Santa, Idaho, with no sender identified.
I remember when, soon after we became engaged, we took a trip with my parents, and what should have taken two hours took four because of all the post office stops we made. I think my folks were beginning to have some doubts about my future happiness, but how could I not give my heart to a man who sought out postmarks from the towns of Ruth in Kentucky, Michigan, Nevada and Mississippi?
Once we were married and the children came along, that pastime dwindled because of other commitments. While his energies were mainly directed toward his family and career, with some time spent on amassing baseball cards and certain coins, I knew that ultimately something would come along that would pique his interest. Knowing his economical nature, I wasn't surprised when, with the advent of double coupons at the supermarket, his next obsession was born.
One or two nights a week he can be found sitting on the floor of his den, scissors in hand and surrounded by piles of newspaper inserts. I can tell by the expression on his face whether it's going to be a good or mediocre visit to the check-out counter.
Again his organizational skills come into play with this endeavor. All the coupons are categorically placed in envelopes that are alphabetically stacked in a large box. That container goes to the supermarket whenever he does. The first and only time I took the box to the store, I left it in the grocery cart as I went out of the store. Luckily a call to the manager revealed it had been turned in, so his collection and our marriage were saved.
My friends tell me how fortunate I am not to have to do the bulk of the grocery shopping, but there are drawbacks. We don't need, nor do we have space for, 20 jars of spaghetti sauce or 18 rolls of paper towels. But it's the cat food (we don't have any pets) and the diapers (our children are teen-agers) that really set me off. My assertions that ''we're not saving money if you buy items we don't need'' are met with assurances that he knows people who can use them and after all, the products are just about free.
While coupons bring savings, they also create embarrassment. When I accompany my spouse to the market, which is rare, he delights in surveying the contents of other shoppers' wagons to see if he has coupons for the products they are purchasing. I cringe as he accosts them to share his booty, but the hobby has increased his circle of friends. He's met many people in the aisles of the stores, and a talk before the local women's club resulted in a bevy of swapping activity. Women, stacks of coupons in hand, knock on our door, and I have explicit instructions on which ones they are to receive in the exchange.
Each outing to the market entails hours of standing before the items in question, debating which size would be best to buy. I have no patience for this time-consuming activity, but I must admit that his efforts pay off. On most trips he realizes savings of $30 to $40.
While coupons are a major source of enjoyment for my husband, bottles and cans have become his No. 1 recreational priority. In 1985, when the state enacted its bottle bill, our 10-year old son began collecting the containers and redeeming them for the nickel deposit. His goal was to buy a Mercedes-Benz when he reached 16.
Eric's enthusiams for the activity was short-lived, but his father was quick to fill the void. Now, whenever he has some free time and feels the need to get out and walk, he pursues what has come to be known around our house as canning.
First and foremost is the profit derived from the hobby, and while Eric may not be seen behind the wheel of a Mercedes when he's ready to drive, he will no doubt have some form of transportation to show off to his friends. Many people are quick to throw out empties, not willing to take the time and effort to clean, store and return them for a meager nickel, but my husband knows nickels quickly add up to dollars. His perseverance and foresight have paid off; Eric's car account now has a balance of $6,800.
In pursuing this quest, my husband claims to have received a great deal more than money. As a school principal, much of his time is spent under pressure. This diversion allows for exercise, relaxation and interaction with a variety of people he would never have a chance to meet. He has also done a great many undocumented studies on the drinking habits of the American people, which he is quick to share with anyone who will listen. And, of course, he is pleased to be doing his small part to help clean up the environment.
While he often just walks along the roads of our town, his largest hauls come from scouring state parks during summer weekends. Dressed in old clothes, he rummages through garbage pails, seeking his finds. While many onlookers shake their heads, no doubt as an expression of sympathy for this poor fellow who must be down and out on his luck, my husband inwardly chuckles. He loves to imagine their reaction if they were to recognize him when registering their children at his school.
Her dad's hobby has brought some mortification to our college-aged daughter, whose male friends have sometimes been recruited to help carry and hose down some of the bounty. I, of course, decline all invitations to accompany him on these excursions and direct my energies into making up believable excuses why we can't attend social functions on summer weekends.
I suppose I shouldn't complain. He could have worse habits, but I can't help bristle when there's no room in the cupboards because of dozens of jars of peanut butter or salad dressing, and the mounds of empty cans that line our backyard.
My main concern is, what will be next?

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Ill-Timed Suit to Save the Pine Barrens

BYLINE: By Michael LoGrande; Mr. LoGrande, former County Executive of Suffolk County, is the executive director of the Association for a Better Long Island.

 BODY:
THE old adage ''can't see the forest for the trees'' might never have been more appropriate than on the day the Long Island Pine Barrens Society hurled a massive lawsuit at the people of Long Island.
The strategy of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society is to use the largest lawsuit of its kind in state history to force a halt to projects worth $11.2 billion. Not only is this lawsuit ill conceived, but it is also ill timed, with the potential effect of shifting millions of dollars of property taxes onto Suffolk homeowners when they are already suffering from the largest tax increases in county history.
No one disputes the need to preserve a portion of our pine barren areas if we are going to insure an adequate supply of drinking water for Long Island's future. In fact, the Association for a Better Long Island, whose members have more than $20 billion invested in Long Island, was one of the first organizations on Long Island to support the 1987 0.25 percent sales tax referendum, which is now being used by Suffolk County to fund pine barren purchases. 
That program has been working particularly well. During the 1980's, Suffolk County acquired more than 10,000 acres of open space, which does not include the properties taken by New York State under such programs as the environmental bond act. The beauty of this program is that it enabled the land to be preserved in its natural state without resorting to additional property taxes.
The lawsuit by the Long Island Pine Barrens Society is an entirely different matter. Everyone, even developers, agrees that we need to preserve a significant amount of open space, not only to protect our drinking water, but out of concern for the environment in general. The problem is that the Pine Barrens Society really seeks to prevent construction on nearly every piece of vacant land in Suffolk County.
The Pine Barrens Society is relying on its ability to manipulate the legal system to halt construction on more than 100,000 acres of property. Because this lawsuit uses the power of government to deny the permits and thus diminish the value of property, it amounts to a de-facto taking of the property by government.
So it is important to remember that under the same legal system, the owners of that property have the right to recover the lost value of their property from government. This could cost hundreds of millions of dollars, on top of the highest tax increases on record. In addition, there will be tens of millions more in lost property tax revenue, taxes that government will no longer be able to collect because it has become the owner of these properties.
As bad as the threat of another round of property taxes might seem, that isn't the only disaster that might result from the Pine Barrens lawsuit. There are several other economic dangers inherent in bringing to a screeching halt nearly all projects in Suffolk County. To begin with, the local economy, which appeared to be almost invulnerable during most of the 1980's, enters the 1990's perched on the brink of a potential downturn. The Grumman Corporation has been given only three more years to build its most famous airplane, the F-14; unemployment figures are up, and sales tax revenues have fallen considerably short of expected levels for the last two years.
Economic growth, which could help overcome those problems, will be strangled if no construction is allowed for any significant period of time, thereby compounding the difficulty of the situation. In addition, we will be unable to confront some of the other critical problems that endanger our economy. For instance, the lack of affordable housing is driving away the young families on whom we must depend for an educated, talented work force. Because housing is so expensive, many of the young workers on Long Island, needed to sustain our future, are moving away.
A lawsuit provides no special exemption for worthwhile purposes. If this lawsuit makes it illegal to build in vast areas of Suffolk, it will also be illegal to build the housing that these young families so desperately need.
There is a good side to the debate over preserving the pine barrens. This is not an either-or question. If we abandon extremist approaches to the problem, we will find reasonable solutions that can satisfy the goals of protecting our water supply and natural heritage, as well as allowing for reasonable economic growth.
The solution is not to go off blindly and halt all development, thus risking destruction of an economy already poised on the brink of an increasingly narrow precipice, but to use already proven methods of land use planning. The 32,000 acres of pine barrens to be acquired under the Suffolk County land preservation program are a good start. In addition, we can use innovative methods, such as clustered housing on plots with much open space, to preserve large natural areas at no cost to the public.
Only if we use common sense rather than incendiary tactics will we able to enjoy the forest as well as the trees.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Compromise Is Possible For Housing

BYLINE: By By Jeffrey Rubin and Joseph J. Seneca; Jeffrey Rubin is an associate professor and Joseph J. Seneca is a professor of economics at Rutgers University at New Brunswick.

 BODY:
THE two Mount Laurel decisions by the Supreme Court and the subsequent passage of the Fair Housing Act have brought nationwide attention to New Jersey. The state's housing policy has also fueled intense local debate and continued litigation.
One of the most controversial aspects of the Fair Housing Act allows municipalities to transfer up to 50 percent of their affordable-housing obligation to other communities. Recent disputes over attempts by Middletown and Parsippany-Troy Hills to negotiate regional contribution agreements with other communities exemplify these problems. 
The difficulties arise, in part, from an underlying conflict between the two primary goals of New Jersey housing policy: to increase the supply of affordable housing statewide and to achieve a more equitable distribution of this supply across communities.
The Fair Housing Act and other housing programs offer communities fiscal and legal incentives to expand the supply of affordable housing. In addition to regional contribution agreements, communities can construct affordable housing themselves and rehabilitate existing substandard units. They can also offer builders a density bonus. In return, the builder agrees to dedicate a portion of the new development to low-income and moderate-income households.
When choosing which methods to use, municipal officials are likely to be guided by community preferences. For example, some communities may be unwilling to accept the possible congestion and character change associated with inclusionary developments. They may also be concerned with the effects of such developments on housing values and property taxes.
A regional contribution agreement offers a community the opportunity to avoid or reduce these consequences. In a recent study, we examined how local economic conditions and other factors influenced decisions by municipalities to include such an agreement in their affordable-housing plans.
We reviewed 45 municipal plans certified by the Council on Affordable Housing. Our results indicate that the 11 towns using a regional contribution agreement had a higher average per capita income, higher average residential value and lower average equalized property tax rates than the 34 communities that did not.
In addition, a measure of the subsidy per housing unit that existing residents would provide to owners of affordable units was significantly higher in towns that used the regional agreement method compared with towns that did not. Such subsidies may arise because affordable units are taxed at their restricted price rather than at full market value. The communities receiving regional agreement funds have predominantly been older cities.
These findings and the use of these agreements have several implications. First, the agreements effectively shift some of the burden of financing affordable housing to communities that are willing and able to pay. Without the agreement option, the additional urban housing it finances either would not exist or, if it did, would require an alternative source of funds.
In the past, communities could use, without penalty, their zoning authority to exclude low-income and moderate-income housing. Now, they can limit the number of affordable units, but only at the price of paying for a regional agreement.
Second, in a weak housing market, municipalities are less likely to be challenged by developers seeking to build large numbers of market-rate units in inclusionary developments. If the threat of litigation diminishes, municipalities may have less incentive to expand the supply of affordable housing.
In such a housing market, the state must assure the availability of options that make it easier for a municipality to develop an affordable-housing plan. A regional agreement may prove essential to encourage some communities to participate in the affordable housing process.
Finally, these agreements affect the distribution of affordable housing in complicated ways. If the agreement option were eliminated, or the 50 percent constraint tightened, two possibilities exist.
One is that communities that would have relied on an agreement would, instead, meet all their affordable-housing obligation within their borders. If this occurred, the total supply of affordable units would be unaffected, but the distribution of this housing between city and suburb would be different.
A second and worrisome possibility, however, is that by eliminating the agreement option, some communities may react by delaying the implementation of any housing plan. This would reduce the supply of affordable housing and frustrate the basic goal of the Fair Housing Act.
Allowing communities to buy out of their affordable-housing obligation will remain a controversial policy. We believe that the need to increase the supply of affordable housing is compelling and deserves precedence over the distributional goal when these two conflict.
Constraining regional contribution agreements at 50 percent of a community's affordable-housing obligation represents a reasonable compromise. As long as receiving communities are free to accept or reject an offer, and absent a state commitment for broad-based financing of affordable housing, regional contribution agreements serve the basic intent of the Fair Housing Act.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1421 words

HEADLINE: O'Rourke Sets New Goal on Housing the Homeless

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
INITIATING what he clearly intended to be a major assualt on Westchester's homeless problem, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week that he was moving from ''the think-tank stage to the let's-do-something stage.''
Mr. O'Rourke established a 15-member Housing Implementation Commission consisting of private builders, developers, union officers and elected officials and assigned it the task of ''developing 1,000 units of family shelter'' by the end of the year.
He said that some of the 1,000 units might include ''upgraded apartments and conversions, rather than new construction.''
The commission, which he acknowledged would have a difficult time dealing with communities opposed to housing for the homeless, was also told to develop plans for 5,000 units of permanent housing for the homeless. ''We won't produce them by the end of 1990, but I'd like the plans to exist,'' Mr. O'Rourke said. 
 
Cost to County Has Risen Steadily
The County Executive has watched the cost to the county rise steadily as the homeless population increased to 4,455 last year from 1,173 in 1985. He said last week that he had given up on any present or future financial assistance from Federal or state agencies.
''I no longer trust the state or Federal Government to produce anything of substance in coming years,'' he said. ''If anything, I see them hardening, instead of making it easier for us to do our job.''
If the county is to solve its homeless problem, he said, ''we're going to do it, in the main, by ourselves, and through the creative use of existing state and Federal regulations.''
Mr. O'Rourke, speaking at a news conference on Wednesday, suggested that the situation might get worse even as solutions were sought. He said the county could lose more than 13,000 low- to moderate-income housing units by 2005 if action is not taken to avert the impact of certain Federal and state regulations.
The current law, he said, permits private lenders and owners who built subsidized rental housing in the 1970's to prepay their mortgages and then terminate the below-market rent guidelines that apply to those buildings. Mr. O'Rourke did not offer any specific plan to counter this change but said: ''It has come to our attention that there has been no concerted approach to solving this problem. So we'd like people to know that something has to be done.''
The low-interest loans and guaranteed subsidies were offered in the 1970's to encourage private developers to build and operate moderate-income housing units. The loans can be prepaid on their 20th anniversary, and apartments originally covered by rent subsidies can then be rented at market value. Mr. O'Rourke conceded that so far there had been few such ''buyouts.''
 
20 Communities Affected
Perhaps, he said, ''prepayments will be disallowed, giving us more time'' to find solutions. ''Maybe there are state and Federal programs that would enable the people in those apartments to buy out the mortgages, and own their own apartments.''
More than 20 Westchester communities could be affected, with four cities being especially vulnerable. There are more than 6,700 such units in Yonkers, 1,721 in White Plains and 1,800 each in Mount Vernon and New Rochelle. Mr. O'Rourke said he was sponsoring a conference in April to study ways of addressing the situation.
The new push being made by Mr. O'Rourke to build 1,000 transitional and 5,000 permanent units for the homeless was also addressed only broadly, although Mr. O'Rourke acknowledged that the major impediment would be what it has always been, the resistance of local officials to accept such housing.
''We're talking about some heavy-duty movement, and some political strife,'' the County Executive said, adding with a smile that he hoped his audience ''realized why I need 15 people to hide behind when those things happen.''
The Housing Implementation Commission was one of two such agencies that replaced the four-year-old Commission on the Homeless. The new agencies were intended to implement housing goals but with memberships better able to accomplish those objectives, according to two members of the outgoing unit, Dr. Anthony A. Cupaiuolo, the chairman, and Ann Tourk, the vice chairwoman.
 
'More Political Involvement'
Dr. Cupaiuolo, who is a professor of public administration and director of the Michaelian Institute at Pace University, said the reconstituted commission needed to have ''some more corporate involvement and more political involvement.''
Political leaders, he explained, ''could be helpful in trying to persuade some of their former colleagues to be more responsive to the needs of homeless people.''
Ms. Tourk agreed, saying that the composition of the old commission ''did not have enough broad-based representation or enough clout.''
''We're all cut from the same cloth - advocates for the homeless,'' said Ms. Tourk, who is the area director of the American Jewish Committee. ''We needed people from the business community, people with greater visibility in leadership positions, a more diversified group.''
 
A Division of Responsibilities
Mr. O'Rourke replaced the old commission with two advisory boards: the Housing Implementation Commission to implement the housing goals, and also a Commissioners' Interagency Advisory Group on Homelessness, which will deal primarily with the day-to-day issues of service.
Mr. O'Rourke said that the chairman of the Housing Implementation Commission would be ''a senior officer of a major Westchester corporation'' and other members would come from the ranks of builders, developers, elected officials and union officers. The establishment of the commission is subject to approval by the Board of Legislators.
He is expected to name the members shortly and said the commission would probably conduct its first meeting before the end of February, or before the Board of Legislators is likely to act.
Mr. O'Rourke was asked if he would identify possible sites for the 1,000 units of housing. ''I don't know how else to do it,'' he said, indicating that he would do so.
 
Board Updates Its Housing Policy
The Board of Legislators, meanwhile, has commissioned experts on suburban housing at Rutgers University to study Westchester's needs, said Legislator Timothy S. Carey, chairman of the Community Affairs and Housing Committee, who said it was part of an updating of the board's housing policy for the next decade.
Instead of ''just saying we need 50,000 units, which is what the 1980 study said, we are looking to be able to define it down to a regional or perhaps town or city levels,'' Mr. Carey said. The study should be completed before the end of this year, he said.
The 50,000-unit estimate for the 1980's, he said, ''had no delineation by socio-economic need or by income.'' Now, he said, ''We are looking at needs, so we will be able to say how many low-income, moderate-income, middle-income houses will be needed.''
The results would go beyond the needs of the homeless, but would have an effect on that segment of the population. ''In the last 10 years we have turned 30,000 units of rental housing into co-ops and condominiums,'' Mr. Carey said. In the same period, he added, ''We've built only 250 units of fair-market rental housing, which is why we come up with housing gridlock.''
 
A Final Report Is Delivered
The Commission on the Homeless, in its final report, called for a number of improvements on the state and Federal level, such as increasing housing subsidies, and endorsed an effort on the county's part to have the state amend its constitution to enable counties to create permanent housing.
It also faulted all levels of government within the county for not confronting the issue of housing for the homeless. ''We certainly have a long way to go,'' Mr. O'Rourke said. ''Unfortunately many of our best and brightest ideas are hampered by the lack of initiative and cooperation on the part of other levels of government.
''Perhaps the strongest conclusion that was drawn by this report,'' he said, ''is that the powers who are able to solve the problem are not willing to deal with the problem.''
Dr. Cupaiuolo pointed to some specific accomplishments by the outgoing commission. One was the creation of the Eviction Prevention Program, in which mediators working with the courts and the Department of Social Services intervene in efforts to prevent eviction. Eviction is the cause of 36 percent of the incidents of homelessness, he said.
