LENGTH: 1577 words

HEADLINE: Divergent Goals at River Site Owned by State

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: OSSINING

 BODY:
FOR nearly a quarter of a century, a 17.8-acre slice of wilderness land rising steeply above the Hudson River has remained wild and undeveloped, ignored by the State Department of Transportation, which owns it, and coveted by the village of Ossining, which wants the property on its tax rolls.
Now the Department of Transportation, under pressure from the Governor's office to dispose of surplus land to help meet a growing budget deficit, has turned its attention to its Ossining property. But its plans for the land have become the focus of dissension as groups with different objectives try to balance the sometimes competing needs for affordable housing, environmental protection and fiscal prudence.
 
Decision a Relief to Many
The land was originally purchased for a Hudson River Expressway, which was never built. To the relief of those who feared that the state would sell the property to the highest bidder, the State Department of Transportation decided to transfer title to another state agency to permit construction of affordable housing on a part of the site. 
That decision was confirmed by state officials last week and came in response to a request from the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which will oversee the housing construction, as well as to a proposal outlined by a village coalition of clergy and housing advocates.
But environmentalists have expressed concern because the State Division of Housing is considering subsidizing the cost of the affordable housing on the eastern end of the parcel by also building market-rate units. These would be placed on the 10 to 12 acres that are near the river, an environmentally sensitive area of coastal highland with sweeping views of the Hudson River, the Palisades and Croton Point Park.
While supporting the affordable housing on the eastern section, the environmental groups - Scenic Hudson, the Heritage Task Force and others - tried to persuade the Department of Transportation to transfer the land with restrictions that would preventing development on the 12 western-most acres. But a spokesman for the department said the state agency receiving the land was ''the more appropriate group to decide on the use of the property.''
''We do want to continue to have part of the land on the Hudson remain as open space,'' said Judith A. Engel, director of development and planning for the State Division of Housing. ''But you do need to sell some units on the river at market rates to finance the affordable units.''
Trying to balance the needs of the environment with the need for affordable housing and the demands of the budget is important and difficult, Ms. Engel said. ''The sale of market-rate housing is particularly important when there are very few dollars to go around,'' she added.
 
A Plus for Village Tax Rolls
The state plan would fill what many agree is a critical need for affordable housing in Ossining and would also bolster the village tax rolls. But housing advocates say that if there is no cost associated with obtaining the land, as now seems to be the case, market-rate housing should not be needed to subsidize the affordable units.
The Ossining Ministerial Association, a 30-member group leading the effort to build affordable housing in the community, opposes selling part of the land for market-rate housing. ''If the land is given to a nonprofit housing corporation, we believe that decent, affordable housing could be built, and financing obtained without the need to sell off a beautiful, priceless plateau,'' said Dr. Robert J. Berson, a leader of the association.
Dr. Berson said a nonprofit consortium of trade unions and builders that recently offered $250 million from its pension funds to finance affordable housing in Westchester was one of the sources the Ossining group would turn to.
The 12 acres in question are landlocked and nearly inaccessible by foot; it is generally agreed that construction would be difficult and therefore expensive. David Bogdanoff, a Westchester developer, has studied the affordable housing potential of the site for the village and believes that between 80 and 160 co-operative units could be built for residents with incomes of up to $30,000, ''using available financing.''
The village should not try to build market-rate homes along the river, said Mr. Bogdanoff, the managing partner of Montrose Construction Corporation in Yorktown, explaining that the project would require an expensive extension of Beach Road.
Environmentalists and neighbors are opposed to the development of the 12-acre portion of the land at any cost. The Beach Road-Brayton Park Homeowners Association, representing a neighborhood just northeast of the parcel; a coalition of regional environmental groups, and some state legislators argue that construction of expensive housing on the riverfront runs counter to the objectives of the Hudson River Greenway Council and to state policies that advocate the acquisition of open space.
The Greenway Council is a state-appointed group studying how to establish a linked system of trails, recreation areas and open spaces along the Hudson. It recently heard a presentation by the Brayton Park Homeowners Association that asked for help in preserving the land.
 
'This Magnificent Property'
''As construction removes, once and for all, more and more of our wilderness landscape,'' the association said, ''communities like ours have come to recognize acutely the precious value of the few remaining pockets of undeveloped land.''
Louis B. McCagg, president of the Westchester Land Trust, expressed his objections in a letter to the Transportation Commissioner, Franklin E. White. ''This magnificent property is one which, if it were in private ownership, the state would seek to acquire for open-space preservation along the Hudson,'' he wrote. ''Since it is already in state ownership, it would be a false economy, indeed, to sell it now for a use that would destroy its open-space value.''
His comments have been echoed by leaders of Scenic Hudson, the Heritage Task Force for the Hudson River Valley and Clearwater, among other environmental groups.
 
Pataki Objects to Sale
''Whether this is a sale or a transfer of state land to an agency that is going to turn around and sell it to a developer, makes no difference,'' Assemblyman George E. Pataki of Peekskill said last week. ''It's ridiculous to sell land that could be a critical part of the Greenway just before the Governor is sending a $1 billion bond issue to voters in November to ask for money to buy more land.'' Mr. Pataki is a member of the Greenway Council.
''No one objects to splitting off five or six acres for affordable housing,'' Mr. Pataki said. But the remainder of the Ossining property, which is adjacent to the Croton Aquaduct and to the village-owned Crawbuckie Nature Preserve, constitutes a ''tremendous asset'' to the Greenway, he added.
''For us to make a profit by selling it to a developer is idiotic,'' Mr. Pataki said. He said he planned to introduce legislation calling for a one-year moratorium on the sale of state land in the 13 ''Greenway counties'' of the Hudson Valley. It is unclear whether such a moratorium would stop a transfer to another state agency or prevent housing from being built.
 
Governor's Help Is Asked
There has been no official announcement about the future of the property. But Ms. Engel said last week that the Transportation Department ''has committed itself to transfer their land for the purpose of building affordable housing.'' The transaction was confirmed, she said, in a letter on Jan. 5 from Commissioner White to the Housing Commissioner, Richard Higgins.
After learning of the land transfer last week, members of the Brayton Park Association wrote Gov. Mario M. Cuomo asking for help, said Christine H. Miller, a lawyer who lives in Brayton Park with her husband, Mitchell. The letter asks for the Governor's support to divide the use of the site between affordable housing and green space.
Thomas Cambariere is a Village Trustee who has been a strong advocate of affordable housing. ''It's all coming to a happy ending, unless you live on Beach Road,'' he said after he learned of the state's decision last week. ''The affordability of the houses we build is affected by what we do with the land on the bluff. Now, it's up to the money. If we can get enough money to build affordable housing without the use of this parcel, there will be a park there, absolutely.''
As for what influence the village has in the matter, Mr. Cambariere said that state housing officials had assured him they would cooperate with the desires of the village.
 
Many Questions Remain
Later this month, top officials from the Department of Housing are to meet here with village officials and iron out the details of the plan, Ms. Engel said. State officials hope to issue a request, in conjunction with village officials, for proposals from potential developers of the site The Ossining Village Manager, Gennaro J. Faiella, said last week that he was pleased the state had finally decided to allow the property to be used, but he added, ''We have a whole series of questions.''
A survey is planned to determine the extent of the need for affordable housing in Ossining, he said, and officials also need to decide whether parkland should be set aside and how that might affect the tax ratables generated by the project.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 23, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 699 words

HEADLINE: Both Germanys - Almost Unified

BYLINE: By Graham Allison; Graham Allison was dean of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government from 1977 to 1989.

 BODY:
No country, especially the U.S., can any longer avoid addressing the issue of German reunification.
While politicians continue to scramble, they are being outrun by the galloping political and economic forces in both Germanys. Even Mikhail Gorbachev, who fears reunification most, this week acknowledged its inevitably. But he warns sharply against the ''chaos of nihilism, the diktat of the crowd.'' 
Has reunification already occurred? Yes, almost. Historians will identify 1989's closing months as decisive. Both Germanys reawakened to being a single nation in the currency that matters most: hearts and minds. Formalities and legalities remained. But de facto, Deutschland again became one nation that increasingly acted as one state.
The terms are evident, though dip lomatic rhetoric will seek to obfuscate them. In business language, this is no merger; it is an acquisition. The Federal Republic is acquiring the German Democratic Republic on the basis of West German values, economics and deutschmarks.
What impels these developments? The proximate cause was Mr. Gorbachev's decision not to use troops to maintain Soviet-imposed governments in Eastern Europe. What kept these governments in power was Eastern Europeans' belief that the troops served as prison guards.
Once that dam was removed, natural forces rushed to predictable results. First, nationalism was no less authentic in Germany than in any other Eastern European state celebrating independence. Second, East Germany collapsed. Its original claim ''to build socialism on German soil'' had a certain credibility. In practice, the experiment failed. The peaceful revolution exposed German Communism as worse than a failure: It was a fraud.Third, the scars of 40 years left East Germans with deep convictions that shaped politics. Enabled freely to express their own views, solid majorities will be anti-Soviet, anti-Communist, pro-Western values and pro-German.
Could these forces produce formal anschluss sooner rather than later? Two German elections loom this year: March, in the East; December, in the West. Nearly 3,000 East Germans vote with their feet daily; annualized, this amounts to 7 percent of the remaining population.
The East German Government's desperate search for ways to persuade the populace that their prospects are as promising in the East as in the West is under way. Large-scale West German subsidies and investments will hinge upon guarantees for property and investment. But this will in effect mean rapid acquisition of the East.
Under such conditions, what are the prospects for preserving separate political authorities? If a plebiscite is held, most East Germans are likely to vote for immediate unification. If they do, no West German government could refuse the offer.
Only Mr. Gorbachev can arrest this march of history. His words, however, suggest that early anschluss lies beyond even his bottom line. While he might find ways to accommodate to an evolution over time, he reportedly told President Francois Mitterrand that ''the same day the reunification of Germany is announced, a general will be sitting in my armchair.'' With 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany, he can prevent unification if he so desires.
Although it seems hard to believe, he could threaten to use the troops. Or he could attempt to replay Stalin's 1952 card: the price for unification would be a neutral state (as proposed by Prime Minister Hans Modrow) empty of all foreign troops.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl, preferring to remain in the NATO fold, has rejected neutralization. If Mr. Gorbachev stands fast and can make it stick, Mr. Kohl may be forced to rethink his options. For the U.S., neither the use of Soviet troops nor neutralization would be acceptable.
Failing to appreciate the forces in the saddle, Western goverments could wring their hands and simply allow the inevitable to take final shape. But this could have very damaging effects on relations with Moscow. Thus, Washington and the West would do far better to make unambiguous their support for unification, endorse Mr. Kohl's concept of the process and explore with Moscow the terms for accepting a united Germany inside NATO.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

PUB-DATE: February 4, 1990

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 2, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1386 words

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: THE STRATFORD HEADQUARTERS OF TEXTRON LYCOMING;
At a Defense Plant, No Peace if Jobs Are Lost

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
LAST year, Textron Lycoming in Stratford was predicting a secure future: It had orders to produce 1,000 Army tank engines a year through 1996.
But last week workers at the sprawling plant near the mouth of the Housatonic River were told that 1,350 employees - nearly a third of its work force of 4,000 - could be laid off in the next couple of years if President Bush's deficit-reducing proposal to eliminate the M-1 tank program is carried out. Textron Lycoming makes the 1,500-horsepower gas turbine engine that powers the M-1.
The proposed cutback, one of several announced Monday, is regarded as a response to the easing of East-West relations and to a perceived decline in threats to world peace, but many of the workers at Textron Lycoming said the President is moving too fast.
''Just because the Berlin Wall went down doesn't mean there's no threat,'' said Robert A. Meier, who makes parts for the tank engine. ''There are still other countries.'' Robert Koetsch, a plant security guard, said: ''This could be part of a plan, a plan to get our defenses down, get our guard down. If they shut this place down, and something happens in two or three years, it's going to take a while to start up again.'' 
Theresa R. Bruno, a 30-year veteran of the inspections department, said plant workers take pride in their work and find the prospect of losing the M-1 tank frustrating. ''We work and strive to give them a good product,'' she said, ''and I don't see why they have to eliminate it.'' Not just workers are worried. Neil F. Sherman, vice president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, said he was concerned about how the loss of the M-1 project would affect the rest of the local economy; Textron Lycoming is one of the two largest employers in Stratford, along with the Sikorsky Aircraft helicopter plant farther up the Housatonic in the north end of town.
''In Stratford, we like to say when Sikorsky and Textron catch a cold, the town comes down with pneumonia,'' Mr. Sherman said.
The same might be said of much of the state and its ties to its defense industries. With $4.9 billion in military contracts, Connecticut - though it is 28th in population among the 50 states - ranks eighth in dependency on military money. Connecticut's $1,531 per capita in military spending is second only to Virginia's. Under Mr. Bush's budget, contracts at Pratt & Whitney, the jet-engine builder and a subsidiary of the giant United Technologies Corporation in Hartford, would also be cut back.
In Stratford, this dependency can be felt down the road from the Textron Lycoming plant, at the Windsock Restaurant inside the terminal at the local airport. There, many Textron Lycoming workers go for lunch or after work for a beer, and the owner, James E. Boone, said he worries about losing customers if plant workers are laid off.
After Textron's last layoffs, in 1988, business at the Windsock dropped 30 percent and never recovered, Mr. Boone said. Now, he said, if the company cuts a third of its work force, his business will go under. ''If they go, I go,'' he said.
Mr. Boone and some Textron Lycoming retirees spent a recent afternoon in the lounge area of the Windsock guessing which of the people signed up for a shuffleboard tournament in February would have to withdraw because they would be too busy looking for jobs.
''That place goes up and down, up and down; nothing surprises me anymore,'' said John Morrison, who retired last June after 27 years as a gear inspector at the plant. ''I guess the generals have enough tanks to play with for a while.''
William B. McDaniel, a spokesman for Textron Lycoming, a unit of Textron Inc., an aerospace company in Providence, R.I., said the M-1 program represents 60 percent of the unit's business; the rest consisting of government and commercial contracts for jet engines.
The M-1's elimination, he said, would mean the layoff of 1,350 workers at Textron's Stratford plant and 150 more at its Greer, S.C. plant, where some of the parts are made.
Mr. McDaniel also said that Textron Lycoming buys parts, material and equipment from more than 900 vendors in 32 states, so the effect would quickly spread.
The President's budget proposal calls for about a 3 percent increase in defense spending but actually cuts the defense budget 2.6 percent after inflation is factored in. The expected saving from an elimination of the M-1 tank is $1.1 billion.
Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat of Bozrah, has called for a diversification of the Connecticut economy for most of his 10 years in office. The military money spent here has been declining, from $5.54 billion in 1985 to $5.44 billion in 1986 and $5.03 billion in 1987, the last year for which figures are available.
''For years you couldn't get anyone to pay attention to our calls for diversification,'' Mr. Gejdenson said. ''All of a sudden, we're getting so much attention it's frightening.''
There have been exceptions, however. Some companies, like Pratt & Whitney, the jet-engine maker, long ago diversified into nonmilitary products.
Mr. Gejdenson said he will lobby heavily for legislation that would require retraining of workers and retooling of plants when defense cutbacks are announced, rather than when the effects start to be felt.
''If you go to Stratford today, you'll find very low unemployment'' -roughly between 3 and 4 percent, Mr. Gejdenson said. ''It's stupid to wait until it climbs up to 10 or 12 percent before the Government steps in.''
As Connecticut starts to face a loss of military contracts, defense-industry workers are beginning to recognize some unlikely allies - groups that for years have pushed for more spending on domestic programs and less on the military.
Patricia Wass, executive director of one such group, Connecticut Sane Freeze, said her organization has been talking with several labor organizations about converting defense plants to non-military uses.
''Conversion planning should have begun 10 years ago, so it's a little late to start, but better late than never,'' she said. ''Our concern is that the workers not be left out in the cold. We want to make sure the money goes back into programs like housing.''
Ms. Wass said that Sane Freeze, the United Auto Workers and the Machinists Union are organizing a workshop in March that will examine conversion efforts at the local, state and Federal level and that she is seeking as examples businesses that made the switch from a dependency on Pentagon money to the making of peacetime products.
''We haven't come up with a scheme for Electric Boat to make subway cars instead of submarines, but that's not our role,'' Ms. Wass said. ''Our job is to just make sure the planning happens.'' Mr. McDaniel, the Textron Lycoming spokesman, said: ''We recognized three to five years ago that there would be a decrease in military spending, and we began an active program to change our business mix to predominantly commercial. We are talking right now to aircraft manufacturers all over the world about the new generations of regional jets and business aircraft.''
But it will be 1994 or later before the company can reach full-scale production on some of those projects, he said.
''Certainly, we did not forsee even three years ago that they would cease M-1 production,'' Mr. McDaniel said. ''We thought it was going to be scaled back, over a much longer period of time.''
But the cutbacks at the plant could also be an opportunity, Mr. Gejdenson said. He noted that during the last economic upheaval in Connecticut - the withdrawal of the woolen mills - what was left behind were plants so aged as to be useless, equipment that was designed in the 19th century and people whose skills were not adaptable to any modern industries.
''The good news today is that while there's going to be some dislocation, the skills, the facilities and the equipment we will be left with are among the most sophisticated in the world,'' he said.
Mr. Gejdenson said the focus of domestic industry on military goods has contributed to the trade imbalance in this country. While Textron Lycoming built tank engines, he said, engines for trucks and buses were imported from overseas.
''Instead of buying rail cars from a company in Japan,'' he said, ''let's buy them from a Connecticut company.''

HEADLINE: Health Insurers, to Reduce Losses, Blacklist Dozens of Occupations

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
In an effort to avoid losses, many insurance carriers have quietly blacklisted dozens of types of small businesses and professions. A wide variety of occupations, from bartender and gas-station attendant to oil driller and dentist, have been declared ineligible for health insurance.
The exclusions are adding heat to the growing debate over how to protect the 31 million uninsured Americans, more than half of whom are working people and their families. At least three Congressional committees and several state commissions are drafting laws that could help make health insurance accessible to those without it. And the insurance industry, hoping to ward off new Government programs and regulations, is scrambling to come up with its own proposals.
 
Situation Is 'Just Awful'
In his State of the Union address last week, President Bush said his White House domestic policy advisers would review ''recommendations on the quality, accessibility and cost'' of health care being developed by Government study groups. A number of Democrats in Congress are working on bills that would require all employers to offer health coverage. Some critics of the insurance industry are also calling for national standards of conduct for insurers. 
The situation is ''just awful'' for small businesses that need health insurance, said James Bissonett, an insurance broker in Eden Prairie, Minn., a suburb of Minneapolis.
The exclusions can have serious consequences for workers in the affected industries. In a number of states, including New York, they may turn to a Blue Cross or Blue Shield plan for coverage, often at a high monthly cost, but in many states such people go without insurance. And many hospitals, doctors and medical clinics will not treat uninsured patients.
While some health insurers have been accused of denying coverage to people in cities and occupations where the insurers contend the AIDS virus is most prevalent, the exclusions extend well beyond these groups. More than 40 industries are listed as ''ineligible'' in correspondence to insurance brokers from several large insurers. The lists were provided by a New York insurance broker, who asked not to be identified, as examples of the exclusions imposed by many insurance companies.
For instance, a list under the letterhead of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company, based in Hartford, includes service businesses like laundries, service stations, hotels, motels and restaurants; hazardous or seasonal industries like oil drilling and ski resorts, and health-care providers.
At the Hartford Group, a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation, types of businesses listed as ineligible for medical, disability and life insurance included barber shops, bars, beauty salons, car washes, entertainment groups, fishing enterprises, logging or mining operations, Government-financed nonprofit organizations, drilling and exploration operations for oil and natural gas, scrap dealers, taxi drivers and used-car dealers.
For dental coverage, the same company said chiropractors, dentists, education groups and municipal employees were also ineligible.
 
Insurers Cite Reasons
Insurance executives cite a number of reasons for the exclusions, which they say are based on their profit-and-loss experiences with such groups. Insurers say that employees of some businesses that sell alcohol, like restaurants and bars, have higher rates of alcoholism, resulting in expensive health problems. They say businesses like lumberyards, munitions plants and sanitation companies can be unprofitable for insurers because of frequent accidents or illnesses.
Other businesses with high turnover and many part-time employees, like motels, convenience stores and hair salons, are excluded because transient employees may be in poor health to start with and insurers find it difficult to verify their health histories, said Henry Raymond, a director of insurance, managed care and provider relations with the Health Insurance Association of America, an insurer trade group in Washington.
''Some industries that have high turnover and low pay may be perceived as occupations that attract an employee whose truthfulness and veracity may be difficult to verify,'' Mr. Raymond added. He said that in analyzing the health of applicants to decide whether their group should be accepted for insurance and what rates to charge, ''it is very difficult to verify what hospital a transient individual went to, or to get a documented health history.''
Yet another reason for exclusion, insurance executives say, is a high incidence of claims by people in the health-care professions, like doctors, dentists, nurses, chiropractors and other medical workers. ''Because they are highly aware of health-care needs, health providers tend to have a high rate of utilization,'' said Joan Herman, a senior vice president at Phoenix Mutual.
 
Administrative Costs
Finally, some groups are excluded because insurers say they require high administrative expenses. Insurers say they usually take several years to earn back the start-up costs of enrolling new members, so they shun clients like local governments that require annual open bidding and may frequently switch insurers. Similarly, they contend that some small nonprofit organizations may lose their financing and drop their coverage before the insurer can recoup its costs.
But many groups say the exclusions are arbitrary and unfair. ''I would like to see statistical data to show why the arts community is treated like the ammunition industry,'' said Ted Berger, executive director of the New York Foundation for the Arts.
Arts and dance groups and people like florists and interior designers say their groups are often unfairly excluded on the mistaken assumption that their employees are likely to contract the AIDS virus, even though many states prohibit discrimination against people thought to be at increased risk of AIDS.
Mark Scherzer, a Manhattan insurance lawyer, said small businesses with employees who have consulted mental health therapists were also often refused health insurance.
 
Individuals Also Denied Coverage
The exclusions extend beyond certain groups to individuals in small businesses that have not been blacklisted. Many individuals who are ill or have a sick dependent go without health insurance after being rejected - while their fellow workers are accepted - or after being charged steep rate increases. About 2.5 million Americans are considered medically uninsurable, according to Federal estimates.
''Middle-class folks often don't realize how shallow their coverage is and how vulnerable they are,'' said Maryann O'Sullivan, executive director of Health Access, a California consumer coalition based in Los Angeles. The most impoverished Americans are insured by the Medicaid program run by states and the Federal Government.
The exclusion problem ''has gotten worse over the last few years,'' said Lisa M. Carroll, health services director of the Small Business Service Bureau, an association based in Worcester, Mass., that arranges group insurance for 35,000 businesses.
Insurers say the exclusions have resulted from rapidly rising medical costs that increase their risks. ''We're being told the problems are becoming more acute,'' said Mr. Raymond of the Health Insurance Association. ''We hear it from the state insurance commissioners, customers having trouble getting coverage and on Capitol Hill.''
 
Small Groups Suffer Most
Critics of exclusions, including some insurance executives, say blanket denials of coverage are adding heat to a growing debate over improving access to health care for uninsured Americans. The insurance exclusions are felt most by groups of fewer than 50 employees, whose combined premiums frequently do not meet the costs of a single expensive illness. While insurance brokers say they can sometimes negotiate exceptions to the exclusions, small groups often find the price beyond their reach.
The critics say many insurance carriers now concentrate on the customers considered least likely to have high medical costs, avoiding people who would once have been insured as part of a communitywide group.
''The insurance industry is killing itself softly,'' said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health-care expert and professor of political economy at Princeton University. ''I understand their business needs, but I would like them to get out of the game of picking the favorable risks and excluding the rest. They are getting a terrible reputation.''
Ms. Carroll of the Small Business Service Bureau said the restrictions were often unfair. ''Even though they may hire part-timers, the owners and operators and permanent office staff are also being excluded,'' she said. ''And most diseases are not industry-specific.''
 
Some Insurers Are Alarmed
Some insurance executives have also expressed alarm. ''We are clearly concerned about accessibility, both as a company and as an industry,'' said John P. Cole, executive vice president of the Lincoln National Corporation, an insurer based in Fort Wayne, Ind. ''What we have to do as an industry is get back in the insurance business, to look at small businesses and take on more risk than we have in the past.''
Some insurance carriers have tried to avoid exclusions. Indeed, Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations in some states still accept all applicants, although their rates have also risen steeply and often include added charges for people in cities where health care is expensive, as well as for elderly people, who are more likely to submit medical claims.
The Small Business Service Bureau arranges coverage for pooled groups of its members with nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans and health maintenance organizations that have fewer barriers to membership.
Insurance groups are also discussing special pools financed by the insurance industry that would accept high-risk people, spreading the costs of their care among all insurers. Small employers would still pay a premium, but would receive tax credits or government assistance.
At least 18 states have pools that receive little or no government help. Bob Griss, a policy analyst in Washington with the World Institute on Disability, an advocacy group for disabled people, said groups using the pools must still pay high premiums.
 
Higher Rates for Everyone
Under the current system, unpaid health costs not covered by insurance are transferred through higher rates to everyone who does have coverage. ''We all end up paying more,'' said Dr. Stephen Crane, a health policy analyst at the Boston University School of Public Health.
Insurers voice frustration about efforts to insure small groups. Joseph Fazzino, a spokesman for the Hartford Group, said the company stopped selling group health insurance last year to most businesses with fewer than 50 employees. He said the exclusion list ''may still apply to groups of 50 to 100 employees.''
''We've found it is very difficult to adequately price small groups,'' he added. As for government-financed nonprofit agencies or municipalities, ''those might be cases where the clients go out for bids on a yearly basis,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Incumbent Easily Wins Second Term as the Mayor of New Orleans

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won re-election to a second four-year term here on Saturday, making a comeback after polls last fall showed that he had lost the confidence of the voters.
Mr. Barthelemy, 47 years old, beat his main challenger, Donald Mintz, by a comfortable margin. Mr. Mintz, who is white, is a successful lawyer who had never before run for political office.
In the final but unofficial count Mr. Barthelemy received 79,995 votes, 55 percent of the total votes cast in the open primary, and Mr. Mintz, 65,047, or 44 percent. In Louisiana's nonpartisan election system, a candidate who receives more than 50 percent of the vote in the primary wins outright. Both candidates are Democrats. 
Mr. Barthelemy, who is this city's second black Mayor, won re-election with a coalition that included black ministers, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and conservative and moderate whites, giving him 86 percent of the black vote and 25 percent of the white vote. The electorate here is 54 percent black.
 
'A Complete Flip-Flop'
''This was a complete flip-flop'' of the support Mr. Barthelemy received four years ago, said Edward F. Renwick, director of the Loyola University Institute of Politics and Mr. Mintz's pollster. In 1986, when his challenger was a black State Senator, Mr. Barthelemy won 85 percent of the white vote and 30 percent of the black vote.
Among Mr. Barthelemy's supporters was former Mayor Moon Landrieu, who was Housing Secretary for President Jimmy Carter and is now a real estate developer. Some of the city's more conservative white elite also supported Mr. Barthelemy.
''What you have in this election,'' said Arnold Hirsch, a professor of history and urban studies at the University of New Orleans, ''are some of the city's most conservative whites combined with blacks, which means that someone is going to be disappointed in the next four years.''
 
Fears About Crime and Economy
Polls showed Mr. Barthelemy's popularity declined precipitously last fall as voters expressed fears about crime, drugs and the economy. But in January, his popularity rose after the death of this city's first black Mayor, Ernest N. Dutch Morial, a civil rights leader and political enemy of Mr. Barthelemy.
Mr. Morial's friends had been urging him to enter the race but the former Mayor announced he would not be a candidate and died a short time later.
Mr. Morial and Mr. Mintz had been old friends. Though a newcomer to politics, Mr. Mintz has long been prominent in New Orleans business and civic circles.
Both Mr. Mintz and Mr. Barthelemy were perceived by voters as liberal, said Silas Lee, one of the incumbent's pollsters. In virtually a single-issue message, Mr. Mintz tried to convince voters he alone had the drive and competence to revive the battered New Orleans economy, which declined with the collapse of oil prices.
Mr. Barthelemy responded by saying he was ''quietly getting the job done.''

HEADLINE: Costly Pitfalls in Worker Retraining

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT SMITH, Ark.

 BODY:
The best way to deal with workers who lose their jobs when industry shrinks, Washington has thought for years, is to teach them to do something else. But retraining is more talked about than done, and in this blue-collar city on the Arkansas-Oklahoma border, it is off to an uncommonly rocky start.
A critical problem with retraining in Fort Smith, one that is almost uniquely American, is the way employers juggle their labor forces, laying people off when business dips and calling them back when it brightens.
While the juggling has reached an extreme here, it has been going on for decades in some industries, especially in automobile manufacturing and defense contracting. And industrial experts say it could worsen in today's slow economy. 
 
Cutting Costs to Bone
The need for retraining arose because Fort Smith's biggest and highest-paying employer, the Whirlpool Corporation, is cutting costs to the bone. A generation ago, Whirlpool, like other industrial companies from the North, flocked to communities like Fort Smith in pursuit of lower wages and compliant workers.
The company, which makes refrigerators here, is replacing hundreds of its workers with machines, and next month it will move some of its production to Mexico. In September it will also cut wages for the first time.
The highly competitive appliance business is littered with the corpses of other brands, said Lee R. Ross, the division vice president who runs the Whirlpool plant here. Because large numbers of people in their 30's and 40's have already bought and furnished their homes, he said, growth in the industry has stopped, and ''we're slugging it out with the guys who are going to remain.''
There have been some successes in retraining laid-off workers, especially young people who are able to handle major changes in their lives. But for most former workers, retraining is difficult because wages for new jobs can be half and even a third those of the old factory jobs, leaving them little incentive to seek retraining.
Even as it is reducing its work force here over the longer term, Whirlpool is recalling workers.
 
From 5,400 Workers to 1,900
Less than two years ago, the company employed 5,400 people here. But with a series of big cuts, mostly in the last year, it chopped the payroll to 1,900. Management says it does not expect to need 5,400 workers again, but it is calling back 500 on Monday and perhaps 1,500 more through April. It says many of the people will be let go again in September, but it says it cannot be specific.
The juggling is unavoidable, Mr. Ross said. ''Our season is historically very seasonal or cyclical,'' he said. ''In past years we were able to work around it, '' but in a more intensely cost-competitive market that is harder to do.
Whirlpool's struggle for survival is playing havoc with a comprehensive community retraining program set to begin this month for 670 workers from the company and its suppliers.
Martha Anne Pearcy, head of the Western Arkansas Employment Development Agency, which is coordinating the retraining program largely financed by the Federal Government, said she was wary of rankling a company that can dictate Fort Smith's fortunes. But she said, ''It almost seems you're playing with workers' lives.''
As long as workers think there is hope for a recall and a Whirlpool wage, the retraining experts here say, they are unlikely to join the program. Many who might have enrolled will choose to take a Whirlpool paycheck instead, even though they are likely to lose it again.
While retraining, the workers would collect only unemployment benefits and, if they qualify, an extra $50 a week.
 
Other Problems With Recall
The workers' willingness to wait for a recall causes other problems. More than 100 jobs - some in electronics and nursing that pay as much as Whirlpool, most paying less - have already been lined up for trained people from Whirlpool, and these could dry up.
Worse, delay in getting all 670 workers into the program could jeopardize its financing. In December, before Whirlpool disclosed how many people it would call back, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced she would provide $2 million for the workers under the Job Training Partnership Act, the six-year-old program that Congress devised to help communities assist dislocated workers.
Fort Smith has 18 months to use the money, and if fewer than 670 people sign up, it would have to return some of the money. The city could ask for an extension so it could pick up workers who will be laid off in the fall, but with scores of other communities competing for the money, the Government could send the funds elsewhere.
One person who could be recalled is 25-year-old Kathy Fox, who started at Whirlpool in October 1986. ''I was laid off in May last year,'' she said. ''Three weeks later I was called back. Then I was laid off in July, and I haven't been called back since.''
Work force juggling like Whirlpool's occurs most often in communities where a single employer dominates the economy and pays the highest wages. A prominent case is Framingham, Mass., a city of 65,000 where a 50-year old General Motors Corporation factory was the biggest employer. Seven years ago the company shut the local plant, then expanded it and recalled the workers the next year, disrupting the retraining programs.
In late 1987, General Motors closed the factory again, idling 3,700 workers; it reopened the plant a second time in early 1988, recalling 2,000 workers. Last summer the plant was closed a third time, because of lackluster sales of the cars made there, the Buick Century and Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera.
''You'll get a lot of autoworkers who go on layoff and live in the hope they'll be recalled,'' said Jerome M. Rosow, president of the Work in America Institute in Scarsdale, N.Y., a not-for-profit research organization. ''They'll scrimp and wait two years or more.''
Last year, Whirlpool proposed that workers here take a 58-cent cut in their hourly wage, dropping it for most to $10.19. Over a year, the cut represents a reduction of about $1,000 from wages that typically are $22,000, excluding overtime. The union leadership, which negotiated the contract, urged the members to accept the wage cut.
Workers are also irked by the company's move to Mexico and its latest form of automation. The move involves the company's cheapest and smallest refrigerators, those that are 24- and 28-inches wide. Whirlpool says it simply cannot make them in the United States and meet the competition's price.
Mr. Ross appears to have the upper hand. The union is reluctant to strike because it lacks the money to provide benefits. And because of Arkansas's right-to-work laws, Whirlpool has a nucleus of nonunion workers to keep the factory running in the event of a strike. With a rise in Fort Smith's unemployment rate, to about 8 percent last November from about 5 percent a couple of years ago, Mr. Ross also has a growing pool of people outside the company to draw on.
He said Whirlpool intends to remain in Fort Smith but on terms dictated by the appliance market.
''What we're trying to do is work with the people to get them to understand we have to do things differently so we can be here another 25 years,'' he said. ''We think we can be successful in Fort Smith, Arkansas - at the wage rates we're currently paying. Fifty-eight cents, is that take it or leave it? No. But net, net, bottom line, that's where we've got to be.''

HEADLINE: The Year, Perhaps Hour, of the Child

 BODY:
This year, the President and Congress have an extraordinary opportunity to speak for the poorest and most helpless of all Americans. Those Americans don't have the vote or any economic clout; they don't know how to read and write; and while they may fight among themselves, they can't possibly fight for themselves. They are, of course, children - ''all special'' as President Bush put it in his State of the Union speech, ''because they are the very future of freedom.'' 
Some are what the Governor of Oregon, Neil Goldschmidt, recently described as ''the children in the shadows - the ones ill provided and ill equipped to learn and prosper.'' These kids have had so bad a beginning in life that even by first grade it's clear they're never going to catch up. Unless, that is, they're lucky enough to be enrolled in a Federal program called Head Start.
Head Start's graduates are more likely to be employed, have a high school diploma and go to college than comparable children. They're less likely to be arrested or live on welfare, too.
President Bush knows that: it's why he's seeking a $500 million increase to bring Head Start spending to nearly $2 billion. Such an increase would allow 180,000 more poor children to be added to the 450,000 already served, thus enabling the program to reach about 75 percent of the nation's eligible 4-year-olds.
But why stop at 4-year-olds? The Bush proposal represents the largest single-year increase in Head Start's 25-year history. But it doesn't allow for better salaries for instructors or broader programs; most important, it doesn't allow for Head Start to enter a poor child's life as soon and as often as possible. Ideally, Head Start would be all day, all year and so generously funded it could include all the children eligible.
Mr. Bush also knows that ''a better America'' is one ''where women working outside the home can be confident their children are in safe and loving care, and where Government works to expand child care alternatives for parents.'' Congress has a chance to insure that confidence right now, by passing a good child care bill.
Last fall, the Senate approved a $3.5 billion package that would boost the working poor and increase their access to safe, decent child care. The bill would provide expanded tax credits and grants directly to low-income families, and it would help states increase the supply of day care providers and establish standards for them.
The House has a similar though somewhat costlier bill that's been held up by members' stubborn inability to agree on whether funds should go to the states through direct appropriations or through block grants. The battle looks more like turf warfare than honest disagreement. In the meantime, it has, sadly, delayed help for low-income families.
''When it comes to hope and the future, every kid is the same: full of dreams, ready to take on the world.'' George Bush said that last week. If the President means what he says, he and the Congressional leadership are going to have to knock some heads together - so that all kids get the same fair chance to take on the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Staying a Superpower

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Take a long look ahead. Assume the Soviet military threat continues to recede, as grim necessity imposes a policy of contractionism.
Assume, too, that U.S. military strength can subsequently be reduced to the ability to take on one and a half downsized aggressors, and to defend our skies against incoming terrorist missiles.
Finally, make the equally hopeful assumption that the U.S. wants to continue to advance the cause of human rights and free markets in the world, as well as to defend its interests and nationals abroad. 
How do we square that last hope with the first two assumptions? How do we remain a superpower in a world in which military strength does not define supremacy?
The answer is self-evident: we have to maintain and enhance our national economic power. Although multinational corporations will abound and stock exchanges will interlock, for the next generation, at least, a few political entities called nations will lay the power lines for the world economy.
Some nation is going to be No. 1; better it should be us, with our tradition of raising standards of living and of not starting wars. And since enlightened capitalists do not treat business as a zero-sum game, our ambition for preeminence poses no danger to any other nation; if we win, nobody loses.
Our superpower competition will be reunified Germany (perhaps together with its European satellites) and expanding Japan (perhaps allied with China, if they can bring that off). Their successful systems are based on central-bank-disciplined, government-supported private enterprise.
Grant me, arguendo, that sort of scenario, with the Soviet federation rebuilding and small wars raging here and there, as the world of the millennium.
In that world, the U.S. will from time to time feel duty-bound to use its muscle. I'm not talking about industrial policy or subsidized consortiums or government research to help U.S. business and labor compete with other superpowers' companies on their terms - that's another subject. Today's tract is about being able to apply the power of the U.S. economy to change the policy of other countries.
Suppose our citizens are molested, or our property is illegally expropriated, or a despot sets up a depot for poison-gas sales or a haven for drug criminals; suppose a new Khomeini or Qaddafi or Idi Amin emerges to assault a neighbor or wipe out a minority. ''Perdicaris alive or Raisuli dead'' is less of an option, especially when Raisuli has an off-the-shelf missile with a nuclear warhead.
We need a way to turn up the economic heat, when appeals to conscience or international organizations fail, to foment internal discontent - thereby to put a real cost on tyrannical or corrupt behavior.
Sometimes sanctions are effective and sometimes not; this and a little hypocrisy produce great inconsistencies in policy.
To South Africa, when world economic sanctions combine with an ebbing Communist threat and a gutsy leader to produce progress toward ending apartheid, liberals say we should keep the sanctions on, and add fresh sanctions against China to protest their massacres; but to the Soviet Union, where technology-transfer restrictions have added to the pain that has yet to bring fundamental reform, the same voices cry ''take them off.''
This proves that economic sanctions - pressures, harassments, denials of opportunity - are presumed to have an effect, if only psychological. In the future, foreign aid (the carrot) and limited economic war (the stick) will be the primary ways we exercise our power, and will be most effective when other economic superpowers act in concert.
Here we are, then, on the brink of a new era calling for a new way to use American power - and nobody in the White House to my knowledge is coming to grips with it.
We are still organized according to old functions rather than new missions. Shall we apply coordinated economic pressure to achieve a policy aim? The men from Commerce and Agriculture shake their heads no, the man from Defense nods yes, the Trade Negotiator other-hands maybe, and on the State Department's seventh floor, eyes roll heavenward. Congress then mixes in.
Needed is a sub-Cabinet council of economic intervention, at first within the National Security Council, to see what muscle we can marshal and what connective tissue will add to its puissance.
New world a-comin', maybe, but not without crises in need of U.S. action. To meet them, a few sophisticated business minds should be put to work to get us ahead of the power curve.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Albany Deadlock Blocking U.S. Aid To Poor Families

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
The Federal Family Support Act, approved by Congress 16 months ago, has yet to support a single member of the family of New York.
Delays in complying with complex and politically sensitive Federal laws are not uncommon. In this case, though, 27 other states - including New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Florida - have enacted legislation that entitles them to additional Federal funds to help wean people from welfare.
California received $50 million in the six months ending Jan. 1. New York could have collected at least $4.5 million so far and, theoretically, as much as 10 times that. 
Albany's languor is particularly galling to Senator Daniel P. Moynihan because he fathered the Family Support Act and New York is his home state.
''We've wasted 16 months,'' Mr. Moynihan complains. ''All the major welfare states have commenced serious programs of welfare reform in the 1980's except New York.''
New York's welfare officials insist that the state's modest demonstration projects were models for the nation. But they concede that New York failed last year to capitalize on the Federal program. The state's failure to comply by this fall could subject the state to Federal sanctions.
The Family Support Act requires single parents on welfare whose children are over age 3 to get regular jobs or, if they are unable to do so, to enroll in Government-financed educational and job-training courses to prepare them for work. As an incentive, welfare recipients who find jobs are eligible for a year of child care and medical benefits.
But how to comply with Federal guidelines for the work program has stymied the Legislature. These questions dominate the debate:
* Should the program pay welfare recipients to attend college? Federal guidelines provide for post-secondary education, but it is arguable whether that should include college or be limited to vocational training. Under one compromise, the program would cover two years of community college and the last two years of a four-year college.
* Should the program be mandatory for all parents with children between 3 and 5 years old? Or should job or training slots be filled first with volunteers? Does it make sense to force some people into the program to the exclusion of others who are more highly motivated? Or, should the goal be to recruit malingerers and others who are reluctant to participate? One compromise would require participation and accept volunteers; slots would be filled first come first served.
* If, in the absence of alternatives, welfare recipients are assigned government jobs, would they displace regular unionized public employees? One compromise would limit such jobs to six months at most.
''There are two diametrically opposed philosphical views'' between the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democrat-dominated Assembly, says Cesar A. Perales, the State Social Services Commissioner. ''We're struggling to find a consensus.''
The state estimates that 84,000 welfare recipients with children age 6 and older are employable. About 30,000 of those, according to the estimates, have enrolled in some employment or training program. The Federal law, by including single parents of younger children, would expand the pool by about 60,000, about 45,000 of whom are deemed employable.
Tomorrow, Mr. Perales will ask the Legislature's fiscal committees to raise the state's share of the employment and training budget to $54 million, a $23 million increase, to provide for 20,000 additional training slots. (Under the Family Support Act, the Federal Government would pay 60 percent; the state and localities would split the rest evenly). Mr. Perales acknowledges, though, that waiting lists for child care mean fewer single parents will be able to graduate from welfare to work.
Too often in the welfare bureaucracy, results seem as illusory as goals seem elusive.
The number of welfare cases in New York State has declined slightly, from 361,000 in 1979 to 337,000 last year, in part because families are smaller. But since 1969, inflation has eroded benefits to children by one-third. Fewer children previously known to New York City's child welfare system apparently died of abuse or neglect last year than in 1988. But those 45 children still accounted for 4 in 10 of all suspected deaths from abuse or neglect.
The Family Support Act, Mr. Perales says, may not revolutionize welfare, but it may eventually re-define the system from one that seems to perpetuate dependency. Unless the Governor and Legislature do their jobs over the next few months, though, fewer welfare recipients may get to work.

HEADLINE: Thousands of Children Doing Adults' Work

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FREITAG

 BODY:
With its harsh fluorescent lights and faint odor of caustic chemicals, the cramped belt factory on West 38th Street is an unlikely place to find an 11-year-old girl on a Friday morning. But there among the rows of industrial sewing machines and heaps of remnants, Maria Mendez is hard at work.
Wielding a large pair of scissors, Maria trims excess threads from finished belts. She concentrates so intently that neither she nor her mother sees the investigators from the New York State Department of Labor enter the factory. 
Her mother, who is also named Maria Mendez, tells an investigator that her daughter's teacher was out sick and classes were canceled. Rather than leave her child at home alone, Mrs. Mendez says, she brought her to work.
The factory owner, Gabriel Basques, says the girl is not working but is there visiting her mother.
Nonetheless, the investigator, Angelo Valdevitt, cites Mr. Basques for violating child labor laws. If he is found guilty, he can be fined up to $500.
 
A Too-Familiar Scene
''She said she was just playing with the scissors, but obviously she was cutting threads,'' Mr. Valdevitt said.
The scene is all too familiar to Joseph Halik, a supervising investigator with the Apparel Industry Task Force, which inspects garment factories for violations of wage and hour and child labor laws. Almost every day, he said, investigators find children who claim their classes were canceled operating sewing machines or putting finished garments into bags.
''I can't tell you how many times we've heard that story,'' Mr. Halik said. ''There must be a lot of sick teachers in this city.'' He said he has never heard of a school canceling a class instead of calling in a subsitute teacher.
More than 50 years after the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act banned children younger than 16 from working in factories, child labor is widespread in New York City. From the bustling lofts of the garment district and Chinatown to the basement sweatshops outside Manhattan and in the suburbs, at least 7,500 children work illegally in the garment industry every day, state officials say.
These children are missing school and are subjected to health hazards including exposure to toxic substances and injuries from machines they are too young to operate safely.
The extent of the problem is unknown, but studies by Federal and state agencies indicate that child labor violations are rising in many industries, both in New York City and in other parts of the country.
Experts attribute the increase in child labor violations to a shrinking labor pool caused by low unemployment and the end of the baby boom, as well as to intensified competition from foreign companies.
 
Seeking Tougher Penalties
Federal labor laws prohibit most paid work for children younger than 14 and set strict limits on how much children younger than 16 can work after school and on weekends. But Federal and state officials say a growing number of employers are flouting the laws.
In response, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last year introduced legislation that would tighten the state's child labor laws by, among other things, making the penalties against employers more severe.
In support of that legislation, the State Labor Commissioner, Thomas F. Hartnett, testified in Albany last week that the number of children found illegally employed in New York more than doubled from 1984 to 1989. But that may merely reflect stepped-up enforcement.
As in other states, violators included supermarket chains and fast-food restaurants that ignored regulations regarding what times of day and the maximum number of hours 16- and 17-year-olds are permitted to work. But many of the most flagrant violations in New York were by some of the 7,000 garment factories in the metropolitan area.
 
Hampered by Low Fines
Since it was formed in October 1987, the state's 34-member Apparel Industry Task Force has found 370 children working illegally in about 250 sweatshops.
''The violation rate was so terrific when we started out that we had to make child labor a programmatic priority,'' said Hugh McDaid, the director of the task force. About 15 percent of the group's inspections yield at least one violation of child labor laws, Mr. McDaid said.
The task force is empowered to make random inspections like the one last week at Gabriel Belts on West 38th Street. But the group is hampered by the amount of fines it is allowed to levy and by the vastness of the problem, Mr. McDaid said.
''This agency cannot stamp out child labor,'' he said. ''The only thing we can do is educate them about why this is a bad thing.''
 
'This Is a Trap for Them'
In some family-oriented communities, particularly Chinatown, children work only after school or during school vacations to supplement the family income, Mr. McDaid said. ''Their problem is that they're falling asleep in class,'' he said.
But in many other places, particularly neighborhoods of recent immigrants from Latin America, children do not attend school at all, he said. Instead, they work long hours for wages that rarely reach the legal minimum.
''This is a trap for them,'' Mr. McDaid said. ''They sacrifice their education and literally commit themselves to a life of working in a sweatshop. They have no future.''
For more than a year, Dr. Susan H. Pollack and Dr. Philip J. Landrigan of Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan have been studying the medical impact of child labor. Although they expect to spend at least another year on the study, their preliminary findings indicate that hundreds - possibly thousands - of working children in the city are injured each year.
''We know that in New York State there are over 1,000 kids getting workers' compensation for injuries each year, and that's just the tip of the iceberg,'' Dr. Pollack said. ''My guess is that many more children are getting hurt and no one is reporting it.''
Dr. Pollack, who has accompanied members of the Apparel Industry Task Force on several inspections, said she noticed many potential hazards, including machinery like hydraulic hole punches and steam presses. But the greatest hazard, she said, is that the children simply lack the experience to avoid dangerous situations.
''What really struck me,'' Dr. Pollack said, ''was how many 14-year-olds were out there and how little they knew about their rights as workers.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eleven-year-old Maria Mendez trimming thread from belts at a factory on West 38th Street in Manhattan. The State Labor Department's Apparel Industry Task Force enforces child labor laws. Its investigators say violations are common. (The New York Times/Keith Meyers)

HEADLINE: Tourist Love For New York Grows Chilly

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
The number of people visiting New York City for business or pleasure declined slightly last year, but what really worries many in the local tourism industry is the prospect that the 1989 statistics may be the first sign of a long slide.
Travel experts see a number of negative patterns at work. One is that tourists from the United States and abroad, having already visited New York, are increasingly choosing to sample less familiar parts of the country. Second, in a sluggish economy, companies are turning away from the exorbitant hotel prices of New York for business meetings.
At the same time, the budget of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau has been cut by nearly one-third because the city, struggling to balance its budget, stopped appropriating money to it. The bureau, which promotes the city, books conventions and assists visitors, says that other cities are aggressively competing for the travel dollar. 
 
'The Sky Is Not Falling'
Not all observers agree that the downturn will be steep.
''There are signs that suggest an erosion of a pattern of growth,'' said Bern Rotman, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Economic Development, ''but the sky is not falling down.''
At the 770-room Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza at 49th Street and Broadway, which opened in December, the managing director, Michael Silberstein, said: ''I believe there's no reason to panic or to start slashing rates. It'll take about a year to get out of this sluggish economy, at which point we'll all go back to the happy old days.''
But many experts are not as optimistic. ''I think it's going to be slow coming back,'' said Stephen W. Brener, a New York City consultant to the hotel industry.
For the first 11 months of 1989, the latest figures available, the number of people flying into the three major airports that serve New York City was about 35 million, a figure 5.2 percent below the comparable period in 1988, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
International arrivals rose 1.6 percent, but domestic arrivals at La Guardia Airport, Kennedy International Airport and Newark International Airport dropped 7.9 percent, Port Authority figures showed.
 
Hotel Occupancy Is Down
The hotel occupancy rate fell, too, to 75.62 percent, from 79.21 percent in the first 11 months of 1988, according to Pannell Kerr Forster, an accounting and consulting firm that specializes in the hotel and restaurant industry. And the average number of hotel room nights sold through November fell slightly in New York City while rising in cities like Dallas, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Orlando, Fla., according to a survey by Smith Travel Research, a lodging industry research organization in Hendersonville, Tenn.
While more tourists from overseas did come to New York last year, the city's share of all foreign travelers who arrive in the United States is shrinking, partly because airlines in recent years have begun to schedule international flights in many more American cities.
''Ten years ago an international visitor had few options for arriving in the United States,'' said Marshall E. Murdaugh, president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau. ''Today you have major gateways in Miami, Atlanta, Washington, D.C., Pittsburgh, Denver and Dallas.''
And foreign visitors are not just arriving in other cities, but are also staying there to explore them or are venturing into the countryside.
''Foreign travelers are looking to see all of America,'' said Ron Erdman, a market research analyst with the Travel and Tourism Administration, an arm of the United States Department of Commerce. ''They have been to New York. In New York, you have to give them another reason to come back.''
 
Shorter, Family-Oriented Trips
Domestic travel patterns are changing, too, said Linda Scott, director of retail travel for American Express Travel Services. Americans, in many cases working couples looking for relief from job-related stress or wanting to spend more time with their children, are looking for ''weekend getaways'' or shorter, family-oriented vacations. Often they prefer packages that offer the most value for their money and new destinations.
''There's a 'discover U.S.' trend,'' she said.
Higher airline fares and hotel rates last year discouraged corporate trips to New York, tourism experts said. Air fares in general increased as much as 15 percent during 1989, according to the Air Transport Association. New York City hotel rates, the highest in the country, rose 9.2 percent during the first half of 1989, compared with a national average increase of 3.2 percent, according to a survey by Pannell Kerr Forster.
The average daily hotel rate in New York in the first six months of 1989 was $127.83, compared with $52.10 in Houston, $74.40 in Los Angeles and $88.99 in Chicago, the survey found.
 
Choosing Houston Instead
Audrey Lord-Hausman, of Meeting Planners International in the West Coast, an association of corporate travel managers and tourist industry representatives, said travel costs have risen too high for some companies.
''I think we're going to see in the 90's smaller meetings that are closer to home,'' she said.
There was a time, for example, when managers of Fireman's Fund in Novato, Calif., came to New York City for business meetings and a whirl of sightseeing. Now they are more likely to pack for a company trip to Houston or St. Louis.
''You could easily argue that New York is a better destination because there's a lot to do,'' said David Kliman, Fireman's Fund director of travel and corporate events. ''It's the center of the world and all that. But what companies are looking at is, 'What does it cost?'
''We have paid up to $285 per room and that's just very difficult for my company to justify.''
 
From Tourism, 143,600 Jobs
With the outlook for tourism so unclear, the Convention and Visitors Bureau argues, now is not the time to cut back on promoting New York City by reducing the bureau's financing.
''This business has become extremely competitive,'' Mr. Murdaugh, the bureau president, said. ''Two-thirds of the people don't have to come to New York. They have to be motivated to come to New York.''
Bureau officials are trying to convince the new city administration that the cutbacks would have costly long-term effects. Tourism accounted for 143,600 jobs, $9.7 billion in revenue and $542 million in local taxes in 1988, when the city was visited by 19.8 million people, bureau figures show.
Bureau officials said they are looking into possible new sources of public financing, like a hotel room surcharge.
City financing of the bureau dropped from $1.5 million in 1988 to $1.25 million in 1989. There was no 1990 allocation. The bureau's current budget of $3.6 million comes from contributions from its 1,400 members, including hotels and restaurants.
 
Information Center Closed
Visitors' bureau officials say that budget cuts have forced them to stop worldwide advertising of the city. They said that with fewer staff members, fewer conventions will be booked, jeopardizing the visits of hundreds of thousands of delegates this year.
The bureau has also been forced to shut down its information center in Times Square and to close the one at Columbus Circle on weekends, the officials said. An estimated 149,000 visitors who would have received assistance through the centers now cannot, they said.
In addition, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget calls for a $2 million cut in the state's ''I Love New York'' tourist promotion program.
Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, deputy mayor for finance and economic development, said any loss of tourism revenue is a concern but fiscal constraints will determine whether the city can reinstate money for the visitors bureau.
''They're very high on our list of priorities,'' she said.
