HEADLINE: With Kemp at Helm, H.U.D. Gains New Spirit, but Some Doubts Linger

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Jack Kemp was impatient. It was 6 P.M. one day last spring, and he wanted to mail a letter directing 3,300 public housing authorities to evict drug dealers. Unfortunately, the agency lawyer who was drafting the document had left for the day.
Mr. Kemp, unfazed, found the letter on the lawyer's computer disk, polished it and had it mailed. The next morning, the lawyer discovered his disk missing and the letter sent.
With Mr. Kemp at the helm, the Department of Housing and Urban Development has awakened. Unlike his remote predecessor, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., Mr. Kemp has wandered the halls, popped into offices, solicited ideas from staff members. 
Housing and urban experts agree that an infusion of spirit and purpose into the troubled agency has been the greatest achievement of Mr. Kemp's first year as Secretary. But a year after the former Congressman from Buffalo was sworn in, some are still uncertain about his success in putting housing back on the national agenda or in returning himself, as some suspect he hopes, to the political arena. Rhetoric Into Action? ''The question is whether he can translate rhetoric into action,'' said Ira Gribbin, a former president of the National Association of Realtors. ''That will be the test in 1990.''
Mr. Kemp admits that his enthusiasm sometimes exceeds his knowledge of the agency's programs. When he announced last month that he was ending a mortgage insurance program that had cost the Government $1 billion, he admitted he was not conversant with all the details. ''Did they want a mortgage banker or a quarterback?'' asked the former Buffalo Bill.
On the plus side, Mr. Kemp used his Congressional experience to help win enactment last November of a modest legislative package to correct the ravages of the Pierce era. The measure is intended to help avert the pattern of political influence that often determined grant decisions in Ronald Reagan's Administration and enriched developers and consultants with high-level Republican connections.
The new law limits the agency's discretion by creating firm criteria for housing grants, threatens violators with civil penalties of up to $1 million a year.
In addition to Mr. Kemp's efforts, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced last week that he was seeking the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate Mr. Pierce and other former senior H.U.D. officials for conspiracy to defraid the Government in awarding grants to prominent Republicans and close friends, regardless of merit.
Housing experts credit Mr. Kemp for persuading President Bush to support legislation to create a three-year, $5.5 billion program intended to help low-income families become homeowners. The agency is now drafting the legislation.
At Mr. Kemp's behest, the budget for the fiscal year 1991 that President Bush delivered to Congress last week calls for a $1.4 billion increase in housing assistance, to $15 billion. The President's budget also calls for a $300 million increase in money for the homeless.
 
Some Housing Cuts Are Sought
But critics note that the budget seeks a reduction in money for modernization of public housing and low-income home energy assistance. Money for community services block grants would be cut to $42 million from $389 million under the Bush proposal. The President also wants to repeal Urban Development Action Grants, which helped build up the downtown areas in Baltimore, Buffalo and other cities. Mr. Kemp agreed to these reductions to obtain money for Project Hope, the plan for low-income homeowners.
''For every good initiative, they've taken money away from equally good programs,'' said Mark L. Wolfe, director of Federal Funds Information for States, a joint project of the National Governors Association and the National Association of State Legislatures. ''Mr. Kemp has no money. It's a matter of simply pushing things around.''
Although he is no longer a quarterback, Mr. Kemp is still scrambling as he seeks ways to operate the department more efficiently. ''My biggest surprise was the depth of the problem,'' Mr. Kemp said in an interview in his office, beneath portraits of Churchill, Lincoln, Jefferson and the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. ''I don't mean the depth of the scandal, but the depth of mismanagement. There were systemic problems.''
He added, ''The agency had been drifting for decades.''
Mr. Kemp has taken a few steps to end that drift. Last month he announced his intention to appoint financial officers to oversee major departments. ''At F.H.A., with a $300 to $400 billion portfolio and inventory, there is only one actuary,'' Mr. Kemp said. ''People don't know where the money is going.''
 
He Remains an Anomaly
To some degree, Mr. Kemp remains an anomaly, a conservative Republican who talks urgently about housing for the homeless and empowering the poor. Calling himself ''a bleeding-heart conservative,'' Mr. Kemp has insisted that at least 75 percent of the agency's money be spent on the poor.
''I'm dealing with the issues that are the least obvious to most in my own party, yet are the most intractable problems facing our country as it tries to tell the rest of the world that democracy will work for them,'' he said.
Although Mr. Kemp gets high grades for working Capitol Hill, he is faulted for dealing directly with tenant groups rather than local elected officials. This tendency has caused concern among mayors and even some Congressmen fearful of being bypassed in the allocation of money to their constituents.
''They want to shift to less government control over the programs, when those programs haven't had enough control,'' Mayor Greg B. Sparrow of DeKalb, Ill., a Democrat, said of Mr. Kemp's desire to end run city officials. ''Besides, who's going to provide all the support services, if not the cities?''
On balance, it seems Mr. Kemp spent much of his first year with his finger in the dike, trying to stem the fallout from the disclosures of fraud, waste and influence peddling in the Pierce years that rocked the agency. The budget process that just started in Congress will provide a test of his resolve and effectiveness.
 
What He Wants Financed
After persuading President Bush to endorse the Homeownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere program, Project Hope, Mr. Kemp needs to make sure that Congress finances the package, which would cost $1.2 billion in fiscal 1991. It includes $250 million in grants to help low-income families and tenants become homeowners, and would require the states to put up an additional $1 for every $2 in Federal money. The program also calls for $251 million for housing vouchers; $412 million to help resident groups become home buyers, and a $246 million program to help the homeless by providing medical care, education and job training as well as beds.
Meanwhile, Mr. Kemp enjoys some credit for good intentions. ''One encouraging sign,'' said Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston, who headed a study on hunger and homelessness for the United States Conference of Mayors, ''is that Kemp wants to put the Federal Government and the Federal tax code back into the business of producing affordable housing.''
The Secretary's good reviews are attributable in part to advisers who fall into three competing groups: conservatives, managers and Kemp political protegees.
The conservatives are led by Alfred A. DelliBovi, Mr. Kemp's Under Secretary, who strongly suggests dealing directly with antipoverty groups rather than with mayors and what he calls ''poverticians'' who make money and careers out of poverty issues.
C. Austin Fitts, the head of the Federal Housing Administration, leads the managers who coach Mr. Kemp on what procedures need to be changed to improve efficiency.
 
Eye on Political Horizon
The Kemp political faction remains concerned about his image and his future. They are led by Mary Brunette, Assistant to the Secretary for Policy and Communication who served in Mr. Kemp's Congressional office.
Many credit the department's legal counsel, Francis A. Keating, a career prosecutor who first detected the brewing scandals, with protecting Mr. Kemp by making sure he was perceived by the public as a vigorous reformer.
At times, the Kemp team is strained by conflicts between what is good for H.U.D. and what is good for Jack F. Kemp. ''Jack believes that if he does a good job in this situation, the future will take care of itself,'' said Mr. DelliBovi. ''But some are concerned about his image. There are things they don't like the policy implications of, and they say that on top of that, it would hurt his image.''
Although Mr. Kemp dismisses any discussion of future campaigns, some of his remarks have fueled speculation that he plans to return to the political arena. Last month he criticized President Bush for sending his Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, to China after the uprising at Tienanmen Square.
But, as Mr. DelliBovi suggests, the final political reckoning may depend on Mr. Kemp's ability to breath life into the Administration's housing policy.
Critics note, for example, that despite the loss of an estimated one and a half million low-income housing units, Mr. Kemp has not proposed building any new housing.
 
Out of Construction Business
''We're not going to go back into the construction business,'' Mr. Kemp responded. ''The stock of housing in America is vast. I'm not saying it's good. A lot of it is in disrepair.''
Therefore, Mr. Kemp said, he is gambling that he can make his mark by concentrating on the renovation of existing housing stock. He also want to provide vouchers that pay the rent of those who cannot otherwise afford decent housing. The voucher program is already in existence, but Mr. Kemp is seeking additional funds. Mr. Kemp acknowledges that critics will charge that these approaches curtail construction of new federally funded housing, an economic boon to many cities. The big complaints, he said, come from developers who profited from H.U.D. programs started in Democratic administrations.
''It's really ironic,'' he said, ''that Jack Kemp, who was criticized as a trickle-down economist, is now in the position of fighting the trickle down theory of the left: subsidize the big, wealthy developers and hope that the benefits accrue to the poor.''
Mr. Kemp's remarks underscore the hard politics of H.U.D. financing: housing contractors are among the major contributors to mayoral campaigns. Democrats who control many city halls have long looked to the housing department to keep those contractors happy. In circumventing city hall by providing Federal funds directly to local groups, critics charge, Mr. Kemp's strategy is an attempt to bolster the status of Republicans in Democratic-controlled cities.
It is a reasonable suspicion to have about a man who, as a Congressman, talked about creating ''blue-collar Republicans.'' Even when Mr. Kemp insists his interest these days is housing policy, it is still possible to imagine he has an eye on the political bottom line.
''If we're going to subsidize anybody, we should subsidize the poor, the family, the renter, the person in public housing,'' Mr. Kemp said. ''Our money should get people into housing, and not go to a developer who gets a multimillion-dollar profit.''

HEADLINE: After the Boom, Tough Times for Dance

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Dance Theater of Harlem arrived in San Diego in mid-January to find itself suddenly without work because the local sponsors had run out of money. Last week, the company announced that a five-month layoff would follow its March engagement at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. ''I don't feel in my heart it's the end of D.T.H.,'' said Arthur Mitchell, the company's artistic director. ''There must be someone out there who will help us.''
Times have been hard lately for American dance. The Dallas Ballet folded last year. The companies of Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis merged, in part to save money. In December, the financially pressed Martha Graham troupe laid off its dancers for January and February. That same month, Karole Armitage said she was disbanding the Armitage Ballet. In 1988 Twyla Tharp, citing the burden of financial concerns, gave up her company to work with American Ballet Theater.
Other cutbacks have been made; the reasons have been complex and specific to each organization. What is certain is that dance, traditionally a struggling art form in the United States, underwent significant changes in the last decade and is now facing new kinds of problems. 
 
Growth, Then Competition
Dance in America experienced a period of explosive growth from the mid-1960's through the 1970's. Federal and private financing agencies increasingly began to recognize and support this youngest of American art forms, and the arrival of international stars like Rudolf Nureyev, Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov brought new visibility and glamour to the dance scene. By the end of the 70's, there were new companies and new audiences throughout the country for ballet and modern dance.
But dance lost some of its major figures in the 1980's, among them George Balanchine, Antony Tudor, Robert Joffrey and Alvin Ailey. Government support waned as the number of companies continued to grow, intensifying competition for financing from the private sector. And while company directors today talk of the greater sophistication of dancegoers, audiences have not grown as much or remained as loyal as expected, although the youthfulness of much of the dance audience is seen as a positive sign.
''The years of extremely rapid growth for those professional companies that are more than 15 years old are over,'' said Stephen Richard, managing director of the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater and one of 25 dance administrators, presenters and artists interviewed recently on the economic state of American dance today. ''But growth is not over. Artistic maturation is not slowing down. You simply don't have the exponential growth that you did in the start-up years.''
 
Tour Dates at a Premium
The concern most frequently cited by dance professionals was the shrinking of touring opportunities. Engagements produced by local or regional presenters have traditionally helped dance companies, particularly modern-dance companies, to finance home rehearsal periods and seasons. But such opportunities began to dwindle with the demise in 1983 of the Dance Touring Program of the National Endowment for the Arts, a program that provided a subsidy structure that helped reduce the risk of presenting often little-known dance companies.
''The system is so big that Government has to be the largest investor,'' said Donald A. Moore, executive director of Dance U.S.A., a national service organization for professional dance. Not many corporations and foundations want to subsidize touring, Mr. Moore said. Support for touring, as for operating budgets, seems far less glamorous than the commissioning of new work. ''And you can't create audiences if you can't get the company there,'' he added.
In the 1980's, many more companies were vying for the available touring dates. There were 37 ballet, modern and ethnic dance companies in the United States in 1965, write William Baumol and William Bowen in their book ''Performing Arts - The Economic Dilemma.'' Twenty years later, 250 were listed in Dance Magazine's Performing Arts Directory. ''Ten years ago, we had presenters call us,'' said Darlene Neel, general manager of the Lewitzky Dance Company of Los Angeles. ''Now you have to make 10 calls to get the work. We used to come home with a little money for rehearsal. Now we break even, if we've done our homework.''
 
Budgets Up, Income Down
With costs rising, outstripping income, sheer economic survival was another concern expressed almost universally. Company budgets have at least doubled or tripled over the last 10 years, with the ratio of earned to contributed income tending to decline by small percentages. At the same time, arts endowment funds to dance have remained flat - dwindling, in terms of real or inflation-adjusted dollars - as have other Government and private aid in general.
Rising costs have resulted in rising ticket prices. In a 1985 survey by the arts endowment, almost one in three adults cited cost as a barrier to ballet attendance. The hiring of administrators who can woo that selective audience is now an increasingly popular strategy in a domain once ruled exclusively by artistic directors and choreographers.
There are new areas of concern, too, for administrators. ''Most dance companies used to be interested only in selling tickets, not institutions,'' said David Resnicow, president of the Arts and Communication Counselors, a division of the public relations concern Ruder Finn & Rotman that arranges sponsorships for corporations and cultural institutions. As institutions, Mr. Resnicow added, dance companies must band together to lobby the Federal Government and the public effectively.
 
Tax Breaks Gone
''What little stability there was, was governmental, because it was fairly dependable,'' Ms. Lewitzky said. ''The states vary. But the Government not only said it would cut everything across the board; they then took away the tax break that was an incentive for foundations and corporations to donate.'' Under the Tax Reform Act of 1986, tax deductions for charitable contributions were eliminated for taxpayers taking standard deductions, and tax rates were reduced, making charitable deductions less attractive, particularly to wealthy donors. In addition, the law greatly reduced tax benefits for gifts of appreciated stock, real estate and artworks.
Many of those interviewed expressed dismay at having to compete with social programs for money. ''It's hard to give money for a production of 'The Sleeping Beauty' when you go down the sidewalks to the Opera House and see all these homeless people,'' said W. McNeil Lowry, chairman of the board of the San Francisco Ballet.
Audiences were also a subject of concern. Patterns of dancegoing have changed. In the 1960's, there existed a small, dedicated core of dancegoers interested - as Sali Ann Kriegsman, director of the dance program of the National Endowment for the Arts, put it - in ''observing the arc of development, going back to 'Swan Lake' a hundred times.'' Now the audience has more choices and is more selective about dance, she said.
 
An Era of Marketing
In an effort to reach that new audience, dance companies in the 1980's experimented with sophisticated marketing techniques and discovered what the London Arts Council has called the ''snacking effect'': audiences' sampling dance attractions without developing any longer-term loyalty.
''I feel the new techniques had a short-term gain but a long-term loss,'' said Marda Kirn, director and producer of the Colorado Dance Festival in Boulder. ''They used Madison Avenue killer hype, but how many times can you use an exclamation to describe a dance company? I think we're seeing audiences disenchanted because there wasn't any substance to that marketing.
''Dance is going out of the chute with a big disadvantage,'' Ms. Kirn continued. ''Music has radio, audio, CD's, recordings. The visual arts have design and graphics and photographs of work so you can see it all the time. Plays are in books or on film. Those art forms are much more present. You can't turn on dance on your car radio. You've always had to make some effort to go to a dance performance. I think education is really important.''
 
Dance Goes Nationwide
On the positive side, dance has become increasingly decentralized, in part because of the innovative National Performance Network. Devised in 1983 by David White, director of the Dance Theater Workshop in Manhattan, the program works with promoters to produce and commission dance attractions, half of them from New York and half from other areas, at alternative theaters in 21 cities outside New York.
Big American cities have experienced real-estate booms that make it harder to find space - so necessary for dance - in which companies can work. But there is also increased local support for home companies and it is now possible to have a successful dance career outside New York City.
Dancers have been the poorest paid performers in the arts, a fact borne out by the 1980 census, which found dancers' salaries to be 45 percent below the average for all artists. But the standard of living has risen somewhat for dancers performing in major modern-dance and ballet companies, which are increasingly unionized, around the nation.
Dancers also are at a higher level of technical virtuosity than ever before. ''We have the largest, best trained core of young people trained in dance that any country has ever had,'' said Mr. Lowry, who developed the Ford Foundation's groundbreaking 1963 grants program for dance schools and companies.
 
New Means of Support
There are new advocacy and support systems as well. A coalition of dance companies, presenters, state and regional arts agencies and national service organizations helped the arts endowment put together its promising new Dance on Tour program, to take effect in the 1991-92 season. Grants from the program's $1.1 million budget, which must be matched by recipients, will be awarded to regional arts agencies and state arts organizations. The agencies will convene panels to review applications for money from presenters, whose newly important curatorial role may be one of the major developments of dance in the 1990's. The state organizations will apply directly to the National Endowment for the Arts for projects that support the presentation of dance.
And the 1990's? Mr. Lowry worries about finding jobs for the newest generation of dancers, and about a general loss or leveling of standards that has resulted, he said, in the belief that ''everything is as good as everything else.'' Ms. Kirn urges that dance ''look video straight in the eye'' and learn to use it to educate, document and compete as entertainment in the increasingly important electronic media.
''I guess the issues for dance companies are not so different than they used to be: time, money and place,'' Mrs. Kriegsman said. ''I think the transmission of dance - the question of continuity and succession - by the masters, the teachers, is going to be a key one.''
Mark Russell, director of Performance Space 122 in Manhattan, said he thinks dance is stronger now than it was during the boom years. ''We've gone from birthing to a sort of adolescence,'' he said. ''I think we're trying to clean up our acne now.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Many health insurers have quietly blacklisted dozens of types of small businesses and professions. While some insurance companies have been accused of denying coverage to people in cities and occupations where the insurers contend the AIDS virus is most prevalent, the exclusions extend well beyond these groups. The lists also add heat to a growing debate over how to protect the 31 million Americans without health insurance. [Page A1.] 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Changes announced by South Africa's President are unlikely to stimulate new foreign investments in the racially troubled country, say business executives and the anti-apartheid protestors who are pushing them to sever economic ties with Pretoria. U.S. bankers are doubtful that South Africa will find it much easier to obtain new loans from international banks. [D1.]
 
Mexico signed a historic agreement with its foreign bank creditors. The accord will cut the Mexican foreign debt burden by as much as 20 percent and guarantees international bankers that outstanding loans will be repaid. [D1.]
 
Shanghai Center's developers have encountered new snags as the opening of the hotel, office and residential complex draws near. The experience of the American and Japanese investors suggests that China remains as much of a headache as ever to many foreign companies, despite the eagerness of the Government to attract new investment since its crackdown on protesters last June. [D8.]
 
Chile's Government adopted a law granting patent protection to foreign pharmaceutical companies whose products are copied and sold in Chile. American drug companies and the U.S. Government have sought such protection in Latin America for years. [D8.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Bank profits are expected to improve in 1990 from the depressed level of last year, but bankers and analysts see little chance that they will reach the record level of 1988. [D1.]
 
Drexel Burnham Lambert said it lost about $40 million in 1989 on gross revenues of about $4.1 billion. [D1.]
 
Arthur Andersen has added a promising new line of business. Microseal, which produces document-storage systems, is renting its chief financial officer from the accounting firm. [D1.]
 
The purchase of a majority stake in Genentech by Roche Holdings could be the start of a wave of transactions in which large drug companies buy biotechnology companies, analysts say. [D2.]
 
THE MEDIA BUSINESS
 
New sound technology is being used to make innovations in commercials, much as ad agencies adapted videotaping and editing techniques developed for music videos in the early 1980's. [D9.]
 
Books on audio cassettes are becoming an important source of income for authors. Audio rights are increasingly being treated as valuable literary properties. [D9.]
 
Fox Broadcasting's programs may be moving up in the ratings, but the stock of its parent, the News Corporation, is sagging. [D9.]
 
CBS is very much interested in doing business with Ted Turner, whose moves to take over the network in 1985 led to a management upheaval. Recent discussions have centered on the possibility of future relationships in sports broadcasts. Television. [D9.]
 
Family Media's lean operations have become leaner, amid a stagnant advertising climate for magazines. Advertising. [D10.]

Some analysts say bond yields may need to move higher yet to attract buyers at the quarterly Treasury auctions that will be held this week. Credit Markets. [D1.]
 
The Exxon Valdez case will test the courts' ability to adjudicate for thousands of people at a time. Business and the Law. [D2.]
 
A wide range of drug company stocks may benefit from the nation's flu epidemic, but most analysts say that is not necessarily a good reason to buy shares. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Higher Rates Are Expected At Bond Auction This Week

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Even with the sharp increase in interest rates since late December, some credit market analysts say bond yields may need to move higher still in order to attract buyers at the quarterly Treasury auctions that will be held this week.
The sales begin tomorrow, when the Treasury will auction $10 billion of three-year notes. The following day, $10 billion of 10-year notes will be sold. The auctions conclude on Thursday with the sale of $10 billion of 30-year bonds. 
Given the recent rise in yields, analysts said they were not particularly concerned about the first two legs of the auction, but the 30-year bond could be another matter.
 
Higher Yields Seen
''With a yield of around 8.40 percent, there will be strong demand for the three-year notes,'' said Leonard J. Santow, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''That should set the table for some pretty decent results for the 10-year. But yields on the 10-year and the 30-year may have to widen some to get the bonds sold.''
Late Friday, the 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.45 percent, while the 30-year bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.46 percent.
Gauging foreign demand is difficult. At the last refunding auctions in November, the yield on the 10-year Treasury notes had a 2.50 percentage point advantage over the comparable Japanese bond. As of late last week, that spread, or differential, stood at about 2 percentage points. And the recent rise in West German interest rates has virtually erased what has historically been a sizable differential between American and West German yields.
''Will the Japanese invest at a lesser rate than they did in 1989?'' asked Richard M. Kelly, president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. ''I think the answer is 'probably,' but on the margin. Where, in the past, they might have purchased on average 30 percent to 40 percent at the refunding, now they may do 25 percent to 30 percent. Even though rates are high enough to attract domestic investors to substitute, I would expect further modest increases in yields as we move through the auction period.''
 
No Signs From the Fed
The prospect that the Federal Reserve Board will not soon provide any assistance in the form of an easier monetary policy may provide additional incentive to push yields higher.
''In his Congressional testimony last week, Alan Greenspan effectively told the market not to bid at the refunding with the expectation that the Fed is about to ease policy,'' said Mr. Santow, of Griggs & Santow.
Analysts said any chance that the Fed might have been pursuaded to allow interest rates to ease a bit further at some point later this month was virtually eliminated with the release of January's employment report, which indicated that the economy is still firm.
But while the reported 275,000 increase in workers on nonfarm payrolls was unexpectedly large, many analysts said that because of seasonal factors, the rise was overstated and they saw underlying signs of weakness.
''The gains we saw in retail trade and construction employment happen every January and always get revised downward,'' said Joseph Carson, a senior economist at Chemical Bank. ''I think these numbers were very soft.''
David A. Wyss, chief financial economist at Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting firm, said: ''We do expect these numbers to be revised down, but there is not much sign of recession in these employment numbers. If I were at the Fed, I would be sitting on my hands.''
 
Open Market Panel to Meet
Members of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee will gather in Washington tomorrow to consider their options. Market participants will await the signals from this meeting as well as the release on Friday of producer price figures for January.
Much of the suspense surrounding these figures has already been removed: Because of sharp increases in food and energy prices, virtually all economists expect the overall figure to show a steep increase.
Led by the weather-induced run-up in food and energy prices, the increase in producer prices is likely to be the biggest monthly gain in nine years, said Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc.
Salomon expects the overall index to show an increase of 1.2 percent; other economists are forecasting an even bigger rise.
The report is likely to contain some good news, however. The so-called core inflation rate - the rate that excludes the volatile food and energy sectors - will show only a modest rise for January, analysts said.
In contast to the huge increase in the overall index, the core rate probably rose only two-tenths to three-tenths of 1 percent last month, analysts expect. That would be about half the gain recorded in December.

LENGTH: 1473 words

HEADLINE: Old Problems Seen Giving Banks Difficulty

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Although bank profits are expected to improve in 1990 from the depressed level of last year, bankers and analysts see little chance that they will rebound to the record level of 1988.
The banking industry began the year with familiar concerns: that problems with bad real estate loans will continue and that a weak economy will cause more loans to go sour while limiting new lending to businesses and to consumers.
Because losses on large banks' loans to developing countries will be far less than in 1987 and 1989, the industry as a whole is expected to earn more this year than last. But even among the regional banks, whose consumer banking businesses continue to generate steady profits, analysts wonder whether earnings will rebound to equal the $25.1 billion in profits in 1988.
Investors are discouraged enough about the industry's prospects that prices of most banks' shares have fallen by 30 percent or more since October. 
''There is a long worry list, and without a doubt the pressure is on banks in 1990,'' said James J. McDermott, an executive vice president at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a securities firm that specializes in banks.
Thomas Hanley, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Inc., said this year would be difficult ''because growth in loan volume is definitely going to slow, and further deterioration in the quality of bank loans is likely to require increases in loan-loss provisions.'' Provisions, money set aside to cover losses on loans, are subtracted from bank profits, and the reserves are expenses that can change rapidly, with little warning to investors.
Large and small banks are seeking ways to improve earnings without benefiting from high-profit loans to real estate developers. Because of losses on existing loans and of a glut of new buildings in many parts of the country, particularly in New England, New Jersey and Arizona, banks are wary about financing new projects.
''Some of banks' greatest profits in the 1980's came from lending for construction and real estate development,'' said William L. Bitner 3d, the president of Evergreen Bancorp of Glens Falls, N.Y. ''If that business is not there, it will have a dramatic impact on bank profits.''
 
Big Banks and Takeover Fees
Large banks face the additional challenge of replacing the fees earned from financing corporate takeovers and companies with heavy debt, when the number of such takeovers is dwindling. Ronald Mandle, a banking analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, has estimated that the slowdown could reduce bankers' fees by 10 percent to 15 percent. Warnings by regulators about takeover financing and about the increased risk of loss as the economy slows has made bankers more cautious about issuing new loans for such endeavors.
Losses on loans to highly indebted companies would be greatest in a recession. But the bankruptcy filing last month by two units of the Campeau Corporation, the Allied Stores Corporation and Federated Department Stores Inc., whose bank loans totaled more than $2 billion, was a reminder that the lucrative interest rates and fees paid on loans for takeovers are also very risky.
While the volume of bank financing for corporate takeovers is expected to fall, it is not going to disappear entirely. Some bankers see growth opportunites in refinancing older loans, even those that are in trouble. Chemical Bank, for example, is earning fees and interest by arranging for a group of banks to lend $300 million to the nine retail chains of Federated Stores Inc., the recently renamed holding company for Federated and Allied, so they can continue to buy merchandise from suppliers.
 
Expanding Consumer Business
On the positive side, many bankers expect consumer lending to remain a good business, although they are troubled by a rise in defaults on consumer loans in recent quarters.
Rather than rely on new opportunities for high-profit, high-risk loans in real estate or corporate takeovers, many bankers are looking for profits through reducing costs and expanding their consumer business.
Mr. Bitner of Evergreen Bancorp, who is also the president of the New York State Bankers Association, said he expected many banks to acquire ''weaker but unfailed thrifts that have proven themselves to be great deposit gatherers, but just don't have the capital to continue.''
In 1989, banks acquired more than 50 savings institutions with more than $20 billion in deposits, and attracted billions more in deposits from savings and loan customers who were alarmed at the financial condition of the industry. With more than 200 savings institutions being controlled by Federal regulators before they were sold, and with hundreds more expecting to be sold in the next few years, analysts expect bank acquisitions of savings institutions to be crucial to the expansion of banks' consumer business.
''The savings and loan industry has traditionally grown more rapidly than banking,'' said Paul Ross, a banking analyst at Data Resources Inc. in Cambridge, Mass.
But just collecting deposits is no longer enough to guarantee profits. Since the early 1980's, when banks were allowed to pay interest on checking deposits and ceilings were removed on savings accounts, bank profit margins have been under pressure.
As the cost of deposits has risen, banks have found it harder to earn acceptable profits by investing in low-risk Treasury bills. Instead, they have developed what Marc Perkins, a banking analyst at Perkins, Smith Inc., a securities firm in Tampa, Fla., calls ''the compulsion to lend.''
''The real estate collapse was caused by banks who threw too much money at the developers,'' he said.
 
'Reaching too Far'
Alex Sheshunoff, a banking consultant in Austin, Tex., contends that ''some of the best-managed banks are the ones that will accept occasional years of down earnings, if that saves them from reaching too far and making bad loans.''
As the experience of 1989 shows, problems from bad loans made in a quest for increasing growth and profits can linger for years. In the third quarter, the industry's loss was concentrated among New York banks that needed to set aside reserves to cover losses on loans to third world countries, many of them made more than 10 years ago.
The nation's 15 largest banks were hardest hit by loans to developing nations, which caused large losses for those institutions in 1987 and 1989. They are, based on assets, Citibank, Bank of America, Chase Manhattan Bank, Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, Bankers Trust Company, Manufacturers Hanover Trust, Security Pacific National Bank, Chemical Bank, Wells Fargo Bank, First National Bank of Chicago, Continental Bank, NCNB Texas, First National Bank of Boston, Bank of New York and Mellon Bank.
Large banks that lent money to Brazil expect to be hurt in 1990 if the country refuses to make interest payments on the $20 billion it owes to American banks.
 
Regional Influences
According to some bankers, the severe losses from loans for commercial real estate projects last year were caused by more than poor judgment about borrowers' ability to repay. Banks in regions with many new buildings and high default rates by developers had few lending opportunities in other parts of the country, where conditions were more favorable.
The New England Banking Corporation, once the second-largest banking company in a region that had been thriving, was among the hardest hit, as its concentration in Massachusetts and Connecticut led to a $1.2 billion loss in the fourth quarter and $1.05 billion loss for the year.
The company, which was highly recommended by analysts in late 1988, is now fighting for its survival. It is seeking to sell $6 billion in assets and perhaps some of its banks.
Victor J. Riley, the chief executive of Keycorp, an Albany banking company, said the problems in New England were a reminder that ''bankers need to diversify geographically so that they are not too vulnerable to an economic downturn in a single region.''
An emphasis on consumer banking and lending to small and medium-sized businesses has been a successful formula for several years at regional banking companies. Now, and in the years ahead, analysts expect to see more banks following the lead of Keycorp and other highly regarded companies, including the Banc One Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio, and the Security Pacific Corporation, based in Los Angeles.
Mr. Riley, who pushed Keycorp into expanding westward into Oregon, Washington and Wyoming in the 1980's, recalled that the New England states had not allowed acquisitions by New York banks, but did allow mergers among banks within the region.
''The New England banks promoted the idea of super-regional banks, they judiciously protected it, and in the long run, it has been their downfall,'' Mr. Riley said.

HEADLINE: Companies Hold Firm On Pretoria

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Business executives and the anti-apartheid protestors who are pushing them to sever economic ties with Pretoria do not expect the changes announced by President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa to stimulate new foreign investments.
''We have said it would take a complete elimination of the laws supporting apartheid, and the establishment of political freedom and equal opportunity for all, for us to renew the licenses on our industrial controls and distributorship agreements in 1996,'' said Susan Eich, a spokeswoman for Honeywell Inc.
Notwithstanding South African hopes for a quick economic stimulus from the changes announced Friday, which included plans to legalize the African National Congress and to free Nelson Mandela, bankers in the United States said they doubted South Africa would find it any easier to get new loans from international banks.
 
Protests Against Extending Loans
Most banks are more eager to receive full payments for existing loans - South Africa had $12.2 billion in debts at the end of 1989, $2.4 billion of it owed to American banks. The bankers also face continuing protests about agreements they have reached to extend those loans. 
''There's an enormous amount that has to unfold before we have a new South Africa, and I don't see many new options for the business community at this point,'' said an American banker who asked that his bank not be identified.
''It may be that companies that have not pulled out now feel they can hold on because there is light at the end of the tunnel,'' the banker said, ''but it's hard to see an immediate reversal for those that have pulled out.''
Andrew MacThomas, a spokesman for Barclays Bank, the London-based bank that was once a dominant force in South African banking, commented: ''Our position hasn't changed from when we divested in 1986. We won't consider going back unless the existing apartheid laws were rescinded and world opinion has changed to the point that pressure groups and opinion formers feel it is acceptable to trade there again.''
The anti-apartheid groups stressed that many of the laws and policies supporting apartheid remain in place in South Africa. They said they intend to press for tougher sanctions.
''Our basic theme is the continuing need for sanctions until there is majority rule,'' said Timothy Smith, executive director of the Interfaith Council on Corporate Responsibility, which coordinates shareholder lobbying by church groups on a variety of issues. ''The people we have talked to in South Africa - religious leaders, political leaders, labor leaders - say that pressure should continue. We will be pursuing banks not to roll over loans, companies to cut ties, and the U.S. Government to impose new sanctions.''
More than 120 American companies still have subsidiaries or investments in operations in South Africa, according to the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington group that tracks corporate involvement in South Africa. The exodus grew from 7 companies in 1984 to a peak of 56 in 1987. The number of companies leaving fell to 27 in 1988, and to 18 last year.
The center said 176 companies - about half the total that have departed - have retained ties, which do not include ownership stakes of operations in South Africa. These ties include licensing agreements or arrangements to export products. The companies include such heavyweights as the International Business Machines Corporation, the Coca-Cola Company and the General Electric Company.
Anti-apartheid advocates say they intend to continue to use shareholder resolutions at annual meetings, boycotts, demonstrations and other forms of protest to encourage an end to such links, unless South Africa eliminates all laws requiring racial segregation and adopts a form of government that gives equal weight to each vote.
''The South African Government wants to find an excuse for the international community to lift sanctions, but de Klerk is still looking for a way to maintain white privilege,'' said Richard Knight, research director of the American Committee on Africa, a New York-based organization that promotes democratic change in South Africa. ''Now is not the time to let up the pressure.''
Companies that have announced plans not to renew current licenses or other relationships say that much more striking changes would be needed for them to reconsider their policies.
Nor are companies that went through the pain and cost of divesting likely to reverse that course quickly. Although a large market by African standards, South Africa is of marginal importance to most multinational companies.
The Raychem Corporation, a supplier of electronic wire and cable products based in Menlo Park, Calif., said it had no intention of backing out of a deal to sell operations in that country to local investors.
''We expect final approval from the central bank this month,'' said Christopher Margolin, Raychem's assistant secretary. ''Today's announcement is encouraging, but we are listening to our shareholders. We're out.''
In London, RTZ Ltd. and the British Petroleum Company hailed the development but said it would not induce them to change their investment policies. B.P. is one of the largest oil companies operating in South Africa, but the business is still a relatively small part of the company, accounting for only 1 to 3 percent of revenues.
Patrick H. Grattan, the company's regional coordinator for South Africa, said B.P. was not going to increase investment in South Africa. He suggested that the company was waiting for negotiations between the Government and black leaders.
A spokesman for RTZ, John G. Hughes, said of the developments, ''We see it as a positive step, but it doesn't mean we will turn around and dramatically increase investment.''

HEADLINE: Business and the Law;
A Paper Spill Due In the Valdez Case

BYLINE: By Laura Mansnerus

 BODY:
THE Exxon Valdez case is coming - ''one or two million pieces of paper,'' by one lawyer's estimate - and it is already testing the courts' ability to adjudicate for thousands of people at a time.
Fishers, seafood processors, environmental groups, coastal villages and many others who filed suit after the oil spill in Prince William Sound in March are now represented by a small bureaucracy. The ''case management team'' of 17 lawyers was appointed six weeks ago by a joint ruling of the state and Federal courts in Anchorage, which consolidated about 150 lawsuits against the Exxon Corporation, its subsidiaries and its partners in the Alaska pipeline.
In a case of this magnitude, lawyers note, that is how it has to work. ''Otherwise the court system would be absolutely paralyzed, with 79 law firms and potentially 7,000 or 8,000 plaintiffs,'' said David W. Oesting of Davis Wright Tremaine in Anchorage, one of two lawyers appointed as lead counsel. 
Committee management of disaster litigation and product-liability cases has plenty of precedent, including the injury claims from the Bhopal, India, chemical leak; the Vietnam veterans' suits against the makers of Agent Orange, and the cases brought by Dalkon Shield users.
But that does not mean the courts are well suited to the task. ''I don't think the Founding Fathers in their wildest dreams imagined litigation involving thousands of claims, thousands of plaintiffs and multiple defendants,'' said Kenneth R. Feinberg, the Washington lawyer appointed by the court to fashion an accord in the Agent Orange case. ''These cases are not well processed.'' The Exxon Valdez case presents another twist: while liability is not expected to be an especially difficult issue, the plaintiffs have potentially divergent interests in whatever damages the group may collect. Fishing and tourist businesses, for example, must calculate individual losses, while municipalities and the state represent more diffuse public interests. Environmental groups want funds for research and protection of other resources. But all the plaintiffs, except the State of Alaska, are lashed together until judgment or settlement, which is not going to be soon.
Even for individual plaintiffs, damages might be gauged in many ways. ''There's some non-economic loss in intrinsic value of the resources lost,'' said Macon Cowles, a committee member from Boulder, Colo., who originally filed suit on behalf of several environmental groups. ''One of the policy questions raised by the contending claims is whether we're any better off if each fisherman gets $100 or $1,000 for this non-economic loss or if it's better directed to a fund used to enrich the environment for everyone.''
While members of the case management team insist that their main job is putting together a lawsuit, not mediating among plaintiffs, Mr. Feinberg said the most pressing issue would be ''who's going to pay, how soon they're going to pay and who's going to get the money.'' The committee members note that first they must hack their way through pleadings, depositions and exchanges of documents, pretrial motions at every turn and probable appeals of rulings on the motions. Jerry S. Cohen, the co-lead counsel and a partner in the Washington firm of Cohen Milstein Hausfeld & Toll, said that in the two main issues at a trial - establishing negligence and arguing for punitive damages - the plaintiffs would have common goals.
Still, even at this stage there must be provision for those dissatisfied with the committee's representation. Already a small group has tested this rule, complaining that the committee leadership would not be responsive to individual plaintiffs' interests because both Mr. Cohen and Mr. Oesting are class action lawyers. The court rejected that argument last week.
Perhaps the nearest precedent to the Exxon litigation is the tangle of suits growing out of the Amoco Cadiz oil spill off Brittany, in western France, in 1978. These suits were consolidated in the Federal District Court in Chicago, which established liability in 1984 and assessed damages four years later. Three months ago, after many challenges, a court-appointed special master submitted another recommendation.
How the Alaska courts could work more efficiently is not clear. If a trial resulted in a damage award, a jury or the court might simply ''fill in the blanks'' for contending plaintiffs, one lawyer said. In the more likely event of a pretrial settlement, the court could apply its own criteria or appoint a special master, like Mr. Feinberg, to oversee the plaintiffs' efforts to allocate the money.
Mr. Feinberg credited the judge in the Agent Orange case, Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, with finding ways to handle remedies that the judicial system was not intended to handle. ''We created our own administrative system,'' he said.
Does the Exxon case present more potential for conflict? ''Absolutely,'' Mr. Oesting said. Like the other lawyers in the case, he said he was waiting for the courts in Anchorage to be inventive.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Comfed Savings Bank Names New President

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Jack C. Zoeller has moved smartly through many careers, first in the Army, then on Wall Street and now in the banking industry. Mr. Zoeller, 40 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Comfed Savings Bank, based in Lowell, Mass.
Mr. Zoeller, who joined the bank two years ago, takes the post from Jefferson F. Allen, who is chairman, president and chief executive of the bank's parent, Comfed Bancorp. Mr. Zoeller is executive vice president of the holding company.
Mr. Zoeller joined the company in 1987 as a vice president in the Comfed Mortgage Company, ''managing the Wall Street side,'' he said, referring to such tasks as hedging and transforming mortgage packages into securities. 
''Jack Zoeller is a recognized expert in Wall Street financings,'' Mr. Allen said. ''and is considered a pioneer in the securitization of loans and the hedging of interest rate risk.''
The Lowell area is suffering an economic downturn and banks in general in New England are being hurt by bad real estate loans. Comfed is no exception, having posted several recent quarterly losses. The Lowell economy is dominated by sagging high-technology businesses and in particular by Wang Laboratories Inc., which has reduced its work force by about 9,000 employees in the last year.
But Mr. Zoeller is optimistic. ''On new business, things are going surprisingly well,'' he said. ''Despite a slowdown in the real estate market, we've hired a number of mortgage sales people. On the deposit side, we have 30 branches in two states and we've been able to hold and increase deposits without getting involved in rate wars. Unfortunately, we still have a legacy of loans done in the previous climate.''
Mr. Zoeller is waiting for the sunny weekends of spring to bring the home buyers out. ''The market will tell this spring'' how the bank will fare this year, he said.
In 1970, Mr. Zoeller graduated first in his class from the United States Military Academy and went on to receive a master's degree in public policy from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. Next stop was Oxford, where as a Rhodes Scholar he received a master's degree in politics.
In 1978, as an officer with the 82d Airborne, he wrote the operational plan for a parachute jump into Zaire to evacuate Americans caught in fighting. ''For a couple of nights we sat on the runway,'' Mr. Zoeller recalls. Finally, French and Belgian troops were sent instead.
When the 82d Airborne jumped into Panama in December, Mr. Zoeller ''got a vicarious pleasure'' out of the operation, he said. By that time, he was far from the Army, having spent his final two years of service wrestling with Army budgets in the Pentagon.
Leaving the Army, he wrote letters to Wall Street firms and was hired by E. F. Hutton & Company, where he stayed five years before forming his own firm specializing in savings and loan problems.

HEADLINE: Treasury Refunding Scheduled This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a quarterly refunding that begins tomorrow.
Tomorrow's auction is of $10 billion of three-year notes. On Wednesday, $10 billion of 10-year notes will be auctioned, and on Thursday there will be an auction of $10 billion of 30-year bonds. 
Last Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.80 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.75 percent. In when-issued trading, the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 8.38 percent, while the 10-year note was offered at a price to yield 8.45 percent. The new 30-year bond issue was offered at a price to yield 8.46 percent.
Some Government agencies are expected to come to market with debt issues. The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to announce tomorrow the interest rates for two debenture issues totaling $1.5 billion. The 5-year and 10-year securities will be sold through a regular selling group.
The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, plans to price today $500 million in short-term floating-rate notes due Aug. 9. They will be priced at a spread to the bond equivalent rate of the 91-day Treasury bill and adjusted on the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Headaches in China for Investors

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
When officials of the Shanghai Center told the Chinese customs bureau that the complex planned to import 50 to 60 cars, they received a strange notice: for each model of a Japanese car it imported, it would have to bring in two extra samples. These would be turned over to authorities for ''test driving.''
''It doesn't matter that the model you bring in is already on the streets of Shanghai,'' said Patsy Whitcomb, an American executive who is helping to prepare for the opening of the $195.5 million Shanghai Center, which is being financed by American and Japanese investors.
The request for extra cars is just the latest snag in what has been a long, twisted process of constructing Shanghai Center, which will be the city's largest hotel, office and residential complex when it opens in March.
 
Little Flexibility
The center's owner, Seacliff Ltd., hopes that the new rule, which comes on top of a 280 percent duty on the imported cars, will be negotiable, although customs officials have shown little flexibility so far. They have already prohibited the company from importing a Mercedes-Benz, a car that they say would not suit China's new style of ''plain living.'' 
The experience of Shanghai Center suggests that China remains as much of a headache as ever to many foreign investors, despite the eagerness of the Government to attract investment since its bloody crackdown last June.
Yet for the Shanghai Center, there is profound injury as well as insult: it is opening just as foreign business clients are staying away from China in droves. And for all its commitment to China, the center finds itself running up against the same problems that keep its clients away.
With its retail shops and 1,000-seat theater, the center is a showcase project intended to add a cosmopolitan air to China's biggest city. Thus, it would have seemed a likely candidate to get help from the Chinese Government as Shanghai tries desperately to regain its role as a financial and commercial center for Asia.
 
No Change Since Crackdown
So far, however, the Shanghai Center has not found business any easier since the crackdown, according to Seacliff, a partnership among the Portman Companies and the American International Group, both of the United States, and a Japanese concern, the Kajima Corporation. The Shanghai Center was designed by John Portman & Associates, the American architectural firm.
Investors had hoped the Chinese would offer better terms, both to overcome international outrage after the bloodshed in June and to dispel the gradual disillusionment of many Western investors in recent years, particularly after an economic austerity drive that began in late 1988 reduced prospects for economic growth.
Many business analysts in Shanghai say that the center would have been highly successful before the austerity drive began, but that the business climate is now much more sluggish. Uncertainty has also scared away many new investors and potential clients, although some who have been negotiating plans for years still plan to come.
''The real challenge is that there are no new people coming in,'' said Michael C. Kalyk, the general manager of the center. ''New business has to start up again before there's real business for us.''
 
Foreign Investment Dwindles
Like the rest of China, Shanghai has seen foreign investment dwindle since the crackdown. From January to June last year, there were 133 new projects worth $260 million by American investors, a Western diplomat estimated. The diplomat said that from July to December, only 66 projects worth $150 million were started, and most of these were begun before the crackdown.
The first half of this year will be more telling, since those who have invested less time in start-up negotiations may not feel burdened to continue their projects. Some companies who tried to pull out of their contracts apparently were not allowed to do so by the Chinese, diplomats say.
After the crackdown, many foreign companies facing dimmer commercial prospects hoped that Chinese bureaucrats would be more conciliatory at the negotiating table to restore the confidence of overseas investors. Some were offered interviews with senior officials, ministry-level bureaucrats, and at times, an audience with the Communist Party General Secretary himself, Jiang Zemin.
Foreign companies that demonstrated their commitment to China were thanked effusively and given encouragement. Some hope still lies in the prospect this spring that China will change the joint-venture law, extending the allowable term of a venture and authorizing the appointment of foreigners as a venture's chairman.
 
No Widespread Concession
Yet so far the high visibility has not led to widespread concessions, diplomats and business executives say. Only a small number of companies have obtained better terms, notably a foreign real estate developer in Tianjin. In fact, executives say some authorities, in an attempt to prove they are not to be cowed by foreigners, have actually become less cooperative with foreign companies.
''Despite the public relations, the environment for getting concessions is not easier, but harder,'' a Western diplomat here said. ''There are regulations that may have been in place already, but now there is a trend to enforcing the regulations that people overlooked before.''
Seacliff is negotiating with Shanghai's local government for greater concessions, primarily on property taxes and an extension on its current 18-year land lease. But the Shanghai government, which has auctioned off expensive land-use rights for 50 years to a foreign company, might not want to offer a 50-year or even 40-year lease to the Shanghai Center at a bargain price for fear of offending its other client.
A Chinese business official familiar with the negotiations indicated that Seacliff would probably get an extension, although it was not clear for how long.
 
Commercial Reputation
Shanghai has enjoyed a reputation as one of China's most attractive commercial centers for foreign investment and business representation. When the Portman Companies first conceived of building a mixed-use complex in 1979 and then when construction began in 1986, there was a severe shortage of first-rate commercial complexes in Shanghai.
The company had estimated that in 1986 there were about 4,000 hotel rooms for foreigners. But since then, officials all over Shanghai, and throughout China, moved as quickly as possible to sponsor hotel projects.
There apparently was no central plan governing construction projects in Shanghai, and for competitive reasons owners and builders tried to keep their development plans secret. As a result, the Portman Shanghai hotel will add 700 rooms, in March or soon thereafter, to a city that will have a total of 18,000 hotel rooms, Seacliff estimates. When the hotel opens, Seacliff expects occupancy to be around 40 percent.
So far, the company has pre-leased about 25 percent of its apartments, 20 percent of its shopping complex and 30 percent of its office space. The complex will not be fully open until July, when the theater is finished.
 
Complex Behind Schedule
In mid-1985, executives of the Portman Companies indicated that the project would be finished in the spring of 1988. Revised plans set the opening date for December 1989, which then was delayed three months when work halted for 30 days after the June crackdown. Crews were sent to their homes overseas or to other provinces in China, and it took about two months to be ready again.
In late summer, Seacliff injected an additional $20.5 million in capital to cover cost overruns and help start the construction process again, bringing the total project cost to $195.5 million. On Jan. 24, the company and its bankers, including the First National Bank of Chicago, signed an agreement, apparently initiated before the crackdown, to restructure the project's $145 million in loans.
Mr. Kalyk of Seacliff said the Shanghai Center would be able to cover operating expenses as soon as it opened, and he said he was confident the center would be able to meet its loan repayments. About a fourth of all operating expenses, he said, go to pay salaries for expatriate employees. This sum should drop once the center is running smoothly.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: TELEVISION;
New Friend For CBS: Ted Turner

BYLINE: By Bill Carter

 BODY:
A VERY intriguing meeting took place in Atlanta last week, when two top officers of CBS quietly visited a man whose previous role in the CBS drama was playing the bogyman: Ted Turner.
In the television industry, circumstances change quickly and so do alliances. CBS is now very interested in doing business with the man whose maneuvering to take over the network in 1985 led to a management upheaval, the effects of which are still being felt.
Now one top CBS executive says of Mr. Turner and his cable empire, ''We like these people.'' 
CBS had already established a link to Mr. Turner under a deal for cable rights to the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics. CBS won all the television rights to those games but sold a portion of the events to Turner Broadcasting System Inc. for $50 million.
An unusual part of the arrangement calls for CBS to sell all the commercial time in the two events, even for the hours that will be carried on Mr. Turner's TNT cable channel. CBS and TNT will also share the cost of the productions.
As a CBS executive put it: ''We are going to be doing some complicated things with them. Might something else grow out of that? That could be part of the process.''
The possibilities for a CBS-Turner alliance are as fascinating as they are surprising. The main item discussed by the two companies last week was the possibility of future relationships in sports, executives from both companies said. The discussions were held by Mr. Turner; Terry McGuirk, the president of the Turner sports division; Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group, and Jay Kriegel, a senior vice president of CBS.
The most obvious possibility opened by a Turner-CBS sports alliance is to provide a counterbalance to the cable alliances already in place at other networks. ABC owns 80 percent of the all-sports cable channel ESPN and NBC manages and owns half of Sports Channel America.
One cable industry executive said he expected to see ''more and more joint bidding in the future by a broadcast and cable entity.''
Both ABC and NBC say no joint bidding has taken place so far. But, one cable industry executive said, ''ABC was involved in helping ESPN win the right to the N.F.L. three years ago.''
The main reason joint bidding makes sense, of course, is cost. Sports television rights have risen sharply in the last year, with professional baseball and basketball and college football and basketball all getting record television contracts. CBS grabbed two of those franchises - Major League Baseball and N.C.A.A. basketball. The baseball deal exceeded $1 billion.
''The word billion used to only be associated with the population of China, the gross national product and a children's book about cats,'' said Seth Abraham, the senior vice president of programming for the Home Box Office cable channel. ''Now it's turning up in deals for sports rights.''
And the most important and valuable television deal of all, the rights to the National Football League games, is currently being negotiated.
Almost no one believes that CBS and Mr. Turner will form an alliance to secure N.F.L. rights because the broadcast and cable packages will almost surely be negotiated separately. But at least one executive who will take part in the N.F.L. talks does not entirely rule it out. ''The N.F.L. is so wide open at this point I wouldn't say anything is impossible,'' he said.
The executive said he was aware of talks between CBS and Mr. Turner about the baseball deal before negotiations began.
But far more likely are deals for other sports that will be coming up in the next year or two, including such events as the world figure skating championships, the world gymnastics championships and tennis and golf tournaments. All have natural cable-broadcast divisions - early events on cable, finals on network.
The problem of escalating prices for sports rights really cuts both ways, a cable executive said. More and more cable operators are protesting the high rates that cable channels have been paying for sports because those dollars have to come from cable subscribers. The cable operators are worried about anything that may force their rates up because they are struggling in Washington to hold off re-regulation of the cable industry.
But, as Mr. Abraham sees it, the networks are facing a far more ominous situation. ''The networks are a little like Custer at Little Big Horn,'' he said. ''They are surrounded by Indians. Cable is there. The pay channels are there. Pay per view for sports is coming. Sooner or later they are going to be outnumbered. It makes a lot of sense to form an alliance with one of the tribes.''
Even something as simple as sharing the costs of sports announcers and commentators may make sense, Mr. Abraham said, because salaries for the top sports talent in television are now well past $1 million a year.
But sports may not be the only area where CBS and Mr. Turner can find common interest. Another possibility: news. CBS is the only network without an interest in an independent international news-gathering service. NBC owns part of Visnews and ABC is part owner of Worldwide Television News. The independent companies provide news coverage to clients, and ABC and NBC are now able to get coverage from places where they have no correspondents.
With CNN, Ted Turner has his own international news-gathering operation, one that is increasing in reach and impact every month. A link between CBS News and CNN would create an enormously powerful news operation - and something of a shocking one given the past history between the two companies.
But CBS is not ruling it out. ''There are a lot of ironies,'' a top CBS executive said last week. ''But we'd have no hesitation doing business with them. We want to explore every option.''

HEADLINE: Bush Asks Cautious Response To Threat of Global Warming

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
President Bush called today for a cautious response to the threat of global warming, pleasing those in his Administration who want a deliberate policy but disappointing many environmentalists.
In a speech to an international environmental group, the President called for global action but warned against policies that would interfere with economic growth and the free market.
Administration officials said the speech struck a middle ground between conflicting positions among Mr. Bush's aides.
His chief of staff, John H. Sununu, wanted to emphasize scientific uncertainties about global warming and to warn of economic dangers in rushing to act. Several agency heads, including William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, pressed for a stronger message of America's commitment to action. 
 
No New Recommendations
The officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the speech did not represent a victory for the chief of staff. But it is clear that Mr. Sununu, who has a degree in nuclear engineering and has taken a strong interest in environmental issues, is having substantial influence on one of the most important environmental issues before the President.
''The United States remains committed to aggressive and very thoughtful action on environmental issues,'' Mr. Bush said in his speech. But he offered no new recommendations for specific action to slow or reduce global warming. He did not even use the words ''global warming,'' speaking only of ''climate change.''
Although there is considerable disagreement over the extent of the problem, many scientists expect temperatures across the world to increase as carbon dioxide and other industrial and vehicular gases accumulate in the atmosphere and trap radiation from the sun.
Mr. Bush called for an ''international bargain, a convergence between global environmental policy and global economic policy, where both perspectives benefit and neither is compromised.'' He asserted that strong economies around the world would provide the resources for better protection of the environment.
''Wherever possible,'' he said, ''we believe that market mechanism should be applied and that our policies must be consistent with economic growth and free-market principles in all countries.''
Mr. Bush spoke at a meeting here of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, an international body formed under the auspices of the United Nations Environmental Program and the World Meteorological Association. The panel's mission is to assess the changes in the world's climate that many scientists expect will occur in the next century, and the political and scientific implications of those changes.
The President's remarks disappointed environmentalists and some European government officials and scientists at the meeting. They had hoped Mr. Bush would outline specific suggestions for concerted action to lower the gas emissions.
 
Contrast With Europeans
''A year ago this speech would have been exciting,'' said Christopher Flavin of the Worldwatch Institute, a research group based in Washington, adding that in the past year there has been a growing international consensus about the threat of global warming. ''Now it's a disappointment.'' The combustion of fossil fuels like oil and coal is the chief source of carbon dioxide pollution. Mr. Flavin noted that some European governments had committed themselves to controlling emissions, often through taxes on industries and products that emit carbon dioxide.
He added that members of the Bush Administration were seeking to kill a provision in the clean air bill before the Senate that would require improved fuel efficiency in automobiles as a way to curb emissions.
James T. B. Tripp, general counsel of the Environmental Defense Fund, said of the speech, ''The tone is fine but there are no specific commitments.'' He added, ''What is needed now to deal with global warming is a massive energy Marshall Plan that stresses energy conservation and efficiency, renewable sources of energy and a reversal of trends toward increasing oil imports and traffic congestion.''
 
Praise From Industry
Industry representatives praised the President's insistence that any policies to deal with the environmental threat must be consistent with economic growth.
Thomas G. Lambrix, chairman of the Global Climate Coalition, an industry group, called the President's speech ''very strong'' and said it struck a good balance between the global warming problem and the need to achieve a better understanding of the scientific issues and to develop strategies that are premised on economic development.
Jana R. Oakley, assistant vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said, ''The President has outlined strong environmental initiatives,'' and added, ''I don't see how anyone in this room can say he is not an environmental President.''
Administration officials said the muted tone of the President's speech reflected concerns by the White House staff that more scientific data about global warming and more study of the potential costs of meeting the threat are needed before formal international action is taken.
But the officials said that despite Mr. Sununu's influence, most of the changes he sought were not included in the speech as delivered. Those changes would have had the President dwell chiefly on the scientific uncertainties and economic dangers and play down the environmental threat.
Mr. Reilly, who pressed for a strong commitment on global warming, praised the President's speech.
