HEADLINE: Panama Is Resisting U.S. Pressure To Alter 'Inadequate' Bank Laws

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Officials of the new Panamanian Government are resisting United States pressure to change the banking laws that historically made the country a haven for enormous illicit drug profits before Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was removed from power.
The Panamanians say the current laws and the new Government are more than adequate to prevent such abuses. American law-enforcement officials and legislators are concerned that the new Government and the country's appetite for foreign investment will actually lead to even greater use of Panamanian financial institutions to conceal illicit drug profits.
Edgardo Lasso Valdes, the president of the Panamanian banking association and one of the country's seven banking commissioners, said in an interview: ''The only problem of money laundering in Panama is the newspapers that mention that Panama is a big money-laundering center. , To be honest, we don't feel there is any problem.''
But a senior State Department official here, who asked not to be identified, said the existing laws ''are grossly inadequate'' to prevent money laundering, a process in which illegally earned profits are deposited in bank accounts or legitimate businesses, then withdrawn as ''clean money.'' He said the United States was strongly urging Panama to revise them. 
 
A Growing Tension
In interviews in recent days, local banking regulators, senior Panamanian officials and United States officials demonstrated through their comments a growing tension between the two nations over the money-laundering issue. A fight appears likely in Congress over a proposed $1 billion aid package for Panama.
An extensive review of Panamanian banking records and court documents shows that many senior leaders in the Government, while never accused of money laundering, have had strong ties to corrupt banks. Several of the banks have been indicted for money laundering or been shut because of pressure from the United States.
The nation's new President, Guillermo Endara, has for years been a director of a Panamanian bank used extensively by Colombia's Medellin drug traffickers.
Guillermo (Billy) Ford, the Second Vice President and chairman of the banking commission, is a part owner of the Dadeland Bank of Florida, which was named in a court case two years ago as a central financial institution for one of the biggest Medellin launderers, Gonzalo Mora.
Rogello Cruz, the new Attorney General, has been a director of the First Interamericas Bank, owned by Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, one of the bosses of the Cali drug gang in Colombia.
There is no evidence that President Endara, Vice President Ford, Mr. Cruz or other current leaders were aware of or involved with the illegal operations carried out at the banks to which they have ties. But officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Justice Department say the business connections and friendships make it difficult to believe that any real crackdown against money laundering is likely.
American law-enforcement officials said they had evidence that Panamanian banks were used to launder money through the waning hours of the administration of General Noriega, who is awaiting trial in Miami on drug and money-laundering charges. And though most of General Noriega's senior aides remain either fugitives or in jail, all the bankers with whom they are said to have dealt remain in key positions.
''I'm very concerned about it,'' said Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, who has held extensive hearings on money laundering and the use of Panamanian banks. ''This is the moment to do something - but it now appears that not enough is being done.'' Long History of Aiding Money Launderers Panama's secrecy laws and tax breaks for foreign depositors, coupled with the country's proximity to cocaine production and trafficking in the Andes, have long made banks here a kind of hidden tub for cleaning dirty money.
In a recent interview, President Endara acknowledged that the success of Panama's financial center in the 1970's and 1980's was a result of the Latin American drug cartels.
Increased pressure is now on the nation's banks, whose foreign deposits have fired rapid economic growth for two decades, to lure back more foreign investors, many of whom had left during the turmoil of recent months. Illegalities Aid G.N.P. The financial community represents as much as 15 percent of the Panamanian economy, according to Government figures. Last year, the gross national product was estimated at $1.76 billion, and virtually all economists agree that laundered drug money, arms sales and other illicit income have played a large role in the accumulation of that wealth.
The United States imposed economic sanctions on Panama in 1988 in an attempt to halt money laundering. As a result some banks were forced to freeze some deposits, and some banks failed. Until the sanctions, Panamanian authorities would occasionally seize assets of suspected accounts but would generally not provide information to law-enforcement authorities.
Merchants from Colon, on the Atlantic coast about 50 miles north of Panama City, said one common way of laundering money was the purchase of large amounts of clothes with millions of dollars in drug profits. The clothes are then shipped to Colombia and sold for Colombian pesos, which are deposited in local banks. Hidden Bank Accounts And Secrecy Laws But the strongest attraction for money launderers appears to be Panama's hidden bank accounts.
The bank secrecy laws permit a depositor to sue a bank if confidential information is disclosed, and prosecutors can also bring criminal charges against the banker who, without authorization, provides information about an account. Panama also has corporate secrecy protection that enables the founder or founders of a business to keep their identity secret.
 
Talks on Cooperation
Negotiations have been under way to forge an agreement of cooperation between Panamanian and American law-enforcement authorities, following a preliminary agreement signed last month by the Panamanian Government and the State Department.
Nonetheless, the widely held view among drug officials is that as banking restrictions imposed during the period of United States sanctions are lifted over the next four months, illegal profits will again pour into many of the country's 110 banks.
''Given the chaos and general turmoil of the country following the invasion, there is now an excellent opportunity for organized crime and the cocaine cartels to step back in,'' said James E. Preston, an Arizona prosecutor who has spent recent months on a Federal grant studying international money laundering.
President Endara has said he sees no need for any significant banking-law changes and so does not expect any. The National Banking Commission, which regulates banks, is dominated by local and international bankers, many of whom agree with the President and Mr. Lasso that the magnitude of the drug problem has been exaggerated. Feelings of Resentment Over U.S. Pressure Disputing reports by the Drug Enforcement Administration and other people at the Justice Department, the new Finance Minister, Mario Galindo, said in an interview that there was no money-laundering problem in Panama. Many bankers and some officials expressed resentment over pressure by the United States to alter the banking system.
Mr. Lasso, who is also general manager of the Panamanian branch of the International Bank of Costa Rica, said it was hypocritical of United States officials to be citing Panamanian banks. He said the punishment meted out recently in the two largest drug money-laundering cases in the United States shows that American officials themselves are not particularly tough on money laundering.
The settlements were of $5 million over four years in the case of Banco de Occidente and $14 million for Bank of Credit and Commerce International. Both banks admitted in courts that their Panamanian branches were used extensively to launder drug money.
''How can you ask us to break a bank in Panama when all they do in the U.S. is pay a fine?'' Mr. Lasso asked. ''We don't understand it. It gives us some doubts.''
 
Reputable Banks Driven Out
The economic sanctions have driven out some of the more reputable international banks, and many of those left continue to be found to have drug ties, knowingly or not. Testimony in one recent case tied a third of the banks to laundering operations for drug money. Most of those banks were used not as points at which customers would deposit cash but rather as places to which launderers in the United States would electronically transfer funds for deposit.
Virtually all those banks remain in operation today, and none were prosecuted for laundering.
''There are already laws here on the books that make money laundering illegal,'' said a senior banker who has been in Panama for more than 20 years and now works at a large Asian bank in Panama City. ''But the laws have only been as good as the people who enforce them.'' Important Banking Ties Of Top Panama Officials It is difficult to find any senior officials here who do not have important ties to banks.
President Endara has for years been a director of Banco Interoceanico de Panama, one of the two dozen Panamanian banks named in a case based on a Federal Bureau of Investigation case code-named Cashweb/Expressway. F.B.I. agents posing as money launderers were given large amounts of cash in that case by Colombians in the United States who instructed them to transfer the funds to these 24 banks.
Mr. Endara, a corporate lawyer before becoming President, is a close friend of Carlos Eleta, a Panamanian businessman who was arrested in Atlanta in April on charges of conspiring to set up a major cocaine smuggling ring. Released on bail, he is now awaiting trial.
The families of First Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon and the Finance Minister, Mr. Galindo, are also heavily involved in banking. Mr. Galindo's cousin, Samuel Lewis Galindo, is chairman of Banco del Istmo.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 13, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 6 about Panamanian banks and money laundering referred incorrectly to the relationship of the Dadeland Bank of Florida to a senior Panamanian offical and accusations of money laundering. Guillermo (Billy) Ford, Second Vice President of Panama, is not an owner of Dadeland. No Federal or state authorities have accused Dadeland of improper ties to the Medellin drug cartel.

HEADLINE: Peace Plan Critic Is Elected President in Costa Rica

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Rafael Calderon Jr., a critic of the Central American peace efforts of President Oscar Arias Sanchez, was elected Sunday to succeed Mr. Arias, according to nearly complete returns.
Mr. Calderon, the son of a former President who was driven into exile in 1948 after bringing on a civil war by trying to win a second term, defeated Carlos Manuel Castillo, the candidate of Mr. Arias's National Liberation Party. With about 90 percent of the returns counted, Mr. Calderon had 51 percent of the vote and Mr. Castillo 47 percent. 
Mr. Calderon, the candidate of the Social Christian Unity Party, is to take office May 8. Mr. Arias was constitutionally prohibited from seeking a second term.
Mr. Castillo bitterly conceded defeat late Sunday night.
''It's a referendum on 40 years of history,'' a senior adviser to Mr. Castillo said.
Exit polls showed that Costa Rican voters feared an excessive concentration of power. Traditionally, the country has alternated governing parties. But the National Liberation Party, taking advantage of opposition disorganization, had won five of the last six elections and seemed on the verge of becoming the dominant party.
 
Born in Nicaragua
Mr. Calderon's victory also underscored the growing appeal of free-market principles in the region and the rejection of state intervention in the economy. While both major parties promised amibitious social programs, analysts said the National Liberation Party was more strongly identified with a state-managed economy.
Mr. Calderon was born March 14, 1949, in Nicaragua, where his family was living in exile after his father was defeated and driven from the country. His godfather was the Nicaraguan dictator Anastasio Somoza Garcia, who was assassinated in 1956.
The family soon moved to Mexico, where Mr. Calderon went to primary and secondary school. He returned here and graduated from the University of Costa Rica. He is married to Gloria Bejarano Almada and has four children.
He was elected to the National Assembly in 1974 and ran unsuccessfully for President in 1982. He then formed his Social Christian Unity Party from four small parties and ran again. The results were closer, but he was once again defeated, this time by Mr. Arias.
After his defeat, he became the executive director of the Costa Rican Association for the Defense of Democracy and Liberty, a right-wing group. Under Mr. Calderon, the association was among the strongest critics of Mr. Arias's peace plan for Central America. Government officials charged that the group's activities were part of the Reagan Administration's efforts to thwart the Arias peace plan, which called for the demobilization of the United States-financed Nicaraguan rebels.
 
Dispute Over Financing
The association had close relations with senior Republicans in the United States and according to Congressional documents was largely financed by the National Republican Institute for International Affairs, one of four branches of the National Endowment for Democracy. Although technically a private organization, its budget comes from public funds through the United States Information Agency.
Congressional Democrats charged that this financing violated the endowment's charter prohibiting it from supporting political candidates.
Mr. Calderon, who resigned from the association before launching his current campaign, said the United States money was used for ''political development'' and that none of it went to his presidential effort.

HEADLINE: A Grieving Israel Pushes Politics Aside

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Stunned Israelis postponed politics, canceled trips to Egypt and lamented what seemed to be a further blow to regional peace today as the nation recovered its dead and wounded from the terrorist attack on a tour bus near Cairo on Sunday night.
This evening, a transport plane pulled into a secluded corner of Ben-Gurion International Airport, at Lod. With somber ceremony, officers in colored berets carried eight flag-covered coffins out the cargo door and laid them in the beds of eight military trucks. After the trucks were lined up in a neat, careful row, dazed-looking family members, hugging themselves in the chill air, listened from a few yards away as rabbis read the Kaddish, the prayer for the dead. 
''Today the people of Israel are draped in heavy sorrow,'' Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said in Jerusalem this afternoon. After consultations among normally bitter Likud party rivals, led by Ariel Sharon, Likud agreed to postpone what had promised to be a bruising party meeting, a contest for power scheduled for Wednesday night. No new date has been set.
 
No 'Petty Arguments'
''This isn't an appropriate time for petty arguments between Likud members,'' Mr. Shamir said.
Nine or 10 Israelis were killed and 17 were wounded, some of them seriously, in the attack. The death toll is uncertain because of conflicting reports about whether a victim died in transit today. Eight victims died in the attack, and a ninth died in an Egyptian hospital overnight. One more person reportedly died this morning while being flown to Tel Aviv.
An Islamic fundamentalist group in Lebanon took responsibility today for the assault. Egyptians and Israelis said they hoped that the attack would not block movement toward peace talks.
The Foreign Ministers of Israel, Egypt and the United States are trying to arrange a meeting soon between Israelis and Palestinians.
But politics took second stage to grief. As the dead and wounded were removed from the transport plane, the daughter of one victim grew hysterical and smashed through a thick terminal window, screaming ''Mother! Mother!'' as she tried to run to the middle of the field where the victims were being loaded into ambulances. The police and soldiers restrained her.
Grief and regret was not confined to Jews. As a sign of sympathy, the heads of Israeli-Arab local town councils postponed a one-day strike over economic problems. In Egypt, the Palestine Liberation Organization denounced the attack, as did several prominent West Bank Palestinians.
Faisal al-Husseini, the leading nationalist figure in the West Bank, said, ''We condemn this act, no matter who committed it.'' But he and other West Bank leaders came back with a prepared statement a few hours later, reminding Israel, ''We can't mention the attack on the Israelis without mentioning the Palestinians killed every day in the occupied territories.''
At Haddasah Ein Karem Hospital in Jerusalem, Nickolas Aronowitsch, a kibbutz worker from Sweden who was on the bus, lay in the emergency room being treated for shrapnel wounds to his leg and foot. His clothing was wrapped up in a plastic bag under his bed. After the bus stopped, he said, the attackers ''told a couple of Arab passengers to get off.''
The shooting started moments later, Mr. Aronowitsch said. He fell to the floor, then ''jumped out the left side,'' through a shattered window. ''I threw myself into some sort of ditch and saw a man standing there with an assault rifle. He was screaming. I don't think he saw me, thank God.''
''I was told that four hand grenades were thrown,'' he added, ''but I heard only three.'' After several minutes of firing, he said, the assailants fled.
''It was a big highway, and a lot of cars passed us, but very few stopped,'' he said. ''It was 25 minutes before the ambulances came.''
 
Account of the Attack
Noam Lahav, a college professor from Mevaseret Zion, outside Jerusalem, was being treated nearby, and the police were interviewing him. ''There were two terrorists,'' he said, ''and I think one of them was kind of fat. The one holding a gun had a headdress wrapped halfway around his face.
''I got off the bus, and one of them on the ground continued to shoot. I carry an Italian leather bag with me, and I ran toward him. I didn't think first.''
When he was a foot away, he said, ''I hit the one in the face'' with the bag.
Professor Lahav was being treated for a gunshot wound to the arm. He told the police that he was 61 years old.
Interviewed on Israeli radio, Dr. Shimon Shamir, the Israeli Ambassador to Egypt, said Egypt did ''more than could be expected'' in response to the bus attack.
In a speech to the Parliament this evening, Prime Minister Shamir said he held Egypt accountable for the safety of Israeli tourists, adding, ''Our first demand at this time to the Egyptian authorities is to find those who carried out this crime and to bring them to trial quickly and to punish them as much as the law allows.''
But both Mr. Shamir and Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said they saw no reason that the three-way foreign ministers' meeting could not proceed.
At the same time, Israeli tourists are no longer proceeding as planned on trips to Egypt. More than 100,000 Israeli tourists visited Egypt last year, but travel agents across the country were reporting cancellations by the dozens. Aryeh Waknin, manager of a tour agency in Haifa, said, ''In general, people are canceling out.''

GRAPHIC: photo: Bodies of eight victims of the terrorist attack in Egypt resting in military trucks at Ben-Gurion International Airport in Lod during a memorial service after their arrival. They were flown in on transport plane at rear. (The New York Times/Micha Bar-Am)

HEADLINE: Bentsen Leery on Social Security Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, whose support is crucial to adoption of a plan to cut the Social Security tax, declined today to take a stand on the proposal.
At the opening Congressional hearing on the proposal before the Senate Finance Committee, of which he is chairman, Mr. Bentsen said the growing use of Social Security revenues to cover the deficit in the rest of the Government's budget was ''an issue that can no longer be ignored.''
But Mr. Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, added, ''My concern is what replaces the revenue loss to the budget, and I haven't seen anything on that one.''
The sponsor of the proposal, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, was praised by Mr. Bentsen and other senators for having focused attention on the way the Social Security surplus is being used to pay for the general operating expenses of the Government rather than to guarantee retirement benefits in the next century. 
 
Quandary for Democrats
But Senator Moynihan's specific proposal to cut the tax by more than $60 billion over the next two years won no solid political support. And without the unconditional support of Senator Bentsen, whose committee has jurisdiction over the issue, its prospects for enactment are dim.
The proposal has presented Democratic leaders like Senator Bentsen with a quandary.
On the one hand, they agree with Senator Moynihan that cuts in income taxes and increases in the Social Security tax over the last decade have unfairly shifted the tax burden from the well-to-do toward the poor and middle class. Even more important, the Democrats enjoy watching the discomfort of President Bush and his Republican allies as they oppose a tax cut for workers and support a reduction in the capital gains tax, which would largely benefit the wealthy.
On the other hand, the Democrats believe a tax reduction of the magnitude Mr. Moynihan is suggesting would be disastrous for the economy, and they are reluctant to push for a different kind of tax to make up for what would be lost in Social Security revenue.
 
Political Danger Seen
Senator Moynihan argues that it would be politically foolhardy to advocate another kind of tax as long as Mr. Bush remains so adamantly opposed.
The only other Democrat who attended the hearing, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, said he too was ambivalent and needed more time to study the measure.
The Moynihan proposal was criticized as irresponsible by several Republican lawmakers and by the Social Security commissioner, Gwendolyn S. King.
Restating the Bush Administration's position, Mrs. King maintained that a reduction in the tax now could jeopardize retirement benefits in the future.
 
Denies Future Peril
Senator Moynihan, who is chairman of the finance panel's Social Security subcommittee, denied that future benefits would be endangered. So long as the payroll taxes are not invested for the future and are used instead to pay current government operating expenses as well as retirement benefits, he said, the next generation of workers will in any event be burdened with much higher taxes to pay for their parents' retirement.
Charles A. Bowsher, the comptroller general, agreed with Mr. Moynihan's analysis, but he said that if alternative tax revenues were not found to replace those lost under the Moynihan plan it would ''add to the financial risk.''
Mr. Bowsher, who heads the General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress, took issue with the Bush Administration's plan, which involves continuing to use Social Security funds to pay for general government expenses through 1995. That, he said, would lead to another $1 trillion in government debt by the middle of this decade.

HEADLINE: Helping Eastern Europe Helps the West

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the efforts of Eastern Europe to change from state-controlled to market economies (editorial, Jan. 21), serious questions arise about the transformation and the new organization these economies will take. Are small and large enterprises to be transferred from the public to the private sector, and in what form? How would the transfer of ownership be achieved? Through state sales to individuals and foreign investors, or by making workers and employees total or partial owners of the companies in which they work?
Although we do not have much experience in applying such economic reforms, some form of workers' capitalism or employee stock ownership plans could be used in the process of privatization. This economic system avoids extreme wealth accumulation and monopolization by individuals or the state, and combines advantages from both the capitalist and the socialist systems. It is in accordance with Joseph Schumpeter's theory of ''people's capitalism.'' 
Under this system, which has been implemented to some extent by the United States, Japan and the European Community, work incentives and labor productivity improve, strikes and other disputes are less likely because employee-owners share in decision making, and income distribution is more equitable. Thus, the saying that ''in capitalism man exploits man, in communism it is the other way around'' may not be relevant to workers' capitalism.
Along with democratization of the Eastern bloc countries, proper institutions for property titles and mortgages for credit should be established, as well as patent and copyright laws to insure orderly transfer of ownership. Such efforts can be financed and supported by Western countries and world institutions, while international mutual funds can capitalize on Eastern Europe's dramatic changes and invest in productive ventures.
As government subsidies are reduced and prices and unemployment rise, Eastern Europeans will need Western support because it is difficult to make such drastic changes alone. In the long run, such a policy is expected to be beneficial to Western economies as well.
 
NICHOLAS V. GIANARIS
 New York, Jan. 22, 1990
The writer is a professor of economics at Fordham University.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Grasping Reality

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The news from South Africa is as breathtaking, in its context, as from Mikhail Gorbachev's Soviet Union. The leader of the party that institutionalized white supremacy, that imprisoned the black majority's spokesmen and outlawed its political movements, has started down the political path toward a new South Africa.
What led President F. W. de Klerk to such dramatic steps? Why would a man brought up in the National Party and Afrikaner tradition decide to legalize anti-apartheid politics after 30 years of repression? And decide to free Nelson Mandela?
I put those questions to an important figure in the internal opposition, Patrick Lekota, who is visiting here. He is publicity secretary of the United Democratic Front, the largest anti-apartheid group inside the country. The record of his life indicates the price of opposition politics in South Africa. 
In 1976, after a two-year trial, Mr. Lekota was convicted on two counts of ''terrorism.'' He had organized a rally to celebrate Mozambique's newly won independence, and the court said that might encourage South Africans to similar rebellion. The other count was participation in the black consciousness movement of the time, which might incline blacks to be hostile to whites: ''a terrorism of the spirit,'' the judge said.
The sentence was six years. He served most of that in the notorious prison on Robben Island.
In 1988, after a three-year trial, he was convicted of high treason. The charge was that he had helped to found the United Democratic Front in 1983, with the aim of instigating anti-apartheid protests that would make the country ungovernable. Again, there was no evidence of violence.
This time the sentence was 12 years. Mr. Lekota went back to Robben Island. But last December the conviction was thrown out on appeal.
Altogether, including detentions and imprisonment during trials, he has been in prison 13 of the last 16 years - for what would not be offenses under American or European law. At the age of 41, he has been able to get a passport for the first time. But his political comments, on the reasons for the de Klerk moves, were without bitterness.
''Most important there was the sheer tenacity of us inside the country,'' he said, ''the way we responded to the worst excesses they could bring on us. The resilience we had when they cut off our leaders, our creativity in always finding a new way, showed that we were simply irrepressible. ''Second, this is a new generation of Afrikaners, educated in different conditions - some of them in part abroad, including F. W. de Klerk. They have seen that other liberation struggles were not defeated. They have looked at Algeria, for example, and know the viciousness at the end of that struggle.
''Another important element is the interconnectedness of South Africa and the rest of the world. They're not like P. W. Botha [the last President], who said 'The hell with the world.' The reality is we have to be part of the world.
''Then there was the thawing of relations between East and West. What has happened in Eastern Europe has had a big impact. Things are opening up elsewhere, people are saying they have to have political solu-tions, and they don't want to lag behind the world.''
What it added up to, I thought, was that Mr. de Klerk had begun to face reality: the determination of the 75 percent black population to have rights, the economic cost of the world's disapproval and so on. But for a National Party leader to face reality is remarkable. The party has been in power since 1948, and for most of that time its leaders have tried to shut out reality.
Mr. de Klerk showed in a striking way that he was determined. He moved to prevent obstruction of the new policy by the state security forces.
A week before his speech he called the 500 top police commanders to Cape Town and appealed to them not to undermine his plans. Failure to reach a political settlement now, he said, would lead to ''an Armageddon.'' Then, when a young man died in police custody, Mr. de Klerk immediately ordered a judicial inquiry: the first in 71 such deaths since 1963.
It is a long way still to resolution of what are very different views of the political future. But President de Klerk has set out on the path. He knows that the first steps are not enough: that people's expectations have not been met, that foreign banks and investors are waiting. It will be hard to turn back.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Pay or Shiver: Sticker Shock Of Heating Oil

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: WOODBURY, N.J.

 BODY:
rrWinter has not yet run its capricious course, but the near-balmy days of January and early February make the pulse-chilling cold of December seem a bitter memory.
For many New Jersey residents, that is just the word for it - bitter.
''I really, sincerely, absolutely felt I was being held up,'' said Mrs. Ralph Paulillo, 63 years old, who lives in Jersey City with her husband and a sister, all retired.
''The Jan. 10 fuel-oil delivery was $1.39 and nine-tenths a gallon,'' she said, separating every word of the amount as if holding them up to baleful scrutiny like dirty socks. ''And that was for 400 gallons. I made up my mind right then I was going to do something.'' 
What Mrs. Paulillo did was call a cooperative, the New Jersey Citizen Oil Group. Their price a week or so ago was $1.09 a gallon. She signed up immediately for a total fee of $24, which included membership in the parent group of the co-op, New Jersey Citizen Action.
She was not the only new member. In the wake of the December oil shock, driven by bitter cold that seemed to go on forever, the group signed up 650 new members.
''At the end of October we had 957 members,'' said Kendall Miller, the cheery 24-year-old who runs the cooperative. ''I was answering the phone 16 hours a day.''
The cooperative has been in operation for six years, and the 650 new members make up a sizable part of its membership.
Economics is a factor. ''I think anybody in their right mind would change dealers if they could get these prices,'' said Mrs. Paulillo. But there is another factor, and that is anger. ''There is really a sense of betrayal,'' Ms. Miller said. ''A lot of these people had been with their fuel-oil company for 10 or 15 or 20 years. Prices went up and down, but they trusted their oil company. It was like a relative, like their mother. It kept them warm. Then they got these exorbitant bills.'' ''I am not enamored of the oil companies anyway,'' said Martha Viel of Vineland, who signed up after her oil price went from 93 cents a gallon when she filled her 500-gallon tank on Dec. 11 to $1.27 last Tuesday. ''I thought my dealer was probably just passing it on, the extra cost, but who knows? I don't like the abuses of it.''
There is also the feeling of powerlessness, that like death and taxes oil prices are inexorable. Pay or freeze.
''We already pay such exorbitant property taxes,'' said Mrs. Paulillo, whose income is largely fixed. ''Then fuel prices go up. I had never complained about prices before. But he delivered 400 gallons when I wasn't home, and when I saw the price I really flew off the handle.'' For some, anger is not possible. ''One woman, she was 73, called, and she was in tears,'' Ms. Miller recalled. ''She got her oil bill, and it was for $500, and she just couldn't pay it. She didn't know what to do.''
Ms. Miller called the woman's supplier and arranged for monthly payments. And she signed up the woman for deliveries from the co-op.
For most oil buyers, there is little alternative. Converting to natural gas can cost $2,000 to $3,000. Even for the committed, that is not always possible.
''I thought about converting when I moved here in October,'' said Edward J. Sauka of Bloomfield, who bought his house with an oil furnace and who signed up with the oil co-op a week ago after seeing his first bill. ''But it wasn't economically feasible right now.''
Mr. Sauka is a marketing specialist for a big utility, Public Service Electric and Gas.
''Who made the profits?'' he asked, a question that Congress and regulators across the country are posing. For the moment, no one is quite sure. Meanwhile, the oil co-op provides one of the few alternatives to paying whatever the traffic will bear or shivering through the cold.
The New Jersey Citizen Oil Group is able to offer oil well below market prices because it has contracts with five dealers across the state who agree to provide oil at cut-rate prices, partly for public relations and partly to spread deliveries across predictable markets. All five keep their identities secret because they also have regular customers who pay market prices.
There is another consideration, Ms. Miller said, and that is that fuel-oil consumers, angry and frustrated at unpredictable prices, will shift to alternative fuels.
''We're the last stop before conversion to gas,'' she said.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1004 words

HEADLINE: Dinkins Maps Policy of Delay For Raises

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Facing both a $1 billion budget gap and negotiations with New York City unions that are among Mayor David N. Dinkins's biggest supporters, city officials say they are considering offering contracts with minimal raises this year but the promise of larger payments in the future.
The practice, known as backloading because part of the raise is deferred until the end of the contract, might enable the city to hold to something like the modest 1.5 percent annual increase that it now claims is all it can afford for municipal workers in settlements that come due beginning on June 30.
But the tactic could conceivably commit the city to an increase it could not otherwise afford in anticipation of future revenues it cannot guarantee. Municipal contracts settled with delayed increases in pension benefits in the 1960's are generally considered to have contributed to the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's. 
City officials refused to discuss the likely size of wage proposals or possible contract strategies in any detail, and said no plan had been formed. They also noted that in the fiscal crisis, municipal unions agreed to defer wage increases outright for several years until the city could afford to pay them, an idea that is also being floated.
 
Risky Inducements
Fiscal and labor relations experts say the wisdom of backloaded agreements depends mostly on the size of the deferred increases and the cumulative increase by the end of the contract.
For example, the total compensation over the life of a contract might be no greater than it would have been through a series of limited raises, but would simply be distributed differently, with progressively larger payments in later years. More typically, a premium is offered as an inducement for signing such contracts, and the experts say that is riskier.
''It's very hard to speculate on something like that,'' said Charles Brecher, director of research for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private monitoring group. ''If all you did is spread the same money out in an uneven way, then that could be good for the city. But presumably you're going to have to pay a premium for that.''
Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and a member of Mr. Dinkins's council of economic advisers, has urged deferring any wage increases until the city can pay for them outright, or negotiating very modest increases to be offset entirely by attrition in the work force.
 
'Shouldn't Try to Kid People'
''Whatever increase is negotiated should be modest and up front and distributed evenly across the contract,'' he said in a telephone interview from Paris yesterday. ''You shouldn't try to kid people.''
Mr. Rohatyn said backloading a contract, at worst, ''is borrowing, and it's just paying at a different time.
''But as for the overall economics,'' he added, ''unless you think that you're in a really temporary economic downturn and you're very sure of it, it doesn't really solve anything. It just enables you to pretend in the early stages that you have less of a problem.''
Mr. Dinkins's four-year financial plan and preliminary budget issued last week shows a projected budget surplus of $314 million in fiscal year 1993, which ends on June 30, 1990. That amount appears under the heading ''reserve for service enhancements, tax reductions and other contingencies,'' and officials said it could also be used for labor settlements.
 
Counting on the Economy
But they cautioned that the number is merely a prediction, dependent on many variables and the future course of the economy. Even if all that money were available, each percentage-point increase in wages and benefits for city workers is now estimated to cost $130 million a year, so $340 million would allow for an increase of fewer than 3 percentage points, well below the unions' current demands.
''It's obviously a fairly speculative number, because a lot of water has to go under the bridge before then,'' said the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael. He added that the surplus was a consequence of economic projections, not an expectation of future needs, and that ''it wasn't put there as a source of a backloaded labor settlement.''
But he said the city's forecasts anticipate that the economy will improve in the future, while there is not much room for flexibility in labor settlements this year. Officials said that the four-year plan, a legacy of the fiscal crisis, would make it unlikely that the city could hide delayed contract plums as in the 60's, since balance sheets for the future must be included in each year's budget.
While the city says it has included only enough money in the budget for a 1.5 percent wage increase this year, Barry Feinstein, a major Dinkins supporter and the head of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents many city workers, said a 5 percent increase is the floor at which his union intends to start formal bargaining on Feb. 13 for a two-year contract. #1.5 Percent 'Untenable'
Mr. Feinstein said yesterday that no one in the administration had mentioned the possibility of a backloaded contract to him, but he said he would discuss any reasonable proposal. ''What's untenable is saying 1.5 percent and that's all that's there,'' he said.
The teamsters' current contract expires on June 30, along with those of unions representing police officers, firefighters and correction and sanitation officers. Contracts for teachers and most other municipal workers expire on Sept. 30.
The administration has yet to name a labor relations director to negotiate for the city. But a senior aide to the Mayor said yesterday that an appointment would be made soon.
Mr. Dinkins's $27.8 billion preliminary budget for the fiscal year that starts on July 1 calls for $550 million in new taxes, plus hundreds of millions in service cuts and productivity measures to close a budget gap of more than $1 billion caused by unexpectedly large shortfalls in tax revenues.

HEADLINE: Taxes May Increase, Trenton Warns

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Florio administration said today that the state faces a $550 million deficit this fiscal year and that the Governor is contemplating tax increases despite his pledge as a candidate last year that none were needed.
The State Treasurer, Douglas C. Berman, said that the administration was reviewing not only tax increases to balance the budget but also cuts in programs and layoffs.
Mr. Berman attributed the shortfall to a weakening economy and to overly optimistic and misleading budget projections by Gov. Jim Florio's Republican predecessor, Thomas H. Kean. Mr. Florio is a Democrat. 
But during the campaign a number of budget experts said Mr. Florio and his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, were ignoring evidence that indicated the state did not have enough money to reach June 30, the end of the fiscal year.
 
'This Was Not Unexpected'
''This was not unexpected,'' said Senator Laurence S. Weiss, a Democrat who is the chairman of the Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee. ''I sounded warning signals more than a year ago when the Kean spending plan was presented to the Legislature.''
New Jersey's Constitution requires that the budget, which totals more than $12 billion, be balanced by the end of the fiscal year.
Mr. Berman said that all three major taxes in the state had fallen far short of the expectations in Mr. Kean's last budget. He said the sales tax had fallen $256 million short, the income tax $276 million and the corporation tax $172 million. Other taxes, he said, were $26 million short of expectations.
The state is also facing about $120 million in expenses not accounted for in the state budget, including additional funds for welfare, Medicaid and correction programs as well as a new union contract with state workers.
Those calculations leave the state $850 million worse off than the Kean budget had predicted.
The Kean budget had planned a $300 million surplus at the end of the fiscal year. To have a balanced budget, Mr. Berman said, the administration must find $550 million in cuts or additional revenue by June 30.
''Additional spending cuts are contemplated, but I am not sure that would be sufficient on its own,'' Mr. Berman said. ''Almost any tax option you can think of is under discussion.''
As a partial explanation for revenue problems, Mr. Berman referred to statistics indicating that unemployment may be rising in New Jersey while it has declined nationally.
 
Democrats Fault Kean's Budget
Mr. Berman, who served as Mr. Florio's campaign manager last year, said the Democratic candididate depended on Mr. Kean's budget figures when he repeatedly told voters that he saw no need for tax increases.
Some leading Republicans charged that the Florio administration was trying to make the budget look far worse than it is, to enact tax increases.
The Republicans said that Mr. Florio's projections failed to include $62 million in savings from a hiring freeze that Governor Kean imposed last year and that the administration had suddenly reduced projections for the growth of income-tax revenues.
'The administration wants to give us the very worst budget scenario it can,'' said Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, a Republican Assemblyman, ''in order to give Governor Florio the wiggle room he needs to get out of this campaign promise of no new taxes.''

HEADLINE: New Cruiser to Replace The Iowa at Base on S.I.

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

 BODY:
The nation's newest fighting ship, the guided-missile cruiser Normandy, will replace the Iowa as the flagship of the Navy group to be based at its new base in Stapleton, S.I., the Navy announced yesterday.
The Iowa, commissioned in 1944, will be mothballed in an economy drive by the Defense Department. The Normandy was launched in 1988 and commissioned two months ago. 
The change will drastically reduce the number of crew members on the base's main ship. The 887-foot Iowa has a crew of 1,500, and the 567-foot Normandy has 367.
The Staten Island Borough President, former Representative Guy V. Molinari, a Republican, said the economic impact of the reduction would be eased by an eventual increase in other jobs at the base. He said at least five support vessels would be stationed at Stapleton - three destroyers and two frigates.
 
Controversy Since 1983
The base and the deployment of the battleship Iowa were announced in 1983. Supporters cited the economic advantages of having six or more major Navy vessels in the city, with their crews, families and hundreds of supporting civilian workers.
Opponents cited the nuclear threat posed by accidents aboard the ships, all of which are capable of carrying nuclear weapons, or by an enemy attack on the vessels in the port. A spokesman for the Coalition for a Nuclear Free Harbor, Michael Immerso, said the Normandy and at least one support ship would ''carry the same Tomahawk cruise missiles as the Iowa.'' The Navy has not confirmed or denied that the ships would be armed with nuclear weapons.
Although former Mayor Edward I. Koch strongly supported the base, Mayor David N. Dinkins has opposed it from the start on the ground of safety.
''The Mayor's opposition is longstanding and continues,'' a spokesman for Mr. Dinkins, Clifford Chanin, said yesterday. ''He has certain concerns that need to be resolved, and the presence of this ship is not one way or the other going to resolve them.''
 
Number of Jobs in Question
Mr. Molinari said the Federal Government would spend an estimated $387 million a year to operate the port. He predicted that it would use 4,500 Navy workers and 900 civilian employees. Theirs incomes would in turn generate thousands of civilian jobs, Mr. Molinari said.
Mr. Immerso said that the number of jobs at the base was inflated and that many of them would be taken by the spouses of Navy workers, and not by local workers. Navy dependents would have at least 300 of the 900 civilian jobs, he predicted.
The Normandy, cruising the Caribbean, is to arrive in New York in August. The other ships are to arrive over the next year, Mr. Molinari said.
Built at the Bath (Me.) Iron Works, the Normandy is a Ticonderoga class cruiser armed with hundreds of missiles. She also has the Aegis electronic weapons-control system.

HEADLINE: Poll Detects Erosion of Positive Attitudes Toward Japan Among Americans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The percentage of Americans expressing negative views of Japan has increased significantly in recent months, according to the latest Times/CBS News Poll as well as additional interviews with ordinary Americans and leading Japan watchers.
It is not the widespread presence of Japanese consumer goods that is the problem. Even many Americans who concede that they also drive a Honda or listen to a Sony Walkman. The rise in unfriendly feelings appears to be fueled by two other factors: the purchase of American institutions like Rockefeller Center and Columbia Pictures by Japanese investors and the end of the cold war with the Soviet Union as a focus of attention.
It is the trend, more than the raw numbers, that has alarmed some politicians and political analysts. Sixty-seven percent of those polled still say they have generally friendly feelings toward Japan, according to a Times/ CBS News Poll of 1,557 Americans taken by telephone Jan. 13-15. That is down from 74 percent in a CBS News Poll last June and 87 percent in a Times/CBS News Poll in 1985. 
 
Rise in Unfriendliness
A quarter of Americans now say their feelings about Japan are ''generally unfriendly,'' up from 19 percent last June and 8 percent in 1985, the latest Times/CBS News Poll found. The newest increase comes after several years in which unfriendly opinion was essentially stable. To be statistically significant, a shift in poll findings must be at least three percentage points.
''There is a real erosion in the popular mood about Japan,'' said Prof. Gerald Curtis, an East Asia expert at Columbia University.
In follow-up interviews after the poll, Americans made it clear that highly visible Japanese investments here are feeding an anxiety that Americans are losing control of their own country and culture. Furthermore, the collapse of the Soviet bloc has freed them from their fears of Communism and allowed them to turn their anxieties toward what they see as their own nation's slipping economic strength.
Experts on Japan like Richard C. Holbrooke, who was President Jimmy Carter's Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, said the results of the latest polls were ominous and could seriously complicate an already difficult relationship between Washington and Tokyo.
Even around Portland, Ore., an area that has prospered on trade with the Pacific rim, Representative Les AuCoin says he is hearing protectionist sentiment from corporate executives and other people who a few years ago sang the praises of free trade.
 
Pressure on Politicians
The rising anxieties are already increasing the pressure for stronger rhetoric on trade issues, politicians reported. That could well fuel the growing resentments in Japan toward Americans while raising expectations here for economic improvements, a cycle that, as Representative AuCoin pointed out, could make it that much harder for political leaders in both countries to agree on the economic actions needed to solve the very problems that have provoked the anxieties in the first place.
''You have a dynamic in both countries that brings out the worst in both,'' said Mr. AuCoin, a Democrat. ''There can only be catastrophe at the end of that unless something comes out and turns it around.''
At the Republican White House and in the Democratic Congress there is considerable awareness of these trends. President Bush, in his State of the Union Message on Wednesday, and Speaker Thomas S. Foley, in the Democratic response, used strikingly similar language to proclaim their commitment to free but fair trade. The Democrats have made a strategic decision to stress ''economic competitiveness'' as one of their major political themes this year, and Mr. Bush stressed the theme in appearances on Friday and Saturday.
Older Americans, those with more direct memories of World War II, are more likely than younger ones to express negative views toward Japan. But nearly one in five younger Americans now say they have an unfavorable view.
 
Fears Voiced in Colorado
When Jennifer Albright of Denver buys a ticket on the ski lift, she frets that the money is leaving Colorado and going to the resort's new owners, in Japan, she said.
''I think they're buying up a lot of the United States,'' said Ms. Albright, a 25-year-old accountant for a printing company in Denver. Ms. Albright made her comments in an interview in the poll and expanded on her answer a few days later. ''I know they are here in Colorado. We've lost several ski resorts and real estate properties. It seems like they're investing a lot of money in our country and not letting us do that in theirs. It seems the United States isn't reinvesting in our own country and we're letting other countries buy us up. Bush needs to do something to stop it.''
Such sentiments were a major topic at a recent series of strategy sessions among leading Democrats, who spoke about the talks but asked not to be identified. One leading party strategist said the nation's attitudes were at an important crossroads. The question is whether politicians can channel economic anxieties into productive policy without fueling dangerous protectionist or nationalistic sentiments.
 
Warning by Democratic Strategist
''It's such a strong chord in the thinking of Americans that if it's not channeled positively it could become a very negative view quickly,'' said the Democratic strategist. ''Get a couple more instances of Japanese buying Rockefeller Center and there's an opportunity for someone who's dangerous to manipulate that anxiety and fear.''
The latest rise in antagonism toward Japan coincides neatly with the decline in fear of the Russians and the soaring popularity of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in this country. But the response is more complicated than a simple replacement of one foreign enemy with another; what Americans themselves make clear is that the end of the cold war has freed them to worry about other problems.
''The Russians aren't the threat they used to be,'' said Anthony Peone, 39, of Brockport, N.Y. ''We ought to quit subsidizing Japan. We have troops there. We have bases there. I don't have any kind of racial hangup. I think they just ought to pay their own way. There really isn't much of an excuse to keep up all of these military bases.''
Mr. Peone was an electronics technician at General Electric, but agreed to leave and take a severance settlement when the company cut back operations, a cutback for which he partly blames competition from Japan. He is now training to be a computer programmer, a job he believes is better insulated from Japanese competition. ''I don't think they're going to send their programmers over,'' he said.
Interestingly, there was very little regional variation in attitudes toward Japan. More affluent or better educated people were somewhat more likely to express friendly attitudes.
''I have to give them credit for being astute and recovering from defeat and building themselves an empire - a financial empire,'' said Homer Plimpton, a stockbroker from western Pennsylvania. He said that his feelings toward Japan were generally friendly but that he had heard others express fears that Japan was buying out America. ''They've got a long way to go to do that,'' he said.
 
Ambivalence in Assessment
Professor Curtis and others note that the feelings of Americans toward Japan are ambiguous and ambivalent. Many Americans concede that much of the blame for the nation's economic troubles can be found here at home. ''I think a lot of it is unfair competition,'' said Talmadge Fort, 39, a New Jersey auto worker. ''But I also think a lot of it is bad management.''
Mr. Fort said a heated argument had broken out at a recent union meeting in Linden ''about not buying Japanese cars.'' He recalled the debate: ''O.K., you might not buy the cars. But what about the stereos, the radios, the sneakers?''
He said the union local's president had argued for a boycott on all Japanese products. But, Mr. Fort said, ''When they started coming up with lists, there is no way of getting around buying.''
Ms. Albright drives to the ski slopes in a Japanese car, and Mr. Peone said he bought what he thought was an American-made refrigerator only to discover that all its internal works were made by Mitsubishi.
Some Japanese politicians and writers, noting that the British, not the Japanese, are the largest overseas investors in the United States, have perceived racial causes in the far stronger reaction toward Japan. In follow-up interviews after the Times-CBS poll, several respondents volunteered that they were motivated by economics not prejudice.
 
Resentment at Town Meetings
Mr. AuCoin says he sees prejudice at town hall meetings in his district ''in which somebody will stick their hand up and express some form of resentment about valedictorians in graduating class being those non-Americans, by which they mean Asians.''
''There is obviously a racism intertwined in this, and it's very troubling,'' he said.
Mr. AuCoin said increasing antagonism toward Japan has become apparent in his northeast Oregon Congressional district. Oregon, he notes, actually has a trade surplus with Japan, thanks to agricultural exports. And Japanese high-tech companies have actually brought jobs to, not taken them from, his district.
Yet when Mr. AuCoin, who has opposed restrictive trade bills, polled his constituents last year to ask how they would feel about a candidate who supported fees and limits on imports from countries with unfair trade practices, 73 percent said they would look favorably on such a candidate. Fourteen percent said unfavorably.
''That is absolutely astounding for this Congressional district,'' he said in his Washington office. ''If it's happening there, imagine what they're saying in Detroit.''

LENGTH: 884 words

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER

 BODY:

Splish-Splash
To be perfectly discreet, you wouldn't wear a bathing suit to work, unless you're Greg Louganis. Or would you? Liza Bruce, the London-based designer who is introducing a line of swimwear-inspired sportswear for spring, thinks nothing of it.
''Swimwear is no longer swimwear,'' Ms. Bruce said shortly before showing her new collection at Barneys New York last week. She wore a low-cut, glove-tight black jumpsuit, with chiffon blouse, both from her line. Not the kind of thing to wear to work, but definitely O.K. for lunch at Le Madri. 
''It's based on the idea of the swimsuit removed from the beach,'' she said. Ms. Bruce is well-known for sexy, skimpy bathing suits, many of them with a trademark crinkly Lycra fabric, for that wet Fortuny look. But for a designer interested in fashion, the swimsuit business has its limits.
''The swimwear market is controlled by the major department stores,'' she said. ''Everything is on wheels,'' which is industry slang for the practice of returning merchandise to a manufacturer if it doesn't sell quickly.
Swimsuits use barely a half-yard of fabric and are often made with straight seams, so the cost is low and the profit potential is high. But since they take up the same amount of space on sales racks as street clothing, and prices are typically no higher than $100, they have to sell fast for retailers to realize the same profits per square foot.
There is also a limited number of units that can be sold at the designer end, which, as you may have noticed, makes swimsuits for female figures that exist primarily in dreams.
With the multitude of cover-ups and wraps that accompany swimwear these days, it is only a small step for a designer to move into sportswear. The catsuit, or stretch jumpsuit, has become a staple of a number of designer collections, including those by Donna Karan, Norma Kamali and Vivienne Westwood.
Ms. Bruce's set of Lycra coordinates, in the Co-Op store of Barneys New York, includes stretch leggings, high-waisted skirts, bandeaus, bicycle pants and Rudi Gernreich-inspired 60's jackets.
''We are finally acknowledging that the 60's look was the closest we have yet come to expressing female emancipation in terms of fashion,'' Ms. Bruce said. Shamask's Back in Style ''My name is my name,'' said Ronaldus Shamask, sounding vaguely like Popeye while looking out over the poop deck of the Morgans Hotel in Manhattan. Mr. Shamask, who is back in the design business after several months of legal wrangling over the rights to his name, showed his fall men's wear collection in a penthouse suite at the Morgans last week.
The big plaid Clint Eastwood ponchos and unconstructed three-button jackets were a hit with store buyers. After a one-season absence, he will show a women's collection on the runway in New York in April.
 
Celebrating Barcelona
The Barcelona style in art, design and fashion will be showcased when a group from the Catalan region of Spain take over the State Armory at 26th Street and Lexington Avenue for a three-week cultural exhibition.
The exhibit, which includes architecture, painting, sculpture, photography and textiles, begins with a fashion show Thursday evening at 8, with clothes by six designers: Armand Basi, Estrella G., Roser Marce, Antonio Miro, Margarita Nuez, and Lemur. (Sybilla, perhaps the best known of the Barcelona fashion designers, will not be represented. She now manufactures and shows her collections in Italy.) The exhibition is sponsored by the government of Catalan, in northeast Spain. Since joining the European Economic Community in 1986, the Spanish Government has been aggressively supporting businesses that enter international markets, said Sheelagh D'Arcy Hinds, whose marketing company, SD'H International, organized the New York event.
''This is why we're seeing so much going on in Spain the last couple of years,'' she said. ''Just as we looked to Milan 10 years ago, now we're looking to Barcelona.''
 
Leave of Absence
Who says fashion people are totally driven? Emily Cinader, the designing mind behind the J. Crew catalog, is taking a six-month sabbatical from the company, she said yesterday. Ms. Cinader is looking for a house in Los Angeles, to be with her fiance, Cary Woods, who was recently named the executive vice president of Columbia Entertainment, the movie company.
''I'll still be giving plenty of input into the company,'' said Ms. Cinader, the president of J. Crew Inc. and its chief designer. ''It's not a permanent change.''
 
Planning an AIDS Benefit
The Council of Fashion Designers of America, which holds its annual awards gala tonight at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been working quietly on plans for a major AIDS benefit, some members said last week.
Instead of another glittery charity ball, the council is considering a huge auction or sale of designer clothing at the armory on Lexington Avenue.
''We're studying the feasibility of that and a thousand other ideas,'' said Carolyne Roehm, the president of the C.F.D.A. ''Right now I'm just trying to get through tonight. I'm thinking of doing a straitjacket in diamonds for myself.''
The guest list for the awards dinner has gotten so crowded, Ms. Roehm said, she has had to eliminate the dance floor to accommodate more tables.

HEADLINE: SCIENCE WATCH;
Saving the Landfills

 BODY:
Crab scraps are being converted into high-quality compost in an effort to solve an expensive waste disposal problem. The pilot project in Perry, Fla., uses cypress sawdust, yard waste and bark to convert the smelly crab scraps into marketable compost.
The annual crab harvest on Florida's Gulf Coast yields 16 million pounds of blue crabs, 3,000 tons of which become waste. Crab scraps, made up of exoskeletons and viscera, account for 30 percent of landfill material in the Florida panhandle region, and consume up to a quarter of the money set aside for solid waste management. 
''Composting is a way to alleviate the economic burden of landfills,'' said William Brinton Jr., an agricultural chemist and president of the Woods End Research Laboratory of Mount Vernon, Me., which is directing the project. ''The counties run the landfills and are liable for the waste. They want to develop this as an option to keep their crab processors happy.''
The project, begun on Nov. 9, has already converted 500 tons of crab scraps into 1,000 tons of nutrient-rich compost. Cypress sawdust is blended with the scraps in a precise ratio and then turned each day by a special composting machine. Bacteria in the mixture grow at a rate capable of heating the pile up to 140 degrees Fahrenheit. After 40 days the resulting soil is clean and odor-free.
''Each week about 65 tons of crab scraps are blended at the site with 125 tons of forest product residue,'' Mr. Brinton said. ''The piles placed end to end would be 1 mile long, 6 feet high, and 12 feet deep.''
The county will sell the compost for $30 to $40 a ton. Current compost prices in New England range from $50 to $300 per ton.
Results of the project have persuaded other Gulf Coast counties to request similar pilot projects. The project is being financed by a grant from the Florida Department of Environmental Regulation.

International

HEADLINE: Ex-Im Bank Resumes Aid to China

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Export-Import Bank, an agency of the Federal Government that provides credit to the customers of American exporters, has made its first loan to China since the military crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators in June, bank officials said today.
The loan is believed to be the first to China by any Western lending agency since June.
The $9.75 million loan to the China National Offshore Oil Corporation was signed in Washington on Friday. Wary of criticism by those who believe its China policies have been too lenient, the Administration did not announce the action. 
Last month, Beijing lifted martial law, and the Bush Administration responded by easing some sanctions against China, including ending its blanket opposition to World Bank loans to China.
Bank officials said the loan, which is for 10 years at an annual interest rate of 8.3 percent, had been approved after a determination by the bank's board that the American company would lose the contract without the Government financing. Administration proposals to reduce the operations of the bank have drawn criticism from business leaders who are concerned about the loss of such export sales. [Page D8.] The new loan will enable the Chinese oil company to finance engineering services for a gas processing plant that the Chinese state enterprise is buying from McDermott International Inc. The plant is near the Bohai Gulf.
McDermott, based in New Orleans, has annual revenues of $2.4 billion and employs 2,800 workers, selling, among other things, oil and gas equipment and services. Much of its business is overseas.
World Bank officials said their board will take up two China loans on Thursday, one for $60 million for agricultural projects in Jiangxi province in eastern China, and one for $30 million for earthquake reconstruction in Shanxi and Hubei provinces in north China.
The actions of both the Export-Import Bank and the World Bank come against a backdrop of sharp Congressional criticism of the Administration's policies on China. Congressional critics argue that the Administration has been too willing to ease sanctions in the absence of significant improvement of human rights policies by Beijing.
Some officials said today that the United States might approve only the earthquake reconstruction loan because this would have the least political repercussions.
The Export-Import Bank makes loans at subsidized interest rates to foreign customers of American companies. It also guarantees export loans that commercial banks may make. For most of its loans, the bank looks for a guarantor, in case the money is not repaid. The guarantor usually is the national bank of the country receiving the goods.
In this case, the guarantor is Mitsui & Company, a giant Japanese trading concern that has close commercial relations with the Chinese oil enterprise and with McDermott.
Bank officials said a guarantee by a commercial enterprise in a third country was unusual but not unprecedented. ''Mitsui offered the guarantee, and it certainly has the money,'' one bank official said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Productivity Rises By Only 0.2% in Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
American workers' productivity rose a barely perceptible two-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter, while hourly labor costs rose at an annual rate of 6.9 percent, the Government said today.
For the year, nonfarm productivity, defined as the output per hour of work, was up only slightly more, by nine-tenths of a percent; it was the worst showing since the 1981-82 recession. Hourly labor costs for 1989 jumped 5.5 percent, the Government said. 
The annual increase in nonfarm productivity was less than half of the 2 percent gain recorded in 1988.
 
'A Recipe for Trouble'
While attributing part of last year's poor performance to an overall slowdown in economic growth, analysts worried that the combination of weak growth in productivity and higher labor costs would further weaken America's ability to compete internationally.
''That's a recipe for trouble,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company. It is symptomatic, he added, ''of an economy that is near the end of expansion.''
The Labor Department report showed that while productivity was slumping, hourly labor costs - an important measure of inflation for businesses - increased significantly. The 5.5 percent increase was up from 4.7 percent in 1988 and was the biggest increase since 1982.
''Labor cost increases are probably the scariest part of the report,'' said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting firm.
 
White House View
At the White House, the Administration spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, pinned the slight productivity increase in the quarter on the overall slowdown of the economy. The pace of economic expansion, as measured by the gross national product, grew by a rate of five-tenths of a percent in the last three months of 1989, the slowest growth for any quarter since 1986.
''The small productivity gains last year probably reflect the transition to a more moderate pace of economic growth rather than a general weakening in productivity,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''Productivity gains often fall off sharply when output growth slows.''
Output in the nonfarm sector was up 3.3 percent in 1989, while the number of hours worked rose by 2.4 percent, accounting for the nine-tenths of a percent increase in productivity.
 
Debate Over Productivity
The report seemed certain to revive the debate over America's lagging productivity.
Since the end of the 1981-82 recession, growth in productivity has averaged 1.8 percent a year. While a slight improvement over the 1.2 percent average growth rate of the 1970's, that was still far below the 3.3 percent annual rates of the two decades after World War II, when American workers enjoyed healthy wage gains and a rising standard of living.
Improved productivity is considered esssential to improving living standards because it allows businesses to pay workers more as their output rises, without the risk of higher inflation.
In addition to the large rise in hourly compensation, the report indicated that unit labor costs, another important factor in determining future price inflation, shot up 4.6 percent for the year, compared with a 2.7 increase in 1988. Unit labor costs reflect changes in compensation as well as changes in productivity.

HEADLINE: Honda Asked To Sell Jeeps To Japanese

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company said today that the Chrysler Corporation had asked it to sell Jeep recreational vehicles in Japan, and some Honda officials hinted that they were likely to strike an agreement soon.
Japan's leading economic daily, Nihon Keizei Shimbun, reported today that Honda expected Jeep sales to reach 5,000 to 6,000 vehicles a year. A Honda spokesman said no figures had been calculated because no agreement had been reached. 
Chrysler's talks with Honda are another sign that its long relationship with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation may be coming apart.
 
Poor Sales in Japan
Chrysler's performance in Japan has been dismal. The company owns four exclusive dealerships; two are in Tokyo, where Chrysler Japan Sales has built large showrooms in expensive areas of the city. In addition, there are 43 independent dealerships around Japan that carry Chrysler cars in addition to other models.
For all that, Chrysler sold 970 cars in Japan last year, according to industry statistics, and 260 Jeep Wranglers, which are classified in Japan as trucks.
Chrysler's future in Japan has taken on particular interest here, because Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman and chief executive of the company, has been the most outspoken American auto executive about barriers in the Japanese market. Last year, he suggested in a television interview that was widely rebroadcast here that he would ''knock heads'' if allowed to compete directly in Japan with Japanese auto makers.
 
Reduced Stake in Mitsubishi
So far, Chrysler's main affiliation in Japan has been with Mitsubishi, a second-tier auto maker in which Chrysler once held a 25 percent stake. In September, apparently to raise cash, Chrysler reduced its stake to 12 percent and took a $310 million profit.
At the time, Mr. Iacocca said the company's ties with Mitsubishi would remain ''as strong as ever.'' The two companies have a joint venture in Diamond-Star Motors, whose plant in Normal, Ill., builds the Plymouth Laser, Mitsubishi Eclipse and Eagle Talon specialty sports coupes. Mitsubishi also builds more than a half-million V-6 engines for Chrysler each year, and Chrysler dealers sell several Mitsubishi car and truck models.
Still, there have been frequent reports that the relationship between the companies has become strained. Mitsubishi is said to have recently turned down Chrysler's request to sell its cars through Mitsubishi dealerships.
 
Frequent Complaints
At the same time, Chrysler has repeatedly complained that Japanese car dealerships are closed to it, largely because most Japanese companies - Toyota and Nissan in particular - compete with Chrysler's Jeeps for the booming market here in off-road vehicles. Honda, in contrast, offers no off-road models and thus has nothing to lose.
Mitsubishi Motors executives make no secret of their distaste for Mr. Iacocca's remarks about how the United States should take a hard line against Japan on trade issues. And there has been widespread speculation about whether Chrysler would turn to Mitsubishi or other Japanese car makers for help - or to buy part of its operations - should Chrysler's American sales outlook worsen.
Chrysler has laid off thousands of workers and closed several plants in recent months, and it announced last week that in the fall it would reduce its car-making capacity by 20 percent and lay off 3,700 more workers.
