HEADLINE: Plan to Cut Ex-Im Bank Draws Business Protest

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Budget decisions by the Bush Administration to reduce the operations of the Export-Import Bank have drawn loud protests from business supporters of the Administration, as well as from some lawmakers.
Indeed, Congress may well increase the bank's lending authority beyond the level of the budget request.
The 57-year-old Export-Import Bank provides direct credit, insurance, loan guarantees, working capital guarantees and other programs for hundreds of exporters, big and little. The help represents a subsidy for business, since the credit made available to the buyer of the goods abroad is at below-market levels for interest rates. 
In defending the proposed reductions, Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, says the Export-Import Bank was an example of what he called ''hidden Pac-Men.'' He used the phrase to describe situtations in which a mechanism was in place to spring forward and consume future resources.
The proposed cutbacks would reduce the bank's most heavily used program, which makes direct loans to customers overseas who buy American exports. Critics of President Bush's budget say the proposals underscore a gap between policy rhetoric and substance.
These people say that while the Administration acknowledges the trade deficit as a major problem, its actions weaken Government financial support for exports at a time when similar programs are being strengthened by most other industrial countries.
 
N.A.M. Official Critical
''When our competitors are going opposite ways, you have to wonder how seriously we are taking exporting,'' said Howard Lewis, vice president for international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers.
Bruce B. Talley, executive director of the Coalition for Employment Through Exports, which represents exporting corporations, trade unions and state governors, commented, ''The cutbacks are an invitation to American companies to go offshore.''
C. Fred Bergsten, a former senior Treasury official who is now director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington policy organization, said, ''We're losing billions of dollars a year in exports because of the inadequacy of Government finance.''
The budget proposals called for cutting the Export-Import Bank's direct-loan program by 18 percent.
 
Reserve Set Up
Sometimes the bank's loans go sour. Earlier this month the bank established a $4.8 billion reserve to cover possible losses on loans and loan guarantees made in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
The reserve is equivalent to 40 percent of both the bank's outstanding loans and its outstanding guarantee and insurance claims. Bank officials say the action does not mean the loans have been written off. They say they continue to expect all loans and guarantees to be paid in full.
 
High-Tech Involved
Many of the bank's transactions involve high technology and speciality goods and services from smaller companies. The products include CAT scanners, telecommunications ground stations, air navigation equipment, computer software, wood products and even iced soft-shell crabs, now being shipped daily by plane to Tokyo from Chesapeake Bay.
Nearly 30 percent of Export-Import Bank transactions help small and medium-sized businesses, like Sattel of Van Nuys, Calif., which designs satellite communications systems and has just sold one to Indonesia. Ten years ago, bank figures show, the comparable number was 5 to 6 percent.
Increasing use of the bank's resources by small business has heightened political sensitivity over the cutbacks in the direct lending program.
 
Senate Panel's Warning
In a legislative report in September, the Senate Appropriations Committee told Mr. Darman ''not to repeat the mistake of asking for inadequate funding of this program, thereby forcing the Congress to cut programs which the Administration supports in order to fund this vital activity in support of U.S. exports.''
The new budget calls for $500 million of direct loans, down from $612 million authorized in the current fiscal year. In the last year of the Carter Administration direct loans totaled $5.5 billion. In the late Carter years the United States was actually running a trade surplus. More recently the annual trade deficit has been exceeding $100 billion.
John D. Macomber, six months on the job as Export-Import Bank chairman and a friend of Mr. Bush, denies that the institution has been weakened.
In an interview, he noted that comparisons should be made not with the $612 million that Congress authorized for the current fiscal year but with zero in direct lending proposed in the last Reagan budget.
The Reagan budget directors, David A. Stockman and later James C. Miller 3d, exhibited little sympathy for the bank, arguing that it provided a large subsidy for a tiny fraction of exports.

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs I.M.F. Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The United States is willing to accept an increase of up to 50 percent in assessments for the International Monetary Fund, the Treasury Department said today.
Negotiations over raising the quotas paid to the I.M.F. by its 152 member countries have been going on for several months. The United States had previously said it would accept a quota increase of 45 percent.
Negotiators are still divided on a proposal by the United States for the I.M.F. to sell some of its gold reserves to help make up nearly $4 billion in late payments owed to the fund by 11 countries.
The I.M.F., set up after World War II, uses its cash to make loans to countries with balance-of-payments problems, usually in conjunction with economic restructuring plans.
A Treasury spokesman today confirmed a report in The Financial Times of London that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had formally shifted the American position to accept an increase of up to 50 percent in the quotas.

HEADLINE: Visitors to U.S. Expected To Increase 75% in Decade

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The number of visitors to the United States will increase more than 75 percent by the end of the decade from last year's 38 million visitors, the Commerce Department said today.
Travel by Americans has remained fairly constant for the last two years, so the nation's $350 billion-a-year travel industry is counting on international traffic for growth. The Commerce Department's projection, announced at a tourism and travel conference in Washington this week, said that by the year 2000 the United States is expected to play host to 67 million visitors a year. 
Last year, for the first time, tourists spent more in the United States, $43 billion, than American travelers spent abroad, $42.6 billion, giving the United States a slight travel surplus in the balance of trade calculations. That surplus, the Commerce Department said, is expected to triple this year, to $1.48 billion.
 
Weak Dollar Expected
The projections, released by Rockwell A. Schnabel, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Travel and Tourism, are based on computer models of the strength of foreign economies and estimates that the value of the dollar will continue to be fairly weak.
The weakness of the dollar accounts for much of the increase of foreign visitors, Mr. Schnabel said, but he cited other factors, particularly the intensive promotions by hotels, airlines and city, state and Federal governments.
Another factor in the growth is the change in Eastern Europe. ''There is a tremendous pent-up demand in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to travel here,'' he said.
''They are interested in our philosophy: look at what happened with McDonald's,'' he added, referring to the throngs of people jamming Moscow's first McDonald's restaurant, which opened last week.
On the other side of the equation, the number of Americans traveling abroad continued to taper off last year, growing only 1 percent from 1988, to 41.3 million. And domestic travel by Americans was relatively flat. Trips of more than 100 miles from home increased by only 3 percent, to 1.3 million.
Although international visitors provide only about 10 percent of travel revenue today, they are expected to provide much of the growth in the 1990's, said Don Wynegar, director of the Office of Research at the Travel and Tourism Administration, part of the Commerce Department.
And while most of the international visitors to the United States come from Canada and Mexico, the number of Japanese and British visitors has grown significantly in the last five years, Mr. Wynegar said. During the next decade, he said, there will be large increases in the number of visitors from South Korea, Sweden, Taiwan and Australia.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Moscow and Pretoria News Lifts Precious Metals Prices

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Precious metals prices continued to rise yesterday in reaction to developments in South Africa and the Soviet Union. Dealers said a further decline in the dollar against the yen and the West German mark also bolstered the gold market.
At the close of the Commodity Market in New York, the spot February gold delivery settled at $422.40 an ounce, up $4.20 on the day, while the same silver contract gained 2.2 cents an ounce, at $5.329. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, spot February platinum rose $3.20 an ounce, to $512. 
''Gold always thrives on uncertainty as well as when the value of paper money declines,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''And Soviet President Gorbachev's proposals to end the Communist Party's monopoly on political power has raised the possibility of turmoil there.''
 
Exchanging Paper Money
As it is, deteriorating economic and political conditions in the Soviet Union, a major producer of gold and platinum, have led many people there to exchange paper money for precious metals and stones.
Ms. Raptopoulos said the gold market views the recent announcements of reforms in South Africa as positive over the long term. Should the reforms help improve South Africa's worsening economy, it could reduce that country's need to sell or use its precious metals as collateral for loans.
After President F. W. de Klerk announced last week that the African National Congress would be legalized, the prices of Krugerrand gold coins rose, Ms. Raptopoulos noted.
 
Krugerrands at a Discount
The coins used to be the most popular form of investing in gold. But South Africa's racial policies led many countries, including the United States, to ban the import of Krugerrands several years ago. With the subsequent proliferation of other popular gold coins, like Canada's Maple Leafs, American Eagles, Mexican pesos and China's Pandas, Krugerrands began to sell at a discount of up to $5 an ounce from the spot price.
Since the reforms were proposed by President de Klerk, the price of Krugerrands has moved to parity with most other bullion coins. The Pandas command a premium because many investors consider them the most esthetically attractive of the popular gold coins. They are also produced in smaller quantities each year than other bullion coins of comparable value.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Job Outlook For Middle Managers

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
WHEN middle managers lose their jobs, do they have reason to be optimistic or pessimistic about their chances of finding new positions these days? Even experts on the job market cannot agree.
''It has never looked better for middle management and business,'' Nancy Kovalcheck, a spokeswoman for Management Recruiters International, a large nationwide contingency search firm, said last week. ''More jobs are being created than can be filled.''
But Lynda C. McDermott, who heads a small consulting firm, Equipro International Inc., in New York, has a different view. ''We have a glut of middle managers, especially in the Northeast, believe me,'' she said. ''A surplus of middle-level employees for too few jobs is leading to slower career growth and slower upward mobility for those who remain in middle-management slots after downsizings.'' 
Ms. Kovalcheck supports her brighter view with the results of a survey by the firm as well as figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics indicating an unemployment rate for middle managers of only 1.9 percent, compared with 5.3 percent for the population as a whole.
The survey showed that of 2,700 company responses, only 11.8 percent planned cutbacks in the first half, while 51 percent said they would maintain current middle-management work forces and 36 percent planned to add middle managers.
''If anything, there's going to be a crisis in the 1990's about finding people to fill middle-management positions,'' she said. She defines middle managers as those earning $30,000 to $75,000.
Nearly every day, newspapers carry announcements about corporate revampings that end up eliminating middle-manager positions. Affected companies have included Eastman-Kodak, I.B.M., McGraw-Hill, Gillette, A.T.&T., Merrill Lynch and Pitney-Bowes.
Dan Lacey of Lacey & Company in Lakewood, Ohio, a consultant who follows employment prospects, agrees with Ms. McDermott. ''Unlike the blue-collar employment bloodbath that hit old-line industries at the beginning of the 1980's,'' he said, ''this one is striking hardest at middle managers in advanced-technology companies. Long-term corporate job security is now coming to an end.''
Mr. Lacey added that he foresees years of ''diminishing job opportunities for middle managers'' in terms of salaries and promotions, as well as job openings.
Between the optimistic and pessimistic, the truth will probably be found. It may involve demographics: job losses on Wall Street, and fewer jobs in the computer industry in California and Massachusetts counterbalanced by the need for more managers in some Western and Midwestern states, where business prospects have improved somewhat. Because of these shifts in job opportunities, middle managers should be prepared to relocate.
''Middle managers have to let go of the myth that any job is permanent,'' Ms. McDermott said. ''I advise a middle manager to think of himself or herself as 'Me Inc.,' a business like any other that must consider how best to package the product, which is that person.''
Paul R. Ray Jr., president and chief executive of Paul R. Ray & Company, a global management recruiting company with headquarters in Fort Worth, said, ''The talent pool is greater because of downsizing.''
Recruiting firms that once ignored unemployed managers now will consider them because their clients are more willing to hire displaced managers, he said. ''There is recognition that talented persons have value to add,'' Mr. Ray said.
He predicts a shift toward ''companies reaching lower into middle management'' to award profit sharing incentives because of what he calls ''a corporate fixation on productivity.''
''It has been shown that profit sharing can help boost productivity,'' he said, adding that it can also help assure loyalty among middle managers. As a characteristic, loyalty to one's company has been badly battered by indiscriminate dismissals.
But profit sharing tends to replace salary increases for middle managers while helping to hold down fixed costs. ''We foresee much more pay-for-performance and much more discrimination as far as who gets the extra compensation'' is concerned, he said.

HEADLINE: A $15 Million Penalty for Laundering

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
In the first case involving laundering drug money brought by the United States against a large bank, a Federal judge in Tampa today ordered two subsidiaries of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International to forfeit $15 million, the largest penalty ever assessed against a bank.
Last month, on the eve of the trial, the two principal units of the $20 billion bank, which is based in Luxembourg, agreed to plead guilty to reduced charges of conspiracy and money laundering. Specifically, they admitted that bank officials had engaged in disguising transactions involving funds they knew were the proceeds of cocaine sales in the United States.
The two subsidiaries are the Bank of Credit and Commerce International S.A., in Luxembourg, and the Bank of Credit and Commerce International (Overseas) Ltd., in Grand Cayman. The bank has offices in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Miami. 
The plea agreement with the Justice Department called for the bank to be placed on five years' probation and to forfeit more than $14 million it had placed in an escrow account, an amount that with interest has since grown to just over $15 million. The case involves transactions from 1983 to 1988.
 
'Only Sanction Available'
Judge William T. Hodges accepted the plea agreement, which prosecutors said was three times as much as any penalty assessed against a bank in the history of the United States. Judge Hodges said, ''The only sanction available to the court in sentencing corporate defendants is the imposition of a fine or a monetary penalty, as in a forfeiture.''
Some in Congress have criticized the plea agreement as too lenient. Last week four Representatives and two Senators, all Democrats, wrote Judge Hodges suggesting that a larger monetary penalty be considered.
The bank has served as a depository for tens of millions of dollars controlled by the deposed Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Though Mr. Noriega was not mentioned in the indictment, prosecutors said they might introduce evidence about his dealings with the bank in the case. 11 Officials Named Eleven bank officials were named in the indictment. They included a number of regional and country managers, but none were at the highest management levels of the bank. Five officials are now on trial before Judge Hodges on money-laundering charges in a case that is expected to last several months.
The five are: Amjad Awan, head of the Latin American division and a former banker for General Noriega; Syed Aftab Hussain, an officer of the bank in Panama; Akbar A. Bilgrami, an official in the Miami office; Sibte Hassan, an officer of the Paris branch, and Ian Howard, manager of the Paris office.
The bank was founded in 1972 by Middle Eastern and Pakistani investors, and was headed by Agha Hasan Abedi from 1972 to 1988.
 
Review of Licenses
The bank, which operates in 73 countries, faces further scrutiny and publicity after today's sentencing. Foreign and state regulators said they would review the bank's operating licenses in the wake of the plea agreement.
The bank's offices in the United States are licensed by state regulators. In Florida, the guilty plea gives the Comptroller, Gerald Lewis, the authority to revoke the license of the Miami office. Mr. Lewis has already called the plea agreement too lenient, said a spokesman, Terence P. McElroy.
The Luxembourg Monetary Institute will also review the bank's license, which could affect their operations worldwide, but its examination is complicated by legal and jurisdictional factors.
London serves as the bank's biggest base of operations and its de facto headquarters. However, the Bank of England, Britain's central bank, plays a secondary supervisory role because the legal headquarters of the main subsidiaries are in Luxembourg, the Cayman Islands and the United Arab Emirates, countries that have fewer supervisory resources.
 
Unusual Structure
This unusual structure has caused difficulties for supervisors. The Luxembourg Monetary Institute has primary jurisdiction over the bank, even though it operates ''marginally'' in Luxembourg, said Pierre Jaans, the head of the institute.
In an interview last month, Mr. Jaans said he had been trying for two years to get the bank to ''come to a legal structure that would better fit the economic reality of the bank,'' but he added, ''I can't throw somebody out.''
Mr. Jaans said the institute, consistent with Luxembourg law, would review the bank's license in light of the plea agreement. Professional or ethical fitness figures in such a review, but the issue is complicated because Luxembourg's criminal justice system does not encompass plea bargains. Nor does Luxembourg have the American concept of penal corporate liability, in which a corporation can be held responsible for the actions of its employees.
Luxembourg's review of the bank's license, Mr. Jaans said, will look at these questions: How high up in the organization were the bank officials involved in the wrongdoing? How many officials were involved in the money laundering?
 
'Specific Knowledge'
A transcript shows that Michael Rubinstein, an assistant United States attorney, told Judge Hodges last month that the evidence in the case showed a ''conscious intentional pattern by which the defendants -defendant corporations, their high-level officers, of which had specific knowledge that the funds were the proceeds of cocaine distributions in the United States, proceeded specifically with an eye toward concealing and disguising the nature of the transactions.''
As part of the plea agreement, the bank entered into a consent order with the Federal Reserve, which also has jurisdiction over foreign banks operating in the United States, requiring the bank to improve its record-keeping and screening of customers.
The plea agreement, which requires the bank to cooperate with prosecutors, could lead to more information on General Noriega's financial dealings. A man the Government says was a partner in drug trafficking with General Noriega, Steven M. Kalish, deposited $2 million in drug proceeds into accounts at the bank's office in Panama City in 1983, the indictment said.

HEADLINE: Drug Study Faults Role Of State Dept.

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
An internal State Department review has concluded that the agency has not taken its role in the drug war seriously because it is hampered by the complexity of its mission, limited resources and a lack of interest among senior agency officials.
The audit of the department's Bureau of International Narcotics Matters confirmed what critics in Congress and other agencies have long said about State Department narcotics policy: that it has taken a back seat to other diplomatic efforts and has been left to the initiative of junior Foreign Service officers.
The findings could prove embarrassing to the Administration as State Department officials prepare for a drug summit meeting on Feb. 15 in Cartagena, Colombia; President Bush and the leaders of Bolivia, Colombia and Peru are to attend.
The national drug strategy announced by President Bush last month states that the bureau is the lead Government agency in coordinating American narcotics policy overseas and the nation's drug assistance programs in other countries. Although the bureau does not take an operational role in those areas, it is charged with coordinating such activities as drug interdiction and crop control in Latin America and other regions. More than half of the bureau's budget is for economic support and other efforts to help the coca-producing countries of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. 
 
Policies Corrected, Official Says
The audit, which circulated on Capitol Hill last week, also contradicted comments to the Senate Judiciary Committee on Friday by William J. Bennett, the Federal drug policy director, that ''the scourge is beginning to pass'' and that ''we are beginning to win'' the war on drugs.
''The war on drugs is by now well known, well documented and disheartening,'' said the audit by the State Department's Office of Inspector General. ''Disheartening because it is being lost and is taking a huge toll in human suffering and exacting a high price in political instability in several source countries.''
Melvyn Levitsky, the Assistant Secretary for International Narcotics Matters, did not dispute key findings in the audit but he said it reflected policies put in place under the Reagan Administration, many of which he had already corrected.
''I'm a little frosted by the inspectors putting out a report,'' Mr. Levitsky said in an interview. He said many of the inspectors' recommendations were his own ideas ''for turning the bureau into something which is decent.''
 
'Poor Job of Managing'
Mr. Levitsky, who became head of the bureau last June, noted that while the report was completed in January, it was based largely on inspections here and in field offices from last July until the fall, before he had time to make changes.
''The department before this Administration had not given drugs its proper priority,'' he said. ''Although there was a lot of rhetoric and a lot of focus on it, they had not gotten the resources together.''
But the audit suggested that many of the problems were entrenched in State Department procedures and could not be quickly reversed.
It found that ''the most consistent theme'' reported by department officials and other Administration and Congressional officials was that ''the Department of State did not assign a high priority to narcotics matters.'' This, the audit said, ''set in motion a cycle of below-average Foreign Service personnel doing a poor job of managing an expensive program with little to show for it, with other foreign policy concerns systematically overriding the narcotics aspect.''
Several times, the audit reported, inspectors witnessed other Administration officials bypassing the narcotics bureau on critical drug-related matters. In one recent case, it said, the head of the bureau was not invited to a meeting between a Deputy Secretary of State and the Foreign Minister of Colombia, ''ostensibly because the agenda did not include narcotics.'' The bureau head later had that reversed.
 
Bureau Not Consulted
In another example, the audit said that ''following the assassination of a Colombian presidential candidate, the State Department's press office made several announcements without even consulting'' the narcotics bureau. These slights, the audit asserted, ''are additional items in a long list that reflects low priority for the bureau that is supposed to have the lead on narcotics and, by extension, low priority to narcotics matters in general.''
The audit said that senior agency officials needed to make clear to the American public and foreign leaders that ''they indeed see narcotics trafficking as a threat to national security.'' Another problem cited was the use of bureau planes, which ''are idle unnecessarily for extended periods of time or deployed in reaction to impromptu ambassadorial requests for aviation support.''
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa and a member of the Senate Budget Committee, said the audit raises questions about President Bush's proposal to increase the narcotics bureau's budget next year. In a letter last week to James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary of State, Senator Grassley wrote that ''if this report is true, we are potentially earmarking hundreds of millions of tax dollars for waste and inefficiency in the battle against drugs.''
Mr. Bush has recommended a budget of $150 million for the narcotics bureau in fiscal 1991; the current budget is $113 million.
 
Confusion Over Roles
The audit said that while the bureau's budget had nearly tripled since it was established in 1978, the level of staffing ''has not kept pace with the increasing importance and complexity of its responsibilities.'' The document also found ''confusion over function responsibilities'' in the bureau and a lack of coordination between bureau officials and the embassies.
Moreover, the audit said, the bureau needed to become more active in coordinating intelligence gathering and law enforcement activities. It said the bureau ''should be participating more directly'' in deliberations of the Office of National Drug Control Policy.
The report offered 27 recommendations for improving the bureau, from developing a new policy statement to filling new positions to revising many of its operations. Mr. Levitsky said several recommmendations were his own or were already being put into effect.

HEADLINE: For Moscow, Another Winter Of Revolution?

BYLINE: By Leon Aron; Leon Aron is a Soviet specialist at the Heritage Foundation, a research organization.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev's speech to the Central Committee calling for the surrender of the party's monopoly on power signals the onset of a two-month period that promises to be the most significant in Soviet political history since Stalin completed his seizure of power in 1929.
By the end of March, the country, which faces national catastrophe, may well be radically transformed.
Forces beyond anyone's control have been propelling the Soviet Union toward a fork in the road. There are only two turns. First, a true multiparty democracy, with unconditional return of land to the peasants and privatization of the economy. Second, abandonment of glasnost and a return to rigid economic centralization. 
The middle course, perestroika -gradual democratization, gradual and contradictory decentralization of the economy, preservation of a benign one-party dictatorship - no longer satisfies the left or right.
Mr. Gorbachev has long been accused by his radical supporters of being both the Pope and Luther. Now, apparently, he has finally chosen to imitate Luther by urging the party to reject any legal or political advantages and to struggle for power ''strictly in the framework of the democratic process.''
Severely factionalized and thoroughly discredited, the Communist Party has become an albatross around Mr Gorbachev's neck. The pattern of Soviet public opinion in the last two years makes this unmistakably clear. Whenever he has been perceived as under attack by hard-liners, his popularity has soared. Whenever he has been seen as defender of the party, his popular support has plummeted.
Under the circumstances, distancing himself from the party as much as he can is not merely the best way for Mr. Gorbachev to survive politically, it is perhaps the only way.
The potential catastrophe that the country and the leadership faces is cosmic: a near-total breakdown of the economy; a collapse of local party and state authority in the republics and the emergence of a Solidarity-like, rapidly politicizing workers' movement in the major mining regions; food shortages, which in some areas have caused the rationing of even potatoes; inflation, which by unofficial estimates just passed 20 percent and continues climbing; economic and political hostilities between Moscow and national republics, as well as warfare in Azerbaijan, and a rapidly worsening energy crisis.
While radicals push for dramatic reform, hard-liners are bound to seek ways to prolong the one-party dictatorship. They cannot wait any longer. By May, it might be too late to halt, much less reverse, the collapse of the political system, the demise of the Soviet domestic empire and the further evaporation of its former Eastern European holdings.
Four developments may compel the hard-liners to try to strike soon -or vanish from the political scene.
First, the Supreme Soviet (Parliament), which reconvenes this month, is likely to complete, victoriously, the assault Mr. Gorbachev carried forward yesterday on Article 6 of the Constitution, which guarantees the party's ''leading role.''
Second, elections are due in city, district and republic legislatures this month and next. No one doubts that apparat candidates will be swept from power.
Third, by the end of April, newly institutionalized political structures will be in place in key independence-minded ethnic republics following popular elections: in Lithuania on Feb. 24; Moldavia, Feb. 25; the Ukraine, March 4; Latvia and Estonia, March 18, and Georgia, March 25. Declarations of secession from the U.S.S.R. assuredly will follow soon thereafter. By that time, the only means of preserving Moscow's domestic empire would be massive military intervention.
Even the hardest of the hard-liners would think twice about such action. The hostilities in Azerbaijan have brought home to Muscovites the price, in blood and treasure, of preserving the domestic empire. Moreover, the willingness of ethnic Russians to fight to the last soldier to preserve the empire is now seriously in doubt - and certainly the Estonians would not consent to send their young men to keep Uzbekistan in the U.S.S.R.
Finally, by the end of May, multiparty democracies will be institutionalized by popular elections in Hungary, Romania, East Germany, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. However inconceivable, if Moscow decided to intervene to restore its Eastern European empire, the political and military mechanics of such a reversal would be greatly complicated by the fact that the Soviet armed forces would be overturning the new status quo. Besides, the Kremlin can no longer count on Warsaw Pact forces to cooperate.
If the more than 100,000 demonstrators who marched through Moscow demanding democratic changes on the eve of the crucial Central Committee meeting symbolize the nation's mood, the hard-liners have no future. The awesome aerial photographs of the marchers jammed into Marx Prospekt demonstrated potently how the hopeful populace relishes its opportunity to exploit glasnost to the hilt.
If these marchers and their sympathizers across the nation's 11 time zones do not get their way, Mr. Gorbachev, or his successor, can count on increasingly violent political turmoil and ethnic strife.
The marchers bore their placards aloft through the Russian winter, which traditionally, has been an important ingredient of political upheavals. The Russians tend to rebel in winter - from the Decembrists in 1825, to the Revolution of 1905, to the overthrow of the Czar in 1917. Now, 1989-'90 seems likely to be added to the history books.

HEADLINE: ISRAELIS WIDENING ROLE IN ETHIOPIA

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 31

 BODY:
In an effort to support the last non-Arab presence on the Red Sea, Israel has increased its diplomatic and military links with the embattled Marxist-Leninist Government here, diplomats say.
The Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam needs to be supported against secessionist rebels in coastal region of Eritrea who would turn the ''Red Sea into the Arab Sea,'' the new Israeli Ambassador here said.
The Eritreans are not Arabs, but Ethiopian and Israeli officials contend that they are supported militarily by Arab governments. The leadership of the rebel Eritrean People's Liberation Front is predominantly Christian, but about half the region's population is Muslim, a fact that the Addis Ababa Government has always emphasized. 
Western diplomats say Arab countries sympathetic to the Eritreans have responded to a recent appeal from the rebels, saying that with Israel on the side of Ethiopia, the rebels need help more than ever.
Washington has taken a dim view of Israel's assistance. Some officials say the Israeli help will serve only to prolong the Ethiopian civil war, now nearly three decades old.
 
U.S. View Differs from Israel's
The Ethiopian Government is pressed by rebellions based in Eritrea and Tigre province, divided within itself and practically bankrupt. From Washington's point of view, it appears to be in a terminal stage of collapse and not worth propping up. One American official called the Government a ''dead duck'' and described the strategic value of Ethiopia to the United States as vastly diminished as the Cold War winds down.
Israeli officials, including the new Ambassador here, paint a different picture.
Ambassador Meir Joffe, newly arrived here after a 16-year break in relations, He said it was strategically vital for Israel that the rebels not turn the ''Red Sea into the Arab Sea.''
''You just have to look at a map to see the importance to Israel,'' he said in an interview. If the Eritrean rebels were able to win independence, the Red Sea would be under Arab influence, Mr. Joffe asserted.
He claimed that the rebels get most of their supplies from radical Arab countries, including Libya and Syria. But many Western diplomats agree that the vast majority of the Eritreans' supplies are captured from the Addis Ababa Government.
The Chief of Staff of the Israeli Army, Gen. Dan Shomron, visited Ethiopia last month with an Israeli military delegation to assess Ethiopian needs, Western and East Bloc diplomats based here said.
 
Helping Christians Kill Christians
Already, these diplomats say, Israel is believed to have supplied President Mengistu with cluster bombs for use against the Tigre People's Liberation Front, which is not a separatist movement but rather seeks the overthrow of the Addis Ababa Government.
The State Department has said it has no proof that Israel delivered the bombs, and Israel and Ethiopia have denied the reports. But Western officials here say that descriptions of bombed areas in Wollo province conform with the kind of damage done by cluster bombs.
Military attaches in foreign embassies in Addis Ababa report that several hundred Israeli military trainers have arrived to boost the struggling Ethiopian Army.
An Eastern European diplomat said he had seen an Ethiopian Army brigade in training with Uzis, the Israeli-made assault rifles. Western diplomats say they have had credible reports that the Tigre rebels have captured Uzis from Government soldiers in recent battles. But Israel has denied giving automatic rifles to the Ethiopians.
Israeli officials have acknowledged supplying small arms to the Ethiopian Army. In one account, an Israeli official said that 150,000 bolt-action rifles had been given for militiamen fighting the Tigre insurgency.
The Tigre rebels are Christian Ethiopians, and do not present the Arab threat perceived by the Israelis. But the Tigreans have cooperated with the Eritrean rebels, and it appears that the Israeli Government has decided that its best course is to support the Addis Ababa Government against all challengers.
 
A History of Cooperation
Israeli assistance to Ethiopia is not new. Seeing Ethiopia as a bulwark against a Muslim tide, Israel aided the Government of Emperor Haile Selassie until his ouster in 1973, when relations between the two countries were broken.
Even after the break in relations, informal connections continued between the two countries. When Somalia invaded Ethiopia in 1977, Israel secretly supplied Ethiopia with military assistance, deliveries that were cut when they became public.
From the Ethiopian point of view, the Israeli relationship is helpful not only militarily but also diplomatically. It is through Israel that Ethiopia hopes to persuade Congress to lift the ban on American economic and development aid to Ethiopia.
Representative Mickey Leland, the Texas congressman killed in a plane crash while visiting Ethiopia last year, was hoping to set up an Israeli agricultural project that would be funded in part by American philanthropic interests. These plans are now being pursued by Senator Al Gore, a Tennessee Democrat.

HEADLINE: As Shipments of Soviet Grain Lag, Cuba Reduces Daily Bread Ration

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Soviet Union has fallen seriously behind with its promised grain shipments to Cuba, forcing the Government of President Fidel Castro to cut the bread ration and increase some food prices, Western diplomats and other experts say.
At the same time, Cuba has admitted failing to send as much citrus fruit as it promised to the Soviet Union, adding to the widespread food shortages there. Both countries mainly blame a lack of shipping for the slowdown in trade between them.
But experts on Cuba, which by some estimates receives $5 billion a year in Soviet aid, are divided over whether this is the real reason. Some say they suspect that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, is trying to force President Castro to soften criticism of his domestic policies by witholding supplies, while others say the trade disruption reflects shortages and strains within the Soviet bloc brought about by these changes. 
 
Opposes Gorbachev's Policies
On Jan. 23 the Cuban Government, which has made no secret of its hostility to President Gorbachev's policies, announced that the daily bread ration for Cubans living outside Havana would be cut starting Feb. 1 from 100 grams to 80 grams, or less than 3 ounces. In Havana, where bread is not rationed, the price was raised by about 30 percent. The price of eggs was also raised, reflecting a shortage of grain-based poultry feed.
The Government said promised supplies of Soviet grain and flour had failed to arrive at the start of the year, although it did not give any figures for the shortage. It admitted dipping into its reserve of scarce dollars to ease buy some grain on the world market, but again gave no details.
Reporting the rationing decision on Jan. 24, the Soviet Communist Party daily Pravda attributed the slowdown in Soviet grain supplies to administrative errors and a lack of ships.
The Cuban Government blamed a shortage of ships from Poland, East Germany and the Soviet Union for its failure to send as much citrus fruit to the Soviet Union as promised in recent months. It said only 72,159 tons were shipped in December instead of 113,505 tons, while in the first half of January it sent 28,350 tons out of a promised consignment of 45,300 tons.
Those who suspect the Soviet Union is pressing Cuba to soften its Stalinist line argue that Moscow did just this during the late 1960's when Mr. Castro criticized the Brezhnev Government for being too liberal. Moscow cut oil deliveries then, forcing Cuba to impose draconian rationing.
 
'It May Be Happening Again'
Only after Mr. Castro endorsed the invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 did the Soviet Union normalize relations and resume full economic aid to Cuba. ''It happened then and it may be happening again now,'' said Frank Calzon, a Cuban expert with the Washington office of Freedom House, a New York-based human rights and public policy organization.
Last June, the Central Bank of Cuba published figures suggesting that Moscow had cut about $200 million from the cheap oil it sends Cuba. Traditionally, the Cuban Government derives much of its foreign currency income from reselling Soviet oil on the world market.
Other Cuba experts argue that the trade slowdown is mainly of economic significance, reflecting the growing shortage of food inside the Soviet Union and the disruption of its barter trading arrangements with Cuba and Eastern Europe caused by the recent changes.
Diplomats say the explanation for the lack of shipping to carry Soviet grain to Cuba and Cuban fruit to Moscow may lie in recent rumors that some Eastern European countries now want the Soviet Union to pay in hard currency for the use of their vessels.
''The trade breakdowns are caused by the accumulating economic incapacities of the Soviet Union,'' said George Dominguez, an expert on Cuban affairs at Harvard University. ''There is no proof of intent to pressure Cuba politically.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The President;
A 'WAR' IS FOUGHT AS BUSH LOOKS ON

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT IRWIN, Calif., Feb. 6

 BODY:
On a day when he hailed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for proposing an end to the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on power in the Soviet Union, President Bush stood on a bleak Mojave Desert ridge today to watch American soldiers fight ''Soviet'' tanks in a mock World War III battle.
Despite the political upheaval in Eastern Europe, Mr. Bush said this was not a time to ''let down our guard against a worldwide threat.''
''I can speak for all Americans when I say we are pleased to see Chairman Gorbachev's proposal to expand steps toward pluralism in the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Bush said over a radio link to the 2,689 soldiers, who stopped their ''war'' for five minutes to listen to the Commander in Chief.
''It's especially encouraging to see anything which might bring the day of true democracy a bit closer for the Soviet people,'' Mr. Bush said. But he cautioned, ''It is important not to let these encouraging changes, political or military, lull us into a sense of complacency.'' 
 
'And Now, Back to War'
''God bless our country,'' Mr. Bush said to conclude his remarks. ''Thank you colonel, and now, back to war.''
Mr. Bush, who is devoting this week to an effort to prove why the United States needs to maintain its nuclear deterrent against the Soviet Union, arrived at the command post on Hill 781 just in time to see Soviet tanks of the fictitious 197th Krasnovian Motorized Rifle Regiment smash through the defensive lines of the real-life Third Brigade of the Ninth Infantry Division from Fort Lewis.
Mr. Bush went down the hill, part of the sprawling Fort Irwin Army base midway between Las Vegas and Los Angeles, to talk to some of the American ''dead.'' He wore a camouflage jacket above his blue pinstripe trousers, binoculars around his neck and wing tips on his feet. But perhaps mindful of the pitfalls awaiting politicians in photo sessions at military bases, Mr. Bush did not try out any of the weaponry or ride in one of the M-1 tanks, like the one in which his Presidential opponent, Michael S. Dukakis, took a politically damaging spin in 1988.
It was a day packed with the heavy ironies and political paradoxes that have become commonplace as the Bush Administration, Congress and the United States military struggle to come to grips with a rapidly changing world in which the old strategic principles that were being played out today in the exercise on the Mojave Desert floor are called into question almost daily.
 
A Speech on Military Policy
Mr. Bush flew 2,340 miles from Washington to Fort Irwin for this first stop on a trip that will also include a visit to the Strategic Air Command, a major speech on military policy and a tour of a laboratory working on the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile shield. The purpose is to head off lawmakers who argue that the receding Soviet military threat justifies more than the 2 percent cut, after accounting for inflation, that Mr. Bush is offering in military spending.
The Third Brigade training today at Fort Irwin is a light, motorized infantry brigade, just the kind of highly mobile unit on which Mr. Bush and the Pentagon want to concentrate as they begin the reshaping of the United States military.
But Fort Irwin, site of the Army's National Training Center, concentrates primarily on the sort of operation that the military leadership concedes is increasingly unlikely, a land war against the Soviet Union.
The 197th Krasnovian, which almost always wins its war games since it is based at Fort Irwin and highly trained in its desert terrain, charged from the Whale and the Furlong, two low ridges in the Mojave Desert, behind a barrage of simulated artillery fire and chemical warheads and made quick work of the less-experienced light brigade.
 
Tactics Used by 30 Nations
On a hill above, Lieut. Col. Michael Ryan, who designed the day's war games, dealt good-naturedly with the same questions of strategy that are perplexing his commanders in Washington. Although the training at Fort Irwin is clearly intended to simulate a war against Soviet troops, Colonel Ryan took care to point out that Soviet equipment and tactics ''is used 30 nations around the world.''
When a reporter asked if he would have offered that caveat six months ago, Colonel Ryan grinned and said, ''You all are asking a lot of questions you wouldn't have asked six months ago.''
Colonel Ryan said the base had not ''loaded'' the battle to give the Americans a victory. ''We've been nervous about what the fallout was going to be, but the battle was designed before we knew the President was coming,'' he said.
As he gazed out on the hillside, where the Third Brigade had dug itself in, Colonel Ryan said this choice was likely to lead to a defeat.
''If they stay where they are with no armored protection, they're subject to getting killed pretty fast,'' he said in the dry, matter-of-fact speech of a warrior talking to untested civilians.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush talking yesterday with troops taking part in exercises at Fort Irwin, Calif. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;
U.S. Backing West German's Unity Idea

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The United States is backing a proposal by the West German Foreign Minister that a reunified Germany be part of NATO but that no NATO troops be based on the territory of East Germany, a senior Administration official said today.
The official, speaking to reporters after a meeting at Shannon Airport in Ireland between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France, said a majority of NATO members appeared to favor such a unification formula.
The official said Mr. Baker would raise the issue with President Mikail S. Gorbachev when he goes to Moscow on Wednesday. After his brief layover in Ireland, but before his trip to Moscow, Mr. Baker stopped in Prague for talks with President Vaclav Havel.
 
The Genscher Proposal
The remarks by the Administration official, who is in a position to speak authoritatively on behalf of the State Department, amounted to the first indication that the Bush Administration was ready to back the unification proposal, which was presented to Mr. Baker last Friday by the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher. 
Mr. Genscher, who is the chief of the Free Democratic Party in West Germany and who often floats ideas on foreign policy, has been discussing his unification idea with European officials.
The plan has not been endorsed by East Germany, which officially seeks a neutral and unified Germany sometime in the future. It has not been endorsed by the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who heads the Christian Democratic Union in the coalition government, or by the Government itself. But it has gained widespread support in Bonn, and Government officials there say it is likely to become policy.
American officials added that they were not wedded to the proposal, meaning that if it proves impossible to put into effect, or if a better idea comes along, they will also consider those.
 
'A Pretty Good One'
''Genscher has come up with one proposal, and we think that proposal, in terms of not having NATO forces move further east, is a pretty good one,'' the senior official said. ''It maintains a NATO structure that will try to achieve not only the new missions we've talked about but the political purposes of the alliance. So we think that is a very positive contribution. This is the sort of thing that will have to be discussed among the various parties: NATO, the Germanys, the Soviets.''
Asked what kind of support the proposal had in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the official said, ''I think many of the other countries in NATO think that this serves the elements that we set and will help maintain stability.'' Up to last week, Bush Administration officials studiously avoided lending support to a detailed or concrete plan for German unity.
 
Four Conditions
Instead, whenever the President or the Secretary of State were asked for their preference on the unification question, they answered that they supported the basic principle, provided that it took place with four conditions. Those conditions were these:
* Unification must come about through the free voting and self-determination of East and West Germans. As Mr. Baker said in his speech in Berlin on Dec. 12, ''We should not at this time endorse or exclude any particular vision of unity.''
* Unification should occur in the context of Germany's continued commitment to NATO.
* For the sake of European stability, unification must happen step by step.
* There should be no enlargement of Germany's postwar borders, except through peaceful negotiations.
Administration officials said they were forced to move from those general principles to a more detailed blueprint two weeks ago, when the troubled East German Government announced that it was moving up elections from May to March 18.
 
'Takeover' or 'Merger'
Given the fact that the vast majority of East German parties running in the campaign urge unification, the voting is expected to be followed by the establishment of a new East German Government that will immediately take steps toward merging the countries.
As the Administration official put it, Washington recognizes that after the elections, ''you can expect a very quick process dealing with the economic, political and legal aspects of unification between the two German states.''
The question for the Administration became more immediate: on whose terms would unification take place? In Wall Street terms, would it be a ''takeover'' of East Germany by West Germany, or a ''merger'' between relative equals? The East German Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, weighed in last week with his own proposal, in which a ''united fatherland'' would cease to be a member of NATO or the Warsaw Pact and would set up its government in Berlin.
 
Brakes on Modrow Plan
It was in an effort stop the Modrow proposal in its tracks, before it gained any momentum with the German public, that Mr. Genscher, encouraged by the Administration, came up with his own concrete proposal in a speech on Jan. 31. The hope in Bonn and in Washington is that by the time the vote takes place in East Germany, the West will have a formula for keeping a unified Germany in NATO and resisting calls for its neutrality.
The Genscher formula postulates that a united Germany remain in NATO but that NATO promise that its troops in West Germany would not be extended into East German territory once the nations were merged.
The hope is that such an arrangement would make German unification less threatening to the Kremlin. Mr. Genscher has also proposed that the Soviets be allowed to continue maintaining some troops in East Germany, ideally in much reduced numbers, and that those troops could even engate in joint exercises, exchanges and other confidence-building measures with NATO troops so that Germany would be, as he puts it, a venue for East-West reconciliation, not confrontation.
 
Avoiding a Public Stand
To date the Bush Administration, unlike Mr. Genscher, has declined to take a position on Soviet troops. Officials traveling with Mr. Baker said, ''We don't want to rule them in or out.''
They do not want to rule them in so as not to appear to be sanctioning the presence of the Soviet Army in East Germany, the officials explained, and they do not want to declare that they must leave by a certain date because to do so would probably undermine hope of Soviet cooperation. The Soviets have about 390,000 troops in East Germany.
The Soviet position on the German question appears to be in flux. As to a meeting last week in Moscow between Mr. Modrow and Mr. Gorbachev, the Soviet President for the first time gave a cautious endorsement for a discussion of reunification.
But a day later, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze seemed to back away from that idea, saying that given Germany's Nazi past, unification was a concept that might be best put before an international referendum. ---- Thousands Rally in Prague PRAGUE, Feb. 6 (AP) - Thousands of people filled Prague's Old Town Square today and demanded that 75,000 Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia withdraw unconditionally by May 31.
The crowd, estimated at 8,000 by a Western reporter and at 30,000 by the official press agency, applauded a speaker who demanded that Vasil Bilak and other former leading Communists be put on trial. Mr. Bilak and the others are deemed responsible for inviting troops into Czechoslovakia in 1968 to crush the liberalization movement known as the Prague Spring.
The new coalition Government, headed by President Havel, has demanded the withdrawal of the Soviet forces by the end of 1990.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Baker Offers Prague Economic Aid

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today offered Czechoslovakia a package of economic assistance similar to that provided by Washington to Poland and Hungary to help the new leaders in Prague consolidate their revolution and establish a free-market democracy.
The Czechoslovak assistance program was part of a broader set of proposals included in a speech Mr. Baker is to deliver in Prague on Wednesday that outlines the Bush Administration's thinking on how ''Czechoslovakia and its neighbors in Central and Eastern Europe can move from revolutions to lasting democracies.''
In the address, copies of which were distributed to news organizations this evening, Mr. Baker tried to provide some suggestions to help the Eastern European revolutionaries of 1989 become the efficient democrats of 1990.
He said: ''If 1989 was the year of sweeping away, 1990 must become the year of building anew. The spirit of revolution needs to move from the streets into the Government.'' 
 
Baker's Assistance Package
To help Prague make that transition, Mr. Baker, the first Secretary of State to visit Czechoslovakia since William T. Rogers came in 1973, held a round of talks with the new Czechoslovak President, Vaclav Havel.
During the Secretary's discussions with the dissident playwright who has become the President, he presented the following assistance package:
* An immediate waiver of the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which had prohibited preferential trade benefits for Prague because its previous Communist leadership did not allow free emigration. That presidential waiver will permit export of Czechoslovak products to the United States with lower tariff rates as soon as the trade agreement can be signed.
* A presidential request to Congress to let the Overseas Private Investment Corporation operate in Czechoslovakia. OPIC provides insurance for American businessmen who want to invest abroad.
* Support for Czechoslovakia's request to join the International Monetary Fund and a move to make Prague eligible for export-import bank lending programs.
* A reopening of the American Consulate in Bratislava, which has been closed since 1948.
* American support for the location in Prague of the European Development Bank now being set up to aid Eastern European countries in reconstruction.
Mr. Baker also proposed the opening of American cultural centers in Bratislava and Prague, an increase in cultural and educational exchanges, the start of a Peace Corps program for English-language instruction in Czechoslovakia, and a joint American-Czechoslovak study on the Czechoslovak air-pollution problem, the worst in Europe.
 
Initiatives and Technical Aid
The Czechoslovak Government is not expected to respond to the package formally until it is officially presented by Mr. Baker, who is to speak at Charles University. But there is little doubt that officials here will be pleased that most of the details were worked out in quiet discussions through diplomatic channels during the previous weeks.
Unlike Poland and Hungary, Czechoslovakia does not have much foreign debt, so it does not seek from Washington outright cash grants but rather initiatives and technical assistance that would enable it to compete better in the world marketplace.
Besides meeting with Mr. Havel in the gilded music room of the Presidential Palace, the Secretary also met with other leading members of Civic Forum. A loose coalition of Czechoslovak dissidents and intellectuals, Civic Forum was responsible for organizing the street demonstrations and on Nov. 28 forced the Czechoslovak Communist Party to relinquish its 41-year monopoly on political power.
Administration officials said they were struck in their conversations with the new Czechoslovak leaders by how candid they were about the difficulties they were encountering in governing the country - not only because they had been dissidents and outsiders for so many years but because they were discovering that die-hard Communists were still in many ministerial posts and were doing their best to obstruct change.
 
Establishing Free Elections
In many ways, Mr. Baker's speech was aimed at addressing precisely such problems - not only in Czechoslovakia, where Administration officials are fairly confident that the leadership is on the right course, but also in Romania, Bulgaria and East Germany, which have started down the path of change but not gone nearly as far as Washington feels is necessary.
Mr. Baker outlined four basic areas in which, he said, the United States would try to work together with those countries to help them achieve the full promise of their revolution.
The first area is how to bring about free and fair elections to establish legitimate governments. In that regard, Mr. Baker proposed that the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 35-nation umbrella organization tying together Eastern and Western Europe with Canada and America, ''join with the United States in sending observer delegations to insure that people power elections'' in Eastern Europe during 1990 are conducted properly.
He also added an American warning that ''the peaceful transition to democracy now underway in Eastern Europe will not tolerate rear-guard maneuvers from any quarter.''
 
Threat of Ancient Feuds
''We will proceed on the basis of a new democratic differentiation: any backsliding in the movement to creating legitimate governments will isolate a nation from the support we can provide,'' the speech said.
The second area involved arms control, where Mr. Baker underscored the urgency of achieving a conventional-arms reduction treaty in Europe, but then added a proposal that was clearly aimed at diffusing the pent-up ethnic and nationalist tension brewing in Eastern Europe. East-West conflicts, he said, are no longer the greatest threat, but rather old feuds between ancient peoples of Europe.
''We need to develop measures that would impede an assertion of military might by any European nation against any other,'' he said. ''We should consider new proposals to promote greater military transparency between neighboring states.''
In the third, area, economics, Mr. Baker did not provide much in the way new ideas beyond the aid package to Prague and the notification to others that the progress any Eastern European Government makes in meeting the challenges of moving toward a free market ''will influence the availability of the full range of aid'' that Washington will extend from the $300 million pool of new funds the White House has budgeted for Eastern Europe for this year.
 
Overcoming Old Animosities
The final area involves what is still a loosely defined proposal for new regional associations in Eastern Europe to provide stability and mutual support for the new governments there as they try and get on their feet without the aid, or hindrance, of Moscow.
''We believe voluntary associations follow naturally from democracy and are, in a sense, a natural way for democracies to build an international civil society and overcome old animosities,'' said Mr. Baker.
''We welcome the recent discussions of mutually beneficial economic cooperation by the Governments of Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia, including a possible free-trade agreement. If you do your work together, we will respect your decisions by providing our assistance in a way that supports your association.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Poland;
World Bank Approves Its First Loans to Warsaw, in Support of Economic Reforms

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The World Bank today approved its first two loans to Poland, totaling $360 million, part of a package of more than $2.5 billion that it is preparing over the next three years to help break economic bottlenecks and support reforms of the Solidarity-led Government.
The action, taken after a daylong board meeting here, follows approval on Monday by the World Bank's sister lending organization, the International Monetary Fund, of $723 million in shorter-term credits to shore up Poland's international accounts over a period of transition from a centrally planned to a market-oriented economy.
The moves represent a Western seal of approval on Warsaw's reform plan, the most far-reaching of any in Eastern Europe. The plan calls for scrapping price controls while maintaining wage controls, ending many subsidies for goods and services, selling state-owned enterprises and making the currency convertible to dollars. 
 
Cushioning the Shocks
The large-scale international support, which is being supplemented by aid packages from the United States and the European Community, among others, is aimed at cushioning shocks on consumers and workers. Already prices have shot up, and unemployment is expected to rise sharply.
Poland's Labor Minister, Jacek Kuron, has cited I.M.F. estimates that the number of jobless could rise to 1 million by the end of this year. This is more than twice previous estimates.
Some of the Western aid would help the Polish Government prepare a safety net to help the jobless similar to unemployment insurance programs prevailing in most Western nations.
The World Bank loans include $260 million for projects in industries including chemicals, electrical power and forest products, and $100 million for agricultural programs. In the farm sector, the money would be spent on imports of cattle feed to build meat supplies and on food freezing, storage and processing facilities. Much of the money will flow back into purchases of equipment from Japan and Western industrial countries including West Germany and the United States.
Barber B. Conable Jr., the president of the World Bank, said at a news conference here that the loans would make the Polish economy more efficient, help it boost exports and provide more and better goods for the population.
 
'A Close Partner'
The World Bank, which altogether commits more than $22 billion a year to promote development in the third world, ''intends to be a close partner'' of Poland in the process of economic transformation, Mr. Conable said.
The loans are the first by the World Bank's principal lending unit, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which makes loans at subsidized rates to about 80 countries. But a subsidiary of the bank, the International Finance Corporation, which helps the private sector in developing countries, made a $17.9 million loan to a Polish frozen-food enterprise in 1988.
The loans are for 17 years, and the first repayments do not have to be made until 1995. The interest rate is 7.75 percent but is subject to change every six months, based on the bank's own cost of borrowing in international capital markets.
Poland already has a major external debt problem. It owes $40 billion to foreign creditors, half of which comes due in the next three years. About $30 billion of the total is owed to foreign governments and the rest to commercial banks, mainly in Western Europe.
The international support now being mobilized includes what are expected to be generous rescheduling terms when the Warsaw authorities go before the so-called Paris Club of creditor nations to negotiate repayment terms.
Poland has been allowed to suspend interest payments and has not been paying principal for years. American Treasury officials said they expected Poland to be given at least 10 years to repay its official debts. On commercial debts, the Treasury has told Poland that it could qualify for reduction under a plan put forward last March by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The Germans;
Exchange Rate Crucial In a Move to One Mark

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
If West Germany and East Germany move rapidly toward a single currency, the crucial decision for both the politicians and the economists will be the rate at which the East German mark is exchanged for the West German mark, several economists said yesterday.
Moreover, some economists warned, a monetary union should not occur until other important economic changes, like the removal of price controls and Government subsidies, were undertaken in East Germany. Without such reforms, the potential benefits of a single currency and monetary policy would be undermined. They also agreed that the biggest concern about such a move at this time is that it would create a burst of inflation in West Germany, which would then force a sharp increase in interest rates to curb the price rises. 
 
Knocking the Dollar
As for the dollar, the prospect of a unified Germany alongside a fast-changing Eastern Europe has also knocked it down more than 10 percent against the mark since November, when the Berlin wall was opened. A successful move toward economic union would mean an even weaker dollar, economists say, but if the process falters that could strengthen the dollar temporarily.
For the politicians, like Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who proposed immediate talks on such a union yesterday, the more favorable the rate is to East Germany the more likely it will be to slow the flood of East Germans to West Germany, now running at about 2,000 a day. The West German Government is pushing for a quick union as a way to slow this outflow and avoid the collapse of the East German economy.
The more favorable the rate, the stronger the lift for East Germany's sagging economy and the country's standard of living, which are both changes that could keep more East Germans at home. The closer the exchange rate is to one East German mark for one West German mark, the more generous it will be to East Germans, giving them more purchasing power. In West Germany, the exchange rate being talked about now is four East German marks for one West German mark. The official rate is one to one, while the unofficial rate in West Berlin is about six to one.
 
Inflationary Pressures
But for economists and, especially the West German central bank, the more favorable the rate the more likely it is that there will be inflationary pressures as the central bank, the Bundesbank, has to print more West German marks to meet the demand in East Germany.
The president of the Bundesbank, Karl Otto Pohl, opposes the quick move to monetary union. But he does acknowledge that the flood of East Germans leaving the country could lead to the collapse of the economy. And in a speech in New York last week he suggested that there could be some ''gradual'' linking of the two currencies under the right circumstances, which means prior moves by the East German Government toward broader, free-market economic reform.
John Lipsky, director of international bond market research for Salomon Brothers in London, said that no matter what exchange rate was set it would be difficult for the West German central bank to gauge the right policy to follow in setting interest rates and supplying currency to the two economies.
The expectation now, Mr. Lipsky said, ''is that the politicians will decree an inflationary monetary reform'' for East Germany.
If the move to monetary union moves ahead, it is not yet clear how the transition would be made. Based on comments of the West German Finance Minister, it is possible that the two currencies could become exchangeable relatively soon but that the West German mark would not fully replace the East German mark until 1993.

HEADLINE: Come Snow, Rain or Heat, 30/ Letter Seems Likely

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
It looks as if it will cost 30 cents, a nickel more, to mail a first-class letter next year.
The increase, which would be the first since 1988 and the largest ever, will be considered by the United States Postal Service's board when it meets March 6. And if things follow their usual course, stamp prices will go up next February, 11 months after the rate-raising process begins.
Although an increase in 1991 had been expected for some time, the size of it did not begin to come into focus until last week. That was when the Postal Service issued the text of a speech, delivered by Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank to the Economic Club of Indianapolis on Jan. 25, in which Mr. Frank said it appeared that 30 cents was the most likely new price of a first-class stamp. 
 
Criticism Is Expected
Mr. Frank made clear he did not expect the increase to play well with the public. He noted that the raise would be 20 percent, substantially above the 14 percent that he estimated consumer prices will have risen in the three years since the last rate increase, and he said he was ''committed to paying back to the American people that 6 percent'' difference.
Today, addressing a California meeting of the Postal Service's board, Mr. Frank offered one way to do so, saying, ''We may very well be able to hold increases in rates after the 1991 adjustments to one more increase in the balance of this century.''
But that ''would be no small achievement,'' he said.
 
Relatively Low Rates
Regardless of whether there is an outcry over the new increase, as Mr. Frank expects, the United States will continue to have the lowest first-class rates among industrialized countries. By comparison, the rates are 47.2 cents in West Germany, 46.5 cents in Japan, 38.3 cents in France and 31.8 cents in Britain.
If, as seems certain, the postal board acts next month to raise rates for all classes of mail, the independent Postal Rate Commission will then ask for comment and hold long hearings before making its recommendation.
It will then be up to the board to put the new rate into effect. Only once since the rate commission was created in 1971 has it proposed a lower increase than the board had asked for. In that case, the board overruled the recommendation and did what it had proposed.
 
Expected Battle Over Charges
While public attention focuses on the cost of sending a first-class letter, the real battles occur over second- and third-class rates.
Advertising firms, charities and publishers of magazines and newspapers inundate the rate commission with pleas to hold down their portions of the overall rate rise.
Although the Postal Service managed to achieve a $404 million surplus in the last three months of 1989, it expects a record $1.6 billion deficit for the fiscal year that will end Sept. 30. And the outcome of contract negotiations this summer could make the deficit even worse.
Mr. Frank, addressing postal costs in his Indianapolis speech last month, noted that the Postal Service had been required in the last two years ''to contribute $800 million to deficit reduction, even though we don't use a penny of tax money,'' and that ''health benefit costs are out of control - a problem we share with the private sector.''
The Postal Service was created in 1971 out of the old Post Office Department. It was separated from the Federal budget, and tax subsidies were eliminated. Later, when the service was showing a surplus, the agency was returned to the Federal budget.
The service was subsequently taken back off the budget, but was also required to cover some retirement and medical payments for people who had been employees of the Post Office Department. That expense has added millions of dollars to the service's annual costs.

HEADLINE: Bush Offers Farm Plan, but Without Specific Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today sent Congress a package of recommendations for new farm legislation but did not spell out how farm subsidies should be cut to help meet Federal spending cutbacks next year.
In releasing a list of more than 60 recommendations for the 1990 Farm Bill, the debut of the Administration's farm policy, Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter said the Administration did ''not intend to make specific recommendations on how to meet budget requirements.''
Last week, in his Budget Message, President Bush called for a $1.5 billion decrease in Federal price supports in the fiscal year 1991. But the Administration is apparently looking to Congress to come up with the blueprint for those cuts. 
''We'll have to legislate in cooperation with Congress,'' Mr. Yeutter told reporters.
The debate on the farm bill comes at a time of soaring incomes for the nation's farmers and declining levels of government price supports. Federal farm price support outlays for 1990 are forecast at $11.3 billion, down from a high of $22.4 billion in 1987, according to figures supplied by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo.
 
Bill to Set Minimum Prices
The bill, the Food and Agriculture Act of 1990, regulates and finances a wealth of programs ranging from food stamps to setting the minimum price that farmers can receive on crops like peanuts, sorghum and rice. The bill will replace the 1985 farm bill, which expires at the end of this year.
Lawmakers, farmers, lobbyists, environmentalists and commodity traders have been eagerly awaiting some sign of the Bush Administration's view on questions like commodity-price supports, Federal disaster relief for farmers and programs to halt soil erosion, destruction of wetlands and the pollution of water by pesticides and chemical fertilizers.
Congressional Democrats and environmentalists characterized the administration's first foray into agricultural policy as timid and said it failed to go beyond much of what is currently embodied in law.
''Unfortunately, the heart of the farm bill is simply not there,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee. ''The administration fails to tell farmers what it thinks target prices should be. American farmers don't know what their incomes will be and Congress does not know how much the administration will be willing to spend on farm programs.''
The Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City has projected that farm income will be $54.5 billion this year, up from $46.7 billion in 1985. Economist say the rise in farm income has resulted from Federal subsidies, a weaker dollar, which helped exports, and the drought conditions of 1988 and 1989, which drastically reduced grain surpluses.
