HEADLINE: How U.S. Can Cut Trade Imbalance With Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leonard Silk attributes to Edward M. Bernstein, first research director of the International Monetary Fund, the belief that the chronic United States trade deficit with Japan is chiefly the result of the undervaluation of the yen, which represents deliberate Japanese policy (Economic Scene column, Jan. 12). Moreover, Mr. Silk believes this to be part of the reason trade pressure is mounting on the Japanese. I would like to clarify United States-Japan trade issues.
As for the assertion that the yen is undervalued because of a Japanese policy to purchase billion-dollar bonds, I would mention first that the fundamental relationship of international balance of payments components is that the surplus of current balance is equal to the deficit of both capital balance and balance of monetary movements (the amount of inflow of money to Japan must be equal to the outflow). This is not economic theory, but accounting fact. 
Japanese investors have to invest surplus money overseas, but the monetary authority of Japan does not manipulate how or where that money is invested, nor can it influence the investment with regulations or guidelines. Japanese investors are said to have bought West German mark assets and, since the collapse of the Berlin Wall, are starting to shift money from the United States to West Germany. The yen has thus weakened against the mark and become more stable against the dollar in the last two months.
Political changes aside, one striking feature of the recent past is the dominant influence of nominal interest rate differentials on international capital flows. This has led to the somewhat paradoxical result that countries with deficits, like the United States, with relatively high inflation rates and high interest rates, have experienced large-scale capital inflows, which have put upward pressure on their exchange rates. Countries with surpluses, like Japan, have the reverse effects. Such situations produce clear risks.
As the upward movement of the currencies of deficit countries with high inflation rates implies a real appreciation, and conversely a real depreciation of the currency of surplus countries with low inflation rates, there is a strong possibility that current-account imbalances will worsen and that unsustainable foreign investment levels will give rise to serious policy dilemmas and disturbances in financial markets. To counter these risks, the Japanese Monetary Authority is monitoring and acting in the foreign exchange market in close contact with other countries in the monetary Group of Seven (the United States, Britain, France, West Germany, Italy and Canada).
To cut trade imbalances, we must keep in mind the basic relationship, which is also the accounting fact, that the difference between a country's exports and imports is exactly equal to the difference between its savings and investments. In recent bilateral talks, the United States focused on such Japanese problems as the tendency to save a lot, but not invest enough on infrastructure, an inefficient distribution system and business practices that exclude newcomers. Japan responded with its list: the American tendency to consume a lot, but not save enough, lack of emphasis on exporting, inadequate worker education, business practices that focus on short-term profits, rather than long-term productivity.
The Bush Administration and Congress have to make a plan to cut the budget deficit in real terms and should not resort to bookkeeping gimmicks anymore.
As for increasing America's savings rate, the following episode has relevance. Before World War II, Japan had one of the lowest savings rates among major countries and just after the war the rate plunged even further with inflation. In this crisis, the United States brought in a Detroit banker, Joseph Dodge, as the Occupation's economic adviser. He proposed a sharp increase in income tax rates, even on fairly low incomes, a well-known balanced budget principle, and an exemption from all taxes on the interest earned on deposits of up to three million yen a person. Inflation disappeared within weeks, and six months later, the savings rate turned up and kept climbing. Tax revenues also began to rise almost immediately.
Finally, I would like to point out that the United States has been counseling countries whose deficit of international balance of payments is caused by excess domestic demand to take a restrictive fiscal and monetary policy and to push through structural changes to raise savings rates through the International Monetary Fund (where the United States is a top voting power). It's time for the United States to put into practice the same principles.
 
TOSHIHIKO MORI
New York, Jan. 19, 1990
 The writer is associate representative in the United States of the Bank of Japan.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Bicycles, Not Cars, Show True Progress

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The caption on the photo of bicycle traffic in Ho Chi Minh City accompanying your ''Phnom Penh Journal'' (Jan. 9) calls bicycling a ''primitive'' means of transportation. The further implication is that although bicycles outnumber cars in traffic there, progress will reverse that. 
The situation for most developing countries is very different from the late 19th century in the West, where the bicycle industry was the precursor to the automobile and aircraft industries. Economic and resource constraints make it most unlikely that societies such as Vietnam will take this route.
In global ecological terms, moreover, it is not clear that such development would be welcome. Air pollution, the greenhouse effect and resource depletion will escalate dramatically if the entire human population reaches the high energy use of societies that rely heavily on the private automobile.
Sensible and sustainable transportation development will see industrial countries moving toward a combination of efficient mass transit and human-powered transport like the bicycle, rather than the automobilization of developing countries.
Signs are in evidence. The president of the Volvo Corporation has called for elimination of cars from the urban areas of Sweden. Bordeaux, France, plans to eliminate motor traffic from 50 percent of its streets within 10 years. In Italy, partial car bans are in effect in the centers of Naples, Milan, Bologna and Florence.
New York City public officials have yet to offer a serious initiative to restrict auto traffic. They will have to if New York is ever to become a truly livable city.
 
JON ORCUTT
New York, Jan. 23, 1990
 The writer is executive director of Transportation Alternatives, a bi-cycle advocacy organization.

HEADLINE: Time to Stop Bashing The 'Wealthy' Elderly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The final paragraphs of Charles Peters's ''Disturbing Signs From the Bush Team'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 15) repeats the canard that the repeal of the catastrophic health bill was the work of the wealthy elderly.
How does Mr. Peters define ''wealthy''? Elderly couples whose income from pensions and Social Security combined seldom exceeds $30,000 annually were united in opposition to the bill. Why? Their income in these inflationary times seldom leaves them much in discretionary funds. It may hardly equal the money they earned when there was far less inflation; it scarcely allows them to maintain the standard of living they enjoyed in less inflationary times. At the present cost of living, it keeps them above the poverty level, but that is all that one can honestly say. Is it any wonder that the supplemental Medicare premium was seen as discriminatory? Are the elderly required to be impoverished?
The ''greedy geezer'' rhetoric was used by members of Congress who were embarrassed by having passed a flawed bill. Failure to study the consequences of the legislation was a bipartisan failure.
Those whose annual income is far more than that of most of those ''wealthy'' retirees whom they attack should not engage in the popular sport of blaming the victim; they should rather earn their salaries by doing the work for which they were elected.
 
JOSEPH FIREBAUGH
Ann Arbor, Mich., Jan. 19, 1990

HEADLINE: How To Fight Global Warming

BYLINE: By Elliot L. Richardson; Elliot L. Richardson headed the U.S. delegation to the Law of the Sea Conference from 1977 to 1980.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Environmentalists and politicians can argue the costs and benefits of international action on global warming from now until doomsday, and they probably will. But nothing will get done without an institutional mechanism to develop, institute and enforce regulations across national boundaries.
The need for a mechanism emerged clearly from this week's meeting of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group sponsored by the United Nations. President Bush's speech at the conference, in which he called for more research on the ''uncertainty'' of global warming, may have disappointed some. But that misses the larger point. 
Little can be accomplished in the absence of multilateral institutions that will eventually carry out whatever remedial environmental actions the world community can agree upon. In short, we need an international treaty, modeled perhaps on the Law of the Sea Treaty, to coordinate and enforce international action on the environment.
Of course, many scientific questions need to be answered. We need to know the costs and benefits of various means of stopping the buildup of greenhouse gases. We need to discuss regulatory standards and cost-effective enforcement measures. Eventually, however, we will have to act.
The world cannot afford to rely on independent action by individual countries. The results are bound to be highly uneven: One nation could cut back on its carbon dioxide emissions; one could stop the destruction of its own forests; still another could do nothing. The least responsible transnational corporations will seek out and encourage the most permissive regulatory environments.
For maximum impact as well as equitable burden-sharing, there will have to be universal standards universally accepted. Deliberation about the political palatability and enforcement of these standards should be concurrent with, not subsequent to, deliberation about science and regulation.
Take, for instance, the question of whether to strengthen organizations like the United Nations Environmental Program or the International Maritime Organization, combine them or build a new one - a global Environmental Protection Agency -from scratch. Or take the question of what powers should be granted to the chosen institutions. Should these institutions be limited to formulating recommendations or should they also have the power to promulgate and enforce regulations?
Political considerations must also be discussed. Will there be a single governing body with universal representation? What kind of voting arrangement will govern its decisions - a one-nation, one-vote system like the United Nations General Assembly, a weighted system like the World Bank or Intelsat or something in between? Dispute-resolution mechanisms must be put in place.
Whether the international institution is given power to enforce rather than merely recommend regulations obviously affects representational and decision-making issues. In fact, the more power the organization will be expected to exercise and the more money it will be authorized to spend, the fiercer will be the battles.
The arena in which these battles are fought will be an international conference of some 160 sovereign states to be held in Brazil in 1992. These states will vastly differ in their contributions to environmental degradation. Their delegates will represent every race, culture, ideology, geographical circumstance and state of economic development on earth.
Given the scope and complexity of this conference's task, a thorough preparatory process is indispensable. The U.N. took four years to lay the groundwork for the Law of the Sea Conference, and the conference spent nine more years, with twice a year meetings, to produce a treaty.
The U.S. has not yet taken a prominent role in laying the groundwork for an environmental treaty. Our leadership in such effort nevertheless can make a critical difference. It is in our own interest and in that of the entire world community to take the initiative.
Our responsibility, our economic stake and our breadth of regulatory experience are unequalled. It is not too late.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 25, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 544 words

HEADLINE: The 'Half Free' Are 'Half Enslaved'

BYLINE: By Albert Gore Jr.; Albert Gore Jr., Democrat, is Senator from Tennessee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The poem was a simple, dramatic dessert to a long dinner around a table laden with delicacies rarely seen during a Soviet winter: plates full of beef and fish and a pyramid of fresh oranges.
We listened, Soviets and Americans, as Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the legendary poet of conscience, declaimed it, freezing into awed silence what had been a spirited debate about the course Soviet leaders must adopt. The poem, Mr. Yevtushenko said, was a new creation, but it was delivered with such command that it seemed to be recited from memory. He said that it would be called ''Half Measures.'' 
Our host, in an ornate room in an old Moscow restaurant, was Vitaly Korotich, editor in chief of the controversial magazine Ogonyok. He is also a member, in the Congress of People's Deputies, of the Inter-Regional Group - a loose alliance of delegates who believe perestroika will fail if Mikhail Gorbachev does not dramatically accelerate economic reform. Mr. Yevtushenko is also a delegate to the Congress, which meets at least once a year. He brings an unusual blend of poetic insight and knowledge of insider politics to his responsibilities.
When asked how virulent national rivalries and ethnic hatreds could boil over at a time of relatively unfettered political life, he spoke of a mastodon, perfectly frozen in time. Imagine, he said, that the scientific expedition that discovered the animal takes great pains to defrost it. Even if they proceed flawlessly, unseen to their eyes but thawing with the huge beast would be tiny microbes carrying ancient diseases with the ability to destroy it. Only the onset of decay would signal the microbes' presence. This is equally true of ethnic conflicts and anti-Semitism, which are now thawing along with political processes frozen for so long, Mr. Yevtushenko said.
It was while we talked of the possibility of a ''third path'' that Mr. Gorbachev might follow to lead the Soviet Union to safety that Mr. Yevtushenko's low, musical voice captivated us with ''Half Measures.''
For some, the ''third path'' involves an economic transition from the discredited ''command'' model to something approximating a free market, yet not quite capitalism. To others, it involves giving up the old imperial structure for something resembling a confederation, yet not quite entirely a union of sovereign equals. For still others, it means a society in which people need no longer lock their thoughts away in secret places, yet a society that is not quite based on the paramount value of individual rights.
The essential truth about the circumstances of the Soviet Union is conveyed in Mr. Yevtushenko's few lines. None of us in the West can presume to know how the Soviet Union can best make the excruciatingly difficult transition it is now attempting. After all, this is a society organized along lines so alien to our own that opening a McDonald's restaurant in Moscow has been accompanied by planning and economic life-support arrangements worthy of sending a mission to the moon.
It is worth appreciating, however, that many in the Soviet Union believe that the only real choice may be all or nothing: full economic and political freedom or the possibility of a return to conservatism: ''Those half free - are half enslaved.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1415 words

HEADLINE: THE TALK OF CAMDEN;
A City in Pain Hopes for Relief Under Florio

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
When people here talk about the future, they do so in a most guarded manner. ''I wouldn't call it anticipation,'' said the Rev. Michael Doyle, the pastor of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic parish, who has worked among Camden's poor for 21 years. ''But there's a general feeling that things are going to improve. Or at least that they won't get any worse.''
Rosemary R. Jackson, executive director of the Camden Urban Women's Center, said, ''So many things have been promised to Camden. I hope we don't get more of what we've been getting for the last 30 years.''
There is reason for a trace of hope in this poorest of American cities. 
A $42 million state aquarium is taking shape on the Delaware River waterfront. The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority is wooing two of Philadelphia's major-league teams, the 76ers and Flyers, promising to build an arena in Camden if they agree to move across the river.
Perhaps most important, Camden's Congressman for 15 years, Jim Florio, is now governor, and its mayor for three terms, Melvin R. Primas Jr., is Mr. Florio's commissioner of community affairs. While offering no specifics, Governor Florio has vowed to make Camden an urban laboratory for trying new ways to overcome the old problems of poverty, unemployment and despair.
Driving along any of the city's streets reveals how much still is wrong. And there is a chance that things could get still worse. The city's most prominent resident, the Campbell Soup Company, is undergoing a restructuring that has prompted speculation about a takeover. It is re-examining all existing plans, including one to build a new international headquarters on the waterfront. Next month it will shut down its old Market Street plant, ending nearly a century of food production in Camden.
But some people here say that if anything managed in any way to turn around Camden, it would be a victory for urban areas everywhere.
They say that this city is so poor, so devastated by drugs and crime, so bereft of the qualities that make a place a community, that if Camden can be saved, any city can.
 
Rust on the Soup Can
The water towers atop the seven-story building are painted in the familiar red and white of a Campbell soup can. But they are streaked with rust, and the old factory on which they stand looks like the remnant of another age that it is.
It was on this spot in 1897 that condensed soup was invented. And it will be here next month that the last jar of Prego spaghetti sauce, another Campbell product, will come off the factory line as the plant is closed. Some 940 workers will lose their jobs. The closing was announced last August, a few months after the death of John T. Dorrance Jr., whose family owns 58 percent of the company. Campbell's director of community relations, Jeremiah F. O'Brien, said the plant was just too old and inefficient.
As part of Camden's efforts to revive its waterfront, Campbell had agreed to build a 20-story office building alongside the aquarium and a planned hotel. Now those plans are being reviewed.
Campbell is still planning $45 million in improvements to its adminstrative offices, where 1,800 people work. And while the company is no longer the center around which this city revolves, Mr. O'Brien, who has worked here since 1956, said Campbell is not abandoning Camden.
''If anything,'' he said, ''we'll become more involved in some type of human service or community interest activity.'' One possible project could be to work with local schools to make sure students get the training they need to fill corporate jobs.
''We're here, and we're concerned,'' he said.
 
No Warmup to be Mayor
The day after Aaron A. Thompson was sworn in as interim mayor, succeeding Mr. Primas, a group of ministers marched on City Hall. They charged that Mr. Thompson had been selected by the City Council because he was a puppet of the Democratic bosses. A 59-year-old retired telephone serviceman, he had been a councilman for only six months.
Mr. Thompson defends his qualifications, citing his long involvement in Camden's neighborhoods, mostly in volunteer or ward positions.
''In this seat has sat a plumber, a judge, a lawyer, a high school dropout and a degree man,'' he said, slapping the swivel chair in the mayor's office. ''There is no preparation to be mayor. Not this seat.'' Mr. Thompson said he expected to be able to get the ear of the Governor and the Commissioner of Community Affairs when he needed to, but he did not expect Mr. Florio and Mr. Primas to give Camden special privileges.
''They've got responsibility for all the communities now,'' he said. ''They can't just worry about Camden. But they know Camden well and their hearts are here.''
 
Wooing Flyers and 76ers
The state owns 100 acres of riverfront, now used by the South Jersey Port Corporation. Some months back, under Gov. Thomas H. Kean, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority started trying to interest the Philadelphia 76ers and Flyers in crossing the Delaware and playing in an arena the state would build.
At a news conference last week, Governor Florio said he supported bringing over the teams. But neither he nor the sports authority would give any details of the negotiations.
In Pennsylvania, Gov. Robert P. Casey and Mayor W. Wilson Goode say they have made their best offer for keeping the teams, which now play in the 23-year-old Spectrum. But they, too, won't discuss details.
They have expressed pique at New Jersey for not putting its offer in writing, and there have been suggestions that the teams were playing one state off the other. The owners deny it.
In Camden itself, people seem to be divided over whether having the 76ers and Flyers cross the river would be good for the city. Some believe it would boost Camden's image, but others say most residents will neither get jobs at a new arena nor be able to afford tickets to go there.
''Nobody's saying hip-hip-hooray about it,'' said Miss Jackson of the women's center. ''People here know it's not for them.''
 
'It's Not Good Here'
Camden must still bear the burden of its statistics: unemployment tops 12 percent, more than half of its high school students drop out, 61 percent of its children live in poverty, with the rest never far from it. The city has about 80,000 people, down from over 120,000 in the 1960's.
''There's too much fighting, too much drugs,'' said seven-year-old Maria Christina Feliciano, who was spending a few minutes outside with her mother and sister before going in for the night.
Next her family's blistering two-story rowhouse on Clinton Street is an empty lot, and next to that, abandoned buildings, spilling over with garbage. A rooster crowed as Maria Christina said she will leave when she grows up. ''It's not good here.''
A few blocks away, outside the new Camden County jail, Tracey Best stood with a cluster of young women using hand signals and gestures to talk with their men inside the jail. They spell out letters, sometimes using abbreviations for frequent words like ''what'' and ''you.'' Pressed to windows that don't open, the men sign back.
Miss Best, 25, the unmarried mother of two, said she didn't know whether having Mr. Florio and Mr. Primas in Trenton would help Camden, but she hoped it would. She said she wished Governor Florio could know just how bad it is on the street.
''We don't go out at night,'' she said, rocking her year-old daughter, Bianca, in a stroller. ''Everybody's strung out.''
 
Invincibility Still a Dream
The gray stone of City Hall still bears the inscription ''In a dream I saw a city invincible.'' It is from ''Leaves of Grass,'' which Walt Whitman finished in Camden. It is a phrase used frequently here, a mantra for a whole city.
Where the inscription leaves off is important, for what came after ''invincible'' was ''to the attacks of the whole rest of the earth.''
Camden has suffered attacks of fear, of racism, of disinvestment, of time. It has not proved invincible. But it may yet prove to be ''the new city of friends'' Whitman dreamed of, especially, say people like Lucy Aveni, if its friends in Trenton don't forget it.
''It was a pleasure to live around here,'' said Miss Aveni, a surprising 75, and even more surprising 44-year resident of the same neat rowhouse where she was washing windows and even the electric meter on a recent afternoon. ''Now I'm afraid. I don't even sit outside in the summer anymore. But maybe it'll be different.''

LENGTH: 455 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Hard Work As Closing Of Classes Approaches

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Last August, Katherine R. Stearns came to classes at the Mercer University branch here despite casts on both feet. Another student, Geri S. Brown, quit a part-time job to increase her class load from 15 hours a quarter to 25 hours.
Both women say it was desperation, not love of learning, that drove them: they must complete their degrees by June 30, because that is when Mercer's trustees will close the Cecil B. Day College of Arts and Sciences here. 
Earlier this month, a DeKalb County Superior Court jury ruled that all the college's students and faculty have the right to recover damages from Mercer for what it decided was ''bad faith'' on the trustees' part. It said Mercer's rules required the trustees to consult the faculty before making a decision to close the arts and sciences college, and it also said Mercer breached its contract with the college's students.
Seven students, including Ms. Stearns and Mrs. Brown, filed a lawsuit on behalf of 465 others enrolled at the college. Separately, five faculty members filed suit for 57 colleagues who may lose their appointments when the college closes.
 
Goal Pushed Back
''Our ultimate goal in filing suit was to keep the college of arts and sciences open,'' Ms. Stearns said. ''From a financial standpoint, we were attempting to make it more economically sound for them to keep the school open than to pay the damages and close it.''
Mrs. Brown, 41 years old, said she could transfer her credit hours to another university, but other schools have told her that she must retake several courses she completed at Mercer toward her education major.
Mrs. Brown said she had hoped to be teaching by 1991, but thought that goal was now out of reach.
Mercer, affiliated with the Southern Baptist Convention, is more than 150 years old and has its main campus in Macon, Ga. In 1972 it took over a small, struggling Baptist college in Atlanta that had failed to win academic accreditation after almost a decade in existence. Mercer then used the campus for the arts and sciences college, a school of pharmacy and a graduate school of business and economics.
University administrators gave several reasons for the closing. ''It was not purely money,'' said Mercer's general counsel, Corinne A. Houpt. ''I think for most of the trustees the overall financial condition of the university was the trigger for the need to make a decision.''
 
'Unique Case' in U.S. Education
Ms. Houpt said Judge Carol W. Hunstein of DeKalb Superior Court had ruled that students and faculty members were not entitled to an injunction to prevent the closing, which she said would happen as scheduled.
Mercer announced last April 21 that the arts and sciences college would close.

SECTION: Section B; Page 6, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 763 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Milwaukee Plans a College Guarantee for Pupils

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
This city is pledging to guarantee a spot in college, with financial aid, if needed, for any student in the city who graduates from high school with at least a C-plus average.
Or for those who want to learn a skill, the city would make certain that training was provided, along with a job afterward.
''I want that guarantee to go out to every youngster in our school system as soon as possible,'' Mayor John Norquist said recently. ''They need to know and believe that somebody is behind them and that hard work and achievement will be rewarded.'' 
The Milwaukee Guarantee, as it has been named, is the latest measure by a big city to join with business in making specific promises of education, training and jobs to students who meet a certain standard. About a dozen cities, including Boston, Detroit and Baltimore, have similar programs.
And Rhode Island plans to start a program next year that gives third graders the option of signing a contract aimed at strengthening their resolve to stay in school. If the children do so and do not become pregnant and stay off drugs, they will be given a scholarship to a public university or college in that state after graduation.
In New York, the Liberty Partnership Program links colleges and universities with elementary and high schools around the state. The university provides counseling, tutoring, testing and visits with children considered at risk of dropping out of school.
 
Business Leaders Involved
In Milwaukee, the pledge buttresses a campaign by business leaders that provides one-on-one tutoring for elementary school pupils deemed at risk of dropping out of school. The business leaders also provide awards of $500 each to about 30 teachers annually who have been chosen as superior.
Officials here concede that the odds facing inner-city pupils are daunting. Days after the Mayor's announcement, The Milwaukee Sentinel published a school system report showing that 11.5 percent of black male pupils were held back this school year. According to the report, only 22 percent of black boys attained a cumulative grade-point average of at least 2.0, a C average. Only 2.2 percent attained a grade point of 3.0, a B average, or better.
With unemployment rates below 5 percent here, business leaders have complained recently of a dire shortage of trained workers.
''Business has a strong self-interest in seeing that these students - the future employees - are better trained,'' said Robert H. Milbourne, executive director of the Greater Milwaukee Committee, a consortium of business and civic leaders here. ''We are increasingly finding that employers are desperately in need of trained workers.''
Few details of the Milwaukee plan have been worked out. A group of business, labor, education and political leaders will meet next week to begin studying the proposal.
Mayor Norquist has said he wants to avoid a major expenditure of tax money for the program and will seek financial help from business and industry.
Officials at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee are hopeful about the plan.
 
'Need for More Counseling'
''It's a great idea, but it's not going to be an easy issue,'' said Frank Cassell, dean of the School of Social Policy at the university. ''The fees are going to have to be paid for those students. They may need special help, so there will be a need for more counseling.''
Moreover, he said the school would not want to compromise its standards. ''This is an urban university, but it's also a research university,'' he said. ''It has very high standards. And the worst possible thing would be to simply let in a lot of young people who would quickly fail.''
For now, Wisconsin residents who graduate in the upper half of their high school class are admitted to the school. Indeed, those who achieve a C-plus average are, in most cases, already accepted at the school.
But Milwaukee officials believe that the prospect of a written guarantee of college would improve pupils' motivation in early grades.
''It's the message that's most important here,'' said James H. Miller, executive director of the Wisconsin Policy Research Institute, a private group. ''My impression is that C-plus students from the inner city can already get into college. But if they don't understand that, early on, it doesn't matter until it's too late. There is something important about a guarantee. It's tangible.''
Of the 98,000 pupils in Milwaukee public schools, about 70 percent are minority members and about 60 percent live at or near the poverty level, according to school officials.

The city has pledged to guarantee a place in college or in a vocational training program for any student who graduates from high school with a C-plus average or better. (Milwaukee Journal/Richard Bauer)

HEADLINE: Bernard Bernstein, Aide to Eisenhower In 40's, Dies at 81

 BODY:
Bernard Bernstein, a lawyer and Treasury Department official who was a financial adviser to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in World War II, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan. 
Mr. Bernstein was one of a group of finance officers identified with Treasury Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr., who pressed for hard-line proposals in dealing with postwar Germany. But career military officers and State Department officials who favored softer treatment, particularly on economic issues, prevailed.
When his faction lost, Mr. Bernstein, an Army colonel, was removed from the Control Commission for Germany and put in charge of investigating cartels. He soon requested a return to civilian status.
Mr. Bernstein was born in New York. He had bachelor's and law degrees from Columbia University. After practicing law, he joined the legal staff of the Treasury Department in 1933. He was promoted to assistant general counsel in 1938, and from 1940 to 1942 he administered foreign funds.
After the war Mr. Bernstein was a legal adviser to the American Jewish Conference and was chairman of a committee of Jewish organizations dealing with proposals for treaties with enemy countries. He continued practicing law until his death.
Surviving are his wife, the former Bernice Lotwin; three daughters, Elinor Balka of Forest Hills, Queens, Dr. Kate Bernstein of Manhattan and Anne Chesnin of Seattle; a brother, Hilliard, and a sister, Blanche, both of Manhattan, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:

A Mandela Life
Harper & Row said yesterday that it was rushing publication of ''Higher Than Hope,'' the authorized biography of Nelson Mandela. Mr. Mandela, the longtime leader of the African National Congress, is scheduled to be released soon after 27 years' imprisonment in South Africa.
The author is Fatima Meer, who teaches sociology at the University of Natal in South Africa, and whose friendship with Mr. Mandela dates to the 1950's. The manuscript was approved by Mr. Mandela, and his wife, Winnie Mandela, has written the book's foreword. Harper's publisher, William Shinker - who acquired the book at the Frankfurt Book Fair in 1988 - said that Professor Meer had had exclusive access to Mr. Mandela, as well as his correspondence and close associates in the African National Congress. 
A first printing of 50,000 copies is planned, and Harper expects to begin shipping books the first week in March.
 
More About Gotti
John Gotti, the reputed Mafia leader, continues to fascinate authors and publishers. In 1988, Gene Mustain and Jerry Capeci wrote a book about him, titled ''Mob Star'' (Franklin Watts). Now two more Gotti biographies are planned for publication by this summer.
The first, ''Goombata: The Improbable Rise and Fall of John Gotti,'' by John Cummings and Ernest Volkman, will be published in April by Little, Brown. Since the book is already at the printer, it will not include the verdict in the current trial in Manhattan State Supreme Court in which Mr. Gotti has been charged with assault and conspiracy in the shooting of a union official.
''But we feel it's more important to have the book out now, to benefit from the trial publicity, rather than wait for the verdict,'' said Jennifer Josephy, the book's editor. ''And the subtitle indicates the authors feel that Gotti is headed for a fall.'' Ms. Josephy emphasized that the contract for the book was signed in December 1987, not written to capitalize on the trial.
The other forthcoming biography, ''Sleeping the Good Sleep: The Life and Times of John Gotti,'' by Doug Feiden, is to be published by Random House in August. While the book is likely to include the verdict, which is expected soon, ''it doesn't hinge on the verdict,'' said David Rosenthal, the book's editor.
The authors of both books had previously written competing books about the multi-million-dollar robbery from the Lufthansa Air Cargo terminal at John F. Kennedy Airport in 1978.
 
For Managers of Chaos
On Monday, Mikhail S. Gorbachev talked about economic reform in a speech to the Communist Party's governing Central Committee. Less than 24 hours later, Carol Janeway, the director of international rights for Alfred A. Knopf, received an inquiry by fax from VAAP, the Soviet copyright agency, ''urgently inquiring'' whether Russian language rights are available to Thomas J. Peters's book, ''Thriving on Chaos.''
Ms. Janeway responded within the hour that rights to the book, whose subtitle is ''Handbook For a Management Revolution,'' were indeed available.
 
Home to Britain
Derek Johns, who last November was appointed editorial director of Times Books, part of Random House, has decided to return to Britain. He said yesterday that his family preferred to live in England but that he would remain a consultant to Random House and to Times Books.

HEADLINE: For Sears's Discover, Next Step Is Harder

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 6

 BODY:
In the rough-and-tumble world of credit cards, Sears, Roebuck & Company's Discover has been the card with nine lives.
Competitors predicted that Discover, introduced in 1986, would go to an early grave, unable to attract enough consumers in a market glutted with Visas and Mastercards. But Discover officials signed up more than 20 million people in the first two years alone. When skeptics predicted the card would fail because merchants would balk, thousands of stores accepted it virtually from the start.
And while Wall Street analysts said Sears would grow despondent over Discover's deep initial losses and close the operation before it had a chance to prove itself, Discover broke into the black in the first quarter of 1988. On Monday, Discover reported that its profit had more than tripled last year, to $80.2 million. 
But those accomplishments may seem easy compared with the task the Discover organization now faces: proving that it can make enough money to justify Sears's $1 billion investment.
Even top Discover officials acknowledge that for the card not to be considered a big waste of the shareholders' money, profits must rise to at least $150 million a year. That Discover's profits are not even close to that, industry experts say, is proof that the card is far from the blockbuster success that Sears had hoped for.
 
A Needed Boost
Still, Discover's progress has been welcome news at Sears's headquarters here. With the company's core retailing operation in the throes of an overhaul that is eroding earnings, Sears executives need the boost that Discover is providing. The card group is proving to be particularly helpful to the results of Dean Witter Reynolds, the Sears subsidiary that contains Discover. The financial services subsidiary reported that Discover accounted for just under half of its 1989 earnings.
Considering that Discover did not exist five years ago, many industry analysts consider it remarkable that the card has made it as far as it has. By relying on the existing base of Sears credit-card customers, the Greenwood Trust Company, the Sears-owned bank in Wilmington, Del., that issues Discover, has been able to place 33 million cards in more than 20 million households. That represents more than 20 percent of American homes.
In fact, by adding Discover, Greenwood Trust has surpassed Citibank as the largest card-issuing bank in the country, measured by the number of cards. And with customers owing $8.5 billion on their cards nationwide, Discover has clearly grabbed business from banks issuing Mastercard and Visa.
 
'One of the Great Success Stories'
After suffering combined losses of $230 million in 1986 and 1987, Discover reported profits of $26.8 million in 1988 and $80.2 million last year. Some 1.1 million stores and restaurants now accept Discover, which amounts to about two-thirds of the merchants who take credit cards.
''The Discover card is one of the great success stories in financial services in the 1980's,'' said Mark Kamm of SMR Research, a consulting firm in Budd Lake, N.J.
''Sears has done a fantastic job of getting the card into people's wallets,'' added Bruce J. Brittain, president of an Atlanta consulting firm that has tracked Discover.
There are several reasons that achieving much higher profits will not be easy for Discover, and some of those reasons have to do with the card's success so far. While Sears has succeeded in getting Discover cards into consumers' hands, the acceptance reflects that card holders pay no annual fee and receive annual cash rebates of up to 1 percent of their total charges.
 
Negative Reaction to Fee
Consumers reacted negatively in two states where Discover officials, unable to charge the card's full 19.8 percent annual interest rate, imposed a $15 annual card fee. Other research shows that most card holders say they would cancel Discover rather than pay a fee.
And people are not charging merchandise on the card with anywhere near the frequency necessary to give Discover a larger piece of the charge-card pie. Analysts say persuading people to use the card more will be a lot harder than getting them to take a card.
''It will be very tough given the competition,'' said Michael Blumstein, a financial-services analyst at the First Boston Corporation. He contrasted it to the bright ''use me'' image of American Express, which, he said, ''has screamed, 'Don't leave home without it' so many times that people don't dare.''
 
A Big Job Ahead
Thomas R. Butler, president and chief operating officer of Discover Card Services Inc., acknowledges the job ahead, saying, ''We have to add some additional value features that will make people use our card.''
Even as Discover officials work to increase use of their card, other perils remain. A recession could send Discover's percentage of uncollectible accounts, now one of the industry's lowest, soaring. Higher interest rates could squeeze the profit Discover earns on the difference between what it pays for money and the 19.8 percent it charges card holders on unpaid balances. That rate is already above the industry average.
Perhaps because Discover is a relatively new card, nearly 10 million, 30 percent, of the 33 million Discover cards in circulation have either never been used or have not had charges made on them in months. At Visa, with 120 million cards, and Mastercard, with 85 million, inactive cards amount to about 20 percent of the total.
 
Lower Outstanding Balances
Discover also trails the competition in average balances outstanding. The average owed on a Discover card is $750; the comparable figures for Visa and Mastercard are $1,223 and $1,230 respectively. And while the typical customer charges $1,500 a year on a Discover card, for Visa and Mastercard the figure is nearly $2,000. Comparisons with the American Express basic card are difficult, because it is not really a charge card that encourages consumers to carry monthly balances on which they pay interest.
Low usage would be less of a problem at the other card companies than at Discover. The reason is that unlike American Express and banks issuing Mastercard and Visa, which receive up to $75 a year in fee income from each of their cards, Sears receives no such income from Discover. And the commission that store owners pay Discover on credit sales is generally about 2 percent, compared with 2.5 percent or more for Mastercard and Visa and 4 percent or more for American Express.
Discover's profitability, in short, is heavily dependent on card holders' running up large amounts, then incurring hefty interest charges by not paying their bills in full.
 
Effort to Gain Merchants
''Merchants are not giving the card the same acceptance as Visa and Mastercard, and shoppers are still reaching for other cards first,'' said George Rosenbaum, president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a Chicago research firm that has also tracked Discover. ''These are big barriers that are not overcome overnight.''
But Mr. Butler, Discover's chief executive, is convinced that, over time, Discover can be as popular as Visa and Mastercard. Believing that shoppers will use their cards more if given the chance, he has been on a campaign to increase the number of merchants accepting Discover. The card is accepted at many well-known stores, including Saks Fifth Avenue, the Dayton Hudson department-store chain in the Middle West, and the Sharper Image, the purveyor of high-tech gadgetry based in San Francisco.
Although there are many conspicuous holdouts, including J. C. Penney, Federated Department Stores, Macy's and Walmart Stores, the card recently passed a milestone when the one-millionth merchant accepted Discover.
Discover officials have also developed programs making it easier for merchants to use the card, through ways of getting money to merchants, providing them with information on customers and lowering the merchant commission charge at stores where Discover volume is high.
 
Promotions to Card Holders
Discover has also been attacking the usage problem by going directly to card holders. Advertising of the annual rebate has been stepped up. But the maximum 1 percent rebate applies only on purchases that total more than $3,000, way above what most Discover card holders are spending. On total puchases of $1,000, the amount returned is $2.50.
To encourage Saks customers to use their Discover cards, the card group recently offered 10 percent off on all Saks purchases appearing on Discover bills. Mr. Butler says more promotions can be expected.
The lack of an annual fee has produced strong ''response rates,'' with roughly 5 percent of customers who are solicited to apply for a Discover card ending up receiving one. Industry response rates average 1.5 percent. The high response rate, in turn, has lowered Discover's customer acquisition costs, as has Discover's use of Sears's existing bill-processing centers. Equally important, because Sears processes all Discover transactions, Discover does not incur the 1.5 percent fee that banks charge to process one another's Visa and Mastercard transactions.
 
Debate Over Fees
''These are the reasons we seem to defy gravity and make money when others said it could not be done,'' said William H. Hodges, the former Citibank credit-card executive who now runs marketing at Discover.
But for Discover to earn the big returns it needs, many industry experts argue that it will have to impose an annual fee. By charging, say, $15 a year, Discover's 33 million cards would bring in nearly $500 million. Since most of that additional revenue would flow directly to the card operation's bottom line, Discover's profit could be increased strikingly.
But when Sears imposed a $15 fee in North Carolina and Wisconsin, because laws on interest rate ceilings in those states prevented it from charging 19.8 percent, many Discover holders cut their cards in half.
So for now, Mr. Butler says that there are no plans to impose a fee and that his group will continue to focus on getting customers to choose Discover.
''My guess is that next year we will be at an acceptable rate of return, and beyond that our returns will be better than acceptable,'' he said.

LENGTH: 896 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Investors Rush to Bid For Notes

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The first leg of the Treasury's $30 billion quarterly refunding auctions received a thunderous welcome from investors yesterday. More than $34 billion worth of bids were placed for the $10 billion worth of three-year notes that were sold.
Bidding by Japanese investors was particularly intense, dealers said.
The total size of the bids, which in Wall Street parlance is known as the ''cover,'' was the largest for an auction of three-year notes since the auction of August 1987, credit market analysts said. 
 
Yield Up Sharply
At the auction, the notes were sold at an average yield of 8.43 percent, up sharply from the 7.77 percent average yield on the three-year notes sold at the last auction, on Nov. 9.
The Japanese, who normally eschew such short-term shorter-term maturities at these auctions, placed bids on about half the issue, or more.
Individual investors and smaller commercial banks, seeking to take advantage of recent sharp increases in interest rates, placed nearly $1.2 billion worth of noncompetitive bids for the new securities, meaning they would take the issue at whatever price and interest rate the average bid produced.
''Bids from Japanese houses could well have exceeded half the issue,'' said Gib Clark, a senior vice president and head trader at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''But the actual award will probably be more like 35 percent'' of the total, he added.
Despite the size of the bidding from Japan, Mr. Clark and others said that unless interest rates rise further, the Japanese are unlikely to be active participants when the 10-year notes and 30-year bonds are offered at auctions scheduled today and tomorrow.
 
Effect of Higher Japanese Rates
''At these yield levels, I think this says that Japanese interest has been spent on the three-year,'' he said. ''But if the yield on the long bond gets above 8 5/8, that could spark some demand since it improves the spread to the yen bond market.''
Interest rates have been moving up in Japan for much of the last month, narrowing the advantage that dollar-denominated interest rates have generally enjoyed.
Robert G. Graustein, a managing director at Sanwa-BGK Securities Company L.P., said ''there is always some participation'' from Japanese investors at the 10-year and 30-year auctions.
''But right now we are not looking for an overwhelming bid,'' he said. ''What we saw at the three-year auction may be illustrative of a new tack by Japanese investors to stay away from the longer-term securities.''
Late yesterday, the 10-year notes to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.54 percent. Meanwhile, the 30-year bonds were offered late in the day in when-issued trading at 8.54 percent.
 
Selling of Outstanding Issues
In what could be a portent of today's market activity, after the results of yesterday's auction were announced at about 3:30 P.M. selling accelerated in the outstanding 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes and 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds.
Those issues posted the biggest price declines in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 94 3/32, down half a point, or $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.58 percent, up from 8.52 percent late Monday.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes fell 11/32, to a late offered price of 95 14/32, to yield 8.57 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 1/2, down 3/32, to yield 8.40 percent.
 
Treasury Bill Rates Mixed
Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.78 percent, down 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Rates on six-month bills rose 1 basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.71 percent.
In the corporate bond market, no new issues were priced yesterday, as corporate treasurers were unwilling to compete with the Treasury for investors.
''Nobody wants to get in the way of the Government,'' one investment banker said.
Prices of secondary issues of investment-grade corporate bonds fell in line with those of Treasury notes and bonds. Actively traded intermediate-term securities dipped by a range of one-eighth point to one-quarter point, while long-term bonds fell by about one-half point.
 
Sale of California Bonds
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was dominated by a competitive sale of $425 million of general obligation bonds from the State of California.
A bid from an syndicate led by Bank of America won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2010.
The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 5.50 percent on bonds maturing in 1991, to 7 percent in 2010.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Will Federated's Chief Have Time?

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
At the helm of Bullock's five years ago, Allen I. Questrom ordered the West Coast department store chain to pull out of a data exchange through which competing chains tracked short-term shifts in market share. He warned his merchandisers and buyers to think of the long term because short-term gains mean little in the life of any business.
The advice epitomizes the strategy of Mr. Questrom, who left Neiman Marcus last week to become the chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation, the financially troubled divisions of the Campeau Corporation.
Given his outlook, some people who know him well are wondering whether he will have the opportunity to apply it at a company that within months must develop a bankruptcy reorganization plan that satisfies creditors.
 
'A Tough Case'
''It's a case where a long-term thinker will also have to worry about paying the daily bills and have all the creditors looking over his shoulder; it's a tough case,'' said Michael Gould, president and chief executive of Giorgio Beverly Hills, the cosmetic producer in Los Angeles. The chairman of the J. W. Robinson Company when Mr. Questrom was at Bullock's, Mr. Gould said: ''I really don't know if he can do it, although I am certain he knows what should be done.'' 
Left to his own devices, Mr. Questrom, who is 49 years old, has carried out similar plans throughout a career spent mostly at Federated. ''His pattern of operation is similar wherever he goes,'' said Norman Matthews, a former president of Federated Department Stores and now a consultant and investor. ''He doesn't believe in a constant round of price cutting. He's a long-term player who will do what's necessary to bring inventory, taste level and physical conditions of the stores up to where they should be. I expect him to do that at Federated.'' Asked what he would most apply from his experience, Mr. Questrom said in an interview yesterday: ''I have not been responsible for any breakthroughs in retailing, just a deep conviction that fundamentals are what count, like having the proper merchandise, fresh, clean inventories and good service. It's when we have to give up on those fundamentals that we run into trouble.''
Federated and Allied, the two American retailing arms of Federated Stores Inc., the American holding company for the Campeau Corporation of Toronto, filed for bankruptcy protection on Jan. 15 saying they had debts of $7.5 billion. The stores include Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and Abraham & Straus.
Clearly, Federated Stores faces enormous difficulties.
To satisfy creditors, its 260 stores must develop a strategy to produce stronger revenue and profit while making their operations more economical. In trying to reach that goal, Mr. Questrom will work with G. William Miller, an investment banker and former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board who is the chairman of Federated Stores. He will also work with James M. Zimmerman, the president and chief operating officer.
Among their choices are whether Bloomingdale's should be taken off the market and sold later if better bids develop, or not be sold at all. Should other divisions be put on the block? What of marginal stores? And, above all, can Federated Stores be refinanced so that its more urgent debt needs are met?
 
Will Aid in Credibility
Because of Federated Stores' immense problems, some retail executives think Mr. Miller and Mr. Questrom were hired more for their public relations value than for any miracle aid they can provide. Mr. Questrom headed two of Federated's best-known divisions, Rich's and Bullock's, the latter of which has since been sold to R. H. Macy & Company.
Their selection will go a long way to creating new credibility for Federated at a time when its stores need fresh merchandise and sympathetic creditors.
Mr. Questrom is expected to guide Federated Stores away from a policy of price-cutting promotions to an emphasis on more fashionable goods at higher prices, which would provide increased profit margins.
When he arrived at both Rich's and Bullock's, he found that the emphasis was on price cutting and on moderate-priced apparel. He changed the approach to higher quality and stressed ''congruity'' of merchandise. As Mr. Matthews put it: '' 'Congruity' in his lexicon meant that a woman who bought a dress for $200 should not be offered $29 shoes but should be offered much more fashionable shoes at $70 to $100. He just wouldn't allow any gap in the taste level.''
 
The '88 Resignation
Given his long-term strategies, it is not surprising that Mr. Questrom resigned from Federated to become president and chief executive at Neiman Marcus in 1988 when he feared that Federated would have to arrange a leveraged buyout to counter the takeover threat from Campeau at the time. Leveraging the company would increase the push on short-term gains or volume for volume's sake, he feared. It was not his view of what the retailing business should be.
Mr. Questrom said his immediate objective now was to visit all the store divisions in the next month and meet with suppliers. ''We are focusing on deliveries of merchandise and making progress there,'' he said. ''About 111 of our top 117 suppliers have resumed shipping to us and we think that is good.''
He said he would stress ''good day-to-day running of the business, which means taking care of the customer in a manner that will make us the best.'' He added that Federated has nine store divisions that ''were well keyed into their markets; but this was disrupted by the financial problems that developed.'' He added, ''We want to get back to what made us good before that happened.''
 
'Pep Rally'
Yesterday, at the company's Cincinnati headquarters, Mr. Questrom met with the chairmen and presidents of the nine store divisions in what was described as both a welcoming session and pep rally.''
The evening before, at a dinner with the group, he told them he had not returned for the money - he will receive about $12 million in a five-year contract - but to respond to the challenge of helping the company survive. ''From the moment I turned down the job two weeks ago, Federated people have been calling me in Dallas to ask me to change my mind,'' he said at the dinner.
Two women influenced his decision, he told the executives. One was Gladys Lazarus, the widow of Ralph Lazarus, a former chairman and chief executive of Federated, whose father, Fred Jr., founded the company in 1926. ''If you don't take this job, Allen, you will always wonder if you couldn't have made a difference,'' Mrs. Lazarus said. ''Besides, there are 100,000 employees whose future could depend upon you.''
 
A Wife's Advice
He discussed that plea with his wife, Kelli, and said he was taken aback when she said: ''You know, when you become successful at any job, what happens to you? You become cranky and you put on weight. That's what's happening now. Take the job!''
A native of Massachusetts, Mr. Questrom started his career in 1965 on the executive training squad at Abraham & Straus, and in eight years advanced to merchandise manager. After running both Rich's and Bullock's, he added to his top post at Bullock's an executive vice presidency at Federated in 1987. In May 1988 he became a vice chairman. When Campeau acquired Federated, it wanted to appoint him chairman, but he left for Neiman Marcus.
Mr. Questrom and his wife frequently visit restaurants and museums, where they study what people eat, wear, watch and buy. Mr. Questrom, who says his wife has been a major influence on him, credits her with ''dragging me to events to make sure I get exposed to them.''

HEADLINE: Bush Calls For Some Regulation

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
In the most thorough presentation of his economic views since he took office, President Bush today embraced the mainstream Republican philosophy of reliance on private initiatives and market forces. But his first Economic Report to Congress did not have the ideological edge of those submitted by Ronald Reagan.
For example, where Mr. Reagan insisted uniformly on less Government participation in economic and business affairs, Mr. Bush advocated greater Federal involvement in such areas as child care, education, basic research and environmental protection.
''In some cases,'' the President declared, ''well-designed regulation can serve the public interest.''
Moreover, where the Reagan reports were often sharply critical of the Federal Reserve, blaming the central bank for whatever woes the economy was facing at the time, Mr. Bush endorsed the Fed's policies. 
 
'Inflation Must Be Controlled'
''I strongly support the Federal Reserve's goal of noninflationary growth and share with them the conviction that inflation must be controlled and reduced in a predictable fashion,'' he said.
The President predicted ''strong, sustained economic growth'' in the years ahead but said the economy's ''potential'' must be ''more often fully utilized than in previous decades.''
Mr. Bush's Economic Report and the accompanying report by his Council of Economic Advisers, both of which are required by law, broke no new ground in terms of policy proposals. But the documents provided the economic rationale behind many of the policies detailed last month in the President's budget and State of the Union Message.
 
Cautious on Promises
Perhaps seeking to justify his Administration's lack of bold new initiatives, Mr. Bush said, ''The American people are ill served by promises that cannot be kept.''
His ''primary goal,'' the President said, ''is to achieve the highest possible rate of sustainable economic growth.''
To that end, he set forth five ambitious, if general, principles that he said guided his economic policies: to achieve a budget surplus so that Government borrowing can be reduced; to support a monetary policy that insures maximum economic growth while reducing inflation; to reform the tax, legal and regulatory systems; to design regulations that do not impede market forces, and to promote freer trade worldwide.
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, who was primarily responsible for preparing today's report, said Mr. Bush ''stays actively informed about the economy.''
The President, Mr. Boskin said, was particularly concerned that the report emphasize the view that a strong economy and an improved environment are not conflicting goals.
In his report, Mr. Bush called strengthening the Clean Air Act ''one of my top legislative priorities.''
The President did not mention in his report the caution he expressed on Monday, in a speech to an international environmental group, when he warned against steps to counteract global warming if such steps might damage the economy. But his economic advisers discussed the reasoning behind the President's position, saying that important scientific uncertainties needed to be resolved before costly moves were made to produce small reductions in carbon dioxide emissions.
Mr. Boskin is an Administration insider who advised Mr. Bush on economic matters during the 1988 election campaign and is influential now in policy making. That is in sharp contrast with the role of economic advisers in the previous Administration. During the Reagan years, the economic advisers were often scorned and almost always ignored.
The other members of Mr. Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, who re participated in writing the report, are John B. Taylor, also of Stanford, and Richard L. Schmalensee of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 
Accent on the Positive
Mr. Bush emphasized the positive characteristics of the economy of the 1980's - strong overall growth, an increase in employment and steady inflation rates. He did not mention an aspect his Democratic opponents have seized on - the shift in the tax burden away from the wealthy and toward the middle class.
He said he was committed to the low income tax rates and broadened tax base enacted in the last decade, but he said a reduction in the capital gains tax rate was one of his ''highest legislative priorities.''
Opponents of a capital gains tax cut believe such a cut violates the fundamental principles of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
Among the other points in Mr. Bush's report and the more detailed one prepared by his economic advisers are these:
* The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law should be extended as an end in itself, rather than a measure of last resort.
* The Government no longer needs to worry about whether enough jobs are available for workers but must shift its focus to whether there will be enough skilled workers to fill the available jobs in this decade.
* Industrial policy and protectionism are detrimental to economic growth and should be avoided.
* A ''fundamental reassessment'' should be made of financial regulations to take account of new banking and market practices.
 
Would Extend Gramm-Rudman
Mr. Bush and his economists stressed the Administration's proposal to extend the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, requiring annual targets for spending and revenues, through the end of the decade so that an overall budget surplus could be attained and a start made on cutting the Government's $3 trillion debt. The law now would expire in 1993.
In the past, the law has been viewed as an unpleasant alternative to invoke when Congress and the President could not agree on budget terms. In his report today, Mr. Bush did not mention working with Congress on the budget.
Mr. Boskin said this was the first time to his knowledge that a President in his Economic Report had specifically advocated a budget surplus. Mr. Bush said it would turn the Government into ''a saver, providing funds for capital formation and economic growth by reducing the national debt.''
The Administration maintains that if its policies are followed and economic growth continues, the budget can be balanced by 1996. Many economists believe that view is overly optimistic.
The policy of achieving a surplus is not a new one for the Administration, but the President and other officials have begun to emphasize it as a counterweight to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan to cut Social Security taxes.
 
Stress on Skilled Workers
The report's chapter called ''Human Resources in the 1990's'' highlights how demographic and economic changes in this decade will lead to the need for more skilled workers. ''These developments,'' Mr. Bush said, ''will shift attention away from worries about the supply of jobs that have haunted us since the 1930's and toward new concerns about the supply of workers and skills.''
That would mean bringing more disadvantaged Americans ''into the economic mainstream,'' the President said. His economists' report suggested it might also mean changes in immigration laws to favor skilled workers.
Mr. Bush reaffirmed his strong opposition to industrial policy, in which the Government would use tax laws and regulations to help some industries over others. ''Second-guessing the market is the way to raise Government spending and taxes, not living standards,'' he said.
In the same vein, he said he would ''continue to resist calls for protection and managed trade'' and declared, ''Increased global competition is an opportunity for the United States and the world, not a threat.''
Some Democrats advocate industrial policy and trade restrictions to reverse what they see as a competitive disadvantage the United States faces, especially in dealing with Japan.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Social Security: Paying the Piper

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FOR most of Washington's movers and shakers, the big question about Social Security is whether there will be enough cash to honor the pension promises made to the giant baby boom generation. For Stephen J. Entin, a Reagan Administration Treasury official now at the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation, the big question is whether the promises should have been made in the first place. It was foolish, he argues, to commit trillions of scarce tax dollars to a doubling of future benefits.
Mr. Entin's view is pure poison to elected officials, who would rather stand trial for wife beating than be accused of touching one curl on Social Security's carefully coiffed head. But the politics of benefits growth may change, as wage earners are asked to underwrite the escalating costs of both pensions and medical care for retirees. 
Employers and employees each pay a 6.2 percent tax on wages to cover old-age and disability pension costs, with a maximum combined levy of $7,387 a year. That is a whopping tenfold increase over the maximum paid as recently as 1970. But an overwhelming majority in Congress supported the last round of tax increases in 1983 in the belief that the public was behind them. And not without reason: A New York Times/CBS Poll taken just before the vote showed that most Americans accepted higher taxes as the price of guaranteeing future pensions.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat whose proposal to roll back the tax rate by one-fifth has caused much gnashing of teeth in Washington, does not challenge the sanctity of this implicit bargain. Quite the contrary: He argues that the higher tax is not worth paying only because Congress and the White House have reneged on their side of the deal. The revenues, he says, are being used to cover current budget deficits rather than future pension costs.
Mr. Entin's attack on Social Security-as-usual is far more radical. As a supply-sider, he likes the idea of cutting the payroll tax because it is a barrier to employment. And as a conservative, he thinks Government has gone too far in fattening prospective retirees' benefits at the expense of workers' take-home pay.
Under current law, initial benefits are computed for each group of workers as they reach normal retirement age. The formula replaces an average of 41 percent of pre-retirement wages, with low-wage earners receiving more (55 percent) and high-wage earners receiving less (27 percent). The monthly benefit is then frozen, save for cost-of-living adjustments.
Today's benefits certainly do not keep retirees in caviar and Dom Perignon: The typical unmarried worker reaching 65 this year will receive a modest $8,300 annually. But initial benefits will climb with average wage rates, which the Social Security Administration estimates will grow by 150 percent over the next 75 years.
The average single retiree in the year 2065 can thus expect to receive $20,300 in 1989 dollars. In that same year, the inflation-adjusted pension for a married worker eligible for the maximum benefit will reach $47,900. And today's tax rates have been set accordingly to cover the anticipated costs.
What is wrong with a rich nation sharing the bounty with its retirees? Nothing at all, say the policy makers who have shaped and guarded the Depression-born public pension system.
But Mr. Entin is unpersuaded. ''Only a handful of people'' have thought through the philosophy of matching benefits to wages, he said. And ''only in the last few years has there been any real understanding'' of the taxes that would have to be levied to support the constant replacement rate.
Even those who support more generous pension benefits, Mr. Entin contends, might think twice if they understood what was happening to the payroll tax-supported Medicare program. Federal hospital insurance for pensioners now costs 1.2 percent of gross national product. But that figure is expected to hit 3 percent by the year 2050. And the combined costs of pensions and health care for the elderly and disabled are likely to reach 9.66 percent of G.N.P. - almost double the current level.
Mr. Entin's proposed fix: Raise the age at which today's young workers could retire at the regular wage-replacement rate. They would still be free to retire at 65, or even 62, and at average benefits no lower than those leaving the work force this year. But to qualify for the hefty increases anticipated in the current formula, they would have to keep working until age 72.
For the moment, this proposal could not fly with the aid of a 100-mile-an-hour tailwind. But under the right conditions, political turkeys have a way of growing the wings of eagles. The politics of Social Security will change if and when a majority decide that Social Security benefits have reached the level of luxury rather than necessity.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finishes Day Mixed As Mark Remains Strong

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed against other primary currencies yesterday as buyers were preoccupied with the West German mark.
Currency dealers described dollar trading as uneventful because the mark has been the center of attention. The mark has been buoyed by developments in Eastern Europe that are expected to benefit West Germany economically. 
''It's more of a mark-driven market right now rather than a dollar-driven market,'' said Thomas Palladino, a dealer at the New York office of the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank. ''The sentiment still seems to be in favor of selling the dollar but more so of buying the mark.''
The traders were also awaiting the outcome of the Communist Party meeting in Moscow, which was unexpectedly lenghthened and will enter a third day today.
News that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had called on the party to relinquish its monopoly on power spurred purchases of marks because it was taken as a sign that the pace of reform in the Eastern bloc might quicken.
The dollar finished yesterday in New York at 1.65605 West German marks, down from 1.6590 marks on Monday. That was below the closing level in Europe of 1.6570 marks, which was down from 1.6670 in Europe late on Monday.
The dealers said confidence in the American currency was shaken by uncertainty before the Treasury Department's quarterly financing later this week. Speculation has arisen that Japanese investors might not be large buyers of the $30 billion in notes and bonds to be sold in three auctions.
In New York, the dollar traded at 145.245 yen, up from 144.70 yen on Monday. The dealers said they expected the dollar to remain firm against the yen before the Japanese national elections on Feb. 18.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late on Monday, included: 1.4763 Swiss francs, up from 1.47275; 5.64 French francs, up from 5.6370; 1,233.50 Italian lire, up from 1,231.00, and 1.18755 Canadian dollars, up from 1.18735.
In Europe, yesterday's late dollar rates, compared with those late on Monday, were: 1.4770 Swiss francs, down from 1.4780; 5.6405 French francs, down from 5.6573; 1,235.00 Italian lire, down from 1,236.00, and 1.1874 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1891.
